There's a lot that can be said about Chivalry: Medieval Warfare, but it all boils down to this:  RRRAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAH!  Basically, you run, you shout, you chop people's limbs off in the most satisfying way imaginable, and you get good, and then you chop even more limbs off plus smash some heads in with a giant hammer (that stuff never gets old). Do some objectives, come hither, oooo look: a rainbow!, run some more, duel, duel on TO servers, get scolded for duelling on TO servers, go on a duel server, get rekt, go back to TO and behave! Rinse and repeat. Fun, fun, fun!  It's like being inside The Kingdom of Heaven (the film, not the actual place) with all its visceral beauty and gore. It will get your heart racing and you'll feel every slash, every bash and every stab. Decent headphones are a must - there is no sound more awe-inspiring than that of someone's helmet, skull and brains being mushed into a sticky pulp with one drop of a maul. It's just beautiful!  Stick around and you'll meet some of the nicest people around (at least EU-side, but I do have friends in the States too). Community-driven events and antics happen all the time and you can count on veteran players helpin you out with tactics, optimisation and anything really. Sure, there are a few bell-ends too, but every game has a few, nothing to be concerned about. Talk to me if you need anything and I'm sure 99% of players over 50 lvl will say the same.  In terms of graphics - little bit outdated, but it's UE3 so there's no surprise. Sound design is superb, rivalled only by that of Alien: Isolation and I'm not saying it lightly. Playability? Let my 1100hrs of gameplay speak for themselves (at the time of writing this review).  In closing: don't be a scrub, join in on the fun!  P.S. DEATH TO ARCHERS!

Don't waste your time or money. Horrible community, god-awful combat, and generally everything a horrible game has. Horridly Pirates, Vikings and Knights-esque, but worse. I'm apalled at the fact that this won indie-game of the year, to be frank. I suppose I'll be fair, though:  Pros: --Interesting and very good concept. --Great graphics. --Decent class system Cons: --Awful combat system; Only recommended if you like a system that's brutally unforgiving and broken. --Classes are heavily unbalanced. Basically, knights and archers are the only two classes with function; the others are just fodder. --Did I mention knights are over-powered? The knight class can one-hit anything and take what seems to be hundreds of hits to kill. --You have to pay even more to use decent weapons, plus features of the game are actually LOCKED after you paid way too much money for what the game is.  TL;DR - I gave this game a shot, never again.

Ok. If this game has had its controls, 'simplified for the mindless masses' as some reviews say, then I would hate to see what it was like before. The controls are god awful. Really really really terrible. I cant currently think of a game I have played that controls worse than this actually.  Why were attacks bound to the ♥♥♥♥ing mouse wheel? You realize there are about 1000 keys on a keyboard right? What is V dodge and only one class can dodge? Why is there a ♥♥♥♥ing progression system that locks most of the weapons so youll have to grind levels over and over? What the hell is with the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ hit boxes?  Archers are hands down my favorite class in video games. Failing that a rogue or a mage come in close second. Its painful to play an archer in this game. They take about 10 years to notch an arrow and the trajectory seems off to me. As if the arrow follows a random path every time you fire.   I cant believe this game got so much promotion and hype behind it. I guess theres a reason I never saw gameplay by the people promoting on youtube outside of the paid promotional stuff.

I've played this game for entirely too long (though not so much since the Steam release). I got back on for a bit to check it out, and it's still fine, but it's also still PS2. I don't really know how else to put it. Mechanics are solid, upgrades expansive, visuals are brilliant, and fights get INSANE. The only thing I didn't enjoy as much was the new (seeming) focus on playing follow the zerg, but again, I may have missed something.  Anyway, quick and dirty: If you like FPS games, flight sims, tank sims, and crazy huge fights, this *IS* the game. THE game for all of those things.

Left my positive review up for a long time, in honour of all the fun this game once gave me - but I recently uninstalled it, because ♥♥♥♥ it. High-level play is simply not fun - it's based around mechanics exploits. Some will argue whether they are 'exploits' and that's fine - but the fact remains they are NO FUN. Even when the servers seem well-balanced, 99% of team objective games involve one side completely stomping the other. It's vaguely kind of enjoyable when you are the stomper the first few times, but eventually anyone who actually enjoys gaming will long for the rare *close* matches, whether they win or lose them. Once in a blue moon, you really do get a magnificent match - two skilled teams grinding away at each other, neither one utterly dominated by spinners and clanfolk, slowly giving and losing ground, until it comes down to a frantic 1-minute count on the final objective -- and when that happens, it honestly doesn't matter who wins, the game is so much fun for everyone. But those games have gotten rarer and rarer and rarer as the community has gotten worse and worse and worse (and 'better' - in the sense of racking up cheap kills that preclude any of the interesting mid-battle duels that used to happen), and now it's just not worth it anymore.

To describe this game in just a few words: immersive and impressive yet anti-climactic. For me, it provides no closure or sense of accomplishment -- there's no way to win in this game, and that makes it feel empty. Taking over territory has no direction besides gaining certification points, which are used to buy upgrades (so you can get more certification points?). By definition, you can't really call this a game -- it's more of a combat sandbox and social experiment. If that's what you want, go for it.  It's only really fun when you have several hours to play at a time during an alert with a platoon with leadership that communicates and strategizes. Otherwise, you're stuck wandering around trying to find a fight that is evenly matched. Nobody wants to just sit there and get spawn camped when you could be somewhere else getting more cert points.   The scale of this game is incredible, but the payoff just isn't there. If you feel like you're winning, it's rarely because of something you did, and it feels like you're just in the right place at the right time. Instead, victory goes to the team with the most people.
It's sort of like League of Legends but different.

First ill say this, i am a huge warhammer fan and have been for many many years...and this game is alot of fun. Howerver there are so truly game breaking things that really cripple the campaign 1. AI agents...truly broken and all powerful not to mention the enemy has no limits on how many they can have. Every 4 turns withut fail your so called 'legendary lords' will be assainated...or wounded as the game puts it only to be rehired put back into play and BAM lvl 1 enemy agent wipes them out again..this may seem exaggerated and really i wish it was. Not to mention that 1 of thses guys can wipe out half an entire 20 stack in a single action...its ridiculous. Your agents as useful...? Nope not even the close...50% percent of the time you will critically fail, 35% of the time you will just fail, the rest you will see marginal results at best. in 63 hours ive never seen my agents accomplish an assasination....not evern once.  2. The AI movement on the map...it doesnt seem to have a limit...i move mere inches they move miles and miles and miles. Ill just leave it at that. Now this game is a blast and a good fix for a warhammer junky...and im sure if any comment get left on here they will only be the 'get gud' or grammar nazis. But seriously this needs balancing for sure. Now back to killing the foes of the Empire...

Just played a campaign with the dwarves which eventually ended with me succumbing to the chaos but the ride to that point was a mostly enjoyable one. I must say Creative Assembly did a pretty good job for their first forray into fantasy. The map is well constructed, though I wish you could occupy settlments from other races, and gives each area a distinctive look.The units are varied between races, with dwarves having axes, gyrocopters and artillery, and the chaos using the fallen and hellish creations such as the dragon ogres. Despite it only being a few days after release the game also runs pretty well, I run it on a mix between ultra and high, mainly putting shadows on high, with a i5 4590 and gtx 970 and the game run above 30fps even in large fights. I have also yet to run into bugs whatsoever. All in all Total Warhammer seems to be a solid addition to the Total War roster that will interest both newcomers and veterans to the series.

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: Although I am fairly new to steam, I have put thousands of hours into this game. This is my favourite game. It is an rpg with fps qualities, taking place in the post apocalyptic US. It has prewar qualities as well as futuristic weaponry which in my opinion is a beautiful and memorable mix. Survival, mutations, storyline, and an open map to explore. Out of the DLCs Point Lookout in my opinion is the best, 'Walking with Spirits' is an amazing quest, and the swampfolk I found made interesting enemies. The Pitt is good as well, with new mutations and weaponry; and you can go back afterwards which is important to me. I wasn't very fond of the other two, but they were still worth doing. Mothership Zeta for me is mainly collecting items and putting them into an area of the ship that doesn't close off after completion.   Anyways there is some controversy over if it should be called Fallout 3 or if New Vegas should be the third installment, what I have to say to that is they are both great games. I enjoy all of the Fallout games though (all 6) and don't feel the need to rank them. Afterall, the worst Fallout game in the series to me still is better than most other games. Most of the games old-new have wildly varying gameplay, but all that to the side, the story, the setting, and their unique mix of prewar qualities, futuristic tech, and mutations makes the Fallout series my favourite. So do I recommend this game? Hell yes I do.

Okay, so, many people say this game is horrid because of the toxicity of the community. And I must agree. But, the game becomes significantly better once you find a group of people who enjoy the game and want to support you, not only in the game, but as a team member.  What I’m trying to get at is, find some friends to play with you, find a Dota group, add players who are nice at the game and party with them and if they're enjoyable to play with, keep playing with them; regardless of the team side.  I joined a group, named “The Art of Warfare” TAW for short, and ever since I’ve had so much more fun. The group is supportive and very kind. And knowing most of the people who read these reviews, you're sick of the game's community and you want to discuss it, or even out of curiosity of the subject of the reviews.  If you're interested, you can send me a friend request and I can set you up for some of the 'In-house matches' and see if you want to join TAW. Matches are Thursdays and Sundays at 6:00 pm PST. At the time of this post we have 80+ member, and we only allow people who are not toxic to other players.

A fun, MOBA-style game that players of that genre will find addictive and competitively balanced. Its only major downside is that it needs English-language only servers for casual players (a setting where you can opt to only be placed on teams with people from your own region) and microphone preferences (a preference where you can choose only to be placed on teams which use microphones to communicate). Hardcore players will tend to join teams and form groups of people with these things already, but the rest of us have to queue solo or with a friend or two, and then often be paired with people who don't speak English, or they do but they don't use a microphone, forcing the team to play at a significant disadvantage because of an inability to easily communicate.

Turn radius delay simulates high ping constantly. If you like having high ping and extremely delayed actions, be my guest and play this terrible game that is based off of RNG and has more foreign players than region specific players even on the respective servers. I would much rather play almost any other MOBA other than Dota 2. If you like being challenged for no reason at all and handicapped in every way with a learning curve taller than Mount Everest play Dota 2. If you don't have autism, don't play Dota 2.

This is the dream shooter if you're a certain type of player. It fulfills the promise of Battlefield 2. Remember squad based com and objectives setting? Remember driving to the front in a variety of vehicles while planning strategy? And large scale? This game does all these things, and better. Communication, team strategy, opening up new flanks with mobile spawn points, a flanker class, combined arms, a map with strategic features that lives and changes, coordination in a small squad up to a platoon of 48 or several platoons, ...in short team strategy and tactics in large scale shooter!   What's more, they got the pay to play (not pay to win) model right and the development model is a thing of beauty. Here we have devs playing all over the game, in clans (or 'outfits'), broadcasting and generally dialoguing with the players all the time. Rich community. They have a roadmap where players set dev objectives. They iterate and patch nearly at the level of a League of Legends. And all in discourse with the players. Heck, there are many continents to come.  Other stuff: sniping as a real thing (not strictly CoD style twitch sniping), stealth against real human beings, vehicles (tanks, atv's, fighters, gun ships and transports), emergent story up the wazoo, whole swathes of the game that emphasies priorities other than twitch shooting (ie. leading w teamwork/objectives, hacking systems, healing, repairing, spotting...)   There is much to dig into and learn to up your game. This is a great, great shooter. It's f-in' free. Check it.

review_text: I'm going to start off by saying this game is fun, I finally broke down and bought it to see what all the hubub is and for the most part I am pleased. That being said... WHY THE ♥♥♥♥ does any company release a game that dows not play friendly with high end pc's. I have never had to do so much work to get a game to run on my rig, which isn't even all that high end anymore (6 plus years old). They realy need to release an update to fix this ♥♥♥♥ as there are still people buying the game, I wa late to the party and I know i'm not the only one. We should be able to bill them for the time we spend getting this game to work.   I do suggest playing it if you haven't before, but, if you run more than dual core, multiple monitors or x64 windows be ready for some dirty work before the game will run smoothly... or at all.

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: fallout 3 is seriously one of the best games i've ever played and i'd def. reccomend it to everyone

I dont play (ok, played) this on my PC but on my Tablet.. I thought I write my warning here..  The game is a time waster.. very good one.. and became with the last update even MORE time waster. Let me explain. The game is a resource game.. running in real time. You can play it clicking your ♥♥♥ off, play it idle and do nothing at all beside a few clicks every here and then.. or a mix of both.  I played a mix, as sometimes I want to click a bit and other times I prefer to sleep! :p So for 5 days I wasted my time.. and I felt very sorry for myself during game time.. why am I wasting my life with this? Anyhow.. got myself a little setup and reached Lv400 in 50min on my farm run for hero souls. Got about 350 on average on a run. Skilled mainly chance to spawn a Primal Boss and Hero Souls drop amount plus more gold in IDLE mode. I was happy wasting my time... and the update came.. no question, do you want to upgrade? Just suddenly I got way more Hero Souls.. niiiice, what a lucky run.. when I hit over 1k Souls.. I started to understand, something goes different as usual. Bed time.. started game again next day and screen pops up.. Transcence bla bla.. Help Screen to explain it all.. like a lerner driver gets this instruction: Open Door of the car, start car, drive as it is demanded by law, park and exit car. So.. basicly nada! Next I start my run.. why are my heroes not guilded anymore?? Why does all take soooooooo much longer? To make it short.. that is what r2games sold you. We made a upgrade and BALANCED the game. How unbalanced it was before.. example: My next upgrade for chance to get a primal boss was 72 Hero Souls... after the update +86k Hero souls.. so the developper thought it needed a balance to a skill that was 1 : 1200 out of balance. Yes, but we gave you more Hero Soul income too... true.. went from 400 average to 1500 on a run.. lets say 4 time more... to 1200 more cost.. my same farm run of 50min is now over 3 hours... and instead of beeing able to upgrade my chance for hero boss 3 times on one farm run to 400.. I would need over 50 runs for 1 upgrade. So wasting time is one thing, this is just simply super stupid.. I guess to many people came to the end of 'get arthritis when you are old game'.. and instead of putting some brain into it.. they just made everything a s h i t l o a d take more time.  So all in short: If you want to kill your last brain cells with boredom, if you cant understand or play games, which demands at least an IQ of 90.. this is your game and you will LOVE it!!! In any other case.. do yourself a favor, man... drill yourself a hole in your head.. makes more sense than playing this game for brain dead idiots. This is THE game for street cleaners, garbage men and bums living under the bridge.. about the IQ you need to play this junk and think this is a great game..

Alright First of all. Great game. The combat felt ballanced and consistant. you make stupid choises and you eat alot of bullets and choke on them. You have an action hero's resistance to bullets... More than most people should beable to take but you take too much and you die and there is suprisingly very little forgiving situations. The game had a bunch of good rather grim and gritty humor and a bunch of other just little things that I apreciated. Not perfect but I say it is solid.  HOWEVER.... Do NOT get this game on steam. Get off your lazy rump and go pick it up for a console... or chance it. up to you. Farcry and aparently other Ubisoft games require an extra program to be downloaded and then... wow read their User Agreement Licence. If their program causes your computer to catch on fire and it was Directly their fault... it is NOT their fault and screw you fix your own computer. I Dont like having extra program things that launch my games. Thats steam... i dont need a second steam for ONE game nor do I apreciate there being a second layer for failure incase the internet or servers go down. Fairly sure Both programs must be in working order and Im very VERY sure that the UPlay program does not have an offline mode... least thats the fear anyway. I have not had an issue but the fact that they make a hole so my game CAN be interupted is not apreciated.

When you are forced leave due to unforseen circumstances they put you in a low priority server, where the only mode you can play is a mode that literally nobody plays  0/10 literally can never play again

Rating while playing in beginners servers = 10/10  Fun balanced gameplay  Rating once thrown out in the cold in non beginner servers 1/10  The game instantly became infuriating. You go from being able to hold your own with at least a 1 to 1 sometimes 2 to 1 K/D ratio in beginner servers, to consistently having K/D ratio's to the tune of 2/25.  I don't really review many games and I guess it's not fair to give a negative review because players are too good, but at the same time it seems like in this day and age developers would balance online multiplayer games for those of us who are casual gamers.  How about servers based on overall K/D ratios? So all those lucky people who have nothing but hours on end to invest in playing video games can play with their own kind, and the rest of us can get some enjoyment out of the same game playing with other casual gamers... In short... unless you are going to commit yourself to a life of playing chivalry... don't buy this game, because you will hate it the second you are no longer eligible to be in a beginner server.

The story and the characters are really dumb, it felt like a 6 year old was the lead writer of this game.  As for the gameplay, while not feeling fundamentaly good, the shooting is fine, the special abilities felt like a last minute add-on just because every single other games are doing it too, also the AI felt really stupid.  But if you can deal with the awful repetitiveness of this game, it might be a good 10$ buy, it's kind of fun to mess around in the world.

Worst game I have ever played.   To start the game is severely broken. Like glitches, bugs, exploits run ravage through the game although the developers clearly have no interest in fixing any issues. In the eyes of torn banner this is a dead game, you are much better off buying a game with a dedicated team because you DEFINITELY wont find it here.   Not to mention the lack of any new content, unless you like paying outragious prices for weapon and armour skins. The game is severely broken and I'd reccommend buying a bottle of vodka instead because you will have much more fun drinking it than playing this.   There is no such thing as a community, everyone hates each other and will instantly kick you from a game if your ping is above 90. YES that's right, you will be kicked for the stupidest of reasons no matter what. Also the game is so unfairly balanced any new players will kick themselves out of frustration for buying it.   In conclusion, this is a dead game with horrible developers who have no interest in futhering the game, let alone fixing it. The community is toxic and incredibly harsh on newer players. I bought this game in the steam sale and believe me, it wasn't cheap enough then so don't pay full price. You're a sap if you do. Buy a better game like cs go, rust, arc, mount & blade. Heck even adventure quest is 1000 times better than this pile of manure. JUST DON'T BUY.

I HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS GAME AND THE DLC!!! the game is EXTREMELY FUN but there are many annoying bugs but the main ones like weapon and rank reset vanguard teleporting and MAA dodge were fixed RANK DOES NOT MATTER AT ALL i was rank 5 (pre patch) form over 3 months so dont judge :D. the game has many pros and cons though  Pros: -Decapitate people -Very Addictive(ly fun) -very very realistic with the first person aspect -Weapons are from real time wars and or fights in the past -can cut any limb off {arm,leg,head) -hilarious at times -battle cry for days -more more and more just discover  Cons: -tons of explotiable way to attack enemies that are kinda ridiculous and sometimes feel OP -LMB spamming is a thing  -broken defense areas, hitting a shield when your blocking goes threw, parry\block goes threw, hitbox broken -huge learning curve especially in duels -many exploits just play to find out But wth all this the game is still amazing 9\10 Such a great game.

Early Access Review

The interface: It's clunky. Important Icons are scattered all over the place. On some dialogs the dismissal button is a checkmark in the middle of the dialog, other times it's on the bottom right. You have menus that jump up from buttons, but look just like buttons, menus that disappear before you have a chance to click the option you want  The AI: The AI is essentially like playing turn based chess. It will choose the softest spot to hit you every time. It knows everything you do. So if you start a siege half way across the map with your main force, don't be surprised when 10 different faction armies suddenly make their way through the fog of war and come take half of your territory. It's really irritating when your allies then come retake the stuff you lost and you have to declare war on your allies to get your territories back.  Cut Scenes: The cut scenes were actually pretty decent  The Tutorial / Intro: It wasn't super bad, but the interface and how everything is laid out made it hard to follow.   General issues: There's this really annoying issue where if you have a Hero (not to be confused with the Leader of your Army) merge in with your army it will somehow always be selected by itself at the beginning of the turn and you'll think you're moving your army when in reality you end up removing your Hero away from the army. The AI will absolutely do everything it can to slay the Hero whom is now all by itself because its movement is higher than the Army and you won't be able to remerge them until next turn. So I spent a lot of time clicking off my army, or pressing escape, and then re-selecting my army to move it.  I played multiple games on Normal, the AI is rediculous. It will move just out of reach every turn. It will exploit every mistake or mistep you make with surgical precision. The only variability, or chance you might survive such a brutal, relentless AI, appears to be in the way it determines winners within battles.   Somehow the AI players get to obliterate your hero even if you lose a battle and are retreated a few spaces away. It seemed like every time I lost a major fight with my main force my hero dies, whereas when they lost a major battle with their main force their hero always had a chance to flee far, far, away.  Otherwise, it's just battle chess with better graphics and units. I would wait for the price to come down before purchasing this game, it's definitely not worth $59.99.

I like the game so much because i learned that no matter how hard the situatuion is, if you believe in yourself, you will win. The game have many skilled players as well as new players. I'm a typical player with an average MMR and I've played this game for almost a year so I can say there are different types of players. Some say that this game sucks because of noobs or noisy or annoying players that will make you play bad and look bad as well. I cant deny that fact because I myself have experienced it but you guys know what I do? I ignore them and play well. For me, the most difficult ally to have in a game is ourselves. Because if have short amount of patience or if we're so boastful, we might ruin the game of others. Remember, any proffesional gamer in the world can lose if the team doesn't have a teamplay. DOTA is a team competitive game. If you can't help yourself being boastful and have a short patience, don't play DOTA. Play solitaire or pinball would be better for you.

The good thing about it is that you can get all the useful items if you play long enough without paying. Paying with real cash is just a shortcut. The community is amazing. Try to get into an 'outfit' right away and you will have a lot of fun. And did I mention it's free? Try it now!

Total War: Warhammer Review (Short and Sweet)  This game is very fun. It is my favorite Total War game to date. The combat visuals look great and are very entertaining. I find myself getting distracted often during battles because I like to watch them fight. The campaign needs some fine tuning, and there are quite a few mods out now that can make that experience a lot better. The maps are well done, I wouldn\'t say they\'re great, and there needs to be a little more added IMO. However, I can\'t complain because the combat is fun. Each faction is unique in their own rights. Learn how to use them efficiently and your gameplay experience will be much better. Online multiplayer has been a blast so far. Everyone is friendly and most of the time communication is not a problem. I would recommend this game for anyone that enjoys the Total War series.   Thanks for reading. :)  TL;DR - Needs a little polishing but is a great game overall and will get better with more updates/mods.

Sublime game, however, it 'blued' my system after i closed the program, rendering my computer unusable for 15 min after a full restart, so I'd have to not recommend this 'game' for those with Intel HD 4000 graphics like myself.

So, let me open this by saying that i am a huge Warhammer fan. TW:WH is a great game, especially because of the awesome mod support. TW:WH is also pretty acceptable lorewise, as much as possible without comprimising the 'fun' part. Now the problems though: This game has not nearly as many factions to play as other Total Wars. And every new DLC costs loads of money. This is redeemed in my eyes by the work that has gone into each faction. In contrast to other Total Wars, every faction is very unique. Also, hopefully at the end there will be the whole Warhammer Fantasy world (which is massive).   To put this all together: This game is great and expansive, expect to get around 30 hours out of every 15 $ DLC and ~100 hours out of the base game if you like either Total War or Warhammer.

This game has honestly changed my life. I used to dream about goating as a child, but was always scared to come out and say it. What would people think? What would they say? For countless years, I was in bondage to this fear. Whenever friends of mine would mention goats, I had to remove myself from the conversation for fear that my goating desires would become evident.   BUT THEN CAME GOAT SIMULATOR.  When I first saw Goat Simulator, my heart began beating faster than a goat with a jetpack. Could it be? Could all of my built-up anxiety from supressing my goating desires finally have an outlet? With a shaky index finger, I pre-ordered the game and waited for the release. After all of this time, I was so close to finding fulfillment! But I was nervous. Nervous that my fragile hopes might be once again dashed upon the rocks of despair and misery. But my worrying was for naught. Goat Simulator is everything I ever dreamed of, and more. I know there are many people out there that are afraid, like I was, of sharing their goating desire with the world. Goat Simulator has given me the courage to do just that, and I hope and pray it will do the same for you.

This game is pure Pay-To-Win garbage hidden as a MMOFPS.   First off, it runs like ♥♥♥. It manages to peak at 45 FPS, but I rarely ever seen anything above 10 FPS even on the lowest setting. And it's not even because it has great graphics or anything, it looks like an early Playstation 3 game. It just isn't a good game on the software part.  Second, I've played for a total of three hours, and I have managed to get 5 kills, because my guns are peashooters and my armor is swiss cheese compared to what everyone else wears. I have emptied an entire clip into a Heavy, in the back, and he lived to kill me while I reloaded. And you don't win that important currency you need to win better weapons, because you don't get kills.   Also, the 'massive fights' are about as impressive as 32 players on Halo 3. Yes, there are alot of people around, no, it doesn't mean you'll get the impression you're fighting a massive fight, because everyone wears the same armor and looks exactly the same, so there's a massive chance you'll have the impression there's only 16 people in the fight. Hell, there's a massive chance you won't know what you're fighting because only 2 classes have different armor, the Max and the Heavy, who just looks like he has football gear on.  The team balance is just fantastic in this game. I made the error of picking the Red Faction, and I have not seen us win a single battle, because the game doesn't seem to limit the amount of enemy soldiers we fight, or balance the gear out, so we can be five people dropping from an APC against 7 people riding around in jets.  Oh, and vehicules are just peachy. Basically, if you are in a plane, no one on the ground can touch you. If you are in a tank, no infantry can touch you. If you have alot of tanks, no one can touch you because you can just break every tank they try to spawn, and they can't do ♥♥♥♥ because infantry cannot do a single thing against tanks. I mean, sure, they can shoot a rocket launcher at you, but it barely dents the armor and then you one shot them and jump out to repair it instantly  The level design is not thought out at all, and they just mash premade buildings together to give a point of interest. I have ran through the same building in every single fight I've been in. It's not like I'd notice because the visual design is so bland everything looks the same even when they're not using premade buildings. If it's a point of interest, you can be sure it's an Halo map defended by clones of Commander Sheperd.  Update: I have played the game for 12 hours now. The planes are ♥♥♥♥ing unflyable. Still have not gotten into a tank, because I'm either in a fight where we can't use tanks due to the map's lack of design or in a fight where the tank terminal was broken by an enemy tank.   I've tried the MAX suit. That was fun for about 15 seconds, until I got instakilled by rockets/C-4/anything explosive. It's really good game design to make a suit that costs as many ressources as a tank, but has half the firepower or half the armor of a Heavy. It does make you slightly immune to bullet, which doesn't matter because headshots still seem to bypass armor. And you can't get healed by medics, so you have to hope anyone plays the worthless Engineer class just to heal you.   The Infiltrator's snipers do no damage, because for some reason, damage falloff applies to snipers. The cloak is also very ♥♥♥♥, it lets you be invisible if you sit completely still, for a very limited amount of time, so you can't use it in any useful situations.  The jetpack guy is decent, apart from the fact that you can't jetpack and aim at stuff, otherwise it's an engineer that can fly. I guess the only way to use it is to drop C-4 on people from high altitude, but I can't afford C-4 because this game is unplayable.  You have no reason to play engineer, unless you're gonna drive a tank or there's an abundance of MAX on the field.  Still have not earned enough certs to buy ANYTHING, so I guess that guy lied, you can't buy everything you need in 20 hours.  The controls are still ♥♥♥. There's no getting used to it, it's ♥♥♥♥ing unplayable, no one in their right mind would be able to play this piece of ♥♥♥♥.  Rocket launchers are worthless, the hitbox on the rocket is so terrible, it'll go through your target most of the time.

The game is good, strong early game with hero units and magic. However, a lot of it is still just a reskin of the last game. I enjoy the game, but I still feel like they did not put as much effort into it as they have in past titles. This game will obviously get better reviews over Rome II and Attilla the Hun because nerd boy fan base for warhammer, which it does deserve, its not good enough to beat previous titles such as medieval, Rome, or the last Shogun. Still, with that being said, I\'m sure there will be some mods to adjust the game into a much better title, but I review based off the core game. Now to give the game a few scores based on 1-10 scale.  Graphics 7 : Its good, but nothing to write home about. It is better optimized for its graphics though, which is great!  Sound 7 : Nothing too special here. Music is good, but you can always pick your own music and enjoy that more.  Gameplay 8 : Good battles, interesting armies, hero units, and spells. Good combination of stuff to enjoy when doing a battle, and enough to make you want to try each faction. Hero units have increased replay value tremendously. You also gear up your hero units with quests and objectives, so you get the 'grind for gear' feel that most of us gamers chase. Such a great add on to the game.  Maps 4 : Really the most disappointing part of this game is the lack of good maps. People may or may not agree, but I feel as though this is by far the laziest part of the game. It is almost enough to ruin the game after a while. The only map that gives a vast difference are 'siege' maps which you don't get to do very often unless you are the attacker since the AI straight up won\'t follow through on a siege. 55 hours into the game, and the AI has only attacked one of my castles once. I'll increase difficulty to see if that changes anything and edit my review.  AI 6.5 : You can read my previous statement about them not attacking my castles to see why I'm bitter. Some of the other issues are minor combat issues. Nothing too bad, but not enough issues to make this a riding the line score. And before you say \'mods will fix this\' I am a firm believer that mods should enhance a game, not fix it.  Anyway, I'm sure there are other things I can score and judge, but you have all the important information. I recommend this game, but be warned its not the best title they have. I apologize if my spelling is off in advance.  UPDATED REVIEW Some more updated info, if you are curious about some of the changes that really change gameplay.  1. Towers on your base now reach the entire length of the map and do pretty high damage. So, if you are one of the players that enjoy actually sitting there and lobbing stuff at a base for a while from a catapult, you no longer can do that (there are mods to fix this since its a common annoyance for players)  2. Combat is pretty quick. Morale is a bit odd, at times it doesn't even make sense. Also I think that they are having issues with the undead 'fear' mechanic, because it really doesn't seem to do anything right now. Could be wrong.  3. Questing for gear is a thing. Its great, I love it.  4. Success chance one assassin to kill another is based on the difference in level, and it makes a VERY large difference. If you get unlucky and don't get one early and level it, it gets so bad sometimes that you have to restart the game. (I feel especially when its between greenskins and dwarves.)  5. Your assassins aren't just reskinned clones of each other. Each of them have very useful talents and abilities.  EDIT REVIEW:  I had a thumbs up, even with all the issues I mentioned. The new problem for me is the DLC policy. I'll never buy a total war game again. Company doesn't deserve to be in business when it puts out crap DLC at high prices. I don't play the sims for that very reason, and someone should make some type of 'mock company' to do legal cloning of these games and put them out with reasonable dlcs. That person would get rich pretty quick. I am tempted to try to hire people to do it for me after I find out what the laws are on that type of thing. Anyway, don't waste your money, move along. Well, I first got this game about a month ago and honestly I absolutely loved it, so much fun and I wasnt half bad at it. Really enjoyable game would have recommended to anyone. Then you hit level 15. Now after this, it changes into a completely different game. You are no longer classed as a 'Low rank' anymore andhave to play with anyone level 16 onwards, this goes up to atleast thelevels 50's. The thing is yes they are betetr skilled players, but these players also use gamebreaking glitches such as moves where you hit twice in one swing and crouch and just do inhumane movements in order to kill you. I know its a game but this total ruins the realism, It just doesnt feel playable when people are killing you for kills that dont even exist, its like why should I play. Also another problem is that the servers do not seem to be as supported from level 15 onwards and are not official anymore, thereforethe hosts etc are laggier, making the game solid to play, I have people stab me from large distances just because the game does not feel catered for and I lag in most game, and I have good interent speeds and a really good computer. But generally it is just annoying all those people who spend so many horus in this game are are good but nothing to compete with doing all these stupid moves. I keep trying to come back to this game but I just cant get back into it. 10/10 till you hit level 15, 2/10 onwards. Sort out these glitches and problems and it should not be a problem anymore.

The game is addictive at first as you can go for what seems like hours. But as the game progresses, you'll find yourself playing it less and less. I play the game once every couple of days, though it seems to be best if played once every 12 hours, to maximize the gold you get.  The game has it merits--but at best it's a idling game and something to do for a quick 5 mintues. Also the ingame microtransactions can get costly, so this is how the developers earn their money. I wanted to like this game. I really did. I gave this game numerous chances to impress, but it fell flat every time.  Planetside 2 starts out as a slaughterfest and you're in the blender. No matter what new players seem to do they are always slain by veteran players who are 50+ ranks above them. One hilarious example I have is how a veteran player with a RPG killed me at long distance. I took the initial shot: a sniper shot to center mass. The shot hit but didn't seem to even phase the opponent. A few seconds later I was an exploded mess of charred flesh and kevlar.  It must be a fantastic experience for people who have poured 100+ hours into this game. For everyone else it is a sea of disappointment and frustration. If you're willing to endure hours of failure and death this game is for you. For everyone else don't look to Planetside 2 for entertainment.

I played 23 hours so far. It's a fairly generous 8/10 for me.  Good looking game, and some sights are gorgeous. Having said that, this is like far Cry2 in Far Cry (1) settings. It's a go get, do this, mission quest. Unlike far Cry which was about mercs and a crazy scientific experiment.   That does make Far Cry 3 a bit of a grind, albeit a good grind. I don't see myself doing much after the main quest is over. I mean I can't see me collecting every loot chest, relic, lost-letter, etc. There is no point to it really, so that part's just a grind, because there's hundreds of them.  Liberating outposts is better than expected. Getting in and cutting off the alarm before the pirates signal help is rewarding. Plus you get extra exp for doing it without an alarm going off. Another place where it excels is missions in the main quest take you to amazing places. The sets they send you to are a bit Tomb Raider style, without the puzzles. All the up-sides then.  It is addictive. I liberate one outpost and think I'll just do another, and another. Then I might finish with a main quest mission. Then another outpost, including hunter mini-quests gained at the outpost.  If it was just a hint more Far Cry (1), I would rate it higher. Also, why oh why didn't they put an inventory/progress quick-save key on. We can go to the main menu and save progress/inventory. It's diabolical they didn't give us a hotkey.

This is one of those games where you play it for two hours, think it's alright, and then come back to it a year later. Which is  exactly  what I did. But when I returned and got farther into the story, I have to admit that I became really impressed with the game and questioned why I left it for so long. While the main characters are very cliche, I feel that this adds to the reality that these are regular every-day people stuck on this island. Meanwhile there are very unique characters, such as Sam, Hoyt, Buck, Citra, and the  oddly attractive  psychopath Vaas. This contrast serves to make very interesting relationships between the characters, which of course adds to the story. Now in the beginning, the game was actually pretty boring to me, hence why I left it after not feeling very captivated, but it honestly picked up quickly after that and soon I was sucked in (and on my second playthrough I really had a better appreciation for the beginning, so maybe you'd like it better than I did). Through the game, as I improved new abilities I was discovering such as paragliding, boating, racing, looting, challenges, completing bounties, capturing camps, crafting, collecting, exploring, hunting, and my all-time favorite, poker, I became more and more comfortable with the environment, to the extent of being completely satisfied with everything the game offers. But legit guys, the poker in this game is pretty immersive. Besides all of that though, I enjoy the soundtrack and especially the game's main theme (though Make It Bun' Dem is definitely up there). The moods of each song echo the feeling of the game in that moment or mission, and I can really appreciate that in all games. Now onto general gameplay, it's solid. I don't see any problems with the fps aspects, and I find driving extremely fun with the realism of it, having your camera angle in a place that makes it feel as if you are actually driving (it's more on the side and not centered). And while events in the game may not always be realistic, specific story elements are always there to back it up, with the plot constantly improving as the game progresses (though there  is  a point where it slows down a bit, but it's a spoiler so I can't say~).  All in all, I definitely recommend this game. It has to be one of my favorites, and I'm still going back to it every now and then just to hunt, drive, and kick Tyrone's ♥♥♥ in poker.

Far Cry 3 is my first Far Cry game and I didn't like it. Maybe it is due to my higher standards after playing mostly games like Skyrim, FallOut New Vegas or Oblivion.  The good thing about this game is that you can just drive around and take over bases. The bad thing is, that the game is too much like a big playground. Icons on the map lead to minigames and missions only start once you went to a special spot. The storyline is very linear and often stupid. Especially the ending of the game makes barely sense. There was almost no immersion when I played the game. Jason Brody was such a wimp... I didn't like him as character. Especially his feminine voice. In the end I had quite some fun with the game, but it ended way to easily.  Reasons why I don't like this game: - No immersion - People look pretty much all the same - Bad AI - You have to kill animals to build bags and in missions you (for example) have to hunt a bunch of dogs with a flamethrower. That's f##ed up. - The pirates don't make counter attacks, so once you conquered all bases you're out of work. - Stupid plot twists. - No realism or depths. - Short playing time. - Invisible walls to keep the player on track.

This game is not as fun as everyone makes it sound.  Initially i thought this is a small little sandbox you can turn on and enjoy with friends for an hour when you have time to kill. It is not even that. I found no fun in aimlessly running around, bugging out rag dolls and exploding stuff for no reason at all. Bugs presented as fun feature in this game are found in almost every game - accompanied by an actual fun gameplay experience.  Also I experienced strong motion sickness within an hour. I don't know if this was due to the severe performance issues - the game seems to not detect the powerful of my 2 video cards - or due to some other stuff going on... i did not enjoy this game at all.

I was excited to play FarCry3 at this time, with FarCry4 coming out soon. I jumped at the sale price. I liked what I saw of the reviews and playthroughs. 'It's a must have', right?  But I have played only a few hours and am about to give up, because I already played TOMB RAIDER and loved it.  Yeah, this game is like TR quite a bit. You visited an island that you shouldn't have. You were captured. You now have to survive and escape. Become the warrior. Bow and arrow, hunt for supplies, upgrade weapons, jumping puzzles and platforming (yes FarCry3 has platforming!) Even running out of burning buildings, searching for relics at shrines, stealth kills, limited ammo, zip lines, radio towers, alarms you have to disable, the ability to purchase map pieces to reveal locations of rare items, wildernessd skill progression, combat skill progression, unlockable takedown skills....  I mean it's a TR knockoff in every way. It's even set in the south china sea, on an island which has it's own flavor of asia-pacific culture and mysticism. There are WWII coastal defense cannons scatered about the map, but they don't look nearly as cool or as genuine as the beautifully rendered, imposing, crusty old cannons in creepy bunkers famed in TR. THOSE are coastal defense cannons. So with all of these cheap imitations, I feel FC3 is not it's own game.  These are story-driven games. FPS + RPG is a great genre, which started with Mass Effect (as far as I know) but they have to have a story leading the player through the game to the end. FC3, in my opinion, has a basic premise, not a story. The premise is that your friends were captured and you have to save them. That's it. No disaster to avoid, no cataclysm to stop, no reason to be afraid to continue for the weight of the story bearing down on your fragile character. Just go and kill people, because you're invincible. No death, no impending doom, no story. There is fun. But there's no fear; if I could compare ME and TR to FC3, that would be what's missing. Being scared. Not knowing what was going to happen next. No insurmountable odds to overcome at the end of the story, thus making you and your character true heroes in the process. Just: become the warrior and strealthkill everyone on the map with ease in normal mode. Le sigh.  TR had bullet-time close quarters combat, which is truly awesome, now that I find it missing from FC3. When an animal lunges at you in FC3, he just eats your face, and you have to mash some random button in order to survive (sometimes it's E which is 'use', sometimes it's spacebar which is jump, but it hasn't been F yet, which would make sense since it's the melee key), then you heal up and you're OK. Or, he eats your face and you respawn, and you're OK. Sometimes you die before the key indicator shows on screen... so it feels like it doesn't matter what key you press. In TR, it mattered which key, and when. It was the melee key, as I recall, and it was all done in slow-mo, because once that animal had his teeth in you it was game over. Damn that was cool.  The only real improvement over TR is that the open world is explorable. You can jump in a car and drive anywhere. So if you didn't like TR's one-path map, then you will like FC3's big, open world.  Another thing: FC3 instantly reminded me of 'Watch_Dogs' when I got in a car. Same engine, same mechanics. Ubisoft, I love you. Open world RPG FPS. Really. I just need more story because I'm spoiled by TR and ME. :D  Honestly there's not much replayability in FC3 or TR, unlike ME where you could choose another class with a new skillset, or another choice of dialog options which gave you a different ending ala 'Choose Your Own Adventure' books. So why did I play TR through a second time? There's nothing I can do differently, except find all the hidden stuff on the map. I guess it was so good that I wanted to do it again.  Sad news: from preliminary reviews and previews of FC4, it sounds to be just like FC3 with a couple new skills and mechanics. Same thing, different place, different characters and story. God, I hope it has a story.  So, If you've played TR and liked it, like I did, then you might want to skip FarCry3 and FarCry4, unless you really want more of the same in an open world, instead of a narrow path.

This game looks good, which you'd expect. It has some nice new innovations, like being about to travel through mountains if you're a dwarf or orc. You get 4 races (yes, just 4) but there is more variation in those races than you usually get in Total War titles.  You will complete it with all 4 races very quickly, then you'll realise that the game does not have any depth, the tech-trees are extremely limited and the late game is tedious . Also this is very much a re-skinning of teh total war engine, which is creaking a little bit at this stage.  The icing on the cake is that Creative Assembly have decided to release DLC at outrageous prices, so getting the full game could cost you way over €100. On the whole a good game but extremely light on content because they've broken the game down into tiny chunks to extract the money from players.

Yes, I know, as of posting this review I haven't played very much at all, however I have my reasons. This game is actually scary for me. Too scary, in fact. I tried twice to get past the first phone call and I couldn't bring myself to do it because these animatronics are the embodiement of my worst fears. The fact that I can't even run or hide from them is also part of the over-all fear. Even though the scares are jumpscares (and I really hate jumpscares because they give me too much of a scare all at once) the build up to them is enough to scare anyone or at least make them tense.  I know it all sounds like a negative review so far, but allow me to explain why I actually recommend this game. It's not the fan base which we all know has its problems (but so does every fandom and subculture ever), nor is it the game play or the graphics or any of that stuff, but it is in fact the lore of these games that keeps my interest. I love the story of it all. In this first game, most of the story is completely hidden, but when you look at it, this restaurant and these animatronics are part of a much bigger story, one of sorrow, murder, deception, haunting, possession, grudges, revenge, and a yearning for freedom. (sorry if that's not spelled correctly) There is seriously a heck ton more to this game than what you see on the surface. I won't spoil any of the story for you. Look into it yourself and you'll be in for one of the most interesting and complex stories in the horror section that we've seen in a while.  There is a reason for everything. Remember that when looking at this game.

Unrewarding and toxic game if you play by yourself. Community is so bad that it is impossible to solo queue without having to wish the apocalypse had hit humanity sooner. Since the game is heavily team orientated, you are basically relying on potatoes to carry since none of them want to or have the right amount of brain cells to play support. This leads to uncoordinated disastrous 'team' fights and you will end up losing the game unless you were lucky enough to be teamed up with decent human beings.    Without taking the community into account, the game is challenging and enjoyable if you play with a 5 stack; otherwise you would've wished you hadn't installed the game in the first place. 10/10 would not recommend if you are looking for a friendly community that openly welcomes new gamers. However, as mentioned above, it is quite enjoyable to play with people you know who understand the mechanics of the game as well as the importance of drafting the right heroes based on the opponents' picks.

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: Fallout 3 is an RPG, to say, with an FPS style. If you bought Fallout 3 for all the shooting, gore, explosions, well, in my opinion, you SHOULD NOT have gotten it. You got to treat this game like an RPG, not an FPS. Anyways, the game has a good story to say the least; it's a good story in my case. The game works with a leveling system, which is pretty cool. Weapons, clothing, armor, items, radio stations, this game is filled with stuff. There is a HUGE variety of monsters to fight, NPC's to talk to, companions, etc. For me, you like this game or not. It just simply is like that. Then comes the MODS. Mods are pretty cool, but the game is older than most games, so not too much good mods are being made anymore. That about wraps it up for this review. Verdict: 9/10 stars. I would definitely play the game once, then play again with all the mods possible.

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: Ridiculous amounts of plot holes. Village full of magically invincible children (not for the game's sake, but for the lore's sake, the mutants going to Big Town could easily waltz into Little Lamplight instead). Project Purity releasing huge amounts of radiation for no reason. BoS being anything but introverts. The list goes on.  Your choices don't matter. The enclave will always be your enemies and you must side with the Brotherhood of Steel for the main quest line, but let's not get started on the BoS love brigade. In addition, pacifist runs are not possible.  Companions are broken as hell. If you are high-levelled, companions are virtually invincible and will tank everything only to lose at most 2 bars of health. Maybe it's a good thing if you're tired of the level scaling. Yeah, there's also level scaling.  Blow up an entire town? Don't worry, you can make up for it by giving water to a homeless guy. The game is heavily dependent on its karma system and people will magically guess if you're good or bad and shun you from places or put hits out on you.  The game ends with a you going into a room full of lethal radiation to die because 'it is your destiny!' If you have the Broken Steel DLC, only then you have the option to send a companion in, three of which would be just fine (a super mutant, a robot and a ghoul, who are all resistant to radiation for their own reasons).  If you're looking for an RPG, this is not one. This is just an FPS with RPG elements.

So why the heck would you want to play this game? These are my reasons:  - Combined warfare (on land and in the air) at an unprecedented epic scale. Up to 2000 players on 64 square km maps: Seeing is really believing and the insane battles constantly keep you smiling. Popular saying: 'Planetside 2 is the closest thing you experience to real war'. - Cooperation between players goes a lot deeper than existing shooters. Once you've joined a good outfit, which is highly recommended, a complete new game play experience opens up to you.  - Solid gun and vehicle mechanics. No Battlefield netcode and hit detection bullsshhit, which is pretty amazing for a game on this scale. Weapons and vehicles feel tight and are fun to use, especially the unique empire specific ones.They're pretty well balanced too as devs are constantly on top of it. - You can be whatever you want to be and change within seconds. Whether it be long range cloaker sniper, a mechanized exoskeleton killing machine, a jumpjet light assault, a bomber gunner, a frontline support medic, there's a use for every role to specialize in in this game. The class system is fantastic in this game and the option to instantly switch classes and load-outs allows you to react quickly to the tactical situation and gives a ton of variety and depth to the game play. - There's a lot more to it than just shooting (if you are open to it): There are many tactical and strategic aspects to this game that open up to you once you've joined an outfit. - The large scale battles create an unique dynamic where no fight is the same and hilarious moments can always occur. Watching 50+ huge Galaxy dropships simultaneously kamikaze into your home base is just another day at the office for this game. Popular saying: 'Planetside 2 has more Battlefield moments than all Battlefield titles combined.' - Lively, friendly and mature community where you really get to know players. Just like in other MMOs, clans/ outfits often become close friend communities that actually meet up in real life. - Continuous development where developers are in close contact with the players, who a have strong influence on the development and get to vote on the roadmap. You can even make suggestions during live work-in-progress dev streams and literally see your ideas implemented in the game. - Great, colourful atmosphere with day and night cycle. Watching the colourful laser/tracer/fireworks shows never gets boring. This video is a good example how beautiful this game can be:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aQ65goFZ-64  - It is free to play without being pay to win. You should be well able to compete with the best (even as a new player) without ever spending a dime on this game. Your starter weapons are considered the best allround weapons in the game and other guns you can buy or as well play for are side-grades, not upgrades, designed to favour a more specific play style.  So why would you NOT want to play this game?  - When defined matches with a clear winner and loser is your thing. This game includes a 2 hour mini-game called Alert and also you can conquer continents to kick the enemy out, but otherwise you are playing on a persistent world map in a meaningless war without end. it's basically and endless Battlefield Conquest mode. - If you are going for instant, brainless, solo playing, run & gun fun. Well this is all perfectly possible in this game, you have to get a hang of the battle flow of this game first in order to consistently find good fights and be successful solo. In the beginning you will just die a lot and it takes some time before you really understand the gigantic maps and game mechanics. Playing in teams/ outfits is heavily recommended if you want to improve quickly. - If you want a game that is 'finished'. This game is a multi-year project. It was good (albeit rough) at launch ( Metacritic 8,4 ) but has been improved so much however that it now ranks as very good ( third best shooter of all time by PC Gamer) and will even further dramatically improve with the planned strategic and tactical additions that are scheduled on the road map . However, constantly improving this game also means bugs and issues (who usually get squeezed quickly by the devs) regularly popping up with every new patch. - If you are going for fair fights. 'Size matters' is the slogan of this game and you will regularly find yourself fighting overwhelming numbers (zergs) or being part of an overwhelming force yourself. Defending against the odds is possible but difficult. Your best bet is to join a public squad/ platoon or outfit and choose a fight where you as a team can make a difference.   TL, DR: This game is basically a Space Battlefield on crack. Massive scale shooters are the future of gaming for sure and this game is just ahead of its time. Once you've played this game how its best to be played, by being part of a good outfit, going back to Battlefield/COD type of games just feels like a small scale and shallow experience.  10/10

Clicker Heroes is, well, a clicking game. And yes, the game is a bit addicting. And, probably, the only thing good about this game is it's art style. And that's it.   Clicker Heroes is a game where you click rapidly on enemies to kill them. Everytime you kill one, they give you coins, which allow you to level up your characters, buy characters, and buy upgrades. That is all the game has to offer, besides a little bit of good artwork. Clicker Heroes is also an online game, which was a GREAT idea. You dont even need to do ANYTHING, and you still get stuff. I mean, REALLY!?!?  I would not recommend this horrible game to ANYBODY, other than people with no lives. It is a bit addiciting,if you even play the game. I played this game for 15 minutes, and 15 minutes is all i ever WANT to play. The most 'heroic' click YOU can do, is click 'Delete Local Content' for this game. This only MY opinion of this game. Some may like it, (I don't know why ANYONE would like this game), but i personally hate this game, and don't recommend it.

A brilliantly simple hack and slash game, complete with satisfyingly gruesome dismemberment and decapitation. The controls are excellent and provide a fun challenge in mastering the timing of chain attacks with different weapons. The game is online multiplayer only and there are a good variety of game modes, with the objective based games (For example, pushing a cart of corpses into an enemy water supply) being the most fun. The game runs very smoothly even on full servers and the chaos you'll find here is very much like medieval warfare. Teamkilling is practically a part of the game as accidents happen very, very fequently, but its hilarious rather than frustrating (Dont expect to go on a 20 kill rampage, your team mate will probably behead you first lol).  I find this to be a great pick up and play game, and have lost many, many fun filled hours to it. My only gripes would be that the levelling up system doesnt really seem to offer that much advancement or exciting new weapons to use and there could be more maps to play on. Other than that, I'd say grab some frineds and give it a try! Highly recommended if you fancy something a bit different from an FPS or are into the Medieval setting.

The game itself is good, but Valve does nothing to remove players that worsen the experience for everyone. One of the problems is language barriers, with especially Russians playing on EU west just to shorten qeue time but then don't speak English so they can't communicate with the rest of the team. Another problem are the players that ruin the game experience for everyone on purpose. This includes people shouting at team members, people who feed on purpose, people who will get out of the way to get you killed, or people who try to make your progress in a match worse. Once Valve actually tries to do something about the players the game will become very good. Up until that point I can't recommend it since there are too many bad games ruined by these people and too little games with teams that are actually working together.

Amazingly addicting and time consuming game. Best part? It's Free. In short it's a click/idle game with rpg elements. What sets it apart from the other clicking games is the stability, amazing dev team, constant updates and being just as exciting and progressive without buying anything such as other clicker games.  A List of potential cons to consider: -In App Purchases -Quickly growing Autoclicker DLC (not required or necessary, I consider it support for the developers) -People can use autoclicker programs and not get banned  But outside of these potential cons, a really solid game. Give it a try and consider a year of your time or more gone to The Outsider known as Borb.

Where do I start with this one?  Ok, so this game is a very basic medieval combat simulator. Swing your sword, shoot your bow, throw your axe or fire your catapult and grotesquely dismember your foes among castles and vallies of a time long pass! Or, just ragequit after high levels of frustration.  So what's fun about this game? The use of medieval weapons like swords and shields, the arena style gameplay, and dismemberment physics that are gore and blood done right!  The bad? Pretty much everything else. I managed to do pretty well in a short amount of time, climbing the scoreboards and getting over the noob hump relatively quick. Unfortunately in my group of friends, I was the only one. Everyone I was playing with could not get used to glitch exploitation and angry MW players that are more obtuse than that little troll the billy goat had to stomp da' ♥♥♥♥ out. The game also disconnected a fair amount and had a lot of lag issues.  Overall the gaming experience is skin deep and the gameplay feels like a mod, not an officially released game. I know, I know, this game was originally a mod. But that's no excuse for this game being so glitchy and unpolished, especially since they seem to release DLC for an otherwise messy game.  If you want to bang your head against a wall for a few hours, buy this game for 2.50 during a steam sale. But if you want rich combat and immersive gameplay with a decent community to back it, then abandon all your hope, ye who enter here.

Most of the bad reviews on game critics/steam are outdated,or just funny ones like,cuase i sucked or they didnt hold my hand enough the game blows...come on ppl  really?.....wtf?)...well  that being said,it is a nice game imo.Yes the grind is long for guns,but so what...anyone who complains about that should be playing wow(thats designed to be played by kids-who like instint gradifaction for things they do..  Starting out with the basic stuff is fine...only takes alitle bit of cert's to boost up the guns with sights,hand grips....not alot..for the differnt guns them selfs,yes it is high.But those ppl complaining about that are also playing the game for free.Yes it would be nice in perfect fair world for the game to be just out right free.But hey,that aint life,get over it...Ive only put 142 hours into it (80 as VS & the rest as NC-like the vangaurd srry VS) and the game seems fine...just came off playing WOT for a year & a half so of course im going to like/be good at tanks hehe :)....the rest of the aspects are ok  tho....med/eng  for cert farming(yes farming),but it aint no differnt then any other game..every game has farming and the grind,some just have longer ones...at the moment to date...its not really as buggy as ive heard it to be,so thats a plus,actually havnt seen a obviose bug yet,when i do ill do another review/edit this one.   As for the guy in the neg review(on steam) complaining about players playing on the side with the most players.and never playing as the underdog...well maybe he should play on Connor as the VS and platooon with JENK or DPSO sometime..jenk loves the underdog role(Yes you cant spawn tanks as fast,or maxs as much-but they give a nice xp+ bonus to the underdogs...so is nice for cert grinds)...And it takes team work and 3-4 dedicated sundre drivers to spawn on,which viods out the spawn room altogather...for someone with 480+ hours..that guy sure in the hell dont know how to play this game...So anyone who says that should stop trying to play solo in a game where each cont. caps at 2k players..seems kinda pointless dont it?  The game has built in Voice with indepentent voice leveling for players,which is a plus,seems to work pretty well.Volume lvlin at first for ppl can be a pain,but once you do it its done perma(kinda intresting to see where it save that at-im sure that file can get big after you ajust the vol for 400+ ppl and more)  The game has ground and air combat(which is why i quit WOT-the 15 vs 15 3 min matchs in that game drove me insane,while in PS2 i can run around in a vangaurd for a hour-get 30+ kills and never die which is nice.Plus the maps being so big also makes it nice for having a good armor groups to just push through the enemie.  All the game takes is team work...the tools to do so effectently are there.Its just alot of players dont use them...if theres alot of tanks on the ground...pull out some Heavy air/max's or if theres heavy air,so pull out ESF's with anti air maxes/tanks with anti air...it just takes team work.Now if ya get a group of players just running around lost and (as the guy in the NEg review pointed out) just spawning and dieing and spawning and dieing in a spawn room,ditch that area and spawn somewhere else jump in a sundr open up chat and type in reginally 'hey have a sundr spawning near *** stop spawning in the spawn room....and get them to spawn on you and kick whos ever it may be your fightings a**(inless you fighting the NC of course-then spawning in the spawn room is a great ideal..just do that,we like easy kills)

Five Nights at Freddys, also known as FNaF, is a great game. Honestly, I used C D + on the last night (And 20/20/20/20 mode) just so I could get the stars, but that's not the point. FNaF has a GREAT storyline: Freddy Fazbear's Pizza was shut down after the parents and children reported 'Disgusting Body Odor' coming from the animatronic animals. You play the role of the night guard, and you have 3 objectives: Close the doors, Check the lights, and Survive 5 (7) nights. Go pick this game up, give it a go, and say hello to Bonnie, Chica, Freddy, Foxy, Golden Freddy, and a whole lot of scares.

A faster paced Total War game. I recommend this for all strategy game fans.  The faster pace is a blessing and a curse, I miss large combats that took a moment longer, but while playing I realized that the faster combats are actually quite fun, there is less waiting to move to the enemy and more fighting. Altough I miss the strategy of maneuvering around the enemy, I enjoy the action as well.  I like the new sieges as well (sue me), they represent a different scool of sieges, more like movies instead of history. I enjoy rushing to the tower blind spots and using siege towers to get up on the walls. It again takes away some elements of the game but adds more action to it.  On the campaign map the game feels like a stripped down total war with roleplay elements. I miss having to actually manage my cities, but as an avid RPG fan I absolutely adore the new heroes and the quest battle system. I hoped for more depth in all aspects of the campaign map, but as a whole the gameplay is really enjoyable. Some factions play styles fit me better than others, so finding the one you like might take more than a single campaign.  I wrote this after playing around 130 hours and I plan on spending many more with this game.  Edit. After numerous DLC packs I'm being drawn back in to the game, addition of new races breathes a fresh new perspectives into the game. I'm not a fan of horde mechanics in this game, but I'm looking forward to the woodelves.

You leave this game with quite the unique experience. Ill never forget the 60 man airstrikes or the massive tank columns. I have some of my fondest gaming memories from this game and it was all provided completely free.

When I first heard about PlanetSide 2, my thoughts were that since its free to play its probably not that great. Then I figured I had nothign to lose if I tried it. Ive been playing ever since. Let me tell you something about this game, it will blow your mind. Open world, multiplayer combat utilizing infintry combat, armored combat, and aerial combat. Pick one of three factions, the Terran Republic, New Conglomerate, or Vanu Sovereignty then jump into the fight any way you like. Dont like playing with groups? Fine go solo. Want to find a group to play with, with an established rank structure? Join a squad or platoon. Whant to form a group to operate as infintry, armor or an air force? Form a squad and get to it. With 3 giant continents (seriously, they are quite big) with no zoning on the continents you can run your platoon of armor from one side to the other with no stops (except to conquer bases), and if you feel that driving is too slow, take to the skies as either a fighter/bomber, high altitude support or crew transport aircraft each with their own weapons and roles. There is so much that you can do in this game it can get overwhelming at times. If you are serious about FPS games, this should be tried without hesitation.

Going into this game, I was willing to accept that I would die alot. I was willing to accept that there would be players that have played much longer than me, and would be much better than me. Even still, this game left a terrible taste in my mouth. I felt like i was dropped into the fight with nearly 0 explaination as to what was going on (played throught the tutorial too), what my objectives were, or who I was even supposed to shoot at. Gunplay and shooting felt clunky and awkward, and the game simply does not look good. I don't have a monsterous rig, but it performs very well in most games, but this isnt the case with Planetside 2. Even at medium settings, I am only able to squeeze out an unbearable 15-25 FPS during fights, which, to me, is when it matters most. Aside from that, there is no story to be had, just a 'shoot the guy not wearing the same color as you' game. Granted, I didn't expect a lot of story, but I got absolutely nothing. As mentioned before, I hated the gunplay, as none of the shooting felt quite right. I could overlook it if there was a story behind the game, but...  Overall, If you have some sort of ungodly computer capable of running this game at higher settings, don't mind zero story and awkward gunfights, and you don't mind dying over and over without feeling like you are accomplishing anything, this game is for you.

To start this off, people have thousands of hours in this game as you can leave it running while you're doing other things.  --  Clicker Heroes is, in my eyes, the pinnacle of the idle/clicking/incremential genre.   This is not a genre for everyone, it's for those of us who have compulsive loot-chasing instincts. The goal is pretty much the satisfaction of faster and faster progress, and bigger and bigger numbers. The game starts off incredibly slow, you click hundreds of times, and if you only play for half an ahour, that's what you'll think it is.  You click and click, and then you get enough money to buy your first hero, Treebeast. When you hire treebeast, the enemies will start taking continious damage over time, and the higher you level your heroes, the more damage they do.   Eventually, you make your way up to Amenhotep, and you can buy his 'Ascension' skill. What this does, is it takes away all your hero levels, and plops you right back at level one. WAIT, COME BACK  When you get to the higher levels, you start aquiring 'Hero Souls', and for every hero soul you hold on to, all damage by you and heroes is increased by ten percent, so you'll start progessing faster, further, and deeper.  Once you get enough, you can start spending those hero souls on 'Ancients', which are extremely beneficial passive effects, and the game will shift to leveling up the Ancients, and less about the heroes.   The developer has been shooting updates and patches practically bi-weekly, and they've added incredible content.  *Relics (Loot that drops once per ascension that grants additional passive benefits)  *Clans (up to 10 players, a message board, and daily 'Raids', which are incredibly tough bosses that last 24 hours, and will give everyone who participates in killing them hero souls based on their participation and damage done)  *Holiday events  *Followers (Think WoW's garrison quests)  There will be those who are turned off just because it's a free to play game, but there is literally no pay to win, everything you can buy is stuff that you get in game extremely easily. The developers also clearly love this game, they can't stop adding stuff to it.  This is an incredibly insidious game, and it's very, very addictive if you have the patience to learn it. When I'm not playing it on Steam, I am also playing it on my phone.  I highly recommend this to all fans of loot based games such as Diablo, WoW, etc, as it will really, REALLY scratch that gear grind itch.   ---  I consider this game one of my Mandatory Steam Games, and a must-have.
