app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: Please not that this review is by no means a reflection of the game in general, but more for an overlying issue: the fact that it is not optimized for any Windows OS newer than Vista.  Unlike New Vegas, which basically uses the same engine, older BGS games like Oblivion and Morrowind, or even Interplay's Fallout games of 1, 2 and Tactics, Fallout 3 generally will not run correctly, if at all, on Windows 7, 8/8.1, and 10. While select few have been able to make the game run just through Compatiblity mode, the overall majority of users require numerous steps to go over and hoops to jump through. And even then, if you are in the minority of those like myself, you can still find yourself unable to play even after jumping through the hoops.  While the avid modder for Bethesda games might find it normal and only slightly more frustrating, the average user might just find it to be one massive headache. And again, they might just find it a waste of time if, like myself, can't seem to get it to actually start up a new game even with things like FOSE (Fallout Script Extender), G4WL Disabler (Games For Windows Live Disabler), a 4GB Patch, and the Unofficial FO3 Patch.  If you are one of those users who actually wants to put in the effort and see about getting it working, then there is a guide located here:  https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=149946772   The Guide itself is simple to understand, easy to follow, and contains links to nessecary additions to help get the game running.  However, it by no means ensures the game will work. While you could find success in the early steps, you could just find yourself stuck with nothing solving it.   If you are truely desperate in playing Fallout 3 again, but don't want to deal with the hastle of the steps in the guide, or are in the minority of users that, like myself, can't get it to run even with the steps in the guide, then you have one of two options. If you are and avid PC player and might even want to mod it, then find a good quality PC that is running Windows Vista. Or, if you don't care about mods, how it looks, or even what platform you play it on, then go down to your local Gamestop/EB Games, or whatever the store is called for you and purchase a PS3 or Xbox 360/Xbox One (as it is a backwards compatible title) and Fallout 3 Game of the Year edition, as the console versions still work fine.

Ok, this game is one of the best multiplayer games I've ever seen or played. Ever wanted to decapitate someone with a sword taller than you are? Check. Hate games with unrealistic and buggy combat? This game has none of it! Feel the urge to yell at the enemy about how their wife provided fitter sport? Don't lie...of course you have.  Pros; -Intense action -High reliance on teamwork, which is fun -Realistic to the point of being satisfying, but not too much so that it's not fun -Huge customizability, both gameplay and cosmetic-wise -Satisfaction of doing crazy stunts -The greatest taunts in the history of gaming  Cons; -Without a good CPU, you need to turn the graphics down a lot for smooth gameplay -Has quite a large learning curve -You will be killed by higher levels a LOT. Don't let it discourage you! -Training area is good, but needs improvement -Some maps feel unoriginal and bland  Overall, I rate it 7.5/10. A great investment and a fun way to kill your day. Just whatever you do, DON'T BUY THE DLC. IT SUCKS.

This game was very disappointing to me. Despite my own decent computer and above average connection I found a lot of slowdown and delay in both the menus and even the game itself. The game looks nice, even on lower settings, but the audio is rather grating on the ears. The customization and weapon options for each class is a fun idea, however most new players will have to use the lackluster starter weapons before they can unlock anything decent though leveling. A lot of the menus feel very cluttered and are a pain to the eyes.  Gameplay overall feels very fun and satisfying when it works, but the game's hair thin hit detection takes a lot of time to figure out. New players should spend a lot of time practicing on thier own until they can figure out the hix box and controls for whatever class works best for them.   Community feels very non-existant at times. I often forgot I was actually playing with other people until I saw a few unique looking characters and even then it was insanely quiet. I'm sure it's full of decent people, but my expierence could be summed up when I saw a Knight t-bagging someone he just killed (to which he was promptly shot afterward).  Overall, I WANT to like this game, but the sloppy and sluggish menus, difficult gameplay, unsettling silence keeps it from meeting my hopes. Perhaps when I finally get better at the game my opinion will improve, but right now I've had a fairly unenjoyable expierence (4.5/10)

A very well-made horror game with an interesting concept, where you can create your own strategy to survive through 5 nights (actually there is 7 nights) as a security guard at Freddy Fazbear's pizza. Basically you're in a room with cameras and doors with lights to press if your enemies are outside the door beacuse you won't be able to see them very well in the darkness which will be a problem then... Your enemies by the way are 4 animatronic characters that will get more active the more progress you make on your nights... the first one is a bunny called: Bonnie. The second one is a chicken called: Chica... and the third one is a bear named Freddy (which is the main antagonist in the game) and the fourth one is a fox called: Foxy. they are going to try to kill you when they get a great chance and you have to stop these chances and survive through the nights... but be aware of the power you have to left side in the bottom corner... if it runs out you will die... possibly... or maybe if you're lucky you can actually make it to the next night... oh i forgot to mention: you have to work your shifts from 12 am to 6 am in the game... and the only help you get is from a guy on the phone, cameras and the doors that can be closed to stop them from coming in... sometimes you can't close the doors that means that you're doomed... because one of them is in your room and will kill you if you put up and then down the camera... You have to watch every one of them on the camera to make sure they don't move so often... but more necessary... only check on Freddy and Foxy... beacause those two are the actual problems in this game... because they can kill you very easily if you don't check on them too often... but you need to be aware of the other two too: Bonnie and Chica... but Bonnie is more active than Chica is... so you don't need to check on Chica too much... but then there are the other two... or actually THE THREE problems: Bonnie, Freddy and Foxy that you need to guard (you can hear Bonnie and Chica step on the floor outside the room sometimes that means that they might or might not be very close to you) ... I highly recommend this game for those who wants to get their socks scared off >:) If you don't find animals scary... Five Nights at Freddy's will prove what kind of hell animals can be...   PS: there is a fifth animal called: Golden Freddy... and he can be found in your office if you look on the cameras on a poster in one room too much... and if you stare on him too much he will crash your game and end the attempt you're doing in this game... so get rid of him by going back to the cameras, because then he'll disappear...

Clicker Heroes is a fun, laid back game, but in my opinion, quite generic. Allow me to explain.  When I say generic, it doesn't really bring anything NEW to the table. Like most other clicker games, it's 'Spam your mouse button, buy some auto-clickers, boom bada bam.' Which I'll admit, kind of disappoints me. Now I know that's sort of the point of clicker games, but I would rather spend an hour on a game I like instead of 5 minutes each day, getting on to upgrade a few things and then waiting tomorrow for more currency.  I will admit however that clicker heroes does have its pros. A level system, where you'll fight stronger monsters as you continue through them. It's got a sort of storyline once you piece together the character's little backstories, you can sort of see how they connect to one another, which I always enjoy a good read. Other games like cookie clicker and adventure capatlist don't really have much insight or backstory.  In any case, I do recommend this game for when you're bored and/or have a few minutes to spare and can just drop by and see how everything is going. It's a good game for a laid-back and patient person.  7/10 Pop-tarts. A bit generic, but still has it's own uniquness.

Pros: framerate, cool fantasy stuff, magic, cowmen that throws giant boulders and stomps litle things to dusty death. No Hun's. Cons: Cities are basically walls with fancy backscreen. Water is useless, trading is scarce, resources are only intresting in regard of recruiting and building. No depth. Lack of content. Simply not enough factions. Too pricy.   Maybe worth 20€, if you love warhammer. The best bit's costs 17€ extra, wich should have been included in retail.  You'll end up at almost 100€ with DLC's and still it feels pretty scarce compared to Rome 2 or Attila. I do like the atmosphere and playable heroes/agents during battle. Also the skill-tree is neat.  It give's me as the commander a feel to be more entwined with my domains and the battles fought. Some heroes are specced and used similarly to agents in other games of the franchise. But it's those heroes specced and honed in battle that makes these new mechanics shine, and they shine bright. Charge in with your faction leader or hero of your lands and obliterate enemy units, boosting morale of your own men. It's really good.  But.  When the new features start to settle in on the player, one realises new features are scarce. In addition some old features from the franchise are nowhere to be found. The first battles and conquests are immersive, it engulfs you as the player into the world of Warhammer.  However, when the battle cries start to echo out into the 'vast' lands and the fog of war finds its escape back into the darkness.   I get this feeling of, this was it.   There is nothing really that motivates expansion except for more armies and bigger battles. It's just the same over and over. Nothing motivates further progress. The world starts to feel shallow and those mechanics and feeling of creating a legacy in the fantastic game Attila is simpy not there.  This is pretty much an expansion with Warhammer map and units. It's is cool and all for us that likes fantasy books and games. But its just too shallow. After a few hours, It's like waking up hungover next to a stranger savage orch.  I constantly find myself playing Attila instead, drafting mighty battles with endless variation due to mods, or simply rewriting history. Trying to marry my persian daughter to the Huns, playing coop with a friend slowly spreading the only true religion for world domination. Launching a mighty offensive to make England pagan again. I conquer fertile lands to farm, investing vast ammounts of gold into science and philosophy, for my people. Because i care.

Great single-player campaign. My favorite of all the Far Cry stories. Some great bad guys. It's open-ended like Grand Theft Auto, only on an island. Even borrows from the TV show Lost with some of its more trippy elements. The multiplayer campaign is a lot like Call of Duty Modern Warfare. You need to level before you have access to everything. Several popular styles of play including one I haven't played before that puts you in a burning field. Great game, great shooter. I just wish Ubisoft would let you link more through Steam. You have to connect through their Uplay client which is an unnecessary pain in the bumb.

'Ever wondered what one quadrillion damage per second feels like?' the store page asks. Spoilers: it feels a lot like one million damage. And a lot like one thousand damage did a handful of levels before that. Everything scales so smoothly and so high that it frankly stops having any impact at all. It's just numbers going up to make other numbers go down. I have never seen a game that gave me less of a sense of just how big a billion is. I can't put it down. If I can get my damage to go from 15,544s to around 300S, I can tackle the next boss. I've lost control of my life.  10/10 defense budget simulator, 10/10 gamer hindbrain stimulant, 0/10 good idea.

In terms oF game design this game is fine. The implementation, however, is garbage. Characters routinely warp into kills due to poor handling of latency. Terrible animations that look as if they're missing frames. It's often impossible to time blocks because your opponent will just warp through their animations. Heaviest class has the fastest strike. Certain classes, like Man of Arms, is damn near useless. Fists are one of the weakest yet slowest weapons in the game. Swords cut through multiple people with no decrease in damage (even with the first opponent hit does not die). You get stuck on people constantly because the characters don't slide along each other completely ♥♥♥♥ing up dodges and other manuvers when teammates are around.  General overall crappy feel to combat system. I would like to see someone make a similar medieval FPS with a technically competent melee system. It's a good idea, but this implementation is trash.

If you have the chance to buy this game and it's on sale(I say this cause we all need to save money), DO SO. People have compared it to Skyrim with guns, and I can see where someone might get this impression but I would compare it like this: 25% Skyrim and 75% Assassin's creed. Yes, you have skills, and yes you have crafting but the crafting is more like Assassin's creed. 'Collect 2 Alligator hides to create the extended holster' '2 Yellow plants for the hunting syringe' ect, you get the idea. And for this game, it's not really a bad thing. I guess for me, I'd prefer the crafting like Skyrim rather than AC. BUT that's just me... You can capture Outposts(which is really fun, by the way. Id kinda like more like this) to open up fast travel points and stores to purchase weapons and ammo. Hunting is rather fun but once you have all the materials to craft what you need, theres no more need to hunt.  Skill are set up very nicely and are displayed in the form of your tatau(tattoo) on your arm which is a REALLY cool way to do it. I hope they do something like this in the next game.  Vaas....BEST VILLIAN EVER...If I was gay, I'd have a crush on him...who I am I kidding...I'M STRAIGHT AND I HAVE A MANCRUSH ON VASS...TOTALLY NOT IN A GAY WAY, THOUGH. I kinda wished he was the main villian rather than a right hand or something.  Overall...BUY THIS GAME....BUY IT...whenitsonsalecuaseletsfaceitweneedtosavemoney.

Goat Simulator... If I had seen a write-up for it, I would have thought that it was a prank of some kind. Something so completely 'out there' in concept would have been a joke. Then I saw the 'let's play' videos by Markiplier, PewdiePie and Yammimash. Oh my...  This game is a blast to play, with nearly everyting capable of being interacted with. When I mean 'interacted' with, I mean smashing, blasting, headbutting and... licking. Plenty of hidden things and locations to find and it's a lot of fun just how crazy it can get.  Downside? Very graphics intensive. As my comp isn't top of the line, I have to set everything at the minimum and it still lags abysmally if I have the camera angle high enough to see far.   Good and bad at the same time. The game is easily broken. Getting the Demon Goat form and having the mutator of 'Goatborn' (which is a wonderful effect, I must say) at the same time causes the goat to so 'super silly-putty' and spaz out all over the place.  Overall, I really enjoy playing this game and I would highly recommend it to folks that just want something silly to play and go into hysterical laughter at the chaos created.

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: I had this game for 2 hours and never played it. Wanna know why? It is taking me(and still is!) that long to actually start it up. ♥♥♥♥ I am sick of starting a game and having it crash.  UPDATE: Woo, got it on console. I won't comment about bugs or anything, only other problems. This game is overrated as ♥♥♥♥. The storyline is unoriginal and flat, the lore is a complete mess ,and it is very tedious. Wanna repair your gun? Oh sorry wait until your repair is level 100 to repair it all the way which even then takes new weapons. The gameplay is basically like a dumbed down version of oblivion. Except this one is very forgiving, the main quest is very short, and the whole karma is stupid. Just nuked a village full of people? You will be forgiven if you do the main storyline the 'good' way. The DLC's are ok, I guess. The only ones worth getting are Mothership and The pitt. For the open world is either a plain landscape or DC, which I guess is ok. This is one of the worst fallout games in the franchise, right above FO:Brotherhood of steel. Wanna real Fallout FPS? Try New Vegas, It isn't black and white, has believable lore, and actually seems like a fallout game that doesn't try to appeal to everyone.

Probably the only thing scarier than the game is the fanbase. But do I blame the fanbase for being scary? No. If I were forced to work the same stupid job for 6 hours a night for 5 nights and I only got $4/hour, I'd be kinda scary too, albeit mostly due to a lack of an ability to buy things I need. They used to be tamer, but then something happened.  Overall, I recommend. Be srue to turn up the volume to max. Beware of the fandom though.

I got this game for the Goaty bundle, and it is so fun, but the game itself becomes boring after a while. This is where the DLC's come in at. Along with the DLCs, this is a really fun game, and you should get it if you are looking for a funny physics game.

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: Fallout become a part of my life back in 2008 when I found this game through my brother. He lended me the game about 7 years ago, but he's never getting it back. Here's why: Fallout 3 is one of those games you will never truly forget. Of course, I cannot be totally biased in this review since I'm absolutely obsessed with this game, but I really really really recommend you play this ASAP.  Pros of this game- I absolutely love the location of Fallout 3 (Mainly washington D.C.) because throughout the quests we learn pieces of the United States' history which is absolutely awesome to me. Also not to mention the incredible sountrack that you can listen to while venturing out into the cold Wasteland.  The characters in this game are heartfelt, funny, and all around just enjoyable to meet. Each character has their story to learn about, and some hilarious side quests.  V.A.T.S. V.A.T.S. V.A.T.S.!  Perks! I think the perks in this game are pretty sweet, and I absolutely adore them.  DLC! While some of the DLC was pretty boring or not necessary, I believe that most of the DLC was very intresting and difficult.  The story was one of the best stories I have played because the whole aspect of losing your father, and going on a wild goose chase for him is so interesting to me. I felt so many waves of emotion while playing Fallout 3's story.  Cons of this game-  Combat is definitely not the best in this game, so if you think that's extremely important then you may not like this game too much. Graphics are pretty low quality in this game, but what can you expect? It was made in 2008, so you have to keep that in consideration. Although I do wish they were a bit better.  Glitches, glitches, glitches galore.  Anyways I hope you have the amazing chance of playing Fallout 3 without knowing much about it because it is an incredibly fun game to get in to, and I believe you will love it. Thanks and happy trails! :)

I have been a Total War fan since the first Rome, I've played Rome 1&2, Medieval 2 and Shogun 2 and this has to be the worst of the lot. I am also abit of a Warhammer fan, but not hugely, so I was really excited to get a Warhammer based fantasy Total War. I have to say I am very disapointed.  The game frankly doesn't feel anywhere near finished as it is, core content/races have been cut out to be sold as DLC which is a discusting practice that needs to stop. I remember when unlocking new races in a Total War game was a massive insentive to finish the campaign and play again, now you have to buy it, it's a joke.  The download size was shockingly small, about 11GB, compared to 25GB of Rome 2 and 20GB of Shogun 2 and when you play the game for a few hours you see why, the campaign map isn't very big, and each region only seems to have 1 battle map, so you end up fighting battles on the same handful of unimaginative and fairly empty maps. Maybe a battle maps DLC is in the future?  The game play is quite good, which makes it a real shame that the game is let down by lack of content.

I'm going to try to be as honest as I can with you. Its a great FPS, if you are NR. Its a great tank game, if you are the purple F***s. Its a bad day to be TR if you don't have at least 100 kids with you. With that being said, it shows factions are super inbalanced. I used to love this game, I really did. I got it a year or two ago and thought it was the best thing I'd ever played. I've been playing it at an average pace since then. I've learned how to drag and feint and all the other exploits and I had a blast.   Then I realized that this game has gone to crap.  The devs have only been releasing skins and items in all the recent updates, and everytime they say they fixed a bug, another 4 pop up. All the combat needs a revision, because I can see an arrow fly above my head, a second passes and then I get killed by it even though it was 10 feet above my sorry ♥♥♥ skull, and people can cut through shields like they were cardboard.   The buttons don't work and the menus are screwed up. And don't get me started on how unfair this game is to new players. All the veterens that have played since the game has come out are at least a rank 30. Being a Intermediate-High rank character myself (I'm around 33 or something like that) I've learned all the combat stuffs and can hold my own against even the most skilled drag queens and feinting goats. Then I realized, I'm one of them now. I had to become one to beat them, I am ashamed of myself for switching to the dark side of the community and exploiting the animation system and hitboxes. 'Dragging' is when a player turns his mouse to a side to either speed up or slow down the swing of the blade and feinting is a game mechanic in which you can cancel an attack by hitting a button.  If you want a game where you will get your ♥♥♥ handed to you by unfair odds, buy DarkSouls or Bloodborne or something. This game is turning into another hat simulator. If you want a game where you have to buy everything to be respected, get TF2 or CS:GO, at least those Dev's still patch the game and try to work with the community. The devs have gotten lazy and greedy. All the updates are just adding items from the workshop as weapon reskins and hats. Rather than trying to revise the things that need revision desperately, they'll release a community made map, or fix a bug where the 3rd bolt of the Mason Knight's right shoe didn't show up properly. Basically, they only release useless or redundent patches.  At this point the game can only get better or get much worse, check it out in a year or two and maybe they'll have fixed things, If not, then this game will live on in the hearts of the veterens and die out. If you really, really, really, really, really, really, really want to get it; do so while it is on sale or when it does another one of it's crossovers with another game, just try to be patient after you've been kicked off of the newbie servers  6/10- Used to be fun, still is at times, good combat if you never encounter Drag queens and feinters, Great fun for Veterens but no fun for new players, unfortunately has begun it's journey to the dark side of Gaming  Pros: +Fun +High potential +Best Medieval combat I've seen  Cons: -Lazy/Greedy Devs -Easially exploited systems -Bug ridden and sub-par maintenance -Lack of attention to where it is really needed by Devs

Dota 2 is a multiplayer online battle arena video game and the stand-alone sequel to the Defense of the Ancients (DotA) mod. Developed by Valve Corporation, the game was officially released on July 9, 2013 as a free-to-play title for Microsoft Windows, concluding a beta testing phase that began in 2011. OS X and Linux versions of Dota 2 were released on July 18, 2013. In most regions, Dota 2 is exclusively available through Valve's content delivery platform, Steam. Each match of Dota 2 involves two teams, both containing five players and occupying a fortified stronghold at either end of the map. Victory is achieved by destroying the enemy's Ancient, which is invulnerable until certain objectives are achieved. Each player controls a 'Hero' character and focuses on leveling up, acquiring items and fighting against the other team to achieve victory during each match. Development of Dota 2 began in 2009, with the hiring of DotA developer 'IceFrog' to serve as the sequel's lead designer. Dota 2 was praised by video game critics, who lauded it for remaining faithful to its predecessor while also increasing the level of production quality, as well as for its engaging and rewarding gameplay experience. However, Dota 2 was criticized for its steep learning curve and inhospitable community. The game has become the most played on Steam, with daily peaks of over 550,000 concurrent players.

To put this game into perspective, it is like a super-sized Battlefield 2142 with a three-way conflict and a seemingly limitless supply of respawn tickets. Customizable weapons, vehicles, and loadouts allow for players to adjust their gear to suit their needs, whether it would be to quickly repair and deal massive amounts of human tissue damage, or to have the long reach of a good sniper rifle to precisely remove HVTs (High-Value Targets), or to fly high and drop slowly down over a wall, where the enemy least expects opposition, or hook their team up with plenty of ammuntion to keep them in the fight. There are many other varieties of loadout that I could not hope to cover here.  This game is not infantry-centric, either. Players have their choice to drive their land vehicles or fly high in various VTOL aircraft, all of which with varying sizes and forms of firepower. An offensive push with a mix of LAV (Light Armored Vehicle) and MBT (Main Battle Tank) could force an enemy frontline to back off and retreat. Air strikes and air support would give a team a high angle of attack to rain death on the enemy forces.  A player can be dangerous, when fighting solo and trying to be a one-person-army. Fighting with a team, however, is deadly. This game can appeal to the officers and leaders of the real world, as well. Coordinating a team and leading them to victory, crushing the less-coordinated enemy force in the process, is a rewarding experience, too.  If you happen to be reading this, and Battlefield was a game you enjoyed playing (like me), you should definitely try Planetside 2. It may surprise you.

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: This game is not good. I very much want to like this game, but i just can't. Heres a collection of reasons why:  1: The story is crap. It's not engaging whatsoever, and its not even your story. You're just a tag-along most of the time, and even when you aren't you still never really feel like you are accomplishing anything.  2: You have no real choice in playstyle. You either shoot things, hit things, or blow things up. Thats it. No pacifist runs. This wouldn't be too big an issue if this was fun, but...  3: Combat is boring, just horribly boring. None of the weapons really pack any kind of punch, and in the end it just feels like you're shooting spitballs for all the balistic impact the weapons have. The melee weapons fare slightly better in this regard, but with exeption of a few lategame and unique weapons they just all feel the same; just with different damage numbers.  4: It looks like ♥♥♥♥. Now, I don't have anything against dated graphics, but the textures are just plain bad on a lot of things, at times worse than oblivion, and definetly worse than New Vegas, which is on the same engine. The omnipresent gray-green filter does not help this any.  5: The AI is terrible. Running into walls, spazing out, not reacting to being shot, the works.  6: It crashes a lot. These crashes are unavoidable in most cases, and can only be delayed by installing some unoficial patches and such.  7: The DLC. Its not great. Out of all of the DLC, only Point Lookout is really worth playing, and to a lesser extent The Pit.  Get Fallout: New Vegas instead. It is everything that this game should have been: Fun.

This game seems as if it would be fun for its 'so bad it's good' nature, and there are perhaps moments of enjoyment which can be brought forth from experiencing the zaniness within. However, the central gimmick this game relies on, being a purposefully broken, buggy game, falls short of being anything more than a mere novelty worthy of no more than a brief period of attention.  The ultimate problem comes not with the joke becoming old fast, however, though that is still a problem. The real problem is the lack of truly having anything to do. In this game, you can wander around and headbutt things and lick things and maybe use an item or two found around the world you wander through. Every once in a while you may discover some new ability, but the abilities don't refresh any replay value the game could've had since the abilities are typically something like becoming stronger, a feat which is entertaining for approximately two seconds.  Besides lacking in meaningful character advancement, the other central problem is the size of the worlds you occupy. I've not played the DLC (and I'd rather not bother), but the overall size of the base game is quite minuscule, as if even the developers were unsure of how they could keep a game like this interesting enough for so long without adding some new tacky, inane gimmick in their DLC. It's small even for ten dollars (thankfully I paid far less), so I don't recommend, if you dare bother, picking this up for that price.  This game is a clear case of 'it's not so bad it's good, it's just bad.' People lapped it up easily due to the 'so bad it's good' label anyway, what with this game becoming easy fodder for people on YouTube to flail about like goons while they giggle and chort over the most mundane occurences within the game. This game, more than anything, readily showcases a major problem within video games, the dumbing down of content and willingness to accept ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. This game is not the worst I've played, since I will give it some slack for at least trying to some extent, but I still would strongly consider this a candidate as one of the worst video games ever.

A good casual game to sit and play for 10 to 15 minutes before or after work. Then after you become a little more powerful you get stuck at doing only up to level 160-170 for about 1 month. Before this game came to Steam and was only a flash game on the internet, with 100-150 souls you could reach level 180 with no problem and with 150+ souls you can do up to level 200+. Now, you play for a week or two, get to 100/200 souls and you can reach level 130-160 with no problem. BUT after that comes the mega-uber-never-seen-before farming. I had 300 souls and I can barely reach level 170-180 level. Unless you give a lot of real money for this crappy game, then you will have to farm for the rest of your life. Oh... and at some point you will see that this game won't be so casual, you will sit for 10 minutes, but you will see that, that won't be enough at some point, the game forces you to waste up to 40-45 minutes of your time and probably even more as you progress. I do NOT think this game even deserves to be on Steam, but that's my opinion. In any case I do NOT recommend this game. It's a HUGE waste of your lifespan, believe me I lost somewhere around 30 hours(the 70 hours you see are because I've been AFK for over 30 hours) in this game. Believe me it isn't worth your time! I regret even starting to play this. I hope my review helped! :)

Bearing the name of a legendary 2003 MMOFPS, sadly PS2 falls short of the mark. Whilst improving in scale and graphics, it has neglected core aspects of its gameplay: community, balance, depth and complexity. This half-♥♥♥♥♥ approach to the design of core components of the game becomes evident early on. It does have some saving graces, large scale battles, and playing with others is a lot of fun. However it comes at a price.  Ultra-Freemium, 9 euros a month premium, with individual items costing from 5 to 20 euros. The cop-out for such ridiculous pricing across their entire range is: you don't have to buy, nobody is forcing you.  The game falls under P2C-up (Pay-2-Catch-up), the most insidious form of P2W (Pay-2-Win). Imagine playing your standard MMO-RPG, such as wow, where instead of playing/grinding for the items you need, you can hand over 60 euros and get all your gear. This Planetside 2's business model.  It's beautiful graphics bely a rotten core of reprehensible business practices that seek to exploit gamers at every turn. It degrades us all as gamers, avoid the game if you can, there are more respectable games out there, and with less cheaters.

I never liked Total War.   BUT   I have always loved Warhammer, since I was a little kid moving to a new town, I had no friends, and I dealt with a fair few ♥♥♥♥ed up things. The first friends I ever made, I made through a shared love for Warhammer. Growing up I got all the games, watched everything I could that had any relevance to Warhammer, and I've been a fan for as long as I can remember.   When I heard about this I was honestly really excited, I pictured MASSIVE wars, from a developer that hopefully cared about Warhammer the same as many Warhammer fans do. What I instead seen was a company that is well known for ♥♥♥♥ing over it's own fanbase, doing the same thing to the Warhammer fanbase.   Warhammer has a lot of love, and a lot of extremely loyal fans (to a fault at times) and the amount of love this has gotten from a lot of Warhammer fans has to do with that.   The fact it's a Warhammer game shouldn't mean we look over the greed of the company that made it.   I honestly hate this game, be it their absolutely pathetic DLC's, that all together are $40+ ontop of the $72 for the base game. The fact the game almost seems unfinished in a lot of areas, and how most of it seems blocked behind Downloadable Content. The fact that the Campaign for each race is pretty much the exact same, the obvious lack of content, and the over-hype.  (Not done yet)   The fact they refuse to release the modeling tools, or really help out the modders at all - The mod compatability being the greatest feature due to all the mods being done by _Fans_ that _Love_ Warhammer. The fact that they instead of making new factions with reasonable prices, opting instead to sell blood packs, release units like the Blood Knights, ones that are inferior compared to a mod creators version.   Basically the game is abhorrent to MANY fans of Warhammer. And hell - even many fans of Total War.  I wouldn't recommend this game to anybody, nevermind a fan of either franchise.
Do NOT bother -- This game is a waste of your time.

Summary:  A solid if somewhat unambitious addition to the TW series geared more towards new players.  Pros:  Well balanced, stable, a few new innovations.  Cons:  Many elements stripped down or removed from previous installments, suffers from TW's perennial issues of neurotic AI and an unbalanced endgame.  I've had a long, tumultuous relationship with the Total War series. From the processor melting release of Medieval II to the glory days of Shogun 2 I've stuck with it. After Rome II I swore I'd never buy one of their products at anything above bargain bin price, but like the siren song of Chaos I've fallen for Creative Assembly's wiles again and shelled out for my release week copy. Well, surprise surprise. I'm disappointed.  On the plus side, CA does seem to be learning from their mistakes. After the hot mess that was Rome II's release the team reigned in their ambitions and settled on a smaller, tighter experience. Siege attacks focus on a single wall 'segment', most unit armor and weapon upgrades have been jettisoned, and diplomacy has been whittled down to its barest essentials just to name a few areas they've put the screws to.  That's not to say there aren't real improvements here. A lot of the changes seem designed to shake up the samey game of 'smash your armored infantry blob into the enemy's face until their morale breaks' so many TW fights fall into. Magic has been added giving generals more offensive heft and lending more nuance to heroic abilities beyond simply spamming your buff buttons the second they recharge. Under the hood physics tweaks have drastically improved cavalry as well. Instead of stopping the moment they so much as tap an enemy horses will now plow into formations, or if the target is unfortunate enough to be loosely packed carve straight through them. Finally agents have been overhauled and can now fight in combat alongside your armies as little mini generals. I feel like CA really hit the mark on this one. They're strong and versatile enough to justify their presence in an army but not so overpowered that you would necessarily choose them over a good combat unit.  The problem is that even all that polish isn't enough to distract me from the essential truth. This is just another Total War game, with all the same issues that have plagued previous installments. Attempts to balance TW's old bugaboo of siege battles did make things more fair, but only barely and at the cost of some of the game's coolest looking set pieces. The AI is back to its old antics, attacking when it has no chance of winning and meandering around when it could. The endgame is similarly uneven. Depending where you are on the map the chaos invasion can be an existential threat or a positive benefit. I've had games where I was gearing up for the final epic confrontation only to find that the Imperials had already killed the chaos anti-christ and were well on their way to building tailoring workshops in hell. I mean it's nice to see that my allies had their ♥♥♥♥ together, but I was under the impression my attention was urgently required.  So all in all? It's progress. CA at least seem to be aware of the series' flaws and taken steps to fix them, even if it was a sort of stumbling half shuffle. If you're new to the Total War series and are looking for something to cut your teeth on Warhammer is a fine enough place to start. Likewise if you're a veteran TW player interested in the warhammer universe the borrowed concepts give a fresh enough buff to keep you interested for at least a playthrough or two. No doubt more DLC is already on the way, and in time Warhammer might be a truly worthwhile addition to the series, but I fear all that will be too little, too late.

Total War: Warhammer  What a game! I just finished winning the Empire Campaign and I have to say this was quite the experience.   PROS:   Graphics are amazing! Unit diversity is really cool for a TW game. The heroes are fun and also makes it quite frustrating when you lose one because there's a huge time investment there. The Lords are similar as above but can totally change the tide of a combat. The action was fast paced for this type of game. I was being attacked in four different directions all over the map. I had no bugs in my entire playthrough. The music was a good compliment to the action. The items on your heroes are very unique and can turn the tide of a battle. It's definitely worth doing the item quests. The battles are really fun and have a lot of great tactics and detail, but by turn 150+ you will mostly auto-resolve.  CONS:  It's VERY hard to get more than 5-6 large armies. The mechanics of the game are limiting in that way, which makes it hard to defend against the Chaos from up North West, North, and North East and the Greenskins and Vampire Counts from the South. I had almost every settlement maxed out to give me gold and it was still hard fielding 6 armies. The long campagin win is longggggggggggggggg. The tech trees make it very difficult to make everything in one province. It would be nice if some of the smaller cities could go up to Level 4 at least--especially in Reiksland.  Summary:  If you like Total War, this is a great game for you. If you like Warhammer, this is a great game for you. I've played both series since Shadow of the Horned Rat came out, and the original TW. This one will be installed for many many years to come.

I've been waiting for this game since a small announcment some years ago that Creative Assembly had got the licence to make a Warhammer Fantasy RTS.  I was not disappointed.   Each race has a different playstyle, although they are all similar enough to be playable without relearning the game each time.  My only slight gripe is the battle AI: As long as it is out of missile range, it WILL just sit there and wiggle its fingers at you, unless you are playing a quest battle where it has been pre-programmed to attack you. The instant you move into missile range, your army gets bum-rushed. I always bring Artillery to assist the AI's decision making here.  My favourite feature, out of all of them, and including flying units, is the ability to individually name units. It allows anything from creating a regiment that your troops belong to, to giving an individual name to a monster or single unit. In one campaign, I named my steam tanks individually.

Pure garbage and a bore. Warcraft III custom games were designed by amateurs who had no idea how to engage the player. Any game banking on its 'team aspects' is bound to be mediocre. Warcraft III is a vastly superior team game that allows for a greater level of flexibility and leeway for individial players. The result is that good players dictate the matchup in ways that is impossible in dotA and mediocre players are still engaged without being discouraged. Fixation on exacting teamplay to the minutest detail is NOT indicative of a good team-game. Looking through the negative 'reviews' attests to exactly what this leads to: A ♥♥♥♥-poor community. DotA does away the RTS skillset and variation of Warcraft III while maintaing the RTS interface. It does not compensate its deficiencies by offering something new in return. Rather it fixates on the most mundane of systems: hero builds and exacting teamplay, and in addition a contradictory ruleset.  -5/10

Clicker Heroes is a great game where you hire and train heroes to fight monsters and advance to higher levels. Enjoy the strangely satisfying feeling as you click your opponents into oblivion. Or have your heroes do that work for you.  The game allows both active and idle play styles, with various upgrade and skill mechanics in place. And once things start slowing down, you can trigger an ascension to restart from level 1 with the various bonuses you have gathered to carry over.  To summarize: train heroes, kill monsters, gather gold, and then rinse and repeat. Pop in the occasional ascension/ancient/mercenary to speed things up.  Overall, Clicker Heroes is a great timewaster for both casual and hardcore players alike.

Originally posted on a different game by mistake (Note to self: Don't post reviews while extremely tired.)  Pegs my four-core 3 GHz system, runs at 3-15 FPS with GTX 780 @ 1920x1200, looks a few years old. Vast barren landscapes with equally spaced 'facilities' that have functional-sounding names but do nothing. Weapon and tech descriptions dry to make everything sound advanced and powerful...even the starter gear that's rubbish.  Beginner sniper scope and first upgrade provide no noticeable zoom compared to bare naked Mk I Eyeball; I can see farther by angling the game camera so that what I want to zoom in on is at the edge of my screen than I can by looking directly at it with or without scope. By the time you're close enough that your vision isn't obscured by the distance fog and your shots have a statistically significant chance of hitting, you're in plain site to enemies--and at such low framerates, that's your life expectancy.  You spend most of the time waiting to respawn, or else deliberately seeking the areas with the fewest combatants so you have a chance of jumping some other poor schmuck who's wandering between stations.   Battles are furious...and meaningless, because whatever you lose one hour you'll probably hold again another hour. There's no benefit to capturing a whole continent aside from a notice that your faction of the moment took it; seemed like the game would just reset ownership to random after a while to keep the 'infinite war' going.

I have been playing Chiv on and off from free weekends since the game came out in 2012. I've owned the game for about a year now after picking it up from a sale when it was like $2 so I've gotten the chance to play with essentially every combination of class, weapon, and map. When the game first came out it was a ton of fun; easy to play, but hard to master.   Unfortunately, the game play has devolved from having correctly time strikes into people cranking their sensitivity all the way up, spamming a combo button and throwing their mouse around while jumping and crouching. This wouldn't be a huge if Torn Banner Studios wasn't a smaller developer. The animations are not very well done which makes the cheesy way people play almost impossible to fight against as a player will attack behind themselves while their character, and more importantly, weapon face an entirely different direction. Most of the time when someone complains about it in-game they complain of lag, but it isn't. It's poor animations being exploited by an exploited combat system.  Additionally, when I first started playing the game the weapon stats listed in-game actually meant something and now those little bar graphs seem to be meaningless. Do you like playing first-person precision fighting games where every enemy no matter what weapon they're using or you're using (regardless of whether you block, parry, or stun-block them with a kick) can attack you faster? Then this game is for you! Seriously though, it seems like the only way to kill anyone is the gang up on them which is another thing I see people griping on in reviews. Plus, it is super apparent the maps were not fully tested as just about every piece of collideable environment will get your player character trapped and killed because the skeletal mesh can't walk over a pebble on the ground.  All in all the game is still really fun, it looks cool, and it's one of the few good options in an under saturated market. All this being said, you should definitely not pay for full price and the DLC is ludicrous. However, it is definitely worth a dollar or two during big steam sales.

Originally, I would not have recommended this game to anyone. When it had launched, the first twenty-four hours the game was practically unplayable for me due to constant screen tearing, flickering, and crashing. I had decided to put the game to the side for a day or so until I figured a fix or something would be out.  Making the decision to put the game down for a bit was a great idea. I say this since the game did a total 180 in quality within those hours. The game went from completely unplayable to a very smooth and enjoyable experience. I'm not sure if a majority of people are having the same experience as me now, but if they are then the game is totally worth it.  At first, I was worried that I had completely wasted my money on this, the same feeling of being burnt when ROME 2 had launched a few years back. While frustrated with the terrible launch, I decided to play other games for a while until a fix was released. Once I had seen that the fix was released and some more time had gone by, I finally got to play and ENJOY Total War: Warhammer and look forward to what the future holds with this game.

It's a bad game, and it was destined to be a bad game from the moment the idea for it was conceived. This game revolves around the statement, 'glitches are funny.' But why? Because we don't expect them; because they're random; because they're rare; because they're ridiculous in a game that attemps to act serious. Goat Simulator throws all these crucial factors away. It doesn't take itself seriously; the glitches aren't random; the glitches aren't rare (they're the main feature of the game!); and we expect them. Everything that makes a glitch funny is thrown out the window in GS.  When's the last time that you laughed hysterically when you got a new quest in The Witcher 3? Never? My point. You're supposed to get quests. It's normal, and it really isn't all that funny of an event. The same is true for glitches in GS.
This is the future. We're doomed.

With the 130 hours in mind, I can safely say this game is absolutely amazing. Far Cry 3 was a major development from the first 2 games, and has become without question, my most favourite game of all time. Far Cry 3 explores various themes, and carries quite an incredible storyline that is deceptively dark and powerful, even if the initial plot is very simple. I've played through Far Cry 3 at least 4 times, on every difficulty and tried different endings and choices. The first time I finished the game was by far, the most moving ending I've experienced in any game. It has great replayability, even after finishing Far Cry 4 I come back to this for the memories and unique gameplay. With amazing graphics, a gripping storyline, and such realistic gameplay, I still recommend Far Cry 3 today. I will never forget my time with Far Cry 3, it was the best experience I've ever had the pleasure to be part in. The map editor probably kept me entertained for months, and while I never played much co-op, what I did play was pretty fun. I personally prefer Far Cry 3 over 4, as it just feels more magical and special. I only hope that Far Cry 5 will return to the brutal and beautiful atmosphere that Far Cry 3 had, without completely redoing it (cough cough Far Cry 4).  So yes, Far Cry 3 is still worth every cent (and probably more to be honest). It still remains my most favourite game ever, and will for a very long time. Don't hold back on getting it, It's an unforgettable journey.

HOW TO: Survive your first night: No need to use any power cunsuming items until 2 AM, keep the phone guy talking until then, check the cameras after about a minute or so after the phone guy hangs up, keep checking on Bonnie in the WEST HALL, once he gets to the corner, close the left door. Wait until the camera shows that Bonnie has left the West hall corner and hall itself and make sure he is in the dining room before you open the left door. During that time, Chica will be in the East hall, keep alternatingly check on him and Bonnie until Chica moves to the East Hall Corner, and keep the door closed the rest of the night. Once Bonnie comes back for round 2 in the West Hall, close once he is in the corner, or you flash the light and he is there, keep checking on Bonnie, you will have little power left at this point, so conserve it, [(OPTIONAL) wait until he is at the end of the West Hall then open that door.] you can keep both doors closed and survive to Night 2. There is your way to survive the first night.

I wasn't prepared for was how much of an utter disappoint this game was. In my opinion the HUD and terrible plot are MORE than enough to ruin the game, and it baffles me that anyone could even get past these two obstacles to even enjoy the game-play. Thankfully, I had installed a couple of mods to improve game-play (more accurate weapons and improved selection) and remove the HUD completely (the official patch didn't go anywhere near far enough in this regard), so the game I am scoring here is not the game I've been playing for the last three weeks, it's the game I would have been forced to play without the mods.  Seriously, who needs that amount of information flashing and bobbing around on their screen to tell them the SAME thing at least three times? The HUD elements, even with all the customisable ones turned off, turn a potentially enjoyable challenge into a ridiculously easy arcade game, where neither thought, exploration or initiative are required. Objectives tell you to 'find' this or 'locate' that, and yet the whereabouts of every objective, no, every STAGE of every objective, is indicated in three different places, two of which are on your HUD (not including what you can actually see with your eyes!). The AI of the enemies is fantastic, amongst the best I've encountered, but the poor sods don't stand a chance because they're splashed all over your mini-map and appear clearly, even behind objects, with big red icons over their heads.  And then there's the plot and characters. Unfortunately, no one's come up with a mod to make the plot or characters any more interesting, and no amount of HUD removal or weapon modding is going to help me give a damn about any of the characters and what's happening to them. Even your own, annoyingly vocal, character, Jason, is a hateful adolescent (not in years, but in behaviour), and his friends are all stereotyped air-heads with no substance.  I get the feeling there is more to the story than it first appears, and there's some kind of 'Alice in Wonderland' sub-plot going on (I've avoided plot spoilers), and that maybe there will be some kind of Fight Club-style reveal where it turns out Jason is actually Vaas, and vice-versa. But you know what? I just don't care any more. I'm about 8 hours into the game and have deliberately avoided following the story, not only because it's weak and the characters are hateful, but also because it means I'm likely to have to sit through endless boring cut-scenes, or stupid, arcade-style mini-games, or encounter the nemesis of any immersion junkie like myself, the dreaded quick-time event (seriously who actually LIKES quick-time events? Who buys a game and says to themselves, 'oh wow, I hope this game has LOTS of quick-time events). Why can't developers just let us PLAY the game, instead of constantly forcing our actions, or taking away our control all together. Valve and other progressive developers have proved time and again that you can have both a great game and a great immersive experience without compromising your in-game freedom, so why is there still this obsession with trying to turn games into movies?  It's a damn shame, because there are loads of things to love about FarCry 3; the hunting, the expanse of the island, the superb AI, the weapons, the beautiful graphics, the best motion-capture acting in a game (Vaas), but all of that can only last me so long, and I just don't want to be in the shoes of this character any more. I'd rather put Jason's friends out of their misery and explore the island.  With mods, such as the removal of the HUD and the improved weapon selection, I'd give the game a 6 out of 10. A better story would have probably meant an 8 or 9. But the vanilla game deserves nothing more than a 1, because developers need to realise that you just can't treat your audience like imbeciles.

Just played the game for an hour... And i've watched about 12 hours of content online leading up to launch. I do not enjoy the game enough to keep playing, it really has done a poor job of gripping my attention for very long:  over-hyped. features that have been discussed simply aren't there (for example - personalising hero's talked about in their livestream) game is overpriced... Doom has just came out for the same price by bethesda - so basically your best of buying doom over this. I could go on but it's better to summarise the points.  To start off with the good points: -The game has a great theme and brand 'warhammer'  -The Menu is good quallity and most the UI looks very clean -The game offers a wide array of combat tools, such as formations. -Lords/hero system is very unquie, skill tree's for commanders add an intresting mechanic to combat -Very easy to understand once you've got a hang of the system.  As for the bad points, this game has a tone of issuies: -This is a re-hash of rome 2's launch- buggy intro scenes, weird AI behavior (you're investing in an alpha game here.) -Completely overpriced for the brand (Games Workshop are doing this alot atm.) -Depdent on internet connection even in single player (for wiki information.) -Combat is really repeatitive after 3 battles that's it and auto-resolve might as well be auto suicide so you have to put up with each battle if you want good results.  -Preorder for OP Race, that's not at all fun to play. -Horrible tutorial, personally i learnt how to make a squad (then used wiki to learn the rest of the feautres)  -Not enough units for launch. DOW 1 had more units reffering back to year 2000 games. -Graphics are not all that great even on ultra.  -The UI is much 'clankier' then most total war games. -Disengaged from story after about 10 minutes. Not very immersive at all -Takes too much time to get into the game

I'll keep it short and sweet.  Spend your money on something else.

'Planet-FappingforFounders-side 2.'  A pay-to-win with good solid gameplay and a healthy player-base, Planetside2 doesn't bring out the best in players who have actual skill, though if you're exceptional at FPS's this game will be quite enjoyable.  I'll lay out one 'Pro' and one 'Con' to give you an idea of its potential and short-comings.  Pro; The massive player-base allows for A LOT of actual tacticality. Both large-scale and small-time.  Con; Players whom have more money than skill will become VERY obvious, as the 'better' guns are exceedingly difficult (but not impossible) to attain in this game with consistent gameplay. 'Cash-cannnons' in the early levels give significant firepower/advantages over players who jump into this looking fer a good gunfight.  VERY skill-based game. VERY team oriented. If you don't care for the Call of duty or Battlefield franchises, but still want a decent FPS, you MIGHT find it here. I'd strongly recommend looking into other options first. (Such as the semi-decent Warframe, or a good console shooter like Army of Two or Gears of War).  1-to-5 Rating: 2 (Possible 3). (A well earned $40). If you're broke like myself, but just want to play a good FPS with relevant strategizing, this is for you. I don't recommend buying the guns in this game. AT ALL. It will kill the gameplay and competitive nature of this broad-scale FPS. The asthetic options however, are sometimes PLAYER-MADE!! VERY, VERY, good, material!! From Camouflage to player-armor visuals to semi-custom Decals, there's something there for you!!  =Edit= Post-700 Game-Hours Review: Just, don't play this unless you REALLY can't play anything else. Why this game made it into the 2k15 Top 50 FPS's, I don't know. With Daybreak Games (Nova Columbus) now in possession of this unbalanced sack of trash, it's been all downhill. New weapons that are too extreme are being put out. Nothing is getting properly balanced. Server stability is mediocre at best. If you must play this game, bring a superior computer and a superior connection on you'll be getting butchered left-and-right with no help from the dozens of people around you. If you're new, start as TR so you get the best sense of community and inter-play possible. I can no longer Recommend this game. Due in particular to the newer weapons, the ever-growing ranks of hateful try-hards, and the balancing ( that's never been there anyway, so oh well).

A fantastically epic and engaging adventure.   Be at one with the jungle and take your foe down like a shadow using diversions and stealth, using only your knife and bow.  Why not invite a bear, tiger or a pack of wild dogs to do your dirty work and thin out the herd a little before you make your entrance.  Or simply paraglide above the enemy encampment jump off and wing suit yourself to the roof of a building, From where you can demolish your enemies with exploding arrows, Molotov’s, grenades and a heavy machinegun, while simultaneously detonating the C4 you attached to the enemy vehicles around the camp. However you want to do it, do it.   The game looks divine, the story is captivating, play to your skills using the extensive upgrade tree, the weapons are plentiful and great while the customisation allows you to further perfect your style, the side missions and crafting is fun and forces you to explore this exceptionally well crafted environment. Buy this game.

Early Access Review

Good luck getting anywhere without buying equipment first. As a big fan of First Person Shooters who easily gets 1.5 K.D. in COD, Battlefield, and all other FPS games I've played, I am at a solid .2 K.D. in this game. With the amount of time it takes to even buy a half decent gun, you've already died several hundred times.  Even as a Free-To-Play game, at least make the first couple guns stand a chance in combat. With the lack of instructions as well as a terrible tutorial, I found myself wandering around the huge map for hours with no clue how the whole air, vehicle, and infantry resources system worked along with other crucial information. Believing I would be spending hard earned credits that have taken several hours to achieve, I didn't want to spend any on any sort of vehicle.  Nothing was pointed out about this because the beginning tutorial didn't work at all. It would say to shoot the target dummies and kill 3, however you would shoot at them and the bullets would go right through them with no way of killing them. It eventually let me go through without being able to kill even one. Then the anti-vehicle lesson was next. Where at least in the last room the texture showed up but couldn't be killed, the tanks didn't even show up at the lesson. Making it impossible to continue through the tutorial. Exiting the game and then logging back in, I found myself having to start back at the beginning of the tutorial where the same problems occurred several times.   Air vehicle controls are awful. It's impossible to take down any sort of tank without firing FIVE rockets into them. There is no control manual readily available in-game(or convenient to find if there is one). The game promotes spawn camping as you are stuck in a tiny room when you spawn in a base that's being attacked. Incorrect times shown on overloaded generators while attacking/defending a big base(Mini map is the correct time, normally the time on the generator itself is 25+ seconds off. The sensitivity widely varies on what vehicles gun you're using and not being universal and fluent through-out all the vehicles weapons. Many more small frustrating flaws that can be found easily after a few hours of playing.  Overall, there are better uses of time and money that could be spent on games that feel more rewarding and don't leave you leave you yelling at your monitor pulling your hair out.

I should quantify everything that follows by first saying I was a HUGE fan of Planetside 1 (yeah...I have my CR5 VS Rexo as my profile picture on Steam).  I've just not been able to get in to PS2 at all however. The primary reason for this would likely be because it plays nothing like the first game - it retains the same kind of scope, but for the most part the core mechanics are completely different.   I realise now I was hoping for a graphically-updated clone of PS1, and while I accept that wouldn't exactly constitute 'progress', I'm not convinced that the design decisions made here push the game on in any great leaps and bounds. As an example, it's worth comparing the inventory or loadout system of the two games. In PS1, players built their own loadouts from the ground up with overall carrying capacity dictated by the type of armour worn. The weapons and equipment available were restricted by the branches of the various combat disciplines that had been unlocked - using points gained by levelling one's character. This approach allowed for HUGE variation between loadouts for individual characters and meant that genuine mulit-tasking was possible. By contrast, PS2 has a much more rigid and defined class system which will be more familiar to players of 'traditional' shooters and is arguably less daunting to get to grips with - if ultimately more generic and unsatisfying.  Less tangible - but equally off-putting, for me at least - is the feel of the battles. PS1 often had very clearly defined battle lines and it was possible to sense and react to the ebb and flow of battle. I don't get this in PS2 at all. Large outdoor fights give the impression of many self-contained deathmatches all going on at once and seem utterly disorganised. Is this a result of the pacing of the game? Possibly. I believe the TTK may be generally lower than it was in the original and this coupled with the faster character movement undeniably makes the game a very diffeerent proposition to the first.  I'm quite sure than in its own right, the fare on offer is enjoyable to many - just don't expect anything like the slow(ish) pace of the first game and the almost 'trench warfare' scenarios that could develop.  Overall, I really wanted to like this game but the sad truth for me is that it's lost too much of what made the original so special.  4/10  ProdigalSon (Emerald)

Having played all the Total War games, I can safely say that, for me, this is the worst Total War game of all time. I'll admit that I am biased against non-historical titles, but I will make sure to focus this review only on the gameplay problems which I encountered.  In terms of battle experience, the battles happen extremely quickly, far too quickly for my liking. This means that the result of a battle is largely decided by unit volume and stats rather than by tactical maneuvers. The hero and general units make battles even worse. On one occasion, I had won a tactical victory, routing a superior enemy army. However, the enemy general, the only remaining enemy, defeated all of my remaining units, even when they were attacking him from all sides.  I found the campaign map to be too limited, with few expansion patterns available to the player. This is made even worse by the feature which prevents certain factions from capturing either cities or holds. Also, the lack of navies really limits the gameplay style options.  The rosters of many factions seem to be distinguished by the lack of a crucial unit type, which means most of your campaign strategy revolves around compensating for tactical inflexibilities. The dwarves lack cavalry, the vampires lack missile units. This really limits what army types you can field, meaning that building armies is largely about volume rather than quality.  Another thing to mention is the new seige mechanics, which further reduce the tactical options by forcing the player to deploy at the city walls and charge immediately, due to the arrow towers. The town battles have also been removed, for no apparent reason, reducing tactial variety even further.  To sum up this game - it is severely lacking in variety and flexibility, both in a strategic and tactical sense. It is a betrayal of the core fanbase of Total War, who were drawn to the title for the unrivaled tactical flexibility which the battles offered.

At one point in time I would have recommended this game, but it has seemingly been abandonded by the dev team. The last update it recieved was some killing floor 2 skins, the most recent actual content if I recall has been over a year ago. The skill in this game is abusing a very, very bad physics system. The better you get at this game, the more you'll be crouched and spinning with a massive sword. It's great to play once in a while for some cheap fun, and this often goes on sale for ~5 dollars (USD) One of the other biggest problems with the game is the player base. It's not toxic or anything but there are two types of C:MW players. One guy has played 100+ hours and plays a lot, the other got the game on sale for 5 bucks and sucks really bad. Theres not really an inbetween and this causes a massive skill gap that is both annoying for veterens because they have little challenge, and for new players becuase they get obliterated.  If the developer ever adds more content, it would still be a fantastic game other complaints aside.   Pros: Very satisfying to get kills in Wonderful looking Runs pretty smoothly Fall to your death server is super fun  Cons Terrible physics Hit boxes are pretty wonky at times Not updated Some weapons have literally no use and is a completely trash (i.e sling) Some weapons preform so well, even other weapons in the same tier aren't worth using because it's signifigantly better (i.e maul, norse sword)  Overall, in the current state I wouldn't buy/play it, but IF updated and more people played would be fantastic.

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: This game is one of the all time greats. 10/10. It is kind of buggy, but not as buggy as the PS3 version, which I played all the way through (including all of the DLC) a few years back, despite freeze-ups every couple of hours or so.

I played PS1 for many years, and safe to say that even after 4 years, PS2 is still an unrefined piece of hot garbage. The influence from modern FPS is pretty clear given the faster pace, but this results in frustratingly short rounds and plenty of instant death.  It's better with a squad, but even then you're just trying to cover up flawed game mechanics with the social environment of a unit. PS1 felt like something unique. PS2 feels like Battlefield with more waiting involved before you get to shoot something. On the off chance you do get to shoot something, it's usually zerg time by then, and you're in a 100v100 messy zergfest that will send your FPS tanking thanks to ♥♥♥♥ poor optimization after FOUR YEARS of refinement.  If you want a superior FPS experience, there are better ones out right now. If you want a superior Free To Play game, there are better ones out right now. I'm kind of amazed that after four years this game still runs and plays like garbage even on modern rigs. I SHOULDN'T HAVE TO READ A YOUTUBE GUIDE ON TWEAKING AN .INI FILE IN ORDER TO GET THE GAME TO GIVE ME 30-40 FPS MOST OF THE TIME.  Edit (updated): Did I mention shallow?  Hoo boy. PS1 had strategy you know, not just tactics. And if you know the difference between those two things, then you'll understand that strategy in PS2 is nigh impossible. All conts (all four of them, of which usually only 2 are unlocked at a time oh lawd) are always in a perpetual 3 way, meaning unless one empire is getting gang-banged, it's basically a stalemate. Due to how easy it is to pull Galaxies from Warpgates, and most importantly how easy it is to REDEPLOY, you can re-mobilize a force from one base and shuttle them across the entire continent in under a minute. Considering the cap times on bases, it results in making it painfully hard to take territory without an army showing up within 60 seconds of the base starting to cap.  We're supposed to be trying to win these 'Alerts' with 'Victory Points' but I've never seen people playing who actively pursue VPs. Everyone's busy grinding Achivements ('Directives') for their various weapons, or kill farming an AMS (Sunderers now, guess that's one way to get people to drive that piece of ♥♥♥♥) somewhere to pad their oh-so-important stats.  Things that should be baseline (AMS Cloak, medpack) are locked behind hundreds or even thousands of certs. Arguably it's balanced because you can pull a default version of everything (Air Cav / Tanks without needing cert) but go figure since you can cert into actual performance upgrades for these things, you will be at a disadvantage against someone who has adorable little things like side armor when you don't.  Good luck. The game was and is a mad cash grab. The pace is manic compared to PS1, and strategy is nonexistent. If you enjoy imaginary treadmills where you farm 1000 kills with 3-4 versions of the same gun and listen to neckbeards argue on coms which version is the best while whittling away your hours in this garbage, be my guest.  It's a time waster at best.
Crashes on startup where it displays the controls. It's been doing this for months and there is no sign of a fix. My system requirements meet the specs so there shouldn't be an issue.

11/10  In the beginning there was just being...  As just being wasn't enough, certain needs arose; food, water, sex, and sleep took priority. WIth those things accomplished, security and safety took precedent. Family, friendship and societal needs soon followed. This lead to self-esteem and confidence. With all of these handled, there was time for problem solving and self actualization. Rising above this entire hierachy of needs came the click.  The entire evolutionary process our species led to the developement of Clicker Heroes.  With Clicker Heroes now a part of my life, I have no need to self actualize nor solve problems, just click.  What need do I have of confidence or self-esteem, just click?  Society, family, friends...psssh, just click.  Safety and security...useless, just click.  Sleep and sex are long gone, but I have a foggy awareness that I miss these things, nevermind...just click.  I have the feeling those other beings around me are taking longer and longer stretches of time before placing food before me and dabbing water on my parched lips, matters not, just click.  Soon, blessedly, there will be only click.  Our entire de-evolutionary process will be blamed on Clicker Heroes.

The game is okay, with a relatively large world, plenty to do, and scenery to appreciate. The main story is your basic Far Cry story: you were vacationing, now you've been forcibly transformed into a killing machine. You level up by tattooing yourself, with 'perks' (gaining new abilities like takedowns and being able to cook grenades, and passive abilities like more health and better healing) and you can level through doing practically anything. The gameplay is pretty fun, but for the most part enemies are dumb (avoiding cover and running right at you) and pretty easy to kill early-on.   However, it's also a console port, with lots of technical problems associated with it. Even with a GTX 770 (which can run Metro: Last Light on ultra with zero framerate problems) I cannot run this game on ultra. Why? Because it's unoptimized. Especially on some of the more hectic parts of the campaign where there are lots of things happening. Even on LOW, I barely manage to reach a semi-stable 60 FPS. There is a FoV slider and plenty of options to tweak, but they don't really seem to do much of anything. After some testing, this is because I was running the game on DX11. Running the game on DX9 gives me a much better framerate on ultra. Again, it's a console port.   On top of that, you have to deal with Ubisoft's inevitable Uplay nonsense. This program interferes with Steam's own Gameoverlay.exe program, which allows you to talk to your friends. Meaning that when/if you get a message, you have to minimize the game, respond, then re-enter the game and re-maximize it (oh, and it enters windowed mode whenever you minimize. You can quickly go back to fullscreen with alt + enter, though).  Oh, also, a lot of the screenshots in the store page are what you would call 'bullshots.' Pre-rendered lies. The game does look good, but while you're hangliding or wingsuit flying, you'll really notice how painted on a lot of the foliage is when you notice it's flat.

This is a good warhammer fantasy strategy game - because there is only a few that fits this description. And this one is the best. However, this is a terrible Total War game.   Streamlined to the detriment of strategic and tactical value. Family trees gone again, public order/taxes management is gone - you can only either tax or not tax a province. The sieges are a complete disaster - every city/town looks the same, theres only one wall and the braindead AI even with the help of the excellent Radious Mod is just standing there, not participating. Chaos is defeated very easily, I havent even had a chance to fight any of them before they were destroyed. For me as a both TW and Warhammer fan, I cannot bring myself to like any of the four factions - the Vampire Counts are the closest to being ok, but the game becomes boring for me after a few turns anyway. Out of the Legendary Lords, I do not find any of those available even remotely sympathetic - so I just play with the regular lords, who can die thus creating some sort of tension and attachment.   The intersting thing here is the corruption. Either spreading it, or fighting against it. Thats something new.   However, I cannot in good heart recommend this game to either Warhammer fans or Total War fans. Just wait for the next one. It will come out more polished, with more factions, better AI, gameplay, etc. Or pick it up when it goes on sale. Full price? Nope. Dont be an idiot like me :/

I honestly am considering going back to War of the Roses. Even that has combat and movement more believable than this ♥♥♥♥.
