app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: It took a real steamer like Fallout 4 to make me look at this a second time. Is it still full of ideas that run contrary to the spirit of the franchise? Sure. Is it still awfully written? Decidedly. Even then, this is still more ambitious and more successful when it puts in the effort than Fallout 4 is at it's very best.  The ability to make weapons out of junk was great. I do like the attempt to prune down on useless skills from the classic series. There is a real crushing sense of atmosphere, it drives home the point that this is a very mean place that does not like you one bit. Everything about Galaxy News Radio is great.   The main issue I have with the writing is that there are plenty of things in there that feel faithful to the franchise or just taking it to it's foregone conclusion, but very few of those are tied into the main story. That aside they had a interesting area like DC and have nothing really all that visually memorable. Lots of green and grey and brown. The weapons and armor are also horribly imbalanced against themselves.  Anchorage is a linear, dull slog. The Pitt is amazing and showcases what the Bethesda writing team is capable of when they put some effort into it. Broken Steel is garbage. Point Lookout is very challenging, but interesting for it's non-linearity. Zeta is just Anchorage 2.0, this time in SPACE!  Oh, and Oasis never happened.
This game is so ba-a-a-a-ad it's good.
Although i cant play the game on my low budget computer, the PS4 version is coming out soon. Cant wait!

In my honest opinion it is already the best entry in TW series, with expansions it will definitely get even better and compared to Rome II  not many bugs. The AI is better than in previous games, although in diplomacy  it makes weird choises, quite frequently giving you money for no good reason.  Pros -Setting- Warhammer is one of the most diverse and lore rich settings with  unique factions and really great art. -Accuracy- CA mannaged to capture the feel of WH with all the quests, events and faithfulness to WH art design. -Diversity- although there are not that many factions yet every one is a unique play experiance. Battles are very enteretaning with all the monsters, weapons, heros and magic.  Cons To be honest I don't think there are that many major problems with the game. I have only some problems with Chaos Warriors as they (yet again in a wh game) do not  live up to their miniature version. The units are somewhat boring without all the Chaos God  specific versions of them and where is Archaon's epic new mount?:).  I also hope there will be two other Chaos facions, mainly for Chaos Daemons.  I'am very happy with how the game turned out and with the fact that CA went the route of  quality over quantity. Although I now have to impantiently wait for the expansions.:)

“My Grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him, “If you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately.” Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exactly was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- “Don’t ever smoke. Please don’t put your family through what your Grandfather put us through.” I agreed. At 28, I have never touched a cigarette. I must say, I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it, because this game gave me cancer anyway.”

This game was a gem. This game was a must have, with fantastic combat that was deep and engaging. Sure it had bugs, a lot of them, but it's an indie game, if we give them time they'll sort it out, right? Dead ♥♥♥♥ing wrong. If you had asked me when this game first released, I would have told you it was a must have, that it was my favorite game. Now, this is a waste of your time and of your money. This game has become plagued with DLC, sure, they're only skins so it's not a big deal, or it wouldn't be a big deal if Torn Banner actually gave two ♥♥♥♥s about the community. Since they don't, this game is still plagued with bugs, bugs that Torn Banner refuses to fix because they're too busy making DLC. The barbarian skins that were released today are the last ♥♥♥♥ing straw. $8 per skin for a single class, and $2 a pop for the four new weapon skins! To buy all the skins is $40, fourty ♥♥♥♥ing dollars. That's more than the ♥♥♥♥ing game; you would think that with all the DLC TB would release some bug fixes, but no, they don't give half of a sack of ♥♥♥♥ about their fans. There's also no point in even playing this game if you don't know how to drag. People will tell you dragging is a tactic but it isn't, it's just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that eliminates the need of any skill whatsoever. It makes it difficult to block with ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s spinning all over the place, slowing down or speeding up their swings at will. It's pretty common to see an instakill weapon swing coming at you with more speed than a dagger. Does Torn Banner care about this? No, the motehr♥♥♥♥ers actually encourage it and call it a tactic. Not because it is, but because TB is too ♥♥♥♥ing busy wallowing in their piles of money. Don't waste your breath on this game, but Mount & Blade Warband instead.

This title offers engrossing and engaging strategic and tactical gameplay in a high fantasy setting. The rich lore and pregnant storytelling of the Warhammer universe launches the player into a cataclysmic countdown towards Chaos invasions and the End Times, against the backdrop of petty bickering between the nations of mortal men. A grim, fatalistic mood grips us as we become more and more determined to beat back the raving, apocolyptic hordes of the Everchosen. My empire has crumbled and been reduced to ash multiple times but I still keep coming back for more.   I wouldn't pay much attention to the occasional nasty reviews from angry basement-dwellers ... just look at the number of people playing the game at any given time and that should give you a sense of how fun this title really is.

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: Fallout 3, surprisingly, is a game that was actually developed and made by Bethesda, and not a fan made mod. This is surprising because from just playing it, it can be hard to tell at times. I know I'm late to writing this review, but I wanted to remind both myself and anyone who reads this of how Fallout 3 was in case Fallout 4 doesn't seem as good as it looks when it comes out. (It may not look like it with the 90 minutes I have tracked, but I have completed the game twice; once from a retail copy and more recently through New Vegas using the Tale of Two Wastelands mod.)  Fallout 3 is set in the Capital Wasteland, a new location set on the opposite side of the US from the traditional west coasts of Fallout 1, 2, and later New Vegas. By doing this, they allowed themselves to have a clean slate of sorts, and have more creative freedom in writing the story. So naturally, being skilled writers as they are, they just copied a bunch of stuff from the old games and rewrote it to be worse. The Brotherhood of Steel is back, only this time they're a splinter faction that's a bunch of goodie two-shoes that go from shunning you to thanking you for letting them bask in your presence over the course of one quest (the 'real' brotherhood is still technically there in the form of the Outcasts, but they barely have any presence in the game). The Enclave is back for no real reason at all, considering they were pretty much ended in 2. They made up their own east coast brand of super mutant just so they could flood the game with them. Even things like caps don't really make sense, since the only reason caps were used as currency in the west coast games is because they were backed by the Hub. The whole game just feels like they went through a picture book of Fallout and saw cool things and went 'hey that looks cool, let's put it in our game too!' without really thinking that much about why they would actually be there.  Gameplay-wise, the game is a mixed bag. The exploration can be pretty fun, especially with mods like DC Interiors (which opens up a bunch of the boarded up buildings that Bethesda was too lazy to furnish), but the shooting is fairly subpar, and you can tell that the engine wasn't really built for shooting games at that stage of its development. Of course, you can always use VATS if you'd rather watch the game play itself instead, since it's effectively been turned into an easy button that lets you have 5 turns to blow an enemy to pieces and then gives the enemy one. The whole stat system is a joke, and between the rate you get perks, the perks added by DLCs, and the bobbleheads scattered throughout the world, it's almost impossible to not end up with 10 in every SPECIAL stat and 100 in every skill by the time you finish the game.   Because it's basically impossible to specialize in any particular ability due to inevitably having to specialize in all of them, and the fact that the game doesn't really give you any major choices that have actual consequences, it can be difficult to feel like you're actually roleplaying in Fallout 3. But that's fine, because it's pretty much impossible with the dialogue anyways. The dialogue options are, as best as I can describe them, schizophrenically written. You can blow up an entire settlement and laugh it off, then five minutes later meet a group of people you believe to be cannibals and have no dialogue option to say anything other than something negative towards them. At one point early in the game you meet a ghoul bartender, and your only options are two choices of mocking him and the last option, 'Let me think about it for a moment, my good man.', which is so cringey that I can only assume that if Bethesda's animators had any talent it would be accompanied by an animation of the player character tipping an imaginary top hat and taking a puff from a wooden pipe. Most of the intelligence choices are just repeating what someone just said to you back to them in a summarized form written in an overly wordy way, and a lot of the speech checks go beyond ridiculousness in terms of convincing people or things to do things they would never realistically do in a single sentence. The game has a karma system, but I don't know if it's even possible to keep a negative karma level because of how much of it you get dumped onto you just for things like killing ghouls or raiders (which are impossible to allign with because Fallout 3 has no faction system), but it doesn't really matter because it's not even that much fun to play evil. There are no real meaningful evil choices, just a bunch of 'for the laughs' things. There are one or two noteworthy evil moments and then the rest of it is just 'ahaha i shoot you in the face' options in dialogue that just aren't really fulfilling, and some of them are just plain nonsensical and make no sense for the player to do, like the one at the end of the Broken Steel DLC. The game also has two factions that hunt you down depending on whether your karma is too high or low, but while the evil karma version is a group of lawbringers who are hunting you down because you're a known criminal, the good varient just gets Talon Company, a mercenary unit that Bethesda just made up and gave no backstory aside from 'they're bad guys and so they want to kill good guys because they're really bad people!' and set them loose on you.  The DLC is about what you would expect so far. Operation Anchorage is essentially just a 3 hour crappy military corridor FPS with a few good rewards, Mothership Zeta is a crappy space corridor shooter with a few good rewards, and Broken Steel is only worth playing because of the fact that it basically forces you to after the end of the base game. The Pitt and Point Lookout are basically the only ones that I would consider 'good', with the former being a brief but interesting quest line and a relatively fun collectathon with some good rewards and the latter being the only dlc to give a more open experience in a new map with new side quests and things to explore. If it wasn't for the fact that the GOTY edition costs the same as buying regular fallout 3 + point lookout + the pitt I'd just tell you to buy those, but oh well.  Fallout 3 is what I would consider a 'popcorn RPG'. It's the kind of game where you can spend 100 hours just exploring the wasteland and looting buildings and doing side quests and then remember that there's a boring main storyline for you to do, but it's not a game where you have to make choices or develop a character or anything associated with more in-depth RPGs, and while to an extent I feel that way about all of Bethesda's post-Morrowind RPGs, Fallout 3 in particular exemplifies the concept. If you're new to the Fallout series you may love it, or if you've played them all you can probably still just forget that it's a Fallout game and have fun exploring, but it's both a terrible RPG and a terrible Fallout game. It's extremely unstable on its own, so either modding it to high heaven or playing it through New Vegas in the A Tale of Two Wastelands mod (which requires both games and all of their DLC) is basically required. If you have time to kill and just want to relax in the wasteland for a little while, there's no reason not to buy Fallout 3 if it's on sale and you've got nothing else to play, but there just isn't anything exceptional that would prompt me to actively recommend the game. Hopefully Bethesda will have learned from New Vegas when we get to play Fallout 4.

I was at first excited to play this game, I had seen videos on youtube and thought it would be fun. Well, its not. Overall: 2/10  Pros first (short list): -Fair Graphics for no visual lag. -Fairly easy controls for all that you can do. -Tons of servers to play on.  Cons (long list): -The games physics as relates to bows is a joke, base-line bows of the time had much better distance and travel time on arrows. -Lengths of weapons are not properly simulated, Classes with the heaviest armor seem to be the weakest (Note on history: anyone in that time period who wore that level of armor was raised to be a soldier from a really young age, they could realitively easily scale walls in full body armor and their weapons, this game fails to simulate that.) -Mapping as for running and slashing is fine, but the Archer class is highly ignored in the designs with a massive lack of elevated areas to shoot from, as was the case in history in defence situations with Archers using walls, towers and rooftops. -Armor ranking seems to mean next to nothing between the classes. -While friendly damage is expected, the penalties for it I found rather stupid given archers always end up hitting friendlies (been on both ends of the bow.) -Team killing/wounding is a common and idiotic happening in this game and commonly makes for failed team matches. Specially when 80% of your teams on FFA right outside the spawn.  There is a much longer list of things I found that makes this game undesirable to play, but I dont feel like its worth the time writing that much out.   In short: If you know anything about history and/or have held/used the real weapons, dont play this game. If you just love seeing tons of gore and blood and dont really care at all about a game being based on a historical time period being inaccurate as heck, then I would suggest this is a game for you.

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: 'Low Violence: German low violence version only available with German language' Beware if you see that line!! It means you will never be able to change to the normal version of the game nor play it in any other language than german. You will have to play a cut, low gore version, which seems to have more bugs. There are thousands of mods improving the game, but this version is incompatible with almost all of them. The script extender (FOSE) does not work with this version (Dec. 2013). After spending days, the only mods I was able to install is Marts Mutants und some texture improvements and lighting mods... A waste of my money. I wish I had only bought New Vegas.

This is the single worst game I have ever played. The developers of this game should be ashamed that they force ANYBODY to pay any money at all for this all around awful game. I purchased this game at full price, becaus I thought that at the very least, it would be funny for a couple days, but no. The novelty of this game wears off after about 2 minutes of gameplay, at which time you slowly begin to realize how much this game has bent you over and screwed you. Having played for 2 hours I think I can easly say this is an amazing game.   Chivalry is one of a few, there are not many games that offer such gameplay.  I could go on and on about how much I love it but i'll just make a pros and cons list instead..  PROS:  Great combat, very fluid, and responsive. Graphics are pretty damn nice. ♥♥♥♥ single player, unlike some games where the only fun part is the multiplayer Chivalry doesn't worry about even trying to make a single player that sucks, instead they focus on the multiplayer c:   Now the important part is the cons list...   CONS! The Pros, by pros I mean people who play this game a lot... It's brutal when you fight someone with 800 hours... pros also act like ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, I accidently hit the guy with my sword (and it's hard NOT TO hit someone when your in a tight pack) so he decides to kill everyone around him on his team because he didn't know who did it.   Team Killing It's hard not to hit someone when you have a giant sword and you're trying to not die, the community is also very unforgiving, I saw someone covered in blood and I thought they had red on them so I killed them, turns out it was a teammate, I said sorry and he then stalked me around the map and killed me every time he could.  Thats about all I can think of for a CONS list.  Bottom line is the community is very unforgiving but this game is so worth it! I got it for 3 dollars (someone sold it on outpost for 1.5 keys)  I play with a controller because I feel besides for aiming the keyboard and mouse set up are a bit weird.

Played through a couple of hours of Vampire and Chaos campaign and I must say it's one of the best Total War games so far... unless you are a hardcore micro-management fan and you actually enjoyed the tedious combat of the previous TW games. For Warhammer TW they really simplified combat, it actually feels nice how the troups take commands and the power levels for units are a nice touch, it makes sense that a huge demon centaur to wipe out squads of foot troops or that a Vampire lord to be able to heal and single handly kill 2000 troops (true story). The game runs at 60 fps even during huge battles of 5000+ units, if you have performance issues make sure to update Nvidia Drivers as this game was developed for AMD and Nvidia released a quick fix (I'm talking out of my ♥♥♥♥ but after the newest patch for Nvidia today the game runs smoother).

I'm still in the very first real area of the game (area covered by the first radio tower). The game has crashed 3 times. There are lengthy cut scenes at the beginning of the game that cannot be skipped through as well, making recovery from the game crashing extremely tedious. The interface to select weapons, loot creatures on the ground, and view objectives is poor. The very first fight of the game (running away into the jungle and struggling with the pirate with a knife) requires mashing the jump button. 'Mashing' is a ridiculous action to perform on a PC, and undesirable to do on any platform outside of a video arcade. This game has potential (open world, interesting crafting system, and good voice acting), but the execution of the gameplay and stability is very subpar.  All of the above makes the game below average, and then there is the Uplay DRM. There are plenty of other reviews that cover Uplay, none of which are positive.  Edit: I am saddened that I cannot rate this game lower than 'Not Recommended'. On my second day of playing, while trying to load my saved game, the game has crashed 3 times on 3 attempts. No longer is the game just difficult to enjoy, it is now quite literally unplayable.

(Wow, I hit the character limit for reviews. I didn't know that was a thing.)   Note: My focus of this review will be on the Archer class. I understand that the melee combat is the selling point of this game, and I will touch on it. But I often see tons of people talk about what is wrong with the melee system, and I feel like the issues surrounding the Archer don't get acknowledged as much as they should.    (Also note that this review will be VERY lengthy; I doubt that very many people will see it, but I want to make sure that the few that do know the state that Chivalry is in. But another big reason that I'm writing this is the fact that I loved this game, and hate to see what has happened to it. This is why my review is rather biased.)      Chivalry: Medieval Warfare has suffered a problem that contrasts the stereotypical 'indie game': A fair bit of the stuff you find from indie companies tends to be a half-a**ed alpha/beta version that runs terribly and is in dire need of improvement. (At least, this is one of many images that the term 'indie' has received.) And in the majority of those cases, the game is later abandoned by the developer(s), and left to rot; it never becomes a better game. Well, Chivalry has run this course backwards: What started out as a flawed, but overall well-executed game has become a pile of glitches and 'features' that has chased away several long-term players, myself being one.      --- Summary (of how the gameplay functions, that is) ---    So let's go over the basics of gameplay. There are four classes: Knight, Vanguard, Man-At-Arms, and Archer. The Knight is a tank class that wields many strong two-handed weapons, along with a secondary one-handed weapon and shield. The Vanguard is an assault class that, while having less protection than the Knight, utilizes a number of heavy swords, spears, and halberds. The Vanguard is capable of charging: After sprinting around for a period of time, he will place his arms in a locked-position of sorts. This indicates that, when you left-click, he will lunge forward and strike the enemy, dealing a massive blow that can even one-shot some classes. The third class, the Man-At-Arms, is agile. He can 'dodge' out of the way of attacks by means of either double-tapping a directional button, or a 'One-button dodge' shortcut, configurable in the Settings. With swords and maces, this class is about running in, avoiding attacks, and landing moderate, fast damage to enemies. This would be the last melee class recommended to new players, due to its low health and dodging mechanics that can be somewhat difficult to understand. Finally, the Archer is the black sheep: His primary weapon consists of either a bow, a crossbow, or javelins. Depending on which you choose, you'll either be in the back firing arrows at enemy classes to weaken/kill them, taking out enemy Archers to help your teammates, or charge into melee range and act as both a fighter as well as a distraction. This class has the lowest health of all, and should avoid melee combat as often as possible.    All attacks cost energy, which is depleted from a bar that appears on-screen with the health bar. Swinging without hitting somebody (and with it, feinting), parrying/blocking, holding a loaded arrow on the bow, and kicking use up some of this energy. And when that bar runs out, you can no longer do combo attacks, and if you parry/block an attack, you get stunned for a little while, which gives the enemy the chance you attack you while you're unable to defend yourself. You have to wait until it recharges before heading back into combat.    The way that maps work on servers is very similar to other PvP games: You have your standard Capture the Flag, King of the Hill, Free-for-All, Team Deathmatch, etc.. I won't go over how each of them works, because I assume that you'll either already know, or are willing to take a couple minutes to look them up. In addition to these, you also have two gamemodes that aren't seen quite as often: Duel, in which a group of people are put up against eachother in a 1 v.s 1 style, and the person with the most amount of victories at the end is declared the winner. And the second, Team Objective: In this mode, players are placed on two teams of either 12 or 16, where one is playing offense, and the other, defense. One of the teams has a set of goals that they must accomplish in a set period of time, before they end up losing the match. The other team's objective is to stop them from achieving those goals. If offense wins, then the two move on to the next objective. These objectives can range from things such as pushing a wagon through a gate, shooting down a barricade with a Ballista, slaying peasants, and even killing one of the two military generals that commands the teams: Feydrid Kearn, and Malric Terrowin.    The game supports player-owned servers, as well as modding. But to raise your rank (which is, for the most part, simply just a number), you have to play on the official Torn Banner-hosted servers. Your 'rank' allows you to unlock special helmets at different levels: At 30, you get a silver version of the default helmets. At 40, a Black version of the Veteran helmets, a gold at 50, and a pink at 60, etc.. You can also gain access to veteran helmets by unlocking all the primary weapons of a class, which involves getting a specific number of kills using any of the weapons in a section of the weapons list.      --- The Issues ---    So, what are the problems with this game? Well, as I mentioned at the start, this is a game that has gone sour the more it gets updated. At the start, people were presented with a game that uses a combat system that relied on timing, accuracy, focus, and didn't have the sort of 'whoever attacks first, wins' feeling that arises from other PvP games, namely first-person shooters. People appeared to have clung to that idea, and as a result, made Chivalry quite a popular game. At one point (in 2013, if I'm not mistaken), they had sold over 1.2 million copies of the game, which is rather impressive for a first standalone game (as it originally started out as a Half-Life 2 mod by the name of 'Age of Chivalry'). Over time, though, that good combat system has deteriorated, to the point that people have left the game entirely.    To make a long story short: Certain melee weapons in the game have been unbalanced for a very long time (some from the very start, from what I've been told by friends), and continue to be unbalanced to this day, 3-4 years later. Torn Banner has adopted the idea of 'it's not a bug, it's a feature' when it comes to the fighting styles that you see. For example, if you turn your player to have their back face the enemy, crouch, point your camera straight up to the sky, and perform an overhead, the weapon will strike the enemy and deal damage to them during the 'wind-up phase'. (This is supposed to be the point where your character is readying their weapon for a strike, and gives players a short window of time to counter-strike, before they have to block or dodge out of the way.) And if your weapon is slow enough, such as the Maul for the Knight, then you can turn your character around after the 'reverse-overhead' attack lands, and hit your opponent twice, which will kill anybody, assuming they don't block either one or both of the attacks. Another combat style, which is used heavily now-a-days, is known as 'dragging'. This is a very basic concept: If you swing your weapon to the left, then you turn right during the attack to 'drag' your weapon, thus slowing the swing speed and causing your opponent to (hopefully) block too early. app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: Fallout 3: How can I describe it in words that do it justice? Besides the obvious fact that it is well worthy of GoTY for whatever the hell year it's from.  Similar to Bethesda's other open-world games like Skyrim and FO:NV, FO3 is the type of game where there is a story to follow, but it takes place in an expansive world and it is soley up to you if you want to play through the story or not. The game's atmosphere accomplishes exactly what it sets out to accomplish, you're alone in the wide, desolated ruins of Washington D.C. with all sorts of dangers lurking around each corner, from robots to bandits to mutated hulks and irradiated zombies. Another huge contribution to the openness (a word I just made up) of the game is a massive artillary of weapons ranging anywhere from antique guns to jury-rigged sledge hammers to retro sci-fi laser guns. All topped off with a level up and perk system that is quick, to the point and doesn't interfere with gameplay.  Fallout 3 has aged well, and is still an enjoyable experience worth the dollar.  Also, Liam Neeson. If that isn't enough to convince you then there is no hope for you.  ***UPDATE*** I think I'm bloody well cursed. Fallout 3, like Fallout: New Vegas has again done nothing but impress me in all aspects possible, but I just cannot fully enjoy for some nagging reason that prevents me from picking it up and playing it. Game is unfortunately not what I expected.  I have played multiple 1000 hours of total war and I'm a huge warhammer fan, lorewise.  So what could go wrong?  - Cheating AI ( theres ppl that claim it doesnt cheat, but trust me, it does, they even recruit stuff they just simply cant recruit with the buildings they have )  - Very limited on Factions, yes the factions are different, but not to the extent that would warrant this MASSIVE downgrade in playable factions.  - Completely broken Diplomacy, once again.  - Very hard onwards, CPU start ignoring other CPU and go out of their way to chase you, exposing their core, but no other CPU take advantage of it because they are also either chasing you or running away from you.  - Confederations are formed way to easy, i.E. all the T2 Orc guys instantly fall to the 1. dominant tribe within 15!!! rounds sometimes, and theres jack ♥♥♥♥ you can do about it.  - Easily the worst Co Op in the whole ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ series, even with mods etc. (Imagine all the Problems above, only that the CPU now goes completely ♥♥♥♥in ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and start throwing 8 stacks of full armies at you with like 2 regions, YES THIS HAS HAPPENED, MULTIPLE TIMES)  I'm still gonna play the game a bit, but for anybody who isnt certain wether to buy this because of the problems the older games had, this game has all of them and then adds some new ♥♥♥♥ on top.  Now feel free to downvote this review as much as you like, it doesnt change the fact that, once again, CA have delivered a game that is broken in every aspect of its core, except for the very, very flashy but ultimately not very demanding RTS part of this game. If you want to play flashy Warhammer Battles, then this is the game for you, if you wanted a good Total War Game, then play Attilla again because it is the far superior title of the 2.

Bought it on sale, tried it, and it was so bad I didn't even finish the whole tutorial.  Graphics are ok but a little weird, controls are all over the place and make no sense, and it seems like it's trying to be the big-battle medieval version of Battlefront. It, however, fails miserably. The gameplay style doesn't really seem to work very well for this kind of game. If you, like I was when I bought this game, are looking for big-battle sanbox style gameplay, I recommend you go take a look at Heroes and Generals, War Thunder, and, of course, Battlefront. I'm sure I missed a few but those are the main ones that come to mind.  Don't waste your money on this game. You won't play it and you could spend that money on something much better.

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: [Review written 15,06,2015] [After Fallout NV] Minor disclaimer before the review; I have actually played around 30hrs of this game upon time of review, however steam doesn't count it as I run the game through FOSE launcher for windows 7 stability reasons.   Fallout 3 is one of the most atmospheric games I’ve played. Fallout 3 unlike its Mojave counterpart describes a world of hardship and fear with a large emphasis on villainy and morality. Much like the people of the wastes the player too must choose how to play, either in self-serving villainy or selfless heroism. Choses can be made via dialogue options or real-time decision making. Combat in Fallout 3 is an excellent cross between fps and real-time strategy, as the player is able to battle using their own accuracy and skill or by entering VATS which pauses the game and allow the player to make precise shots at certain enemy weak points. Graphically Fallout 3 was a masterpiece of its time, however today Fallout 3 is showing its age as some ground and wall textures are looking quite muddy. The one gripe I would have to say about Fallout 3 is that it doesn’t give you an awful lot of direction in the beginning of the game which could turn off some first timers to the series. All in all Fallout 3 is still to this day one of the greatest RPG’s ever created with its enthralling atmosphere and solid combat system.  I give fallout 3 a 9.5/10

NO.. You might have the Dota 2 Logo all bright and shiny everywhere in the UI but this is not Dota. After this mandatory pre-beta Reborn download it's just been downhill, hit rockbottom and kept digging. After every update, it just gets worse.   I'm fine with cinks and bugs, I freely participate in Beta releases like Hots, Reborn, Windows 10 etc. It's not the bugs, it's all these changes, that has made me hesitate to double-click the Dota icon for me. After 700+ hours Dota takes away levels and gives me an icon that changes when I level up. Great but now the one match I'm playing with people with 1000+ hours and it's how Dota always was. Next, a match with people who don't even have a steam profile yet. The experience mmr bracket is ruined by the new levelling system incorporated into this chaos.  The T5I is over and the compendium rewards are STILL buffering. We were supposed to get them easily 4-5 months ago. 'There have been compatibility issues regarding the desert terrain and the axe immortal is still being made', fine you're busy, but then why rush a pre-beta then and release several treasury items when we're still waiting for what we paid for since the beginning of 2015?  I'm not saying it's a horrible game, I'm saying it's not what it was and I don't like the direction it's going into. It changed too much too quickly, it's missing several key factors that is being pushed aside for the illusion of progress.   To those who are thinking of joining the Dota 2 community, Dota is not what it used to be. I do not recommend Dota 2 Reborn at this current time and probably will not in the future.

When I hear the phrase 'Dota 2 is good, just look at how many people play it,' I can't help but make myself blue from facepalming so hard. Call of Duty has millions of players. The thing is they're all 12 year olds with tourrettes and particularly ignorant mothers. The gaming society is so fanatic about numbers that they forget that criticism and praise are reflections of an individual's formed beliefs. That being said, Dota 2 is a terrible game, and that's not an opinion; it's the truth. Valve's fear of the number 3 has thrown them afar by pushing number 2's (yes, I did just say that, laugh it up) of all their other series. Portal 2, Left 4 Dead 2 and Half Life 2 as well as Half Life 2: Episode 2. But now they are doing it to games they don't originally own! Repetition is useful in debates and extremely rarely in games. A lesson Valve is eagerly forgetting to the point where Dota 2 doesn't even have multiple maps to change things up. I see it's up to the players to pose new situations; how inadvertently lethargic. I cannot comprehend how players can have over 3000 hours doing the same thing; let alone 5. To put this in today's terms; Dota 2 is so stupid your mum asked me what I was doing and when I replied 'I'm playing Defense of the Ancients' she freaked out believing that I was attempting to prevent her murder. I weep for future generations that, when asked to list 10 goods things about the 21st century, can only find numerous references to swag, Justin Bieber and the mindset that a large amount of players in a game means everyone in the whole world should enjoy it. And before you ask, yes I did just put a 'your mum is so old' joke in an analysis, thanks for noticing.

I know I'm never going to touch any Torn Banner games ever again, that's for sure, and I advise you to not encourage this kind of bullsh*t and spare you the rage. This game could have been awesome, but it never will be. Shame.

DOTA 2 is the remake of the game that started the MOBA genre as a Warcraft III mod back in the early 2000's. With updated graphics, physics, voice work and animations there is a lot here for someone who played the original. That being said, for newcomers this probably isn't going to be a pleasant experience. DOTA 2 is notorious for having one of the worst communities in the digital world. Players are extremely toxic and many matches devolve into shouting matches and trolling instead of the intense 5v5 combat that they were designed to be. Another problem is the lack of region lock with allows people from different regions in the world to play on servers that are not close to them. This results in your team mates having to overcome several major obstacles which include; a language barrier, a cultural barrier, lag due to distance from the server, etc. You get the picture, in a game where teamwork is more important than individual skill it becomes impossible to actually work with your team resulting in extremely frustrating matches that are more frequent then the good ones. DOTA 2 also struggles from outdated graphics, and overly convoluted itemization options to differentiate its heroes from each other. Hero skills take a backseat to itemization in terms of importance and good luck exploring new builds outside of the current meta without being verbally assaulted by your team mates. In conclusion, I would recommend this game only to diehard fans of the original because it is quite neat to see how far the game has changed visually. Other than that I would direct MOBA newcomers to either League of Legends or SMITE which both offer new players with much better options for learning the game and avoiding negative experiences.

As you can see, I only have some 45 hours played of this game so far, but I think I can make a safe judgement on the game based off of what I've played so far.  I played through an entire campaign with the dwarfs, and it had its moments, for sure. I enjoyed wiping out the greenskins, and I was genuinely frightened of chaos when they first appeared. I liked the gyrobombers, and nothing really came close to seeing an entire chaos warhound charge crumple under 4 squads of Irondrakes setting them on fire. The battles were genuinely fun, and it reminded me very much of the original table top game. So I enjoyed that bit, and it's ultimately what made me keep playing.  As the campaign wore on, though, and I realized how underwhelming chaos was, it came to a point where there was nothing left on the map but me, dwarves I hadn't assimilated yet, and the humans of Bretonnia and The Empire. My turns became nothing but cycling through the towns, managing what was being built, recruiting replacements for my 7 or 8 armies that were on the move, trying to make sure my two main quest-driven characters didn't get assassinated, and hitting 'next turn' a lot more then I really felt was necessary. After mopping up Barak Varr (leaving me with just 2 dwarf factions left to claim) I knew the game was pretty much a forgone conclusion, but I had to sit through it. It wasn't fun anymore, it was just tedious.  So I thought I'd try Chaos instead. Tried them out (got the expansion for free) and found that it was even more 'next turn' waiting, though the combat in battles was more fun due to having mounted units. Still, the waiting was awful. I'd camp after sacking something and it would take 4 minutes to get to a point where my army was safe enough to move on. There was no time-limit. No sense of urgency. It was just 'you know, meander on down south when you get a chance. Destroy the other chaos tribes, if you want. Who cares.' It also didn't feel like Chaos. I can't really put my finger on it, but the army didn't feel like a ravenous hungry mob of crazy chaos worshipers and demons. It felt like a regular army with chaos skins.  The game was fun for a bit, but the really 2 dimensional diplomacy (wiping out dwarfs was not what I signed up for as a dwarf), the long wait times between turns, the fact that you can't really play those other factions in campaign mode, the fact that the campaign victory conditions are just tedious, and the fact that chaos warriors (the faction) is just kinda meh... it means I can't really recommend this game unless it's on sale. It had its moments, but they came in between stretches of boredom or tedium. It's just not a very fleshed out game, by the feel of it, though it is bug free as far as I can tell and the battles are fun.   TL;DR The battles are fun, the campaign map is tedious, the DLC is not worth the money. Get it on sale if you get it at all.

Nearing 1400 hours of playing Dota 2, both competitively and casually with friends, I have long come to the conclusion that this game is worth all the time I've spent playing it. Granted, I may have spent too much money on this game by this point but I don't regret that in any way, as I wish for Valve to continue to create more content as well as perfecting this game whilst respecting the community, however hostile it may be at times. Being competitive is also an amazing aspect of the game, which continously drives me to git gud.  Good job Valve, thank you for creating this game and making it Free2Play.

Plays like a great game, reads like a great novel. Overall just a great experience and absolutely worth your money.  Amazing sandbox/open world feel; feels HUGE when you're trying to get around on foot or vehicle Lots of combat choices: shotgun, smg, sniper, melee, traps, etc. Be a silent killer or be a human tank, up to you Vehicles are.....weird. Sort of a realistic first person driving experience. Amazing visuals, which you expect from a CryEngine game. Take a vacation between killing pirates and drug lords Story reminiscent of Apocalypse Now or Heart of Darkness, how far down the rabbit hole will you go? Plenty of replay value for the adventure and upgrade, though the story isn't as great the second time through Writing this makes me want to play it again!

As a Warhammer World fan, it's good enough. Players will be able to take the field of battle with some of the most iconic figures of the IP. It's good fun, it really is.  For Total War fans, it seems CA has removed more features than they've added. Compared to an outdated Medieval 2 Total War, it falls short in terms of content and versatility. Player armies are mostly going to be cookie-cutter unless a self-imposed challenge has been issued. The AI’s armies, are almost all missile cavalry or missile infantry.  Mods have consistently saved the Total War series since Empire Total War. And the same can be said for Total War Warhammer.  I can't recommend this title as a Total War fan or as a concerned customer of Creative Assembly. It's saving grace is that it's set in the Warhammer World IP ..  I'll happily change my review once I feel CA has lived up to their M2TW standards.

Gameplay in the battles was awesome, and clearly the main focus for this game. I really enjoyed the fast paced, cinematic style battles. Units were diverse and fun.  However, I found the campaign map to be somewhat lacking. Limited factions, short main campaigns and low replayability had me putting this TW game on the shelf faster than any of the others I've played before. This will likely be remedied by all the DLC they are releasing, but in the end I'll have paid over 100 dollars for this game. I'm not sure its worth that much.  Regardless, lots of fun and definitely worth checking out if you're a fan of TW or Warhammer.

After logging many hours in this game, I would definitely recommend this to anyone whose computer can handle it. When I first heard of Planetside 2 from one of my friends, I had my doubts, but since the game was free to play, I decided to give it a try. I have to admit I am impressed. Planetside 2 is an anomaly among most genres, as there are few mmofps games out there. This is the only fps game I know that allows for multiplayer battles between hundreds of combatants. There are no bots in this game. Everything that moves is controlled by a player. In terms of scale, Planetside 2 cannot currently be matched by any other existing shooter.  Despite the fact that the game is free to play, it runs relatively smoothly. The game is still a work in progress, as SOE is continuously releasing new content, which means there is no shortage of new weapons and content to explore. The game can be a little rough around the edges. On several occasions, I've encountered some interesting bugs. Fortunately, SOE is usually quick in patching them.  While some people claim otherwise, it is possible to be very effective in this game without paying anything. There are in-game purchases, but they are mostly for cosmetic items, such as camo, decals, and armor styles. You can also buy weapons for anywhere from $2.50 to $7.00. Player performance upgrades such as nano-weave can not be purchased, but must by unlocked through gameplay, eliminating any pay-to-win aspects. While the prices for weapons are steep, the same weapons can also be unlocked via cert points, which are accumulated during gameplay. Using certs, weapons can cost anywhere between 100 and 1000 cert points to unlock. For novice players, this can be daunting. However, vetern players can easily crank out abouty 70 certs an hour. I was able to mass a decent arsenal through gameplay alone. Before you complain about the grind, know that you can just as effective at killing with the starting weapons, which include a pistol, assualt rifle, carbine, light machine gun, launcher, semi-auto sniper rifle (bolt-action for New Conglomerate players), and the default MAX weapons (varies from faction to faction). While it is not necessary to do so the first weapon I would recommend investing in (using certs) is a shotgun. however, recently, SOE added one to players inventories for free, limiting my suggestions to only a bolt-action sniper rifle and a smg. Of course, if using certs for weapons, be sure to first upgrade abilities and stamina before looking at guns.  Overall, I had a great experience with this game and highly recommend it. If you like fps games with massive battles between infantry, tanks, and aircraft, this game is for you. If not, its free. The only thing it will cost is time and hard drive space.

You might like this game if:  You enjoy humorous games You don't need an objective to enjoy gameplay You enjoy sandbox games.  One of my favorite features is obtaining *goats*. Each time you collect a new goat, you can play as that goat by starting a fresh session. From double jump goat to penguins to jetpacks. Goat Nis Video Part 1 ~ At First Lick   [medavelvan.com]  When saw that there was a game called ‘Goat simulator’ on Steam, I smiled and I was immediately thankful that someone out there had the sense of humor and sufficient motivation to make a game with such an obstinant premise.  I almost bought it full price simply to support free-spirited developers like these; but I am happy that I refrained and waited for a sale. It’s a fun game, but not a good game.  Before playing ‘Goat Simulator’ I imagined the game in two flavors: either a realistic Goat Sim, where players would live the daily routine of a goat with normal goat missions: eat grass, escape fence, eat garden plants, evade farmer~ where the humor would arise from the realism of being a goat.  The second flavor would be an over-the- top, silly goat game with crazy game mechanics and wacky missions, ~ where the humor would be from the absurdity of it all. My first impression of ‘Goat Simulator’, as seen in  Goat Nis - Part One  [medavelvan.com]  confirmed that it was the latter:  ‘Goat Simulator’ is an over-the-top goat sim with wacky physics and unreasonable world interaction.  It is simply impossible to describe the level of absurdity present in every aspect of this game. A complete video review will be necessary in the near future when we have time to edit the highlights in our playthrough video.  In a nutshell, I recommend this game to gamers who like cheap sandbox games. This game is not an immersive rpg or GTA with goats, but it’s fun for $5 if you catch it during a Steam Sale.  ~Medavelvan  http://www.medavelvan.com

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: I bought this game for my xbox 360 a couple years ago and I can honestly say it is one of my favorite RPGs that I've ever played. I was excited to buy it for my PC. However, after it downloaded and said it was 'ready to play' I reached the launch menu and no matter what options I changed or reccomendations I followed I could not launch the game. I would press the PLAY button and the launch menu would disappear and the game wouldn't start. I was dismayed to find out that several other people were having this exact problem with little to no success in fixing it. I'm disappointed that nobody has patched this problem and that the game is even up for sale when a multitude of people are unable to even play it. In the matter of the game itself, it is an absolutely wonderful game. Sadly, the one on Steam is a ripoff and I would like my money back.

Goat Simulator was a good game when I played on Mac. Now, for me to consider to redownload it or not, I would pick no.   Mac has been known to be a bad system to play games on, yet my Mac can play most of the Valve games and some third-party games, like this one. Now I play mostly on Windows now, I said no to downloading this again.  Firstly, this game is riddled with glitches. This is a complete game, not Early Access. I guess it is supposed to make the game funnier.   Which leads to my second point. This game tries very hard to be funny. It just simply is not. It relies heavily on pop culture references and puns for jokes which are very poor and unfunny.  The physics in this game are absolutely horrific. When people get hit by cars, they lie there for a second, and get back up like nothing ever happened. Same with the goat. People get stuck in walls, the goats head flaps wildly, heads extend towards the sky, the tongue of the goat shoots into outer space for no reason at all, and everything explodes and shoots everywhere with one single tap. Also, if benches are pushed away, people float in the air.  The community is the only saving grace, EXCEPT I COULD NOT DOWNLOAD ANYTHING!  Finally, the graphics. These graphics are good, very good, IF THIS WAS RELEASED IN 2004! Textures look murky, the goat looks like an early PS3 model, and people look unpolished. This looks like a PS2 game.  Forgot to mention the fireworks. No control over them, they will just shoot you off in a random direction.  Achievements were the worst. Relied on pop culture references, but at least POSTAL 2 did it right, and that was from 2003!   A Goat Simulator plush was not needed.  Music is just a looped synth beat that gets annoying after at least 10 minutes.  I was bored with this game after at least 10 minutes.  If you want it, get it on sale for dirt cheap. Whatever you do, avoid this game at all costs on regular price.  3 out of 10

If your a fan of both Warhammer (if it has any left) and the total war games you might like it. If you liked Rome 2 and warhammer than his is your game. But if you like playing games more than just watching some small dots run around on some of the more boaring looking games boards in the most bland colors then you just found the holy grail of games.   If you are like most gamers of an age to remember how awesome the original total war gamesare, then you will find yourself asking didnt the Total War games used to be fun?   Maybe its the scale of the game, ie... to far pulled back to see the fights or maybe its how you never seem to get attached to any generals (you can not custom make them) or even how boaring the fighting looks now... possibly the pace?  Whatever it is this game has you hitting auto-battle 3 fights into the story. That is not good. Everything outside of the battles is just clicking through menues.   My only hope for this game is the intense release plans for new units, new heros, new armies etc.. they claim to have planned. although i wonder how much of it was just cut from the original game to be released as DLC.   oh and big con: no skaven. Thats one race that would have done really well with this game engine. lots of big cannons, doomwheels, rat ogres...   additional thoughts:  Fixed starting areas seems lore friendly but means you really only get a few towns to start in. I would have been better to start as a smaller human town or orc clan. Limited replayablity. you end up just playing to do better than your last playthrough but you make all the same choices etc... They needed more of a randomized map or something.

Let me just start off with saying that I waited on this game since it was announced and couldn't wait for it to release. I have also had some fun with it, but...  Wait for a sale since they are being so greedy. The DLC is not worth the cost and is just plain greedy, the blood and gore is really cheesy and over exaggerated, not to mention it shouldn't be paid for in the first place. The fact that they already have so many DLC's is just ridiculous, they should have mostly been free or much cheaper.  Beast men are expensive and boring, mostly do to the copy-paste mechanics.  The AI mechanics and tactics could be much better and are really dull, the fighting animations are barely improved, units take turns hitting eachother instead of having fluid combat, I really think they could have done better if they tried.   UNIT ABILITIES - They are gone.... just gone... except for hero units... why? this is so dumbed down it's made the combat very boring... just flank, that's the only tactic to do, flank and match up spears against large enemies and that's it, no actual tactics anymore.  The agents/heroes are kind of fun at first, it's cool having heroes fight on the battlefield, but using them on the campaign map is very very very boring.   Yes I've put in over a hundred hours into this, the game is very charming at first, but I'm just not having as much fun with is as I had in Shogun 2, which i've put in just over 500 hours. This game simply doesn't keep me as entertained, which is a surprise to me because I wanted a fantasy TW game more than anything, but they dumbed the gameplay down and/or just didn't improve it.

No more buying Ubisoft games for PC   Great graphics, Great gameplay, Great story...  Overall a great game.   You might wonder why I do not recommend the game... The reason is Uplay.  I purchased the game during the Steam summer sale. I installed the game, and launched it. I was told to copy a CD key to the clipboard, and I did. When the you click play here, it opens Uplay, (Ubisoft's stupid DRM) making Steam look like a glorified CD key retailer. It prompts you to enter the CD key. When I did, it said my key was already in use. I didn't freak out, I thought it was just a bug. So I tried again, but it still did not work.   I was not able to launch the game, so I contacted Ubisoft support, they were not helpful, saying that the code was already redeemed to someone else's account. They suggested I contact Steam instead. I did. Steam told me to contact Ubisoft. None of them helped me. None.  I ended up pirating the game to finish it.

Currently, I'm liking this game. This is probably one of the better works from Total War series in recent years. However, at the very beginning of the game, I've already felt the lack of units variety and playable factions compared with Shogun 2.  Also, no more avatar conquest makes me very sad. Imagine avatar conquest was in this game, you're able to customize your own character and leveling him/her up like a RPG, fight a random opponent online with your friends or fight against AI, or putting in unique story/lore related missions/quests like King Arthur. Warhammer is born to be perfect with avatar conquest, and I don't know why the hell they decided not to put that into the game.   I understand DLC is part of Total War frenchise now. But, at the very ♥♥♥♥ing least give us a ♥♥♥♥ing FULL game without ripping out basic contents. DLC meant to create new things to the game, not cutting exsisting content out of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ game. Overall, the game is solid enough. Haven't experienced any problems yet like ROME 2 did.

I very much like this game, however in the most recent patches things have been sliding slightly towards the 'oh ♥♥♥♥ that character is op as ♥♥♥♥' side of the game that no one wants to see. However the game is free and has done right by me for many years now and hopefully many more years to come.   P.S Don't play this game if you're really salty and get mad easily.. *cough* George *cough*

This game is a step up from Attila and Rome 2, however, that's not a lot of praise. Rome 2 was abysmal at release and Attila was on the cusp of being terrible. As of now I am indifferent to this game. I don't like it but I also don't hate it. It's Meh. The A.I is still terrible. Lack of diplomacy options, graphics are not that good (even on max settings). A lot of the animations look the same. CA needs to go back to the drawing board. They continue to use cookie cutter mechanics for every Total War game since Rome 1. I don't think they understand their games need to evolve other than aesthetics.

Okay, I have many critical points for this game. I enjoy it every once and a while, but it doesn't enjoy having me playing it, I swear. So at a first glance, this game is an open world, futuristic, team-based shooter with a couple of classes. Now you may think, oh boy, open world, this ought to be great, WRONG, it's shlock. It's a free to play with a pay to win feel. Now no one enjoys pay to win and I mean nobody, it's not rewarding and it causes F2P'ers to feel very weak and useless. Your base guns are shlock, you get paired up with enemies millions of times more experienced or armed than you are. It isn't fun unless you're goofing around with friends and/or drunk out of your mind. So while I enjoy popping this up with friends I don't recommend playing it long-time, after a while, it'll feel like eating saltines, not filling and mouth-drying.

If you are patient, and understand that at any given point in time you will have to be a foot soldier in an infantry battle, a pilot/gunner in a ground vehicle, or a pilot/vehicle in an air battle--and that at any time, all three of these can and will be happening around or somewhere near you, you will enjoy this game. Just look up a video or two and see what you want to spend your points upgrading, and pick a role and stick with it for at least [the standard amount of time that you would typically try to do something in a game.] Don't play an Engineer for 10 minutes, repair a vehicle without ever getting in one yourself and then say 'this isn't for me,' then switch to Infiltrator, get sniped in the face while trying to line up a shot of your own, and then quit. You will understand if you just give it a day or two. There's a learning curve, which is something to admire. There is no winning gear--your skill and adapatibility will determine whether you conquer the map or not. It's free, what do you have to lose, besides some of your time? (which you have way too much of anyway.) Join a squad, you blueberry.  TL;DR : The most important aspect of the game for me was learning that every situation gives a different build a different advantage, and you can never really be the OP beast you were in that other game you play, so don't be a lone wolf, and learn to have some patience, and some discipline.

I am a long time fan of the Total War series begenning with the first Shogun sixteen years ago. I own every Total war with the exception of Atilla( even having purchased Napoleon despite the fact that it was originally advertised as a free LC for purchasers of Empire because of the terrible condition Empire was released in). In that last seven years fifteen total war games and sizable expansions have been released ( one of them being a free LC I believe as I don't remember buying the Imperator Augustus DLC to Rome 2. Of those I own only two were released in a usable fashion, Shogun 2 and Warhammer. While they still had issues they were not overwhelmingly noticable or impactful to gameplay.  So given the track record Warhammer was a last attempt with this company- and by god the early game in particular and the mid game as well are good! The late game suffers and this is definitly a Total War light experience with several core and complicated mechanics removed (presumably) to make the game more accessible.   Despite the positives which I can laud for this game I cannot bring myself to reccomend the game to others. I made a mistake in preordering this game. The company is time and again showing a general distrust and ineptitude that I can no longer forgive.   This brings me to my final note and the reason why I wrote this review- The dlc strategy of CA / GamesWorkshop.  The game released with a faction that had to be paid to use- on top of pricing the game at 60 U.S. Said faction (Chaos) is pretty lackluster as a horde faction with a lacking campaign that results in a hundred turns( or as high as two hundred) doing basically nothing preparing to invade the world at large with ai mechanics for the subjugated factions being... unpolished. This can be reduced by playing on a low difficulty but that should not be a neccesity for a faction.  Soon to release will be another DLC faction- A horde faction advertised as having unique mechanics- namely the greenskin/dwarf underway reskinned and no horde infighting. Amazing. A slew of reskinned chaos units ( some identical ) and an improvement to how the horde handles sacking and looting settlements which should have been included in the Chaos release. For 20 U.S. This is an utter dissapointment for me 1/3rd the price of the game within a scant two months after release for a reskin of an already dlc horde faction. Combined the two dlc factions ( forming fully 50 percent of the initial game race options) will cost 50 percent of the original asking price. 90 Dollars to play the game at full two months after release? Are you kidding me?  I am done CA - You have lost me as a consumer of your product - maybe MAYBE if in some steam sale they are reasonably priced I will go for it.  I find it much more likely that the combination of a poor sales strategy and customer interaction will result in a dwindling community- even those who would buy the game cheap because they enjoyed the experience of a stolen version will not be touching this mess.

I played this game for about a week, in that time I did a number of side missions, hunted, drove about, and just explored.  Heres what I think about it. Pros: -Amazing scenery -Enjoyable driving -Good voice acting for the most part -GLORIOUS villians -Rememberable characters -Immersion -Good soundtrack.  Cons: -No reason to keep playing after you beat the main storyline -No recoil on guns -Horrid, horrid, HORRID enemy AI, on higher difficulties they will rush with a knife, to the slaughter. -No underwater exploration that is able to be pursued, besides caves. -Diffrent topic.- -Confusing points in the story, no idea what happened with boss fights.

Nevertheless this game is fun if you are just looking to have a good time. Totally worth it though

Far Cry 3 is my current favorite game. Throughout the course of the game you learn the importance of stealth, resources, allies, and enemies. The only complaint I have is the co-op mission glitches that make it hard to invite your friends sometimes. With that in mind, the story itself is very entertaining and well put together. In a way, I would like to say the game is realistic, because once you zone out after playing it for a few hours, you get really intense and into it. The graphics are pretty great a good majority of the time, but my laptop isn't exactly prepared for me to have all the graphics up in 'high'. If you like first person shooter games with a story/theme, I'd definitely recommend this one!

Before reading: this review is more of a neutral review than a not recommended review (which they should add) because I can't recommend it but it isn't garbage.   I decided to buy it because almost everyone I know told me that it's the best horror game ever. I'll admit it's scary the first time you play it because you don't know when the jumpscares are coming and if they're scary, but then after the first couple of them you realize it's just the noise that makes you jump and the actual jumpscares aren't scary, it turns into a strategy game. You can see if a jumpscare is coming if   'it's me' flashes on the security tablet thingy or if the power is off and if you see eyes flashing and hear music  . After the first two or three levels it starts to become boring (play in bursts?). There was something I liked about the vague ending though.   In conclusion, it's not bad, but not good either. It isn't really that scary to me, more adrenaline-rushing when I need to close the door fast (which needs power to close?!), so if you like strategy games with horror elements or something, then this is the game for you.   and for the love of  god ... DO NOT search 'fnaf' into deviantart unless you want to cringe or vomit.

PlanetSide 2 is an open world MMO-FPS which provides a unique experience. I enjoy it because it allows you to do whatever you want, and the gunplay and mechanics feel satisfying. It is fairly complex for a shooter, but it's free so I recommend you try it out. Every non-cosmetic in the game can be acquired for free though it takes some time. The starting equipment is usually the best general purpose gear. Read some guides and watch some videos to learn how to get decent FPS, the basic mechanics, and what to unlock first.   Oh, and population is still strong outside of Briggs so long as you play during your server's daytime.

Chivalry is a first (or third) person slasher game which consists of 2 teams: Agatha Knights and Mason Order. There are 4 classes to choose from: Archer (long range, low hp), Man at Arms (ability to dodge, low hp), Vanguard (uses heavy weapons and can execute a sprint attack with high damage, medium hp) and Knight (uses high damaging weapons at the cost of speed, high hp).  The game has a variety of game modes including: Free-for-all, Team Deathmatch, Team objective (best mode), Last Team Standing and King of the Hill. These game modes are very fun and can keep you entertained for hours. Just to note that Team Objective and King of the Hill matches can last a long time (30+ minutes).  The combat is satisfying with a variety of attacks to choose: slash, stab and overhead. You are able to parry (block) but at the cost of stamina. You will also loose stamina if you miss an attack or kick (breaks an enemies block). These mechanics do work well but could do with some tweaking.  Overall I do really like this game and can easily spend a few hours playing. I very much reccomend this game, although it can be a bit buggy. Make sure your PC is capable of running it, as laptops will suffer even at lower settings (but can still be playable).

Full disclaimer, I am not an FPS kind of guy. I don't have the twitch reflexes nor the situational awareness to do well in shooters. I usually get killed in the middle of trying to get a bead on the person who just head-shotted me. Having said all of that, and not having spent that much time with this game, I can confidently say that this is a good one. The visuals are pleasing and the interface is intuitive. To a noob like me, things can be a little overwhelming at first, but if you are fortunate enough to have a buddy who is a regular player to show you the ropes, it will greatly ease your introduction into the vast battleground in the game world. I like the use of vehicles as well as the character classes, though it does put me off that you can come back as a different class every time you die and respawn. I prefer a certain amount of investment and commitment in the class or role that I play. There is defintely fun to be had here, especially if you play as a part of a team of friends that you are used to playing with. And hey, it's free to play. If I was better at FPS, I'd definitely play this game regularly.

Pros:  This game is a great game and has lots of good features and implements. Despite having lots of microtransactions and such it is still possible to have a good time without spending a dime. Most stuff such as health packs, weapon upgrades, etc can be earned through getting certs, which you get when you level up and get kills.  Cons:  Despite being able to earn certs, it is a hard and long process to earn enough certs to buy anything usefull in the shop. The game emphasizes more on spending your hard earned cash rather than actually earning it, but the fact that you can still earn items for free is great considering that the game is free, so that can be overlooked. The game has a very lackluster 'tutorial' that leaves scratching your head at how the game is even, and at times some functions in the game such as the lattice network and how each building functions to your faction can be confusing, but this is one of those games you'd figure out as you much like I did.   I'm not for FPS games, but I still had fun with this one even though i'm broke and I suck balls at it. I recommend this to all who read this review, which is probably nobody.

Far Cry 3 is one of the best games we've seen lately. Great fps mechanics, GORGEOUS graphics, amazing characters, good story line, and lots and lots of fun.  The islands act a very fun sandbox where you can just roam around and adventure. The amazing visuals make explorations extremely enjoyable, and there are lots of side missions to do while you roam.   The bad? No game is perfect and FC3 does have some defects. The non-story character models are lame and there is only a handful of them, attack of the clones much? Although this is can be a great sandbox game, you will eventually run out of outposts to capture. (This was remedied by adding an option to reset all outposts which is great). The crafting is an amazing feature but it is actually very shallow. A more in-depth crafting system would have made the game that much more fun. The economy in general is gimmicky, new guns and mods can be acquired rather easily.   Overall this is an outstanding game and worth every sacond of your precious game time.   9/10.

I wanted to take a moment to state that this game has its ups and its downs. Overall I would say the multiplayer is glitchy yet addictingly fun (Always fun to yell AAAAGAAAATHAAAAA when running in there). The weapon variety is lacking and any server lag can make the game nearly impossible to play legitly without just swinging wildly. I host my own server with my friends and face bots when we want to have a nice day of carnage. I just wish that the server software had more options and possibly more spawn-able bots (or difficulty levels on them)  A few more details:  The game is 100% multiplayer and due to the nature of the game you tend to get a good deal of people frustrated at each other with at least 1-2 attempts to kick a player every match. Although the controls are rather simple there are a good number of moments where the reach of a weapon isn't clear nor are the enemy's 'telegraphed movements' acurately portrayed so you never really know who is swingging their weapon first and if you're in range of the hit. On that same note, be prepared to be yelled at as friendly fire is a common theme in the game as well as attempts at stealing kills. I can't count how many times I've been fighting a guy one-on-one only to have a teammate run in there lobbing off my head in an attempt to steal my thunder. Yes, you can kick someone for friendly fire (its a nice touch that they include the amount of damage dealt to teammates in the voting window) but I've had matches where people are voted to be kicked due to friendly fire that was clearly on accident and let's be frank here- when a skirmish happens EVERYONE has a little friendly fire.  On the note of multiplayer- the different game modes are refreshing. It's great to go from a free-for-all mass chaos match to an object oriented map or a team battle to a duel arena. The variety is nice but the game feels like it could use more support from the developers- the content is lacking for the price tag and you would think there would be more weapon variety or at least some more 'unlockables' or something a little 'flashy to earn'.  Final notes:  The game is a lot of fun to play but keep in mind that the $25 price tag is a little steep given the amount of content you receive. If the game is on sale for $10 or under however- pick it up and enjoy a weekend of bloody murders!

I have tried playing this game on several occasions. In none of those occasions have I ever had fun. This is, by far, the most unbalanced, most new-user-unfriendly, un-fun pile of garbage I have ever played. Not only is its one goal to basically force you into buying their worthless microtransactions, but it also punishes you for trying to use hard work to upgrade your own stuff to at least match the unstoppable warlords you constantly face. Teamwork is made useless by invincible vehicles that cannot be harmed, and even if you do win it's because you had more vehicles or Max classes than the other enemy. What are Maxes? They're basically a purchasable class with so much armor and weaponry that shooting at one is like trying to dig a hole through prison with your bare hands. Maybe this game would have been fun if it weren't so terribly unbalanced and it gave you a chance to upgrade your items without getting a brain hemorrhage.  Basically? Jesus ♥♥♥♥ing Christ don't play this game.

Free to play FPS with battles of epic proportions (hundreds of players at once). Combat is fluid and fun, the vehicles are neat. Only complaints are balance issues such as the Heavy assault class being much too overpowered, and the terrible fllight mechanics. I'm a former huge fan of WARHAMMER table strategy game (before Games Warkshop butchered it) that enjoyed to play a bit of Total War games like Shogun and Rome.  I recommand this game to any warhammer fan that looks for some epic looking battle and doesn't want to paint/buy a sh*tload of miniatures. This game is more similar to Warhammer than a Total War game.  Here my list of Pros and Cons about this game:  PROS:  -Awesome map graphics and units models/movements and sounds  -Feels like Warhammer  -The majority of your beloved Heroes/Champions/Units are there and they kick a*ses  -The factions are unique and different in the economy management, playstyle, campaign movement and tecnology tree  -The magic is cool and powerful but not game breaking in the Campaign Mode  -They promised that ALL the factions will be added through DLC and expansions  -Developers are constantly working on the game  -Cool siege battles: you put units on the walls and you will fight up there, outside the walls and inside the city, siege battles are also rather fast and intense  -GAME IS FULL MODDABLE: you don't like something about the gameplay? No problem, 5 min into the Steam Workshop and you will find what you need and MORE (over 1900 MODS AVAILABLE)  CONS:  -If you plan to get all the factions i suggest you to wait for some discounts or this game will cost you A LOT  -4 playable Factions in the base game: Empire, Dwarfs, Vampire Counts and Greenskins. If your favourite factions aren't released yet the game becomes boring after some time (i main Wood Elves and i like to get Bretonnia, Khemri, Lizardman, Chaos Dwarfs and are not released yet)  -Non Campaign PvP is terrible: No army restriction except money, you will see any kind of cheese/unbalanced army compositions. Extremely unfun to play for a game mode that is the CORE of WARHAMMER. It's sad because is easy to solve this problem by just introducing the tabl game army restrictions  -Lack of siege maps diversity, mechanically speaking they are similar, always fight behind similar walls, aesthetically they looks different and are full of details  I DO RECOMAND THIS GAME BUT BE CAREFUL:  1-if you are a HUGE Total War fan this game is more focused on the battles and the other aspects are semplified (economy, diplomacy, agents) if compared to the others Total War games.  2-if your favourite Warhammer factions are not released you might wanna consider to wait until they are out instead of buy the game and than complain about 'lack of content'.

this isn't a game, it's a bad physics simulator.   it's just stuff smashing together and exploding in a considerably less satisfying manner than you'd expect from what is essentially a physics-demo-toy.  the humor is gunning for the youtube set as hard as possible, everything is forced puns and memes and self-congratulatory ♥♥♥♥ that got old for me almost immediately.  all of that would be forgivable if it was a decent physics engine but it really isn't. nothing has the proper weight and the soft bodies have no bones so everything goes wiggly right away.  if your idea of pants-pissingly hilarious is a goat flopping around with its tongue out until you push a button to make it stop, this is the executable program for you.  if that sort of thing sounds like it might get old within five minutes of starting up, you should probably ignore the alarming degree of fanwank this is getting and wait until it goes on super-Steam-sale for $0.99 to see what all the fuss is about.

I have now spent a lot of money to get the Full Experience of the game when i should only buy one or a few expansions that come with a few races just like dawn of war or warcraft.. Look at this way there are 9 races that still aren't out yet and plus beastmen which just came out so you are paying about 200 US dollars to get 10 races which is a lot of money spent on one game, Assuming every race is going to cost approximately 20 US each. So should you buy this well if u love warhammer or and total war sure why not but if u dont but would generally like to play a new RTS then maybe wait a year or two until Sega and CA pull their head out and lower the price of each race to half the current price Or release several races at a time as expansions like Warhammer dawn of war or Warcraft for 30 US Dollar for one expansion at a time.
