Goat Nis Video Part 1 ~ At First Lick   [medavelvan.com]  When saw that there was a game called ‘Goat simulator’ on Steam, I smiled and I was immediately thankful that someone out there had the sense of humor and sufficient motivation to make a game with such an obstinant premise.  I almost bought it full price simply to support free-spirited developers like these; but I am happy that I refrained and waited for a sale. It’s a fun game, but not a good game.  Before playing ‘Goat Simulator’ I imagined the game in two flavors: either a realistic Goat Sim, where players would live the daily routine of a goat with normal goat missions: eat grass, escape fence, eat garden plants, evade farmer~ where the humor would arise from the realism of being a goat.  The second flavor would be an over-the- top, silly goat game with crazy game mechanics and wacky missions, ~ where the humor would be from the absurdity of it all. My first impression of ‘Goat Simulator’, as seen in  Goat Nis - Part One  [medavelvan.com]  confirmed that it was the latter:  ‘Goat Simulator’ is an over-the-top goat sim with wacky physics and unreasonable world interaction.  It is simply impossible to describe the level of absurdity present in every aspect of this game. A complete video review will be necessary in the near future when we have time to edit the highlights in our playthrough video.  In a nutshell, I recommend this game to gamers who like cheap sandbox games. This game is not an immersive rpg or GTA with goats, but it’s fun for $5 if you catch it during a Steam Sale.  ~Medavelvan  http://www.medavelvan.com

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: Please not that this review is by no means a reflection of the game in general, but more for an overlying issue: the fact that it is not optimized for any Windows OS newer than Vista.  Unlike New Vegas, which basically uses the same engine, older BGS games like Oblivion and Morrowind, or even Interplay's Fallout games of 1, 2 and Tactics, Fallout 3 generally will not run correctly, if at all, on Windows 7, 8/8.1, and 10. While select few have been able to make the game run just through Compatiblity mode, the overall majority of users require numerous steps to go over and hoops to jump through. And even then, if you are in the minority of those like myself, you can still find yourself unable to play even after jumping through the hoops.  While the avid modder for Bethesda games might find it normal and only slightly more frustrating, the average user might just find it to be one massive headache. And again, they might just find it a waste of time if, like myself, can't seem to get it to actually start up a new game even with things like FOSE (Fallout Script Extender), G4WL Disabler (Games For Windows Live Disabler), a 4GB Patch, and the Unofficial FO3 Patch.  If you are one of those users who actually wants to put in the effort and see about getting it working, then there is a guide located here:  https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=149946772   The Guide itself is simple to understand, easy to follow, and contains links to nessecary additions to help get the game running.  However, it by no means ensures the game will work. While you could find success in the early steps, you could just find yourself stuck with nothing solving it.   If you are truely desperate in playing Fallout 3 again, but don't want to deal with the hastle of the steps in the guide, or are in the minority of users that, like myself, can't get it to run even with the steps in the guide, then you have one of two options. If you are and avid PC player and might even want to mod it, then find a good quality PC that is running Windows Vista. Or, if you don't care about mods, how it looks, or even what platform you play it on, then go down to your local Gamestop/EB Games, or whatever the store is called for you and purchase a PS3 or Xbox 360/Xbox One (as it is a backwards compatible title) and Fallout 3 Game of the Year edition, as the console versions still work fine.

dota 2 review 11/10 This game has taken over all of my free time.....and i'm completely fine with that!  Pros:   - Super FUN!!!!  - Very Team Based Oriented   - Tons of Characters to play  - Tons of items during game (which are used to buff characters)  - A ridiculous amount of combinations from the above two   - Amazong community  - Pro leagues are phenomenal to watch!   I can go on for days about the pro's  Cons:  - There is a significant learning curve to this game  - The learning cuve just doesn't apply to the game, but to each character in the game as well.  - Can take a while to become decent with a character  - Play bad, get yelled at.... but thats what mute is for! =)  - Almost essential to have a microphone for vocal communication (theres almost no time to type while the game is going)  - If you have a bad team, you will almost always lose. There is no 'They're bad, but i can win it by myself.'  Overall I 100% recommend this game to anyone who is willing to spend a few hours to get used to the game before giving up on it. The game can be immensly fun after you get the hang of the game mechanics and a character or two. When you win..... it is super satisfying! Give it a try! =)

Total war:Warhammer Review    This is my first long review that's gonna voice my opinion.    Rating&Opinion   Total War: Warhammer is a really fun and great game, ever since I heard of it I have been wanting to get it! I have played this game for about 91 hours but hoping to add 909 more! I am also a HUGE total war fan and have played most of the games. but the reason you are reading is for my rating yes...I would give it a   8/10   now you might be wondering for this rating but this game leans more into the medieval 2 style of gameplay now I am sure lots of people like this but I have mixed views which I shall express later on in my review.    Gameplay  Now this is the most important part of the review, so this also matters should you purchase this game. because this is such a big part I will make it into smaller sections   Playable Races&Factions  Non-dlc races   The Empire-Led on his fearsome mount:Deathclaw, Emperor Karl Franz leads the armies of the Empire to glorious victory against Vampire,Orks,Chaos and Beastmen! Having a very balanced army roster I am enjoying my campaign with them so far.  The Dwarves-My favorite little stunties, The High King Thorgrim GrudgeBearer leads the charge to take back lost holds and unite the Dwarves under one banner! The Dwarves have a very nice defensive roster with devastating units you will have trouble defeating the Greenskins as they get big quite fast, Playing as the Dwarves can be challenging as with no calvary you often can't run down troops nor block the enemy's.   I have a challenge for you   Playing as the Dwarves you must be cautious and try to win heroic or decisive victorys as every Dwarf life matters with the Longbeards outnumbering the Beardlings     The Greenskins-What a great campaign one of the best always on your feet being at war with someone, the end times just arrived word of advice, do not read spoiler: When the end times happens 4 full stacks will appear in the southern badlands so be ready to deal with chaos Okay back... in my current campaign everyone got the shield of civilization...except the orks, but I decided to make peace with everyone to take my 5 full stacks and attack chaos cuz its Grimgor Ironhide job to 'smash eads an crake skullz'  Vampire counts-I have not decided to play them yet as I find them a bit boring, sorry :(   Dlc Factions   Chaos-I vow on the chaos gods I shall not play it until I get the Blood & Gore dlc, and then finally I will only play it on Legendary.  Beastmen-I will not be getting the Beastmen as there not a faction that interest me and $21 cad is a bit to high for me    Possible future factions  Chaos Dwarves-Lets be honest Dwarfs mixed with Chaos, I'm sorry please tell how thats not awesome, read some of the lore there cruel and love slavery (oh wait some people might get triggered) They actually build some crazy weapons look it up.  Skaven-There Rats and there Rats that kinda resemble a man, Oh course this is your chance to be that knight in shinning Armour to swoon that girl you fancy.  Tomb Kings Expedition-Think about it Settra leads a expedition into the old world can either be a advanced horde or occupy Ork cities and Dwarf Karaks    Battles&Sieges  Earlier in this review I said 'Warhammer leans into medieval 2' that means less skill is needed to play the game as the main tactic I see is, Hammer and Anvil. With the loss of: Shield wall,Heavy, fire,normal arrows, etc, I find this to be less skillful and easier for newer players  Battles can take place out in the open or in cities, I have to say open battles are fun and exciting but Sieges are rather dissapointing and short with lack of planning to make a mighty last stand of the Dwarves against a horde of Orks but resorts to just put your troops on the walls and see who wins. (fix to sieges have a ♥♥♥♥ computer and battles will last hours even on triple speed )I would say the AI has improved but still prone to stupid decisions.     Replayability  With currently 6 factions (including dlc) there are many options for Replayability and with more to be added there is always hopefully something new    Running out of ideas so just read my very long and pointless sentence about my talking about how pointless it is   Now that this is over (guys don't worry I will update this )    Lead mighty armies of the Empire to victory! Capture lost Karaks and reclaim the lost honour of the Dwarves! Raise hundreds of long dead warriors to attack and become the rightful rulers of the Empire! Sound the battle horns of the beastmen and spread Chaos upon those that uphold law and order! Conquer the whole world as Archaon the Everchosen with the end times and countless Norscans and Daemons or you can just 'smash eads an crake skullz' with Grimgor Ironhide!

I have not had the chance to finish this, but I would have to give it a mixed review. Overall, the gameplay is great. Everything looks wonderful and combat feels fun and challenging. A couple of things that break it for me are the endless repeated lines from the NPCs (I think they might only have one) and the really weird behaviors of the friendly AI.  One time I was walking along towards an objective, when suddenly a group of friendlies, which I did not even realise existed before this point, drove up and hopped out of the car (and all had identical character models. Creepy). I got in, drove a bit, and of corse managed to get the car stuck. I hopped out, tried to move it without luck, hopped back in without realising that the 'commandeer' option had popped up, and for some reason simply getting in the car caused everyone to shoot at me. A bit strange.  In any case, the game has been good. I would recomment it, and I have enjoyed it.

As far as I can tell, Planetside is a great game for teaming up with large groups of friends to take on enemies and work together in groups to make an experience where the skill of the individual is equally important as the teamwork between the players. This concept has been tried again, and again, but planetside offers a whole new look on this idea, with much, much larger servers to accomadate tons of players. This makes it more fun the play because your individual skrimishes seem more important and rewarding when the huge objective is completed.  That being said, I spent the first (and last) two hours of playing this game running around, not knowing what at all is going on. The two minute tutorials gave the player a general sense of how the average fps works without explaining the game at all. You are spawned into a giant hub where you press another button to be transported to who knows where, only to find yourself killed by some tank or aircraft camping your spawnpoint. After a few minutes, your team will do all of the work, causing you to either win or lose. Regardless, after that match is over, the whole thing will start all over again, throwing you into another viscious loop in which everyone blames you for being useless, (which of course, you are) but will not be willing to help you learn.  The mentoring system is a good step, but no game should force you look up help on the wiki or youtube videos just to be able to understand what is going on.  I am sure Planetside 2 is a great game, and I will keep playing for now, it looks like it may have quite a bit of potential, but I am sure that I am not the only one with such struggles. I can only assume that Planetside's poor introductory system is a insurmountable obstacle to people new to the game.  I am looking forward to understanding this game better so that I can write a more accurate and insightful reveiw.

Dota 2 will steal your money. This is my latest review of the game. This review is not about the game itself, but the criminal enterprise runnning it. I had spent a lot of money after returning to the game after a few months of not playing. I upgraded my compendium. I was even starting to enjoy it again. Then I told my party 'BRB', as I left to get a cup of coffee. Someone in the party didn't see that, started the search, and I was unable to accept. So what would be a fair thing to do to someone who wasn't there to hit the initial accept button? If you guessed a 24 hour ban from all methods of earning 'points', I'm sure there's a lot of rational people out there who are sickened by that punishment. This compendium is a limited time deal, and now we're getting banned if we happen to not rady up BEFORE the game even starts. Takes about 2 minutes to search. Why would one deserve a 24 hour ban, after he just spent >70$ on the game? This is by far the worst scam I've ever seen. Steam or anywhere, this is ridiculous. I'll be contacting the attorney genereral and I'm going to take every action I can to make sure this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t isn't allowed to happen. Some people unfamiliar with the law think they have a 'ToS', which to them means a license to do whatever you want, because you can pull that, 'consult the ToS' card. This private contract is very very criminal in my opinion. Where is legislation to prevent Valve from continuing to steal my money? They have the right to lock my funds in my steam account 'for my own protection'. Takes 8 days for them to unlock it after a ticket. Now they just stole $70 from me. I never want to see or play this game again. I'll be cancelling payment immediately on my credit card.  I've never seen anything this ridiculous from ANY company. Blizzard, you need to hurry up with the HOTS. I understand now why people play league of legends. Scheme after scheme after scam after theft with Dota and Valve. I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS GAME TO FRIENDS OR ENEMIES.

I joined PS2 way back. And I still play it today. So here is my review.   Pros: ~Large open world maps where you can fight up to over 200vs200 for a single point on one of the many maps.  ~Having such a large open world map means that there is pure freedom to how you fight. Not to mention the amount of weapons that are in the game can add an even more personal playstyle to your already custom playstyle.  ~Realistic flying space-ships that require skill to fly. (You feel like you're an actual pilot. This is my favorite part of this game)  ~Tons of ground vehicles such as: ATVs. Buggies. Tanks. Bigger tanks. And caravans.  ~The Developers are still going strong with this game; Adding stuff like new weapons, vehicles, bug-fixes, and help to those that need it.   ~Graphics are AMAZING.  Cons: ~Graphics are AMAZING, Which can be taxing on a PC, even at lowest settings. Especially in large scale battles where rockets, explosions, bullets, missiles, and tank shells are flying everywhere. This is the main cause to many of the FPS issues.  ~Due to the large scale of PS2, it can be hard for new players to get a grip of the game. But don’t worry; there are youtubers such as Wrel that are here to help!  ~The game can get repetitive after a while. I mean, all you do is fight one base, cap it, and move on to the next. Or if you’re on the losing side: Defend base, lose it, and move on to the next.  «------------------------»  All in all, this is one of the finest MMOFPS games out there.

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: The game is great in terms of atmosphere, story and music. But gameplay wise, it hasn't really aged that well. It's unfortunate that support for the game has seemed to have vanished in favour of its more refined successor, New Vegas.   It's overall a nice budget buy that will keep you busy for a long time, that is if you can mange to run it on your computer. This port is plagued with issues to the point that I can't even play it - and there really should be no excuse for this to happen. It's a shame. because I would love to check out some of the mods that the community has made.  I'm not saying that this is a bad game with my thumbs down review, I just don't recommend this particular port. Go for a console copy, it's the best way to go.

I enjoy Dota - what initially began as a way of connecting with my brother has evolved into a casual play when not conquering AoE/TW franchises or completing Skyrim for the fifth time - essentially, I continue to play Dota even after my brother defected to a second hand PS3. It's one of the very few multiplayer games I play after rage quitting RoTMG.   Here's the problem, I'm no good at Dota and after hours of gameplay, maybe I never will be. As previously mentioned, I dabble in a variety of games and like most, have a life outside fabricated worlds. I die often, fail to purchase 'necessary' gear, haven't learnt how to opperate a courier - nor do I feel then need to. The urge to win isn't strong enough to study Dota - win or lose, its been a good game if I've tried my hardest to support/carry victory. Understand I've won about half the amount of games played, half full.   I think most reading at this point are thinking - just GTFO. Its been the general response I've recieved during gameplay, and generally from team members. I can handle being called idiot and noob, even the rusty english some europeans hurl through their microphones - its harmless and almost pathetic, a laughable offense imo. I've even experienced games where team members will hang back when I've landed into danger/conflict with the enemy - and then be complained to about feeding stats, even if together we could have outweighed the opposition.  I've even been reported - its actually what spurred me to type this review, when I last logged onto Dota I was greeted with yet another drop down in priority. Admittedly, I quit the last game I was in prematurely just because I could be bothered with three angry european/american mix slinging abuse my way - instead I went to go make a sandwich. The agression this game brings out in some people makes Dota feel as if you're grinding through the majority of an hour, necessary back up replaced with heaps of swears.   Pro's  - Beautifal, intense, fast-paced gameplay. - Fantastic balance in characters & roles.  - Responsive & simple to control.  Con's  - A considerate amount of abuse if you're new to the game. - A considerate amount of reports if you're new to the game.  - The least helpful, most angry gamers in a server I've ever seen.  Do I recommend this game?   Yes - If you're a seasoned player  No - If you're just a beginner

Chivalry is a breath of fresh air in an industry that seems to be stagnating; Chivalry: Medieval Warfare delivers the innovation and creative rebirth for us that have been craving something new.  Though not the first Melee Medieval FP game, Chivalry: Medieval Warfare takes from Mount and Blade: Warband and exands on it ten fold.  Pros:  -Addicting, fast-paced and intense gameplay and sword fights will have you losing track of time -Swordplay is heavily skill-based, and requires you to dodge, feign, overhead, stab, strafe, duck, and use directional swings, but for the love of god please watch your swings in a mosh pit.  -Weapons are incredibly satisfying to use, and both feel and are powerful.  -Well designed game-modes and objective based games let us experience the true potential of team based gameplay.  -Although built in the over-used Unreal Engine, the game still manages to look beautiful, from god-rays to the detailed armor and gore.  -Classes are relatively well-balanced overall.  -Map designs are varied, from sand enviornments to lush forests to keeps and castles and desecrated citidals.  Cons:  -Archers are still OP. (Look into your heart, you know this to be true)  -The balance and fairness of some weapons remain up for debate.  -Teammates do not know how to use overheads and stabs and will likely decapitate you in a mosh pit.  -Server browser is slow and a painful experience to work with; joining friends could be easier.  The game is great. Playing with a buddy is massive fun. But for your own sake, please do the tutorial and ALWAYS go into teamfights with the assumption that your teammates have no idea what they're doing, because they WILL get you killed, especially since this game does go on free-to-play weekends pretty often.

Put simply, there much better MOBA's out there. The characters are boring and one-dimensional save a few (Broodmother and Sven are really the only interesting ones.) The game is just a glorified shadow on Defense of the Ancients.  While many praise it's unique factors, it does nothing to set itself apart from any other MOBA. There are plenty of FTP MOBA's out there, and seeing another top-down, barebones, and somewhat fustratingly repressive scenario is getting old.  As for laning, it's boring as hell when compared to other games like SMITE, League of Legends, and HotS. Unlike most other MOBA's, you are very restricted in your spell usage. Even something as simple as regenerating yourself for 30% of your HP costs upwards to 60% of your mana, and it DOES NOT come back quickly. Expect to spend the first 15 minutes of the game right clicking on uninspired minions that look like reject sprites from Warcraft 3...oh wait. They kind of are, in a way.  So with these oppressive mana costs, don't expect high-action, blood-pumping team-fights you come to expect from the genre... especially when 75% of the teamfight is spent with loss-of-control conditions like 4 second AoE stuns, constantly reapplied 70% movement speed slows, and 2.5 second snares on a 6 second cooldown. You know what makes a video game fun? Being able to play it.  For what the game does do well... not much. I do have to hand it to the guys at Valve, though. I like the Hats. Unlike other FTP MOBA's that generate revenue from entire skins that cost $10 a pop, you can customize your favourite Hero with all kinds of small do-dats that are virtually costless... in fact, many of them are rewards obtained for just playing the game regularily. Instead of Valve saying 'Hey kids, buy this recouled version of your favourite Skeleton King, only $10.00!' they instead say 'Here's a bunch of creative apparel; let the 8 year old girl in her grandmothers attic inside of you run wild! Oh, that'll be $0.35 by the way.' If I want to give my Spider Queen a top hat and monocle, they have an item for that; it's like the app store - you want it, they have it for less than $5.00.  My biggest complaint about the game... is the HUD. Enough is enough. I HAVE HAD IT WITH THIS GOD DAMN HUD ON MY GOD DAMN SCREEN! It's constantly getting in your way when you want to move around or scroll through the map (which is literally just 2 colours - green on one side and black the other. It's a VERY dull scene with little to no attention to detail.) In any other top-down MOBA, they did what the obvious step was - get the HUD out of the way. However in DotA 2, they instead decided that the HUD should take up 2/5 of the screen, and have as many buttons tthat could be accidently pressed when going toe-to-toe with the enemy, ruining your combo by putting a gigantic block in between you and the action saying 'This is your Hero's stats. I'm sure this is relevant to you right now, seeing as every millisecond in this genre could mean life or death.'  Over-all, the game is very lackluster when compared to other MOBA's, in some shape or form. If you are looking for a MOBA with beginner-friendly mechanics or a balanced playing field, try League of Legends. If you want to fell like a badass tearing your foes limb-for-limb with a great community and more skill-based system, try SMITE. If you are looking for a nostalgia bonor, play HotS. There is literally nothing in this game that other MOBA's can't offer you a better deal on other than customization.  Final Verdict: 7/10 in general, 3.5/10 by MOBA standards.

I have tons of hours in this game already and still I vote for 'no recommendation'?  This is not a game. Unless you are aiming to become a click master, that practises on clicking faster each time and genuinly tries to improve their clicking skills, this has no game elements what so ever. It requires hardly any thought or skills. Has no real purpose. No goals, no targets, nothing... After a while even the clicking becomes useless as it will be such a minor part of progress, you might as well just stare at the screen.  Addictive though.. Even while doing nothing you get 'presents' and achievements.As you get money while offline, you easilly want to go back just to 'check how much I have accumulated by now' and BAM!   You want to stare at a game while doing nothing, go check out something on Twitch or so. At least then you might encounter a fun streamer. In fact, even if the streamer is playing clicker heroes you still might get more out of the stream than the actual game.  This is not a review, this is a warning.

Goat Simulator is a joke of a game. You take control of a goat in a small town with absurd physics. A simple headbutt from the goat will blow up a car. The goat can climb ladders effortlessly and drag objects around with its tongue. The town is basically a small sandbox with several hours of things to do, but not much more than that. Goat Simulator is small, deliberately unpolished and buggy and its design is simple. But it is a really funny joke, full of great physics-powered slapstick humor and unexpected surprises in every corner of its seemingly peaceful small-town map. It is hard to recommend this game or even describe it, it is such a visual experience that you really should take a look at a video before buying and after that, either you want to move on, or you really need to play this game.  Sounds 4/10 Graphics 7/10 Gameplay 8/10 Atmosphere 10/10  If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:  http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guides   http://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curation

You will play this game not just because you might have heard of it and how challenging it is, but also because it is free. Then it will devour your soul in ways that made World of Warcraft feel like a game you only play during TV commercial breaks on a portable device.   You will play this game. You will play this game a lot. You will suck at first, but you will get better. You will feel good about yourself once you have learned how to play a few characters as you win a match here or there, but you will lose more than you win. Why? Because almost ten years since DotA All Stars, you continue to see things that you never thought were possible. You will continue to learn, but you will never be good, because you realize that there is always someone better than you. Yet you continue to play because you do get better. You do learn. You do win. And then you lose some more, and the cycle continues.   Such is the way of DotA player.
The game itself is nice. The only downside is, that the servers suck and events are often p2w or aren't working like they should.

I had previously written a positive review with strong caveats but am changing it to negative. At this point I feel that the bugs and the developers' ignoring of said bugs (especially after the release of the DLC) have too much of a negative impact on the game to enjoy anymore.  The game from a design standpoint is fantastic. They made the best melee combat system I've seen in a game and there's a good variety of maps and game modes to play around with. The style of the game with lots of gratuitous severing of limbs and decapitations and the ridiculous warcries gives it a nice over-the-top feel that make it a lot of fun.  Unfortunately there are many bugs, some of which completely destroy any concept of class and weapon balance, that have existed since release. The developers flat out refuse to acknowledge that these bugs even exist, much less fix them. They have shown themselves to be completely clueless about weapon balance as well, often buffing the stronger weapons in patches and nerfing the weaker ones. From what I understand the situation has only gotten worse since the release of the DLC. Every server is pretty much guaranteed to have several people exploiting these bugs and ruining it for everybody else.  So while I did have a lot of fun with the game when it was new, mostly before the bugs were widely exploited, there's no way I can recommend it now.

Massive eternal war.    Presentation:  7 The game was released in 2012 so the graphics are not as good as it would be if it was released today, but because it was PC exclusive back then the graphics have aged well and are still quite good. The audio was fairly good to begin with and has been updated several times to be even better. Each faction has unique designs for their soldiers, weapons and vehicles. Each continent has a unique climate and look.   Gameplay:  7 It's a class/loadout based shooter like battlefield with land and air vehicles. It also now features resource gathering and base building. Battles are not usually determined by individual skill, but by the amount of players and the equipment available to the players. Battles can contain hundreds of players.   Story:  5 The different factions don't like one another because of political differences. It's a multiplayer only game without characters, so players are left to create their own stories.   Total:  6.7/10

Tl;Dr - If you're looking for a quick fix for your Total War itch, don't bother here. If you really dig the fantasy setting or already own the previous Total War installments, get Warhammer at a 50% discount minimum. This should have been an expansion back for Attila (price point-wise).  I know I'll get a lot of flack for not liking this iteration of Warhammer come to life in an RTS game, but frankly, it's not the idea of Warhammer I don't like, it's the implementation. Essentially I was pleasantly surprised to see CA go after the Warhammer franchise. A franchise that combines fantasy and the joy of medieval combat sounds like a dream come true, right? Unfortunately, the result is far from the truth.  Quite frankly, this game is a dissapointment on so many levels for me. While you can still get enjoyment out of it, especially if you are a hardcore Warhammer fan, that does not make up for the sheer lack of overall effort that shows everytime you boot a game up. But enough of that, let's get started with the usual list!  Pros:  1. The graphics - The game looks good...I mean...REALLY good. It has plenty of visual flair and charm despite my growing distate for the game as a whole.  2. Leaders - For the most part each leader adds a new and interesting mechanic to your battles, a nice change of pace from the political setups from Rome 2 and Attila.  3. Siege and Regular Battles - Regular battles have different visual styles that vary based on location, whilst sieges can certainly look gorgeous they also have MAJOR cons that we'll get to shortly.  4. No Politics/children - This one just speaks for itself.  And now, the Cons:  1. Complete lack of quanitity - So, remember when I made the jab at Atilla with 'Attila Lite' in my last review? Yeah, Warhammer is even worse, which you would almost think to be impossible. Now I get that there are only so many races, but dear gods, one faction per race? Seriously? And people try to justify that? Basically if you want to play coop with someone you cannot be the same race despite there being multiple factions per race. You also cannot play a different faction after you've grown tired of playing the exact same starting position with the exact same enemies around you. And no, different lords do not add enough variety to change that.  2. Great Power Debuff - This one just speaks for itself.  3. Agents - It was a pretty cool idea to have 'heroes' that you can use to bolster your army, such as using a Dwarven Engineer to increase the stats and reload speed of your artillery. Each hero has unique abilities for each race and you could really benefit from them in battle....oh...you say that the AI will only use them like agents from the previous Total War games and eventually you'll be dealing with the six or so agents from all your enemies that are completely unstoppable just like Attila? Well that was a waste of time.  4. Enemy Units Routing...Psych! - Yeah, this is probably the worst and most unrealistic part of Warhammer, a univese with gryphons (griffons?) and dragons. Picture this, you're in a close battle with the enemy lord, your troops have flanked his best warriors and you've decimated the enemy archers and horseman. Now all that's left is to bring this battle to a clo-....wait....why are my Hammerers dropping like flies? *glance around map for hidden units* Why the hell is that archer unit of only 10-20 men back in battle? ♥♥♥♥♥! How did that horseman unit of 15 come back and flank my warriors?! Yeah, get ready for this constantly happening. It's annoying and drags out battles for far too long. You'll constantly find weak units coming back. My advice? Don't even bother playing the dwarves if that annoys you. The Slayers are the only thing you'll have that can run down those units to make sure they don't come back.  5. Settlements/Cities - Wow do these look half-♥♥♥♥♥, just from the in-game ui alone. Do you remember Yu-Gi-Oh? How about Pegusus' Toon world? Yeah. That's pretty much what every city looks like from the grand campaign...toon towns.  6. Siege Battles - And now for the largest let down of all. I'm sure you've already heard of this, but siege battles suck. About 1/4 of the city is available to you, limiting your encirclment options to a head-on charge, Units pull ladders out of their hidden bags of holding, lodged somewhere securely in their rears, and when you get on the enemy walls? Yeah, your units get down by clipping through the battlements...Such a showcase of effort and time right there. But the worst part? The cities actually look really good, especially the background art. All of which just makes you wish for an actual siege battle like the previous games.  7. Siege Battles Continued - Settlements don't have siege battles unless you've builts walls. What does that mean? It means no more using choke points to your advantage on low level settlements, instead you get to fight on a generic battle map. I guess those budget cuts even hit your engineers.  At the end of the day, the best I can say about Warhammer is that it looks pretty. That it has potential. But sadly there's very little effort and quality here, especially when compared to previous Total War entries (Attila included). The lack of faction choices within each race is a sour taste every time you start a new game, especially so if you plan to play coop. Creatively, Warhammer is a step in the right direction for CA, but from a mechanic and quality standpoint it's miles behind Shogun 2.  9/25 Edit - Spell check

This is probably my favorite Total War game to date! Medieval II will always have a special place in my heart, since it was my first Total War, but I can honestly say I can foresee myself getting just as much if not  more  time and fun out of Total War: WARHAMMER. Especially if those two expansions work out, as I am positive they will. As a life-long fan of Warhammer Fantasy, but having never really been able to get into the hobby, this combination of games is something I've been dreaming about for a long time.  Each of the four factions are fantastically diverse, both on and off the field! The Dwarfs keep their book of grudges, the Greenskins build their Waaagh!, the Empire with their politics, and the Vampire Counts who can raise new armies from the dead!  The battles look phenomenal, the units are really well-done. The magic system is fantastic too, lots of fun and really looks great sweeping across the enemy lines!  The battle maps are all gorgeous too, absolutely stunning. Plenty of terrain diversity, and sometimes obstacles to fight around!  At the time of writing this, I also own the Chaos and Beastmen DLCs, and I have to say this game is worth every penny I've put into it so far. I normally don't write too many reviews, as I'm sure you can tell by the quality of this one, but the rating this game is getting on Steam is just plain unfair to it.

If this is all that's running on your PC and you can manage to play well enough to get kills and/or enjoy yourself you'll find that time quickly blinks by.  I recommend using the Recursion Tracker for increased encouragement (and/or discouragement from deaths) by listening to Radlock taunt in the guise of the old Unreal Tournament announcer.  I'm not a vehicle guy, but the infantry combat is addictive beyond belief. It may seem impossible to fight back against vehicles as anything but a Heavy Infantry or MAX, but there's a reason for that: other vehicles! Air is the answer to all opposition. With enough air support an entire base can be captured with minimal infantry.  The level of immersion and tactics possible make me keep coming back. It helps to be able to pay full attention and really immerse yourself in the voice chat and squad play. Solo has its moments, but the real enjoyment comes from contributing to your squad and helping your faction capture the point from your sworn enemies.  Finally, I implore you to pledge your allegience to a single faction. Those loyal to their empire such as myself feel an intense pride when capturing points due to this cooperation and sense of camaraderie we get with our fellow soldiers as we throw our cloned selves back into the fray to claim ground even if just for a short while.

The developers of Chivalry: Medieval Warfare have been killing the game steadily since launch. They have practically refused to fix bugs and problems but continued to make updates to worsen the gaming experience. The controls and mechanics have been unreliable from the beginning, and the hit boxes are among the worst in multi-player gaming. If it wasn't bad enough, they then released the idiotic Deadliest Warrior DLC for $15. Performance, stability, and the technical aspects of the game are also well below standard, leaving much to be desired overall.  Chivalry: Medieval Warfare is mediocre.

Far Cry 3 is really easy to recommend but it's also a really easy game. I can't recall ever having a hard time doing anything. The game is beautiful, feels great, plays great, sounds great, but lacks a large amount of challenge. Most of the sections of the game which didn't just throw you into the action are all able to be completed with stealth. You're even rewarded extra experince for being stealthy, so it's not like the game isn't encouraging it. But when the action picks up, its still pretty easy. Headshots aren't difficult to pull off, plus you're practically invincible, all you have to do is keep pulling that bullet out of your left arm and snapping your finger back into place and you'll be A okay. The AI isn't briliant, the enemy will just be trained on your position and move forward, nothing complex coming from them. Plus your skills encourage easy mode, like the takedown ability. Next thing you know your knife is the primary weapon. The story is interesting and goes places, some of the characters are alright, some are great but they don't all come together in a good way to really make the story. The whole idea of the game is based around you saving all your friends and thats all but a fragment of what the game wants to tell you instead. It's a bit jarring to go back to the little cave you're hidding you're friends in because it really chops the game up. Far Cry 3 is worth playing at a cheap price, because it is a fantastic open world game, just don't expect much of a challenge at all.

What is Goat Simulator?  Recently there has been a lot of hype revovling around this game for its randomness and such, but is it really worth it to buy and play? Better question, will this game last you a long time, or at least long enough to get maybe a decent amount of hours in before your sick of it? For I regretably found the creul truth of this game, it's just not enough fun. There isn't nearly enough fun, wacky things to do as a goat in this game to keep you occupied. Of course, just as I did, you'll have an hour or so when you'll say something like'BEST GAME EVER!', later you'll find out it's more of a in the moment feeling. I did have a good hour or so when it felt like it was so much fun, not knowing what to screw up as a goat next, but then very soon it was evident, the game got boring. (THE GAME LIVES OFF THE FACT OF YOU BEING A GOAT TOO MUCH!!!)  What do you do in the game?  The game consists of you, a goat, being well, a goat. You basically terrorize a small(and I mean SMALL) town and do what ever you really feel like whether it's ruin a family's dinner or grab a big boulder with your tounge and hurt stuff(kind of fun). Your main things you can do are move around with the W,A,S,D keys(duh), run with the shift key, use the E key to grab to stuff with your tounge and take it somewhere(maybe out for dinner?) and of course jump with the SPACE BAR. Also as you do more things in the game more small abilities unlock like the GOATBORN, which is basically you being able to Fus Ro Da as a goat, which I admit, can be fun.  Should I Buy This Game?  Really I don't know if I can tell you the answer completly, but I may be able to push a little towards my idea of the situation. This game is is fun for only how long you let it be fun. By that I mean it's fun only if you sort of have an imagination or like just messing around with no real incentives, or goals. Personally, when I play a game I feel I need some sort of goal to push towards and acheive because well that's sort of what makes a lot of games fun. Now there are a few small 'goals' you can do, but nothing really worth going into depth like doing a backflip, but earning nothing in return, horay. So if you want to spend 10$ on this game go ahead, just remember, the game in a nutshell dosen't have much substance to it so it won't last long if you don't like just messing around.  NOTE: Also just like to note that there isn't any multiplayer, but there is a workshop kind of thing where you can doownload other people's maps, which could grant a few more hours of play.   VERDICT: 7/10 It's Ok  Pro Your a goat Gives you a good laugh Only 10$(Could also be a con couldn't though?) Good if your bored one afternoon and have nothing to do   Con Causing destruction and such gets old after a while Graphics glitch out(I realize that it's suppose to be in the game, but can be annoying) No goals or at least anything really worth striving to do  Costs 10$

So you wanted to see a Dota 2 review huh? Well Dota is a pretty great game id say being the fact that ive spent my life on it and is still working on it. Dota 2 is a great game like i said but for newcomers its very very very hard to get into it. The reason for this is because the community in Dota can be very toxic. You dont know if you go into a game and find a bratty player that will only do the things that he wants and if he doesnt then he ruins the game for you. Id recommend that if you're getting into dota, play several bot matchs and change the difficulty to challenge yourself and then once you have over come that step go to the online bot matchs and meet newcomers and work on your team capapility skills and further on. Later after you get the logistics of the game youll want to head to the public mattch making and play there. Note: At least have 10 heros that you can play and be able to play different roles. After quite some time in the public matchmaking id recommend playing ranked matchmaking and test yourself to see if youre strong enough for the pros.

When I first started this game, I was struck by it's immediate warning, which had the words 'light', 'loud' and 'scare' - already that sounded like the kind of passive agressive / insane temperament I was forced to grow up with as a child in Long Island, NY in the 1980's.   After many hours being in Freddy Fazbear's Pizzeria, I can say this place is one that you owe yourself, as a human being who uses a computer, watches films, and likes a good story - to vist at least once.  I appreciate the source of emotion this game uses - the fear of inanimate objects being imbued with life - the sadness of tainted childhood (let alone - LOST childhood...) - the anger at an unappreciate employer (you have NO idea what I have been through...!) - the joy of victory...that last one will only last briefly.   The plot is that you are a night watchman at a nearly defunct children's party place, akin to a Chucky Cheese, which was the source of video games/arcades in the 1980's and is what helped even spawn the popularity of games today (this game, in essence - is a twisted homage to the very origin of mainstream gaming). The game was 'sold' to me that you were making sure the puppets do not move, and do not come to your room. I was very confused - to me this game looked HORRIFYING but there was no hint at the horror, and it felt more like a 'Killer Klowns From Outer Space' mixed with 'Child's Play' type of experience...why are all these screenshots so scary, yet the gameplay sounding so innocent?  Because the game itself relies on your fear: of the strange, of adults, and of corruption.  The things I love most about this game are unfortunately, what I feel most big budget developers, and most gamers now, would and will try to change. I see 'complaints' about Five Nights At Freddy's, but to me, are it's sordid virtues:  - The game cannot be played in windowed mode (which means..no distractions! - when you play, you are immersed in the game as if you were playing it on a TV/Console or Arcade - you can't multitask, typing in Word, ordering crap on Amazon, changing songs in iTunes, check your Wordpress, Facebook, Farm, etc. etc.)  - The game can't change resolution or 'insert setting here' (because the developer perfected it for you - this game is an artfully created experience - it's like a video game version of a French Film from the 60's - it's an 'auteur' at work - the game's creator knows what he is doing, trust him - and go with the sound settings and graphics he picked - let the 'Five Nights At Freddy's' take you as its prisoner.....in every way...)  - There is no save setting (The beauty of this game is that an enjoyable play session can go anywhere from 2-20 minutes - and the learning curve is steep - save settings and short levels become redundant)  This game is worth every penny of it's price. I purchased it based on it's uniqueness and that it spoke to me as a lover of a good story well told. I was rewarded with an amazingly crafted and simple Puzzle Horror game that I could play at day or night - and within seconds be swept away to an intense little cramped office, where all that mattered was immediate survival - 'Five Nights At Freddy's' is not just about watching cute animatronic characters in a security camera - it's about why you're watching them - are we as 'dumb' as the person who took this job? Maybe he just wanted a scare and a challenge too.  Play it, enjoy it - take your time - then go watch a horror film and play a game - 'Five Nights At Freddy's' is an ode to both.

I wish there was an 'Okay' button because this game would have deserved that place. But since there isn't I'm going to have to rate this up. The thing is with this game is that it's too short. I did everything (aside from those Ubisoft races) in about 24 hours. The story is great but the ending was meh and the gameplay feels amazing and the graphics are great. But as well with other Ubisoft games, they have great content but it's short and not too many. You can liberate Outposts and (hack?) Towers so you can have view on that part of the Island on your map. But here's the catch, there's only 34 Outposts. It may seem a lot to you when you first start playing but when you get farther into the game it's not that much. Once you finish the storyline and do all the Outposts and Towers you're done with the game. All you can basically do is explore the island once you are done, which is nice but it gets boring after awhile. Multiplayer is dead so don't even try finding one. Buy this when it's on sale because it's worth the $30 (it's the price of the game at this time of review) but at the same time it doesn't. I just wish this game was filled with Outposts like 50 or 100 but that would get too repetitive but atleast it would give you something to do. This game has about 22 hours in total of things to do but in all honesty, just buy it when it's on sale. Great game just too short.

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: It's better than Fallout New Vegas, and it's better than the Elder Scrolls games. Don't let the Steam game time fool you. I originally started playing on X360 when I was 16, maybe 17. I've also played a lot through a script extender, and I'm not sure if it keeps track of those hours since I wasn't able to access Steam Overlay. I've probably put over 500 hours into this game. I've collected so many clothing items, building items, weaponry, and random collectibles in this game for the sole purpose of hording it all and having more options. I would be willing to bet I had every single melee and every ranged weapon in the game, and just about every clothing item if not all of them. I visited EVERY SINGLE location on the map, even all the metro tunnels including all their nook and crannys. Hell I'd even visited just about, if not all of the indoor areas, so I downloaded mods for new areas with interesting twists. The urge to explore and collect everything in the capital wasteland is so high. every hidden back story must be known. But there I was, I'd collected about everything and seen and done about everything. So what did I do? I installed more mods to make the game more difficult, to make me feel like more a of survivor of the wastes. I can't even begin to describe how difficult it had been at times, but it was important to me to make it more realistic after I'd had a chance to complete everything. This game can be a collector and explorers dream. And it can also be a gritty, dark, and difficult survival game. If it weren't for the fact that I've simply run out of things to do besides replay everything I've already done (of which, I've restated this game innumerable times), I'd probably still be playing this game all the time.  This game is crack.

This is not a game for Those Horror fans that like to feel like they can avoid the danger if they are smart enough.   Welcome to Freddy's Fazbear's Pizza, where 4killer animatronic Robots want you dead every moment of every night during your entire shift.  This game does well in what it aimed to do, cause the player feel helpless, and scared, and having them endure each level on the skin of thier teeth. For normal fans of horror, this game probably is not a good fit, unless you enjoy feeling helpless and like the game is short changing your resources. This game comes down to Understanding the pattern of the Four Robots, knowing how to prevent an attack, managing your resource of limited, unrechargable energy, and a quick ear, and luck.  This game also offers a very extensive lore, that is revel only enough to make the player feel like there's some sort of story, but not giving the full picture, cause many fans to theorize what the story is based on in game clues. This is also a negative point though, since the fanbase is childish, most theroies are half baked, and is overall annoying.  7/10 New good concept good execution good feels controls good  not for the typical Horror fan Based more on luck than skill in highest difficulty awful fanbase

So i yet to complete the game so i can't talk much about it.  Here is what i like.  Great graphics, yea the game looks really good, even tho the enemies do need more variety and the landscape may get bored to look at after 10 plus hours. The main missions are very good. Lots of things to do. Ecology and unpredictable creatures make the world come alive. Role-playing elements and difficulty curve make u play more than once. Good multiplayer for this type of game. Lots of weapons and ways to enjoy combat.  Here is what i don't like about the game.  Easy money, yea u get money so fast in this game that just 5 hours into the game u have money to buy the best weapons, money u don't really need since the game gives weapons for FREE. Generic side quests. One word, BORING... Enemy AI is laughable sometimes. Stealth is also not that well implemented which might lead to minor frustrations. Spawns and spawn rates are stupid. Kill all enemies in the area?, wait too long others will spawn and u have to do it all over again. Gunplay is not that good. U will notice this, if u play other FPS games like BF or COD. The wildlife is way too overpower, takes for EVER to kill animals. The main hero who is over sensitive to drops (you could literaly kill yourself by jumping from 3m height!) Also the game may get bored too soon if u get all weapons and done all the crafting upgrades.  So, overall Far Cry 3 is a good game, but one that has a lot of things to work before it becomes great. There r just too many flaws for me personally to completely enjoy it, but enough to recommend to people that might like this type of games.

Planetside 2 is FREE. It's FREE and it's pretty good quality for such a FREE game. It's hard to complain about when the game is FREE, but the game is actually a little difficult to jump into right away. There is a bit of a learning curve and it can be kind of frustrating sometimes. However, once you get a grasp on the concept of how the game works and what you need to do or where to go then it can be quite enjoyable from time to time. The gameplay itself is best decribed as a mix between Battlefield 1942 and the original Tribes but on a much more massive scale. You've got hundreds of people fighting on the same continent so if you have a weaker PC, it might get choppy. The graphics are really nice. Very impressive for a free to play game. I really wish there was a way to win a game. There is no end to it, unfortunately. It's just constant battle you're trying to control points around the world for your faction. But whatever, it's free and it's fun enough. Download it.

I'm going to write an actual simple review for this. The game is stupid. The physics are wacky. I've broken it a few times. Do I regret it? No. This game is 'stupid' in that there isn't a story behind it at all. To be honest, this actually may end up sparking your imagination to the point you make up a story. Why is this goat going on a rampage? Why is it made of a living indestructible alloy? And just why is everyone named in such weird ways?  It's hard to explain how the controls feel, just that they feel right. Your goat does do silly things at times despite your objections, but don't be afraid to smile.  Bugs? Oh, they exist. But many of them are so-called 'good bugs' and seeing the world go insane because you attained the correct procedure to do so and you can be in tears. As of this writing, I have yet to experience a bug that has killed my amusement.  Honestly, for the amount of money you'll pay for it, I think it's definitely worth it. I've had a lot of fun so far with it in just my 2 hours of it, and if you're looking for some simple laughs for an afternoon or so, it may just be worth it to you as well.

I dont play (ok, played) this on my PC but on my Tablet.. I thought I write my warning here..  The game is a time waster.. very good one.. and became with the last update even MORE time waster. Let me explain. The game is a resource game.. running in real time. You can play it clicking your ♥♥♥ off, play it idle and do nothing at all beside a few clicks every here and then.. or a mix of both.  I played a mix, as sometimes I want to click a bit and other times I prefer to sleep! :p So for 5 days I wasted my time.. and I felt very sorry for myself during game time.. why am I wasting my life with this? Anyhow.. got myself a little setup and reached Lv400 in 50min on my farm run for hero souls. Got about 350 on average on a run. Skilled mainly chance to spawn a Primal Boss and Hero Souls drop amount plus more gold in IDLE mode. I was happy wasting my time... and the update came.. no question, do you want to upgrade? Just suddenly I got way more Hero Souls.. niiiice, what a lucky run.. when I hit over 1k Souls.. I started to understand, something goes different as usual. Bed time.. started game again next day and screen pops up.. Transcence bla bla.. Help Screen to explain it all.. like a lerner driver gets this instruction: Open Door of the car, start car, drive as it is demanded by law, park and exit car. So.. basicly nada! Next I start my run.. why are my heroes not guilded anymore?? Why does all take soooooooo much longer? To make it short.. that is what r2games sold you. We made a upgrade and BALANCED the game. How unbalanced it was before.. example: My next upgrade for chance to get a primal boss was 72 Hero Souls... after the update +86k Hero souls.. so the developper thought it needed a balance to a skill that was 1 : 1200 out of balance. Yes, but we gave you more Hero Soul income too... true.. went from 400 average to 1500 on a run.. lets say 4 time more... to 1200 more cost.. my same farm run of 50min is now over 3 hours... and instead of beeing able to upgrade my chance for hero boss 3 times on one farm run to 400.. I would need over 50 runs for 1 upgrade. So wasting time is one thing, this is just simply super stupid.. I guess to many people came to the end of 'get arthritis when you are old game'.. and instead of putting some brain into it.. they just made everything a s h i t l o a d take more time.  So all in short: If you want to kill your last brain cells with boredom, if you cant understand or play games, which demands at least an IQ of 90.. this is your game and you will LOVE it!!! In any other case.. do yourself a favor, man... drill yourself a hole in your head.. makes more sense than playing this game for brain dead idiots. This is THE game for street cleaners, garbage men and bums living under the bridge.. about the IQ you need to play this junk and think this is a great game..

My Grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him, 'If you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately.'. Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exactly was at stake. He gave it up immediately Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- 'Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your Grandfather put us through. ' I agreed. At 28, I have never touched a cigaretter. I must say, I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it, because this game gave me cancer anyway.

I haven't played Total War games before and when i heard about the Warhammer based game i desided to give it a try. Unfortunately the game is built around experienced players only.   The tutorial contains 2 videos that explain how the controlls work in the battle, nothing about how you actually should use your units. The in game tutorial is a very easy battle that you really don't have to do anything to win. while in game you suddenly discover heroes that cannot be killed by regular armies but can assasinate your general or block your path every turn making your life miserable. nothing of this even mentioned in the 'tutorial'. not to mention the computer almost always manages to get almost 2 times as much soldiers as i have at the location despite me having max army cap on the hero and all that on 'normal' difficulty. if you are new to this series prepare to dig into the guides and streams or youtube videos becose thats how you learn to play this game, really dissapointing...  Edit: after some learning(?!): 1) the game feels very linear in the research trees and building trees. very little meaningfull choise to make there and some technologies are just overal better than the alternatives. 2) one resource economy, rare resources are available but depending on your race you may not have any allies to trade them with at all. you can manage economy by just building a few income buildings in your provinces and not recruiting unneeded armies. very simple. 3) agents - the game is about agents not armies, they can assasinate enemy heroes and leader, kill their armies, prevent them from moving, and all that without even declaring war on them. to top it out they can only be killed by other agents so you must have leveled agents or when the computer brings his agents you will be helpless against them. watching how they murder your army.  verdict, very weak and boring for strategy lovers. if you are looking for a nice strategy to force you to think and customize your empire keep looking nothing for you here. if you like the series, warhammer lore and or simplified strategies you might want to check this out.

An amazing free to play FPS. If your computer can handle the big battles, then this is a must. Nothing is more satisfying than getting into an epic base assult/defense when all three sides meet at one point. Turrets, planes, tanks, and 100's of infantry all in the space of a full size battlefield rush map. The unlocking system is balanced without having to pay for higher guns, and those who do pay for them aren't completely dominant due to the quantitiy of players. Teams engaging in real battlefield tactics can dominate a higher number force, but usually battles are just wave after wave of bodies. For a true battle sim, go play arma instead.

Beautiful visuals, clever AI, outstanding vehicles and a glitch-free single player campaign top the list of strengths on this latest tropical-island-of-death title. Players would be well-advised to stop and smell the roses (and maybe craft them into a syringe) in Far Cry 3, however, to avoid the occasional feeling of repetitive gameplay and an obnoxiously drawn out finale in the story mode.   Multiplayer maps are large and mostly well designed but such efforts are too often undermined by underpopulated matches and poor matchmaking that results in disconnections and game crashes.  If you don't already own a title in this well reviewed franchise, Far Cry 3 won't be a regrettable purchase if you grab it on sale and can stomach the anguish of Ubisoft's 'uPlay' DRM and the limited multiplayer possibilities.  STEAM IN-HOME STREAMING RATING: Acceptable. uPlay DRM game launching headaches and some artifacting issues with occasional framerate drops.

Well, Here's what I have to say about Warhammer Total War (TL;DR at the bottom)  First off, one of the best Warhammer games ever made (I still really miss Horned Rat though). As CA's first forray into this universe, I have to say, despite some minor details left to be desired, I had a lot of fun, and I will still have a lot of fun as I try new things and engage more with the different races. I see the potential this IP has, and I want to encourage CA to continue making this experience more vibrant and more in depth. As new races come out and as new features are added, I think this will be one of their best games.  On the tech side, this is one of the smoothest experiences I have ever had when dealing with a Total War game which made me almost cry in joy. On a campaign side... ehhh... They took a few steps back from the normal series, but considering this is the first stab, I can forgive some things. As new installments come out, I will be pretty picky for improvements and MOAR LORE haha.   Quest battles were fun! I just wish that they went a little more in depth with the characters, scripts, and events in game. Most of the time, when Chaos came, I merely shrugged my shoulders and sent my finest armies to meet Archaon head on and nipped him in the bud... So, on that note, more lore, more quests, more story, but overall? It satiated my bloodlust for dead orcs, vampires (ha!), Empire secessionists, stunties, and chaos scoundrels. I did play as all the races except for Dwarves. I'm getting to them, but I really wanted to get my demigryph fix in first haha. I had a great time as all of them, and might I recommend Blood for the Blood God DLC - while I feel like it should be in the base game, It makes everything soooooooooo much more rewarding.  The mechanics are fun, and I appreciate the detail to each race. That was well done where each race had distinct advantages and disadvantages. So, it did NOT feel like Attila in that department.   While the DLC policy annoys me, the developer did make a great base game. The DLC? I'll just wait patiently for a sale and get them all when it's time. the FreeLC is awesome, and it comes to me as a well appreciated little bonus considering they really don't have to do jack for us. The updates and support also meets above satisfaction, so I really can't complain too much.  If we think of this as a first step to something better, then it explains a lot. As a Total War game, it regressed a lot in mechanics, but it also really fine tuned a lot of problems I experienced in other titles in combat, balance, diplomacy, trade, raiding, and conquering. I personally love that I don't have to take over the entire map. I mostly wnated to leave barren wastes in my wake, and I did. It was epic. The really cool thing is that they didn't always stay barren for long! New races and people moved in, and it made the world soooo much more realistic and fun! I had to constantly change strategies because a new race popped up and suddenly decided to live in the barren wasteland near my border.   Considering it's their first stab at the Warhammer universe, and let's face it... most Warhammer games are half ♥♥♥♥♥ and barely playable... the fact that I can sit down and play a Warhammer game that's pretty entertaining, well detailed (JESUS THAT WORLD MAP IS PRETTY), and has a lot of really fun stuff to do and accomplish, I mean... seriously. I'm just glad it finally happened. I'm having a good time.   If you don't like the price, wait for it to go down during the Winter Sale - I don't regret a single penny (unlike Attila).  So, TL/DR: great Warhammer game (FINALLY); Not too shabby Total War Game (regressed in mechanics and gameplay, but still fun and solid). Don't like the price of base game or DLC? No problem, just wait for the Winter Sale - won't kill ya.

For me, the worst thing is that all these animation glitching super skilled 'pro' players ruin the atmosphere of the game.   It used to be so fun playing a first person medieval combat game that had some real weight behind it. Everything felt pretty much right, and win or lose, some epic confrontations/scenarios would often play out. Now, you go on and see all these warriors spinning around, flailing whatever weapon in random directions to exploit the animation/hitbox engine for cheap kills. Winning has become everything. Why can't we just play more realistically and just have some fun in a medieval game?

Warning, no matter how cool this game may look when the proffesionals play it, don't play this game. There is no balance. Every Hero is meant to be 'overpowered' yet half the bloody Hero Selection is never chosen because the same easy2win Heroes are picked every time.   Every other champion has a stun or some form of disruption, and failing that they have way too much damage. Better still, many of easy2win champions have a stun/disruption AND twice as much damage as you.  Don't think the game is really technical with all it mechanics, you'll go up against the same Heroes that are barely skillful in their own mechanics, and tend to bolster this stupidity with the most stupid ideas for items. Items can give your high damage, long ranged carry an easy escape with invisibility. Need to shred the armor of the enemy? Sure there is an item for that too! Stun? Yep. Evasion? Oh yes. They have all these and more to make characters more and more ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t to play against.  Oh, and you shouldn't expect to make a comeback unless the game is close, and 70% of games have 1 person fed by 15 minutes in. And you can't surrender. Enjoy being ♥♥♥♥♥ for a good 20 minutes as you wait for them to push into your Ancient.

I was pleasantly surprised by the 9GB download. The game will unpack to 21GB so make sure to install it onto your SSD. I have not encountered any bugs or crashes as of yet.   Visuals are wonderfull. If you have any interest in the Warhammer universe you will probably enjoy this game. Hero management is quite fun.  One issue I find frustrating is the way enemy Hero will route when 1v1ing your Hero. Watching your hero try and chase down their fleeing opponent is anti-climactic, especially when it's a big Orc boss. I would prefer they fought to the death. I not a fan of how enemy Heroes can be re-recruited after you kill them. It was disheartening to finally kill Grimgor, only to have him respawn later on.  I would also like battles to be a little bloodier, it would make them feel heavier and speak to the violence that Warhammer is associated with. I assume there will be a 'Blood and Gore' DLC pack like there was for Rome 2. So I suppose I will wait and see.  Overall it's a lot of fun, and will expectedly be iteratively improved upon by CA.

I feel compelled to wright a review of this because this SHOULD be a good game.  The concept and play style of this game are great. The objective matches are fun, ffa is a blast, and team deathmatch is excellent. However you will quickly get over the fun of cleaving heads and arms from bodies when you try to improve your skills. Thats where things get frustrating.  There is some skill required to time your stikes and parrys correctly and that is an excellent dynamic, however, it all really comes down to your ping, and your enemies ping in the end. You will freqiently see your arrows pass through others, blows that land, but dont, and you'll be beheaded by enemies that are not even swinging their weapons. The differences between how you perceive your moves and how the sprites perform are sluggish as best. This makes the combat clunky and hard to use, and you find quickly that there are a few weapons and classes that make buttonmashing an easy way to accidentally kill others.  Don't buy this game, maybe someday, some studio will make a great melee battle game but it pains me to say this isn't it. you'll have a few hours of fun maybe but then your left wanting more and wondering why this isn't early access or alpha build.

Far Cry 3 is all about adventure, carnage, the jungle aspect and getting the best guns for your assault type. There are a lot of areas where FarCry succeeds but many more where it simply falls through the floor.   Far Cry 3 offers a compelling storyline through the singleplayer campaign. It is almost unrivaled and allows you to take hold of a person and watch them grow from a normal friend-loving schoolboy to a psuedo-psycho badass of the jungle.   Multiplayer is completely broken as there a lot of bugs and hiccups along the way. The loadout option is pretty much useless as there is currently one build that destroys anything else that you put against it.   Coop is a very welcomed theme within the Far Cry series, it's just a shame it wasn't implemented into the overall storyline. Or atleast contained within it's own world. Rather than you and a friend playing within the island sandbox, you are forced to go through objective-based and competition-based tasks that follow a very crappy storyline of 4 people just wanting to get rich and get out.   ++ Singleplay, Multiplayer and COOP modes.  + Guns and tools are nice + Great scenery  +++Buy this game for the singleplayer  - Multiple bugs - Uplay requirements/overlay - Game-breaking bugs - Overpowered SMG class - Graphics are similar to FC2 but..worse?   I would only recommend this game for the singleplayer and nothing else. The coop is fun if you're with the right people and playing on INSANE mode.

Genueinly fun game with a ridiculous learning curve. There's an exploit/mechanic called 'dragging' that allows weapon swings to not match animations. The developers apparently intended for this to be in the game while conventiently not including it in the tutorial. I spent 21 hours playing this game thinking the hit detection was awful until a player told me that he was using a technique called dragging. I reasearched it online and laughed because suddenly all those times I was killed through a perfect block made sense.  If dragging was explained to new players I would probably give Chivalry a thumbs up and just say it's difficult. Unfortunately it's something that veteran players can use to incite rage in newer players, which I just can't look past. This would be a great game if the playing field was more suitable towards all players.  Disregard this review if you are looking for a skill based game and don't mind hidden mechanics.

I will never recommend this game to anyone. It's far beyond broken and uneven; saying that would mean it was once a pieced together & functioning game.   Here we go:  - Pay to Win = buying O.P. weaponry catered to NC & VS players  - Constant Buffing & Nerfing of weapons - about as predictable as the stockmarket.  - Uneven faction vehicle options = playing as TR you will see how COD**G the game devs are   (just look up Higby NC helmet) from air to ground, TR is underdog in every respect  - Terrible tactical simulation = expect hilariously sureal & delibrate game mechanics: fighter jets have full 360 degree  turning radius (VS) and OP weaponry (NC & VS), instantaneous revives, insanely powerful oversheilds -   players and vehicles (yes you read this correctly - freaking oversheilds on tanks) invisible snipers, flying shotguners,   1000' rocket proppelled airdrops, etc...   This stuff is insanely abnoxius & enraging. I've played this game for too long, putting up with the constant problems that plague this game, simply because of the community & squad tactical approach - which by the way is the only real  way to get the most out of the game IMO. If you're not with a squad, then you mise well be playin' COD - at least that way you'll feel more on the level with other players.   I give this game 5/10: - 5 only because of the platoon aspect & vehicle options (uneven as S**t) & the fluidness of the  game mechanics.  - Everything else is pretty much terrible.

Wow, well, this was just, Im sorry, but this game is awful, not that its not fun, which it isnt except for the first 5 minutes, YouTubers make it look REALLY fun when its not, I should stop with the rant and do the review i guess. Well, here are the catagories: Fun, Atmosphere, Physics, graphics, and the overall game. So, Without Further Ado:  Fun: 2.3/10 This game was only fun for the first five minutes, like i said, but it really is more than that, the jokes arent funny, the glitches are MEANT to happen, Which in my opinion led to its downfall. Make a goat simulator 2 without the ♥♥♥♥ing awful puns, jokes, and ♥♥♥♥, as well as dont revolve it around the physics, Well dont revolve it around BAD physics.  Atmosphere: 8/10 The Atmosphere in this is undeniably cool, you feel like youre actually in a city, Not with people, but the overall level design is pretty good, I have to admit  Physics: 1.4/10 The physics in this game is- ill just put it simply, ♥♥♥♥. its revolved around glitches and trying to make it all for laughs, the way this game bends physics are just awful, the gravity is off, the ragdolls dont change unless you MAKE them, some things dont even have physics, and it was unenjoyable.  Graphics: 7/10 Yes, I know that i have been harsh, but the graphics are pretty good, the shaders are beautiful, and you can tell exactly what everything is, there really is no low point to the graphics, but its not as good as, say the last of us, or other games.  Overall Game: 2.7/10 This game, when i got it, was Hyped SO much and i was SO excited, Everyone was playing it, then the game took a huge ♥♥♥ steamy ♥♥♥♥ on my hopes and dreams, The graphics and level design may be good, but not enough to change the gameplay, the jokes are ♥♥♥♥, as i said, the physics are ♥♥♥♥, the alternate goats you can play as, Such as an emu, or whatever they have, was a nice touch, i like that its not just goats, but the extra costume powers killed this part of the game. I do NOT reccomend this for full price, even on discount its pretty bad, but i think if its on discount, and you REALLY want it, go for it, you may like it,i sure as hell dont.

This is a fantastic game that doesn't require you to spend any money. I've been playing for a full year now and I still stick to most of the default weapons the game gives you. If you wanted a multiplayer game where thousands of people are fighting at any given time then this is the game for you.

This game, through the perspective of a new player, is down right horrible. I say this because it is almost impossible to get a kill with the items they start you out with. Esentially, fighting one enemy to me was like trying to take out an armored car with a nerf dart; damn near impossible. What i would like to see in this game is something like what robocraft had. Some assortment of a tier system would do this game wonders. Maybe to others who have played this game for a long time this review seems biased, however this review isn't aimed to that group. Rather to the new players, who will have to endure the agony of basically shooting glowing cottonballs.    -HOWEVER-  Through the perspective of an open minded person this game actually isn't half too bad. It looks nice, plays smoothly and offers large scale battles, which i haven't seen since the days of Battlefront 2. in addition, the vehicles control rather fluidly and allow for smooth, quick movments.    Overall, this game is as good as it is bad, however through experience it is very confusing and rough on a new player, and the only logical cut around is buying all the pay-to-win DLC's.

I'm really glad that I can finally play this game on my new PC. It would've been a shame missing out on this. It's just amazing, great shooting elements, and even better stealth gameplay. I prefer sneaking up on everyone and taking them out silently with my knife. There are just a lot of playstyles to try, and that's what makes it cool. It's a huge open world with a lot of things to explore. Probably one of my favourite games.
