I played this game in its early days and it was a fun, fantastic game.  Was.  Now the game borders on unplayable. Everything is unresponsive, weapons seem to have no clear advantages over another, everything just feels bland. When I first bought the game I played for hours at a time, I even convinced some friends to buy it. After playing it in its most recent iteration I am left with a bad taste in my mouth. Armor unlocks and paints and exp bars make the game more reminiscent of Call of Duty than an original game. Paints become borderline camouflage as it is difficult to see what team enemies with painted armor are on, and the exp bar for ranks makes the game feel more like a grind and less like a, well, game.  If you would've asked me a year ago, I would've recommended this game with no hesitation. Now, I urge you to buy with caution. If you want a game with real medieval combat, go with Mount and Blade: Warband, as this game has lost s lot of things that made it fun before.

Planetside 2 was fun for a while, the alerts are fun and weapons are very well diverse for people to even customize them with whatever attachments they had available at the time, I have played all three sides, so I have read the chat of the three factions to see their opinions on each other. It's gotten even better since Daybreak does ban cheaters compared to the previous owner SOE. However, of my many times participating in some alerts there are some things I'd like to note for people playing this game either new or returning after a break, which would be some current events that have made it an issue to play this game.  1. The poor connection to this is pretty known to current and past players as even the devs are trying to fix this still, however that's not a real major issue compared to what I have seen.  2. Even though Daybreak bans cheaters all they do is create new accounts and get right back on and cheat again, teleporting behind players and using aimbot at point blank with a shotgun or an smg I have seen now and again. They still walk through walls at times and are reported then banned just to repeat the process all over again.  3. Then we have the outfits, there has been a major issue with every faction's outfits. There is a South Korean outfit for every faction, this wouldn't be too much of a problem if they hadn't actually flooded the Connery (American West) server, usually these outfits control these regions during an alert so I have no idea why they are not playing on their own server, all I know is that they have become far superior outfits to the others and no one really stands a chance anymore while some of us even have to wait to get into some warzones as the zone is completely full of people because of them. There are other awful outfits as they have recently done nothing but team kill other players trying to help them who are not on their outfit roster as I have been team killed by the same outfit over and over again under different circumstances. The strangest occasion being a 30 year old man strangely screaming 'Bad guy!' while I repair his vehicle as he proceeds to shoot and kill me my character says 'I fight for Vanu!' and the outfit proceeded to trash me because I was the little guy in no outfit at all since I didn't meet the 'requirements' of having a microphone. I actually had quit this game because of this very same outfit with their try hard people and some even being cheaters or just don't seem to even have any simple form of common sense.  3. The Terran Republic has a pretty bad reputation of having cheaters join their ranks while the New Conglomerate is considered to be the newbie group and is widely disrespected among the other factions except for the famous 666 Devildogs outfit being one of the very few with actual honor. (Not saying there aren't really any others with honor on different sides but not many actually punish team killing like they do unless apologies are said and people are revived.) The Vanu are considered 'overpowered' no matter what the circumstances seem to be and even have been nerfed by SOE in the past.  The game itself is fun, I loved playing it while being around the few good platoons left. But the community has become awful compared to what it used to be a couple years ago when I didn't play so much on a steam account. I have seen games change like this before and this game has become no different. It has become from a fun game with competition to a game that you will hands down lose because of the outfits being so close to each other that they'll kill any other person on the same faction but not the same outfit just for fun with no punishment other than 'locking' their guns for a period of time and not noticing that the person that they killed was the only support soldier in the local area. As I said, I had fun with this when I could, but there was no more fun to be had and I simply had to leave. People will say 'Well if you joined an outfit you'd still be playing and be having fun as this is a MMOFPS game.' Well, I didn't have enough time to join a outfit, nor did I plan to join one unless it was one of the more honorable ones for fear of being framed for being a team killer while I hate team killing all together, nor did I meet the requirements since I was waiting to buy another microphone.   Overall, I have to rate this game at a 3/10, it's not the worst free fps I've played (The worst being Blacklight: Retribution) since I love how the game works with the people being specific classes while handling jobs like piloting and I loved how teamwork used to be back then but the community once again ruined a good game. I'm sorry but I just can't recommend a game that puts a new player down so hard, or veteran players being attacked personally for the things they do in a game by children or lunatics to the point to where they switch to a similar war game searching for a better community. I honestly expect this game's American servers to be taken over by either South Korea or Russia within the next few years because they are the few outfits I actually saw who seem to just win every single time over any english speaking outfit and almost seem to always be on the Connery server. Sad to leave this game in the dust with a review that bashed it, but I used to love this game, I played a day straight getting certs for unlocking weapons and other useful things. Now it's a game where everyone doesn't trust their own team and would rather kill their own team than work with them.

Planetside 2...  In short, a massive mmo stategical game where 3 factions fight over 4 continents. There is a grinding aspect, and weapons are a little on the expensive side and can become pay to win. But there are some moments where... well... It is freaking amazing. Playing in a squad with almost 50 members, coming together all of us to save a point, winning the continent. In short, most of this game can become a drag, but moments will make you love the game.

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: This game is not good. I very much want to like this game, but i just can't. Heres a collection of reasons why:  1: The story is crap. It's not engaging whatsoever, and its not even your story. You're just a tag-along most of the time, and even when you aren't you still never really feel like you are accomplishing anything.  2: You have no real choice in playstyle. You either shoot things, hit things, or blow things up. Thats it. No pacifist runs. This wouldn't be too big an issue if this was fun, but...  3: Combat is boring, just horribly boring. None of the weapons really pack any kind of punch, and in the end it just feels like you're shooting spitballs for all the balistic impact the weapons have. The melee weapons fare slightly better in this regard, but with exeption of a few lategame and unique weapons they just all feel the same; just with different damage numbers.  4: It looks like ♥♥♥♥. Now, I don't have anything against dated graphics, but the textures are just plain bad on a lot of things, at times worse than oblivion, and definetly worse than New Vegas, which is on the same engine. The omnipresent gray-green filter does not help this any.  5: The AI is terrible. Running into walls, spazing out, not reacting to being shot, the works.  6: It crashes a lot. These crashes are unavoidable in most cases, and can only be delayed by installing some unoficial patches and such.  7: The DLC. Its not great. Out of all of the DLC, only Point Lookout is really worth playing, and to a lesser extent The Pit.  Get Fallout: New Vegas instead. It is everything that this game should have been: Fun.

Looks great, plays great, runs great. Also warhammer, WAAAAGH!  Edit: Well, I don't get annoyed that quickly by forums or internet discussions, but this one bugs me. A lot. The game is great, very solid, there is barely anything to complain about. But still the game gets bad reviews. Why? Because of dlc (that at the moment) isn't out yet. Blood and gore pack is a seperate dlc, because of age rating. It comes at the cost of 2,50 which to me doesn't seem like a lot. I mean, you can buy a coke for that money, maybe 2. Now for the chaos warriors dlc, this is one I'm also a bit icky about, but I still think it's not that bad. Yes, it should have been in the game by default, but most people got it for free anyway in the first week. Still I understand people are upset about this. Now for the 'call of the beastmen' dlc. People are, at this moment, leaving bad reviews on the base game, because of a dlc that isn't out yet. Yes, I do also feel it is a bit expensive, and the unit roster is too small. The solution? Don't buy it. If you don't feel like a dlc isn't worth your money, just don't buy it. It isn't like your obliged to do so.   Why did I write this paragraph about something as silly as this? I don't know, maybe I'm just an idiot, or maybe I don't want to see this game, which is one of the best warhammer games to date, see get buried in bad reviews. Oh well, I'm just one opinion of many, but thanks for taking the time to listen to mine.

Tl;Dr - If you're looking for a quick fix for your Total War itch, don't bother here. If you really dig the fantasy setting or already own the previous Total War installments, get Warhammer at a 50% discount minimum. This should have been an expansion back for Attila (price point-wise).  I know I'll get a lot of flack for not liking this iteration of Warhammer come to life in an RTS game, but frankly, it's not the idea of Warhammer I don't like, it's the implementation. Essentially I was pleasantly surprised to see CA go after the Warhammer franchise. A franchise that combines fantasy and the joy of medieval combat sounds like a dream come true, right? Unfortunately, the result is far from the truth.  Quite frankly, this game is a dissapointment on so many levels for me. While you can still get enjoyment out of it, especially if you are a hardcore Warhammer fan, that does not make up for the sheer lack of overall effort that shows everytime you boot a game up. But enough of that, let's get started with the usual list!  Pros:  1. The graphics - The game looks good...I mean...REALLY good. It has plenty of visual flair and charm despite my growing distate for the game as a whole.  2. Leaders - For the most part each leader adds a new and interesting mechanic to your battles, a nice change of pace from the political setups from Rome 2 and Attila.  3. Siege and Regular Battles - Regular battles have different visual styles that vary based on location, whilst sieges can certainly look gorgeous they also have MAJOR cons that we'll get to shortly.  4. No Politics/children - This one just speaks for itself.  And now, the Cons:  1. Complete lack of quanitity - So, remember when I made the jab at Atilla with 'Attila Lite' in my last review? Yeah, Warhammer is even worse, which you would almost think to be impossible. Now I get that there are only so many races, but dear gods, one faction per race? Seriously? And people try to justify that? Basically if you want to play coop with someone you cannot be the same race despite there being multiple factions per race. You also cannot play a different faction after you've grown tired of playing the exact same starting position with the exact same enemies around you. And no, different lords do not add enough variety to change that.  2. Great Power Debuff - This one just speaks for itself.  3. Agents - It was a pretty cool idea to have 'heroes' that you can use to bolster your army, such as using a Dwarven Engineer to increase the stats and reload speed of your artillery. Each hero has unique abilities for each race and you could really benefit from them in battle....oh...you say that the AI will only use them like agents from the previous Total War games and eventually you'll be dealing with the six or so agents from all your enemies that are completely unstoppable just like Attila? Well that was a waste of time.  4. Enemy Units Routing...Psych! - Yeah, this is probably the worst and most unrealistic part of Warhammer, a univese with gryphons (griffons?) and dragons. Picture this, you're in a close battle with the enemy lord, your troops have flanked his best warriors and you've decimated the enemy archers and horseman. Now all that's left is to bring this battle to a clo-....wait....why are my Hammerers dropping like flies? *glance around map for hidden units* Why the hell is that archer unit of only 10-20 men back in battle? ♥♥♥♥♥! How did that horseman unit of 15 come back and flank my warriors?! Yeah, get ready for this constantly happening. It's annoying and drags out battles for far too long. You'll constantly find weak units coming back. My advice? Don't even bother playing the dwarves if that annoys you. The Slayers are the only thing you'll have that can run down those units to make sure they don't come back.  5. Settlements/Cities - Wow do these look half-♥♥♥♥♥, just from the in-game ui alone. Do you remember Yu-Gi-Oh? How about Pegusus' Toon world? Yeah. That's pretty much what every city looks like from the grand campaign...toon towns.  6. Siege Battles - And now for the largest let down of all. I'm sure you've already heard of this, but siege battles suck. About 1/4 of the city is available to you, limiting your encirclment options to a head-on charge, Units pull ladders out of their hidden bags of holding, lodged somewhere securely in their rears, and when you get on the enemy walls? Yeah, your units get down by clipping through the battlements...Such a showcase of effort and time right there. But the worst part? The cities actually look really good, especially the background art. All of which just makes you wish for an actual siege battle like the previous games.  7. Siege Battles Continued - Settlements don't have siege battles unless you've builts walls. What does that mean? It means no more using choke points to your advantage on low level settlements, instead you get to fight on a generic battle map. I guess those budget cuts even hit your engineers.  At the end of the day, the best I can say about Warhammer is that it looks pretty. That it has potential. But sadly there's very little effort and quality here, especially when compared to previous Total War entries (Attila included). The lack of faction choices within each race is a sour taste every time you start a new game, especially so if you plan to play coop. Creatively, Warhammer is a step in the right direction for CA, but from a mechanic and quality standpoint it's miles behind Shogun 2.  9/25 Edit - Spell check

What is Dota 2?  Dota 2 is an art form. With its own take on the MOBA gaming genre, Dota 2 has etched its place within gaming history. As more and more players flock to check out the generously free-to-play game, one must ask - What is it thats so appealing?  The free-to-play is certainly an excellent carrot, and you get an astounding amount of content for that free-to-play tag. Every hero unlocked, and a complete even playing field. The only thing you can buy is cosmetic upgrades and battlepoint boosters which - You guessed it, improve your chance of more cosmetic upgrades. The fact that both paying and free-to-play customers are on an even playing field is attractive already.  Back in the Beta, I paid the £15. Im glad I did, because I know that money went to developing an amazing game. But in its heart, in its very essence, Dota 2 has a learning curve the size of a cliff. You dont just play Dota 2, you -learn- it. Knowledge is power and without knowledge you are nothing in this game. You'll spend your first 30+ hours being stomped, smashed, brutalised and annihilated into the floor. And yet, you never feel bad about it. Every death is a chance to improve, every pub stomp is a chance to reflect on where you went wrong.  Even now I'm improving my game, every game. But once you pass that initial curve. Once you can jump into any hero and play them 'Comfortably' then Dota 2 moves on to something even better. I'm at that stage now, and yet I know that even now I have to improve my game every match.  Its free, and will entertain you for hours. What are you waiting for?

TL;DR: No, items aren't useful enough and punishment for deaths are too harsh. ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ To be honest, despite the low amount of hours I have on this game, I would not recommend this game by any means to anyone who wants to play a Moba and aren't gods at them. Two big reasons:  One: Items.  Most items are very useful and easy to use, but simply don't offer enough in terms of defense against stacked characters. No matter the items, if you are versing a Lion who is decent enough, he will kill you unless you or others kill him first.  Two: The biggest one, YOU ARE PUNISHED FOR SUCKING NO MATTER YOUR SKILL LEVEL Yeah, this might seem weird, you would want people to be punished for doing bad, but apparantly to Valve missing out on XP and possible kills isn't bad enough. So they thought about how else could they punish someone who is sucking, no matter if they legitimately don't know what they are doing or if they just are having a bad game, and it struck them: Let's have them lose gold. Yeah, if you are having a bad game, you will never come back from it because you'll never have the gold to get the items to help you. It's a simply screwed system that can't be fixed.  So yeah, thanks for reading this through if you did.

*** This review is 'NOT' about the game, but Uplay, as this is the fundamental cause of all problems. And stop complaining without reading my review. Or if you think I have something against the game, then by all means, stay ignorant. This negative review is about Ubisoft, and Uplay, NOT Far Cry 3. ***  First of all, I have loved Ubisoft back in the old days, and I thought they were one of the best game companies.  Now? I think it is one of the worst.   First of all, let me ask, what the hell is Uplay? And how am I supposed to make this god-awful client even work? I start Far Cry 3 from desktop, by clicking on the icon and nothing happens. But on Steam, it says the game is running. So I have to shut down the game manually....which is not really running in reality. And then I try starting the game from Uplay and I see where it says 'Play', but it doesn't look like it is highlighted and not really clickable. In fact, it is not clickable. So then why is it there?   So....I downloaded the Uplay client itself and tried to play it from Uplay directly. Oh, now 'Play' button is clickable there, Yay! Click! It says the game is running on Steam, but I do not see anything again.   I actually installed it once, removed, and re-installed and still nothing is happening. Let's see, Ubisoft, uh, THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR MAKING ONE OF THE WORST CLIENTS MANKIND HAS EVER SEEN.   And guess what, it doesn't seem like I am the only person here. Google 'farcry 3 uplay not working' and see for yourself how many people are having problems with this garbage-like client.   Or you need even more proof? Go to the store page of Far Cry 3. I have found a few solutions for this, and well, some of the suggestions are to remove certain files, install some new driver, go into some folder and change something........uh....I bought the game, and I have to put up with all this garbage? They might as well put up a warning sign that reads 'This game has one of the worst clients that will drive you nuts, so if you don't think you are sure about your PC being able to run the game because of Uplay, then you might want to reconsider purchasing.'  GFWL was not that good, but not as bad as this. EA Origin is not bad, but it's actually pretty good. Steam, is definitely one of the best.   Uplay? Pure garbage, in fact, it really proves the whole point of Ubisoft being one of the worst companies in the world.   May I ask why Uplay is necessary? Is it necessary?   Ubisoft has the history of screwing up the PC ports of Devil May Cry 3 and Resident Evil 4, the old PC version. What is Goat Simulator?  Recently there has been a lot of hype revovling around this game for its randomness and such, but is it really worth it to buy and play? Better question, will this game last you a long time, or at least long enough to get maybe a decent amount of hours in before your sick of it? For I regretably found the creul truth of this game, it's just not enough fun. There isn't nearly enough fun, wacky things to do as a goat in this game to keep you occupied. Of course, just as I did, you'll have an hour or so when you'll say something like'BEST GAME EVER!', later you'll find out it's more of a in the moment feeling. I did have a good hour or so when it felt like it was so much fun, not knowing what to screw up as a goat next, but then very soon it was evident, the game got boring. (THE GAME LIVES OFF THE FACT OF YOU BEING A GOAT TOO MUCH!!!)  What do you do in the game?  The game consists of you, a goat, being well, a goat. You basically terrorize a small(and I mean SMALL) town and do what ever you really feel like whether it's ruin a family's dinner or grab a big boulder with your tounge and hurt stuff(kind of fun). Your main things you can do are move around with the W,A,S,D keys(duh), run with the shift key, use the E key to grab to stuff with your tounge and take it somewhere(maybe out for dinner?) and of course jump with the SPACE BAR. Also as you do more things in the game more small abilities unlock like the GOATBORN, which is basically you being able to Fus Ro Da as a goat, which I admit, can be fun.  Should I Buy This Game?  Really I don't know if I can tell you the answer completly, but I may be able to push a little towards my idea of the situation. This game is is fun for only how long you let it be fun. By that I mean it's fun only if you sort of have an imagination or like just messing around with no real incentives, or goals. Personally, when I play a game I feel I need some sort of goal to push towards and acheive because well that's sort of what makes a lot of games fun. Now there are a few small 'goals' you can do, but nothing really worth going into depth like doing a backflip, but earning nothing in return, horay. So if you want to spend 10$ on this game go ahead, just remember, the game in a nutshell dosen't have much substance to it so it won't last long if you don't like just messing around.  NOTE: Also just like to note that there isn't any multiplayer, but there is a workshop kind of thing where you can doownload other people's maps, which could grant a few more hours of play.   VERDICT: 7/10 It's Ok  Pro Your a goat Gives you a good laugh Only 10$(Could also be a con couldn't though?) Good if your bored one afternoon and have nothing to do   Con Causing destruction and such gets old after a while Graphics glitch out(I realize that it's suppose to be in the game, but can be annoying) No goals or at least anything really worth striving to do  Costs 10$

One of the best games of all time. What I love about it is that there are vehicles, jungle with animals, hunting, crafting, gun combat, stealth combat... and every single aspect of that game is perfectly balanced with others. This allows you to clear camps with many different styles, but each of which is rewarding: - you can rush in all guns blazin' - you can sneak in - you can release animal - you can shoot them up from a distance with a sniper rifle - you can set whole place on fire -YOU CAN BRING RANDOM BEAR TO THEIR BASE WITH STONES and enjoy the show.  I love this kind of freedom, especially when everything is at the top of its genre - you will have trouble finding better stealth game, better action game, better jungle (you are scared and hoping that you wont find tiger/bear/... on your walks), more immersive driving (in not carsim games that is).  After all is said and done, you have this kind of freedom only in Skyrim and maybe (didn't play yet) in GTA V. For example assassins creed 3 doesn't have that - yes you can do many things in it, but those things are not interconnected and balanced to provide one great package - you have hunting there, but no reason to hunt - same goes for (awesome) ship missions, stealth is broken, bullet shield mechanic is hillarious, forest animals are almost unable to kill you... this just shows how unique far cry is.

Chivalry is like CS but with swords. And gore. And fire. Lots of fire. The game is what I consider a 'Server-Based-Game' where there is no story or campaign but rather you get a big list of servers and you choose a game to play in. Similar to TF2, CS, ect. Normally I don't like games like these because I do enjoy -some- story to go with my game before I jump into multiplayer. I discovered however that Chivalry does in fact have just that! The Blue Agatha's are fighting against the Red Mason's who are rebelling against the kingdom! And that's it. That's all I need. The decapitations in Chivalry are always amazing to see and perform on people and surprisingly the games hit detection is really well done for a first person sword game. You wouldn't think it would be as polished as it is, yet the game is amazingly well crafted for being indie. The combat is fast, dynamic, and if you want a Medieval campagin to go with it then I recommend picking up Mount and Blade: Warband. Both games go great together and play very similar! I love Chivalry and it's one of those games that goes perfectly with a good music playlist going in the background. I'll give Chivalry an 8/10. I would rate it higher but I think the game needs more maps! Other than that: It's GREAT!

Singleplayer : Campaign: I played the campaign on it's hardest difficulty and it took me somewhere around 15 hours. The story is about Jason Brody having a vacation on an island. And wakes up in a cage realising that his vacation is over and he has to save all his friends so they can get back home. This sounds and also felt generic. But as you continue through the game the story gets more and more interesting, due to well voiced characters and the inspiring monologues. The game also felt like some kind of total recall to me, because the character has many drug trips. So even when I was playing the normal sp missions I was asking myself if it wasn't just a drug trip. Because if the bulk of the story was a drug trip the story would make a lot more sense. The campaign story was mostly the reason that kept me playing.   Gameplay: The gameplay other hand was good and entertaining, but nothing special for me. Some early missions could be annoying, because you were forced to play stealthily. Also the sp missions can sometimes feel as a narrow route. The power of the gameplay itself is that you can choose how you want to play. stealthily or guns blazing. Both can be fun but both also have some issues. The stealth problem is that the ai can be annoying. And for guns blazing you can easily run out of ammo and have to break your arm to revive yourself many times if you play guns blazing.(Atleast on my difficulty. I would maybe recommend to play 1 difficulty below or first do a lot of side missions to unlock more health, weapons etc.) Also if you have no ammo you mostly have to camp until you can easily knife someone, without getting hit. Sadly every endboss fight from the game showed the definition of insanity in gameplay. The game was also a bit overwhelming in the beginning because of the many menus with upgrades. At first I ignored them, but later I really saw the benefit of it. Otherwise you will easily die. The graphics of the game still look nice, I especially liked the lighting. And how much effort there had been put into the building.   Open World: I have to be honest I haven't done that much in it. Because I wasn't really interested in it. Still I can say if you are interested in exploring the world there is alot to do! There are enough side-missions, which is mostly killing enemies/animals in a certain way, missions where you have to go from A to B as fast as you can etc and, of course, collecting stuff. Really the only thing that made me stop fast-traveling from mission to missions was the tower climbing and the animal/flower hunt to unlock stuff. They were more rewarding to me than the side missions that just give you money and xp that I already had enough of.    Online :  Multiplayer: In my opinion the mp isn't that special. It has 4 standard game modes. Of course they are varied with some nice ideas. But to me it just feels like a cod-clone. The multiplayer also has a strong map editor. Probably at the time there were many great mods made. (I found some interesting ones on youtube. ) But now that the game isn't as active anymore, I couldn't find a modded map to play. -Co-op: I played the co-op with someone many months before continuing my singleplayer campaign. It was pretty long at 6-8 hours. But still the co-op was pretty generic and forgetable. The only thing that I liked were the mini-games. What is strange is that the multiplayer and the co-op leveling system are combined. So if I had only played Co-Op, I would have all the unlocked loadouts for the multiplayer.    Overall : I can say Farcry 3 is a great game, but you can ignore the multiplayer and co-op, because they aren't that special and that active anymore. I think for the people who only own FarCry 4, FarCry 3 is still a great game to play, especially for the campaign, that makes it something special.

You only need to click, but then after a while you really need to click.  Simple graphics, like a fight screen from an old RPG like Dragon quest, and a fluid growth curve that sees your many heroes becoming stronger every time you return to them. Truly free to play as you can just keep clicking and you will be given the 'Rubys' that are the in-game currency. You will have enough to buy the most valuable things in no time.  The real trick is knowing where to invest your earnings, and going after the right powers, or achievements that will either increase your attack power or that of the heroes that you collect, and upgrade. at times the heroes are all very strong, and other times all of the power is coming from just 1 or 2 of them.  At the time of this review I am 14.1 hours in, I have reached level 137, and I have over 50 rubys already. I have 1 hero soul, and if I ascended now I would get 9 souls, and the 3 gilded heroes will go with me. (4 if I wait till I kill the boss on 140 I'm certain) but I won't be ascending for at least another 50 levels. when I have rounded each hero to at least level 1000 that will be the day. Now I must click. (Only 60K more clicks to 250K) I have spent nothing, and I got a booster pack for being online with Steam as well so that is like being paid even if only pennies to play this free game.

Chivalry was looking like it was going to be one of my favorite games of all time until I reached level 16. From level 0-15, this game has servers exclusively meant for new players which is pretty cool. These servers are full of intense battles and fun combat scenarios, lots of fun! You may ask how the hell this game just becomes bad at level 16. Well, when you jump in your first non 0-15 server, it is likely that you will be called out for being a 'noob'. This part doesn't bother me as trashtalk is common among many games nowadays, so I say 'whatever- I'll just prove them wrong with my swordplay'. The first ♥♥♥♥ing person I fight kills me with 2 seemingly unblockable swings. I think this is odd considering the swings looked fairly straightforward. 'No big deal. I'll just try again' *same thing happens* 'must be my ping'! *ping is at 42*.  After this, I just kept having this exact experience over and over. After many rage inducing games, I quit the game and did some research. I made the discovery of the absurd exploits of this game, the fact that these techniques have not been patched is beyond infuriating. This ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t seems to have ruined a once amazing game for many long time fans. I am Honestly very glad I didn't grab this game until it was on sale this summer and I'm glad I started playing only recently, the fact that this game was ruined would be even more painful as a long time fan. ♥♥♥♥ Torn Banner, ♥♥♥♥ these game breaking techniques, and ♥♥♥♥ this largely toxic community. Save your money.

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: Fallout 3 is a post-apocalyptic nightmare. Things will scare you. Things will gnaw at your soul at night.  I would recommend playing 3 before New Vegas. Why?  I think so many players were bothered by Fallout 3 not being as funny or witty as the other games because Fallout 3 is literally the deconstruction of the Fallout universe. It's the real dark nightmares of Fallout, because there's no NCR, there's no Master, no ghoul city... There's nobody out here. The city was annihilated. Whatever's left are just dregs.  In New Vegas you have hope humanity will rebound in one way or another. It's just a question of picking your faction. I mean the Followers of the Apocalypse are already working on ways to replace ancient technology with newer methods that can be reproduced. The NCR has water purifiers. Legion lands are free of raiders. House is a giant mainframe with self-replicating robots at his disposal.  In 3 you have no such hope. In 3, even the Brotherhood of Steel realized it was pointless, the struggle was futile.  It crashes harder than a Fiend on Jet though. There's tricks to making it work better, but save early, save often. Just wish Bethesda re-released this without GFWL.

Good potential spoiled by game developers A) forcing you to play oline; you cannot play as a single player against the AI in anything other than the most basic games, and B) MASSIVE lag on the controls means incredibly unresponsive controls. if you get hit, you will not be able to counterstrike immediately. If you have made a strike already but get hit first, your strike will be voided. Then you won't have enough time to strike before getting struck first, meaning you get hit again and just die. If you block with your shield, then try to strike back, there is a HUGE delay, your opponent will then hit you first, after your skillful block and kill you, meaning that blocking with a shield is effectively completely useless. The combat has more complexity than Skyrim, but the MASSIVE unrensponsiveness ruins it, you can't use your skill to win, it's just the first man to make a hit on the opponent will win! Very VERY disappointing. Why do the game developers make games like this, it's just poinless!

This game was fun for about 15 minutes. 15? OK, maybe 30 minute (I got lost trying to get a trampoline achievement).  Goat Simulator was pretty hyped up. It was the only game I saw commercials for that didn't rhyme with 'Cattlefield' or 'Cacaw of Duty' that had so much hype seeping out of the TV. I thought to myself  'Cold! What a wonderful idea! You've always wanted to simulate a goat-based reality. Or was it an Earth-based goat reality? Doesn't matter! You've purchased this game. It's your rite of passage as a gamer to play this game.'   So what did I think? It was OK. I feel like I hopped on the Hype Train in a village with the population of 1 person. After getting the gist of the game, I felt like I should be playing this game with someone else. Or perhaps with a group of people whilst intoxicated and/or pretending to be intoxicated for fear that Mary will think I'm a deviant drug user and won't go to the prom with me!. Well that's fine. If she won't go to the prom with me, I'll spread a rumor that she never even tried Goat Simulator! That'll ruin her gaming cred!  Where was I? Oh, right. I cannot recommend this game to anyone. Why, you may ask? Simply because of the fact that its purely meant to consume your time.   You kill mosters by clicking or idling and use the gold which they drop to improve your character and buy heroes and imrpove those. So far for that. You do that until you reach lvl 130-140 where you simply never ever will pass the bosses. (too low dmg) Then, you restart the game. You gain Hero Souls, which give you dmg boosts if you keep them or can be used to buy other extras.  Thats it. You play the game util you can't proceed any further, then you resett, gain hero souls, play until you [...]  As always, there is the shortcut of paying. You can pay to improve your heroes, you can pay for hero souls, you can pay for relics, you can pay for basicly anything you want.   So... either play this for hundreds / thousands of hours (because there is no 'end' unless you count 100% achievements as finishing a game) or you ... quit halfway through. Optional, you don't play it at all, which i advise you to do.  The game is soley a waste of time and trying to get you spend money on it.

The good thing about this game is that even if you're not in for the horror, it is still a pretty good one. See, most horror games are pretty boring if you are not the easy-to-scare type. Not this one though. Even if the scares are not for you, this is still a pretty tense race against time and the ever-decreasing power supply. First night I finished with 10% power left. Second nite I actually ran out for the last couple seconds, it was pretty nailbiting.  By the third night I got better about my power saving patterns so I finished with about 20% left. Fourth night I deliberately burned my power to see if the jumpscare gets me (it didnt).  Thats where I am now. Cannot wait to see how hard the latter nights get.

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: Greatest Bethesda game ever made. This game is an absolute wonder to play. My experience on both pc and console (pc is most certainly better than console) really showed me how great the game itself is. The environment is astonishing as it takes place in a post-apocalyptic setting in Washington D.C. Within the game, there is an endless amount of activities and quests that result in many different ways and are always fun to do! It has been a privelige for myself to play this game for the amount of time I have, and I think that more people should be playing it.

I have played hours of Total War series. Many hours. This game feels like it was released 10 years ago. Small sieges. Cramped battles. Not big enough. It would be a big gamke if they actually spemt time like in Napoleon or Attila making massive maps. Adding deep gameplay. This is a simple game and to small to be at a high price. The units and battles are good but are to small and to rushed. The city assults need to be massive. Smarter AI and most of all. When i attack a village i want to acctually fight at that village. Not a small feild with nothing on it. Magic is pointless. Dont buy. If this game was bigger. An epic scale for fantasy battles. And its so simple. Its like a kids game. Agree or not. This is the worst TW game ever. Unless you like small maps and no city attacks. Oh, and naval battles. You know, navy. Pure lazy. Waist of my cash. And watch Black Fire pass on youtube. Then divide it by 5. Thats the size. Small. I had to mod this just to make it playable even with friends. Thanks

A great game with a not-so-great story. Far Cry 3 has a very solid gameplay aspect to it. I love roaming around the jungle, gathering plants for potions, hunting animals for their skins and upgrading my equipment and killing mad baddies. I love activating the radio towers for more weapons and to reveal more of the map and I love trying to unlock the signature weapons. I enjoy that the collectibles that aren't impossible to find, but that's not my thing really. If you enjoy them, you'll like this game. The gun's are awesome, and for once, the melee isn't useless if you know when to use it! I played this game through on hard and the difficulty was perfect for me, as I died multiple times, but still felt like I was making progess. Except some times when it throws you back 5-10 minutes on a really hard mission multiple times, but fortunately this is very rare. Now the story on the other hand is very basic, and after about 2/3 through the game it get's dreadfully boring. You'll see why. But if there is one thing I love about the story it's one character. The character who single-handedly saves this game's story. Vaas, the main villain, a maniac pirate who loves to tell you the meaning of insanity. Sadly the other characters are boring or just plain annoying (except for Dennis, he cool mang.) This game's advertised as a game that breaks the rules of story-telling games' cliches, but honestly it follows many of them. Except every once in a while it throws some crazy-♥♥♥ riddles at you that go away so quickly you don't even have time to think them through. And the ending, in my opiniion, is the worst thing since Shaquille O'Neal's acting career, but some people think it's fine. Even after that rant I still enjoyed this game a lot, and you can see I played it as a single-player game even though it has a multiplayer aspect to it. So if you're into that, this game has it too!  I'll give this game a 8/10 for it's amazing gameplay and Vaas.

Firstly, I have to tell you that I really love this game, total war with fantasy settings, but I can't recommend this game as it is overpriced due to the starting contents and other gameplay issues. Noted that; my game is still the base game without additional dlc at all (except for Warrior of Chaos from pre-ordering).  I have been playing total war series since shogun 2 (except Attila) and find out that there are various new features as well as missing features, but maybe it's because they have to make it lore-friendly which I don't know any background info about warhammer universe.  The campaign map is divided into many provinces with several settlements, but when it is leveled up, the icon of the building does not distinguish at all and the size of the city does not expand like in Rome II. This makes the city's defense range (I mean the aura around the city) too small to gain strategic positon as the campaign map is the vast plain with some mountainous area.  Although I like the underground stance that make you be able to march through the mountain, lack of river and bridge is another issue that almost every single battle I have faced is a wasteland with some hills and forests. However as I've said, the original warhammer Old World mays limit these issues.  For factions, each race is designed to have their own playstyle which is a great step because in other previous total war games, each faction is slightly differentiated with only a distinguished buff. Nonetheless, within the same race but different faction, it is not likely to be unique for the playstyle as it is very similar with each other with additional contents (from DLC :P) e.g. Dwarf and Clan Angrund.  The politic panel in Rome II is also missing together with the family tree. Again I know that it is lore-friendly, but if we can play in our own story, it will be very interesting. Shogun II can auto-generate sons and daughters so the orc or dwarf or vampire in total war Warhammer should be able to do that too.  Lastly, the siege battle which should be an epic moment for us. Even though it is exciting to see the beautiful background of the city itself in the battle, the wall is in only one side in the north or south or in the corner of the map. Therefore, it is very limited for you to siege from only one direction instead of surrounding it from several points. Furthermore, the most annoying thing is the siege battle map is so small that once the battle starts, you will almost always under-fire from the tower. Even at the furthest part outside the city, my units keep dying so the only choice is to charge in.  Therefore, if you want this game, I recommend to buy it on sale. DLC is optional because the contents in dlc are already in the game, but you can't have access to it unless you buy it ????? lol (for real)  P.S. sorry for my bad grammar.

I really do like this game, I like the concepts and everything for it. I wish they would introduce positional blocking (similar to what they have done for attacks) to keep it interesting.  I have some very large complaints about the game however, firstly, the keybinds are fairly complex and should vary from character to character. I enjoy setting things up so that the origin side of the swing comes from the same side as the button I am pressing (to keep it logical). However since all keybinds are set together as 'offside swing' or 'mainside swing' some characters will swing from the opposite side when you use the same button. I really wish that you could have profiles for character archetype to change that.  The second large issue has to do with what I see 'good' players doing. I enjoy parrying and poking and fighting with people and enjoy that kind of engagements. However, what the good players do is more a fault of how the hit detection works. Basically 'if a sword on a swing touches you, you take damage', so what do good players do to upgrade their chances to land hits? They abuse the system, they literally spin backwards to block and then overhead swing because it instantly throws the sword overhead scoring a hit, or they grab a two handed sword, after a block they look flat at the ground and crouch and it insta-hits the people in front of you. These types of game mechanics make me not want to play the game at all because you cannot block fast enough to deal with it.  The game IS still pretty fun regardless of the glaring issues, in fact the new player introduction stuff and the first 10/15 levels (whatever new player games a limited to in levels) were great! The problem is that beyond that there are at least 2 people abusing the broken mechanics in each game. If you still want to continue playing I would recommend playing in a server that disables third person view, as from my experience the people using instant hit abilities have a harder time with that disabled (especially the 1h sword ones where you have to block backwards).

The different factions are great, but still there are a lot of them missing. Also the diplomacy could be better, the only thing it is good for is declaring wars, especially as Orcs you don't have any diplomacy really.  Like in the rome games they should unlock every faction that is on the map so you would be able to play them. At least in multiplayer.  If you are a warhammer or total war fan you should buy this (if you have enough money for the game plus the overpriced DLCs)

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: I loved it with an incredible passion when I had it on xbox, but now I understand that the game, though it is good in many aspects, lacks quite a bit, and is, for the most part, unplayable. Crashes will occur reliably at least once every hour of gameplay if not more. Bugs are wild throughout the game. Bethesda released an unfinished product with the hopes that the modding community would help fix it, but the engine itself only allows so much progress.

Broken hitboxes, very abuseable mechanics, incredibly unbalanced weapons, quirky/glitchy animations, and snotty devs to top it all off... There is charm here sure, based on the unique factor of what it is mostly; but beyond that everything is too flawed.

review_text: WARNING:  If you download the game in Germany, even if you bought it on Steam while living out side of Germany, it will only download the German Cut version and you are no longer able to change the langauge in the preferences -> language tab.  As much as I'd like to play this game I feel scammed as I paid the full price but am forced to play a dubbed version, although supported langauges clearly lists 'English' as alternative.  If you live in Germany do not buy or download the Fallout 3 GOTy on Steam.  As much as I've enjoyed playing Fallout 3, I can not recommend anyone living in Germany to buy this game.

It's been the first full priced game I bought for like 10 years and I even preordered it so very untypical of me. But I just love the Warhammer setting, I suppose the medieveal part even more than the 40000 part. Additionally I already played a game which was kind of like TWW, it's called 'Warhammer: Mark of Chaos' (I can only recommend it). I've been playing it averagely 5 hours every day for the last 2 weeks, mostly the empire in different difficulties but also with mods, especially to my liking was the 2 Skillpoints instead of one. Unfortunately I'm a newbie reagarding Total War games so I cannot really say anything about it except that I found it quite hard to match the yellow bar indicating your strength of force compared to the enemy when I was fighting the battles myself. But I guess in all of us there is a more or less big conqueror who just wants to see the world burn and his heroes levelled up. The lords and heroes were the part which kept me going the most because I just love strategy games and RPGs combined. To see my imperial lords receive their griffon and/ or pegasus or the zombie dragon for the Vampire Counts was simply thrilling, even the third time. Not only in battle you can see them but also on your campaign map.  So all in all the best 50€ I have ever invested in a game. Then there should be 10 years of continous DLCs and mods, what do you want more? Total War: Warhammer - I love it!

Gamers are often divided when it comes to narrative driven or sandbox game play. In TW: Warhammer you are basically playing sandbox with a set of rules and a set of goals to accomplish, how you do this and whether you strive to accomplish any of the goals is really up to you.  For the sandbox to be successful I find a game needs plenty of options and routes, this game offers 4 races + 1 DLC race and it sort of limits the experience as you try to find your preferred style of play. Being a very conservative player who doesn't like to pace I found the Empire and Dwarves to be the only viable options, that´s my personal flaw and I cant blame the devs for not pleasing my personal wishes. I would at least have wished for 7-8 playable factions but the good thing about the existing ones is that they differ from one another.  I would personally have loved if they had gone much further in the narrative development into one of the factions, you are told a story as you progress doing certain objectives. They could have made this an optional feature as all the requirements for a traditional sandbox play was already present. I wasn't however expecting this as a feature, I was merely hoping they would please us narrative driven folks.  I do still enjoy a good strategy game and TW: Warhammer delivers for the most part with the traditional battle setups, diplomacy, wars and choices within the different factions campaigns. There are however no battle formations, only the choice between ranged and melee at the front and the whole strategy map and faction choices seem a bit dumbed down from a game like Shogun 2. The game is fairly friendly to beginners though once they get accustomed to the battle scenarios.  Its a decent interpretation of the Warhammer universe with lots of fun battles to experience and the 5 existing faction do provide variety. My personal wishes wont interfere with my verdict of the game, it gets a 7/10 from me.

I'm going to be honest. In my eight hours playing this game, I've had good times, and I've had bad.  But overall, I'm going to have to give this game a no.  Allow me to explain.  The combat is heavily skill based, relying on you learning how to ' Get Gud '. While this is usually perfectly fine, and I enjoy a challenge, it does not work well when most of the rest of the community has two bodies, and a spare leg and a head above you in experience.  You will rarely find other players that are at the start of the leveling tier. Why? Because most are turned away by the sheer cliff of difficulty when it comes to learning the moves of the game, and actually being able to combat people who have done it for far longer than you, of which is little to impossible.  It gets worse when most of these high level players stack on their own team, making it impossible to make a dent, and ending with the match being steamrolled.  I had fun at times, but overall, there's more rage than fun to be found here.  I cannot reccommend this game, at this time.  I'd more than happy give this another shot, if some sort of rank matchmaking system were implemented, placing you in games with people of your own level of skill. But unfortunately, even servers ment for someone of my skill level, are filled with players levels 20+, who mow down people like me in a moment.  This needs to be fixed. Hopefully, someday it will.  TL;DR: I want to badly love this game, but I simply can't.

Coming from an Age of Chivalry background, long time player, I've recently decided to purchase both the original and the expansion. The time I've spent on this game, it was an awkward trade of fun and frustration, the only fun I had was when I wielded a 2 handed spear, how it provided me with enough distance to poke enemies to death easily, yet what I really looked forward in this game was being an archer, or for the expansion, being a pirate.   If you purchase this game, don't bother much with range weapons, either you're good enough to hit a human with an ant-size bullet/arrow, or be killed easily by a spear and shield Spartan, given the reason that range classes have poor melee weapons, pirates have a default short sword which is not going to save you from a 2 handed sword landing a building breaking smash over your defenseless head. Not only I find it rather annoying and difficult to land a shot, but reloading takes all of your patience, especially crossbow, the character would bend over, spending about 3 seconds to reload and when the character gets up, you only see the tip of a spear ramming down your eye, nonetheless whether you score the shot or not, it only takes about a few percent of life, you still need to draw your safety-precaution approved sword and land a few hits.    I feel the game is unbalanced, for that reason, you barely see range weapons, just Spartans, Knights, Vikings, and some Samurai around. Because people like to win easily, they would rather sprint towards you, slice you in half before you even get a chance to respond, given the fact that it takes time to swap weapons and mispressing would lead to swapping back to another weapon, not to mention if you are reloading and get hit, your weapon remains unloaded. My biggest complaint is with range classes, they are plain hard to use, forcing most people to for the easy win classes. I wouldn't recommend this game if you like pirates, playing as one, or unbalanced games.

No other F2P MMOFPS empowers you to NGAF if you play it or not as much as PS2 does.   No waiting, just go in, shoot people and when you need to walk your dog, press Alt-F4, go walk the dog, maybe make a sandwhich, watch some telly or spend some time with your family if you care about them. It's still gonna be there for you once you have the time to get back to it.  After hours of grinding and looking at the repetitive, unimaginative and simply cheap graphics, the game still offers the same immersive feeling of being in a massive battle as it did when I started playing.  As you can get quite good at this game without spending any money on it, it will probably turn to ♥♥♥♥ sooner or later, so I recommend you try it out before it goes down the drain.  The graphics and the back story of this game might be Jersey Shore level tasteless, but forget all that. This game is about big impressive fights and letting off some steam every now and then.  Simply put, if you have little time for matchmaking, excessively long waits between spawns, silly game mechanic gimmicks or other bull ♥♥♥♥, PS2 really delivers.

An absolutely fantastic concept, almost everything I hoped for in a game; it also looks really good as well. However, it fails terribly. The combat is 'floaty', slow and lacks any feel. You simply wave your weapon in front of you and either you or the opponent dies. There really doesn't feel like any connection at all between the weapons or direction of the supposed strike from you or your advesary. Perhaps the worst aspect is the glitching, where players will skip across the map, only slighty, but for no reason at all, even when played on high ends PC's with very low ping servers. This makes archery, or any attack, very frustrating. It is such a shame. A valiant effort but unfortunately falls short, 3/10.

Regardless of what other reviewers might say Total War: Warhammer has really good bones. Immersive and simply a joy to look at the game plays smoothly and I've suffered very few (Only a handful of small things) bugs since launch. A huge improvement over Rome 2's release to be sure. One might be able to make an argument for some of the DLCs being overpriced (Honestly I feel like Beastmen was overpriced and that Chaos should have been in the base game) but that doesn't detract from the solidness of the base game and it seems like things are improving with The Grim and the Grave which is set at an extremely fair price by pretty much any reasonable metric.  Should you buy it? Yes. If the DLC worries you though then wait for sales. Simple as that.

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: I love this game but I would not recommend the G.O.T.Y. edition. It does not connect to the internet (At very least not in game. It only records the time you spend in the launch engine for me. Thus the .6 hrs it says I played.), has no achievements, and requires mods to even be playable on later versions of windows. If you want to get this game and it's DLC, I would highly recommend that you spend the few extra dollars and buy the non-G.O.T.Y. version and DLC.  P.S. I would very much recommend this game in it's other version to anyone. It is a good FPS but an AMAZING RPG.

Chivalry Medieval Warfare is a very intense and frusterting game, yet it also happens to be the most rewarding and stimulating game I have ever played. It's best that I say it now. This game is completely dead even in it's review potential. Please allow me to explain...  1. Gameplay:   Gameplay is extremely well thought out and precise. To me, there is nothing more satisfying than shooting a Heavy Crossbow Bolt a hundred yards away into a Knight's neck. Or Being on the verge of death and managing to get that lucky stab with my dagger through an enemy's chest. The pacing is quite good and you are always on your toes. However, this game's precision also comes at a price. The way the weapons work in Chivalry is that as long as the weapon it'self hits you, it counts. This means that if I jump and do a 360 of of a bench and my sword hits you while spinning, you will get hurt. Most experienced players use this to their advantage. This results in new players being completely demolished and experienced players being nearly one-man batallions if they are good enough. This however also presents a learning curve. I came from Chivalry on the Xbox (We do not speak of that atrocity) and I was shocked at how people were playing. Twirling around and managing nearly impossible hits. BUT, if you take your time and are patient enough, you WILL learn how to counter-act these people. If not by Sword or Hammer, than by bow. Because what's the easiest way to take out a twirler before they hit you? Shoot 'em.   2. Community:  The comunity goes without the need for explanation, yet I will do so anyway. I have made SO MANY friends by playing this game. So many nice people who are funny, honorable, and just all around fun to play with. I personally haven't met anyone who hates me or vice versa, yet I have seen the ocassional jerk. I have seen a lot of kicks in my play-time, yet all of these people where either jerks themselves, causing a hostile enviorment (I.E. arguing with people in chat, spouting random insults, ect). The community loves to be helpful and most importantly to everyone, keep the game going. This means that if you are AFK for a while without telling anyone, they will most likely kick you in order for other people who are playing to join. Things like that. Yes, there will be jerks. They are on every game. But if you are light hearted and go in with good feelings and attitude, you will be surprised how many people that you never even knew will become your best friends.  3. Classes:   Each class is dynamic and unique in it's on way. Some out do others in stamina, others out do others in health, ect. But no class is better than the other. Examples; you may be a hulking Knight in full clad armor, but one good shot to the head from a Crossbow and you are done. You may also be a nimble and accurate archer, but if you are caught off guard or with your bow drawn, it's game over. Finally, you may be a Vanguard with a long Polearm, keeping enemies at a distance, but if someone gets through you with a dagger or short-sword, you are at a disadvantage. But what I like most about these classes is tht nothing is impenetrable. Any class can die by any class. A quick thing you will learn in this game is that Stats do not matter at all. Your weapon is only as good as the person weilding it. This means that if you are good enough, you can smash the face off of a Knight with a stick, or kill a Vanguard with well placed axe throwing. No class (Heh) Out-classes the other. Yes, I did a funny.  4. Servers:   There are many servers in this game. Each one is in a certain region or consist of certain mods, certain maps, ect. You will not have any issue finding what you want to play and where you want to play it. Although, make sure you keep an eye on your ping level to the right of the server names. Your peformance may varry on certain servers if you are not within your region, though, that is obvious.    So in conclusion....  1. There are really good players. Some of the tactics are cheap. But if you are patient enough to wait/learn/practice with others, you WILL match them and beat them.  2. There are good and bad people in the world. But a long as you aren't stiring up trouble, AFK without informing the others, or if your ping is too high, you will not be kicked.  3. Each and every class is hard to master. Very hard. But once you do, you can be very dangerous to anyone who crosses you. Also, people have a little disdain for archers. but those people are quickly silenced with a shot to the head! xP  4. Each and every server suits your needs in a particular need. There are so many, game modes, weapons, maps, and mods. Pick whichever fits your fancy.  So that's it. This review was to show anyone interested that this game DOES have it's pros and cons. Some will find it interesting and give it a try and love it. Others may do the same but find it lacking or not to thier liking. As long as you know what you are going in to, it's up to you what you do with the information given to you. I still however MUST recommend this game. For any Competitive, patient, medieval loving gamer out there, this game is NOT worth missing.  Thank you very much for reading. I hope to see you on the battlefield!

Great game, endless multiplayer slasher fun!  Almost everything in chivalry is fantastic, theres something great about the whole experiance of cutting an opponents limb off and screaming 'FOR THE GLORY OF AGATHAAAA!' over his bloodied corpse.  The only downside to the game is the developers, torn banner, with every update they seem to break a critical game feature (Eg the entier ranking system being broken for a fair few months), which is a shame as it can make you stop playing the game for a long while and put you off it.  The only other annoyance is the community, often players can be very overly competative and immature, but i guess this is a given with most online games with lots of players.  Modes such as Duel and 3v3 battles are often much better in terms of players at they take a lot more patience and honour to play properly, i highly reccomend them.  My last point is to the learning curve of the game, there is a rank system to classify newer players from the more experianced, but due to the game having been out for a while, there are a lot of very good players which can put off newer players, however it is still often hard to have to take in scores of 3 kills to 30 deaths in a game, but its just down to practice.

A persistant Online Game which Pits Hundreds of Players in 3 opposing factions against one another on huge land masses with their assortment of guns, tanks, planes, and troops all at one time. However it suffers from Latency Issues, Load problems, Faction and weapon balance, and most critically - Population Issues. While it is true that Hundreds of other players all connect to the same world you do, the square-footage to player ratio is so small that the game feels largely empty in spite of this fact.  And in the few instances where you actually find yourself fighting a sizable opposing force, the map grid you fight over is often no larger then the average Battlefield or Call of Duty Multiplayer map and usually lasts just as long as one of those maps as well because either you grossly outgun or outnumber them, or they grossly outgun or outnumber you.   If you do get this game you will find yourself dipping Hundreds of hours into it... but not actually fighting, but instead looking For a Fight.

Coffee Stain Studios has opted to take a break from their usual offerings of FPS/Tower Defense Hybrids to tackle the incredibly touchy and high bar genre of Farm Animal Sims.  You may ask if we truly need yet another goat simulation experience. With Maxis pretty much hitting it out of the park in the late 90′s with their PC classic: SimGoat. There were many poor attempts to cash in on the farm animal simulation craze of the era. Most notably were Goats! Goats! Goats! and Goat Herder Tycoon. However by the mid 2000′s the industry seemed to have milked that goat for all they could and turned their attentions towards farm machinery simulation.  Then out of nowhere came last year’s surprise hit: Goat Petting Simulator. Now the industry seems to be clamoring to get on the goat wagon once more. The first out of the gate of what will undoubtedly be a large herd of goats is none other than Coffee Stain Studio’s Goat Simulator. As you would expect from the well established genre, you are put in charge of a goat and must do goaty things.  There is the usual eating, licking, bleating, and jumping over things as you might expect from any goat sim. Also, with a modern graphics and physics engine we can experience the more destructive side of goats in full glorious 3d. Rag-doll physics are of course everywhere and you can get a little bit of glee as you watch your evil goat smash about.  There is also a lot of depth hidden here under the glossy surface. If your four legged fellah gets bored of his pen’s toys there’s plenty to explore and see. There is a nice, beautiful farm stretching off into the distance or your goat might fancy exploring the city. Like Goat Tycoon there are shops and such but there seems to be no sort of in-game economy. Lots of nice things to see in the store but no way to buy them. I was very disappointed there.  The game also tries to incorporate a quest system, like Goat Control. Although they are not clearly labeled there is plenty of things to do if you’re willing to explore and find it. Rise to the goat throne, summon aliens, rocket yourself off to space, or SACRIFICE THE BLOOD OF THE INNOCENT TO YOUR DARK GOAT GODS. Really they did a great job of coming up with so many little side quests and distractions. Some of them require a fair bit of planning as well, getting to space is especially hard, much harder even than Kerbel Space Program.  I must say though, mixing modern physics engines and graphics into Goat Simulation is quite a pleasant experience. The game is really well polished here and I’m quite amazed how well they pulled it off. There’s very few instances of objects clipping through walls or the goat suddenly spazzing out and rocketing up into the sky. There’s also a well done skater game style trick system that works really smoothly allowing you to land cool flips and such. Is that a person sticking out of a wall with their shadow left behind or modern art?  Is that a person sticking out of a wall with their shadow left behind or modern art?  Goat Simulator also does a great job of incorporating cool unlocks and add-ons. As you explore the world you will come across collectables here and there, some unlocking cool additions. Other add-ons are unlocked by completing some of the many quests, such as  SACRIFICING THE SOULS OF THE INNOCENT TO THE DARK GOAT GODS . This adds to an already lengthy game as you can play through again as a tall goat, a fast goat, or even a rocket powered goat!  I also thought the combat in the game seemed a little over powered. I mean   THE SOULS OF THE INNOCENT DO NOT OFFER ANY INKLING OF RESISTANCE  . And once you upgrade your goat with the baseball launcher, just forget about it. Game over. Nothing can stand in your way. It’s like a Michael Bay film and nothing will stop you as you blast everything in sight.  Overall though as I played and    UNLEASHED UTTER TERROR AND HELL UPON THE SOULS OF THE INNOCENT   , I couldn’t help but think this game just does not quite stack up to the old goat simulator classics of the late 90′s. Sure the graphics are shiny and there’s a nice new physics engine but the game just doesn’t bring anything new to the table. In the end you are just looking to set a new high score and I was very disappointed at a lack of multiplayer modes. The quests are cool and it’s fun trying out the different combinations of goat add-ons but did we really need another Goat Simulator? However if you’ve got $10 to spare I suppose you couldn’t do worse for a purchase on this April Fool’s Day.  Final Score: Graphics: 8/10 Game Play: 7/10 Music / Ambiance: 5/10 Story: 7/10 Value: 7/10 Overall: 6.8/10  Check out the full review with screenshots on my blog:  http://markofithian.com/review-goat-simulator/

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: Fallout 3 is definitely a good game, but whether or not you think it's one of the all-time greats will probably depend on whether you play it or New Vegas first. If you played New Vegas first, Fallout 3 will initially be a little bit of a letdown. New Vegas is definitely the better designed game overall. Better game mechanics, more options, more nuanced, and better overall design. Fallout 3 can sometimes feel like a generic FPS, with all of the 'closed space, tons of enemies, just keep attacking dozens of times and repeatedly using stimpaks' design that you encounter in about a third of the map. That flaw doesn't really exist very much in New Vegas, so it can initially be offputting when you repeatedly encounter it in Fallout 3.  However, if you played Fallout 3 first, you'll probably think it's one of the greatest games ever made. It was the first Fallout game that really showed that 'wow' factor and hinted at just how great the franchise could be. Plus, you'll be really impressed by the one thing that Fallout 3 does better than New Vegas: emotion. In New Vegas, you are basically a mythic character, with little back story. You don't have that much in common with the NPC's, who are basically mere mortals while you are pre-destined to be a god. I mean, the game starts off with you shrugging off a point-blank shot to the head. The courier might as well come from a different planet than all of the NPC's.   In Fallout 3, however, you really get emotionally pulled into the game. You're just an ordinary person who takes it upon themself to do great things. Your whole backstory is very fleshed out, and pretty heartrending. Karma plays a much bigger role in this game than in New Vegas, and makes the playing experience that much more immersive. Family plays a huge role, as do genuinely good NPC's such as Three Dog. The emotional depth of Fallout 3 is some of the best you will ever encounter in a game. If you played New Vegas first, you won't even realize that emotional depth was missing. If you played Fallout 3 first, you will be disappointed by New Vegas' lack of emotional depth, despite the fact that New Vegas is superior in pretty much every other way.  In the end, you'll learn to appreciate each game for what it does best. You'll probably wind up preferring whichever one you played first, but you'll still really enjoy both of them. If you already have New Vegas and not Fallout 3, I definitely reccomend purchasing this, just be aware that you'll have to adjust your expectations a bit and look for different positives in this game than you found in New Vegas.  PS.- Be sure to adjust some of the game files after you install the game. Once you do, the game seldomly ever crashes. Until you do that, it crashes every few minutes. See this thread for details, and also look up a fix regarding Games for Windows Live, which drastically affects the performance of Fallout 3:  http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2814142

I don't remember English and Japanese are the type of people always try to get max payment and do minium work, but somehow CA just turned into this after it was bought by Sega.  For so many years, CA didn't try to make decent siege battle. AI became slightly smarter, but I have seen people made better AI for Medieval II mod within few months.  Combat system has zero improvement, and even worse compare to that game they made 10 years ago.  I do not against adding health bar into total war game, but seeing a whole infantry get knocked down or send into air by calvery charge then they just stand up and beat the poop out of those knights makes me feel like being an idiot. Where is the anti charge animation?  By the way, it seems that CA didn't distinguish the difference between large units and calvery. It makes sense to have pikemen and halberdmen get bonus against knights because their weapon reach kept them safe while effective against men on the horses back, but why should giants care after all? Gaints‘s large clubs have the size of several men, and there is no pike or halberd long enought to touch their upper body yet in this game.   At last, all these features they added to force players to focus more on campaign did not make things more interesting nor realistic. Players buy Total War games for decent battles instead of manipulating agents and having armies fight automatically all time. Civilization, Crusader Kings did better job with campaign stratege.  Removing walls and limiting the armies player can recrut, and the attrition caused by Vampire corruption or the attrition for Vampire armies to enter uncorrupted provinces did not make things more interesting.

What Dota 2 lacks in combat, artstyle, innovation, entertainment value and pretty much everything else that is supposed to make a game good, it makes up for in its addictive qualities. If you enjoy investing over 1000 hours into a dull and repetitive game and getting practically nothing in return (except for the odd aesthetic item), then I would thoroughly recommend this game to you. It will have you glued to your computer for days on end, and even though your friends will slowly drift away over time, the thrill of clicking your mouse to move the collection of polygons that is your hero to another destination, or clicking on an enemy to attack them just never gets old or boring or stale or dull.

Incompetent developers that are:  1. Incapable of making a vehicle/infantry relationship that doesn't involve one cheesing the other.  2. Creates an anti cheat that automatically kicks and in some cases bans most high end players for legit play on new chars.  4. Refuses to unban said high end players even when they streamed or recorded entire play session until community uproar reaches critical mass and even then said devs makes sure to have plenty of insulting remarks in reddit/forum replies.  5. Extremely arrogant.  6. Incapable of optimizing the game.  7. Incapable of releasing a patch that doesn't create more bugs than it fixes.  8. Despises its own competitive community/fanbase.  9. When given the choice of dumbing the game down or adding more skill based mechanics, always dumbs it down.    I could go on. Its sad really. It happens to so many games these days. A great idea and a mechanically decent engine able to put so many people together. Unfortunetly SOE/DBG turned into what amounted to cavemen trying to run a nuclear reactor. Every time they try to fix or add anything they are just flailing around with their beating sticks hitting the reactor creating meltdown after meltdown. Combined with the extremely poor leadership of Smedley and some very poor choices from Higby (maxes are almost fine lol) until very reciently the game was simply doomed to ever be anything but a decent shooter turned mediocre by terrible vehicle/infantry relationships and a complete lack of using the larger scale of the game in a positive manner. Hopefully it recovers from their taint now that they are both gone, but I doubt it. DBG seems to be in its death throws.
