I'm a little surprised at the overwhelming positive response Five Nights at Freddy's has gotten. I suppose I can understand it's entertaining at first glance, but a lot of the reviews I've read have play times mostly less than an hour or two, and some admit they didn't get further than Night 3, which is totally understandable, post-Night 3 was probably where the entertainment factor dropped off for me and the game became an exercise in tedium. And then I played it for 6 or 7 more hours just to try to finish the thing out of obligation. Anyways, let me get this out of the way:  The game is innovative. The reason it's gotten as popular as it has is because it's a fresh take on a genre that sadly has been dragging its feet lately. I'd absolutely love to see more Horror games try new things like this, and it's not bad that people are experimenting with new ways to convey interactive horror. I'm just as sick of seeing cheap-quality episodic Amnesia knock-offs and 'Collect-Items-While-Monster-Stalks-You' romps as anyone else, but I still have severe enough gripes with Five Nights that I really can't give it a recommendation for anything other than as a very temporary novelty.  If you intend on fully experiencing this game, prepare for the possibility of a good couple hours failing the same night over, and over, and over. Seriously the 9 hours I spent on this were mostly Nights 4, 5 and 6, I eventually gave up at 6 because I decided the payoff was seriously not worth my time.  As it turns out, Five Night's idea of using energy management to build tension just doesn't work in its favor in the long-term. Once you boil the game down to its base mechanics, all the charm falls away really quickly, because there's a pretty limited amount to see, a very limited amount to do, and the strict limit on how much energy you can afford to waste on the latter nights becomes unrealistically tight to the point where if you don't play almost perfectly to each situation, and the AI is uncharacteristically passive for its activity level at those later points, you are often destined to lose before you're a little more than halfway through the night.  There's not much more frustrating than fending off your aggressive attackers for 10 minutes straight, only to realize you've failed the night because Bonnie wouldn't leave the door alone, or because Foxy made a run for you twice because you weren't watching Pirate Cove enough, or watching it too much.  Read all the guides you want, learn all the animatronics' behaviors, that's what I tried to do once just winging it on my own wasn't working out, but Five Nights gets tough as ♥♥♥♥ by late-game, and intense difficulty in what should be a short overall playtime for the length of each night does not impact the horror aspect positively. A horror game does not flourish by treading over the same ground time and again, and that's essentially all that Five Nights can do once you've died a few times.  The more time you spend with the game, the more you understand, the less likely it'll have anything new to scare you with, and once you hit that point all you have left is frustration that you can't save enough energy to last a couple seconds longer to the safety of 6 AM.  Five Nights builds suspense very well, and its characters are fittingly creepy, but in the end it's always coming up to a couple different animations that play alongside the same exact sound clip with a different model shaking in your face. It loses its edge, and fast. Especially once you learn the tells, like if your wall panel stops working and you check your camera, or if Pirate Cove is empty and you check the West Hallway camera. You come to expect every death, and the only fear comes from how irritating and headache-inducing that damned screaming sound clip is.  If you're looking for anything more than a novelty, something to spook friends with once or twice, you may find Freddy & Co. becoming a lot more frustrating than they ever were scary. However, if that's all you want, a quick little game to mess about with then uninstall and probably never play again, go for it. As for me, I've played enough of this thing to never really feel inclined to reinstall it. Also, it's getting a sequel? Come on...

To be honest, I didn't play this game a lot. However, I have seen the thousands of Youtube videos showing it. I was almost forced to buy it from my friend, now it just sits in my library. I wasted 10 dollars on this thing.  It got repetitive and not fun. Yeah, it was funny, for the first 20 minutes. Don't forget the graphics are way to 'you need a beast computer or else the crappy one you have now will explode'-like. Especially for a game like this where it's taken as a joke. A 10 dollar joke. There is no gameplay value. You bump into random people and things, find trophies, find easter eggs, thats all you get.   I'm really sorry, buddy, but this game that you forced me to get isn't good. There were so many games that I could get and you could have gotten. Both of us wasted our money on this thing. You might think it's fun, I don't. You're entitled to your opinion and I'm entitled to mine. I sold my Strange Bushi-Dou for about 10 dollars and I regret spending any of it on this piece of crap. I could have spent it on other, cheaper, and better games.   Whoever has this on their wishlist, get it off. This game isn't worth it. See that 0.5 hours up there? That's all I needed to play to fully experience it. I could spend 1 hours, 2 hours, or even 10 hours playing and I would give the same review. Every minute it's the same thing. The same boring and dry comedy.  I know this review isn't the best as I'm not the best review giver, but this is my honest opinion. I've been pondering over this exact game and what it means to me and this is what came out my finger tips and on to the screen. I said it once, and I'll say it twice, this game is a 10 dollar joke. Not those comedian jokes that actually have the slightest bit of potential of being funny, but one of those jokes you see on a popsicle stick, until you throw the popsticle stick away.

First: I like the style and the beautiful graphic design!  I am playing Total War Games since MTW 1 and I am a big fan of the series especially since mtw 2 introduced the multiplayer campaign. Multiplayer Campaigns never were the best designed mechanics in Total War Games but this time it´s horrible! I tried several campaigns with friends and the factor of unbalancing (also tried several mods to help balancing) is immense. Not only that the Game counts the provinces that both players have to determine the time to send in the chaos troops (the worst case was round 36 smashing the empire player to pieces) but also the scripted part that helps the single player to get some more income is missing entirely in multiplayer. Next problem are the diplomatic penalties that occur for playing coop with a friend. The only way way to play a multiplayer campaign is one player playing humies and the other the dawi and even is this case the balance is totally broken. The mod for playing both the same faction is a nice idea but if you are playing empire/balthasar you cannot use the offices for your generals. I could keep writing but I think there are too much problems to write them all down. By the way: If you play this campaign once (imagine the problems I described didnt´t exist) another game would be boring.  So my advice: If you want to play a great multiplayer campaign play Attila. This game is only for single Players who want to play a campaign in two or max three days and enjoy good graphics in battle. The strategic part is for 10 year old kids now.

I am almost certain that lots if not all people who have played the next-gen games would like to be a goat. i may not have played much of the great Goat simulator but i assure you that it is well worth your money. I think that people are too harsh on reviewing this game because of the fact that you are a goat. But they underestimate goats as a whole. If you think about it, without goats we would not have Frostbite 3, Titanfall, Hand cream and who can forget the wheel. The Wright Goats flying for the first time led to this game having jetpack goats. we humans think so much of ourselves and too little of the goats. So i ask you, not as a Goat supporter but as a fellow steam user and in some cases a friend. Give the goats a chance... Thank you.

Great game - I played Vampires with no problems.. but now am playin' empire and im getting game crashes which im currently trying to fix.   Apart from that - its great strategy and storyline, MUCH better than Rome/Rome II/ Attila, not quite up to the epicness of Shogun/Empire but still its pretty good.. Also - the vampires add a whole different playstyle and strategy to the game, which is really refreshing. Im guessing the orcs will be another dimension too..  p.s. This game is HARD :-) I tried 2 campaigns on vampires on hard mode and got killed both times! Had to revert to normal but still thats a real challenge too! Not for the faint-hearted.. :-)  Updated: The crashes have not been a big issue... had about 5 in total, and if you ask me - they are all related to graphic card overload (usually they happenin when im fielding many units in a battle and click on a spell or somethin that takes bit graphic power).. Simply followed the advice on forums etc to fix my crashes and seem to have mainly gone away..  Lovin' this game even more than when I wrote this review.. its actually pretty epic.. All the sh*t stuff that was in Rome/Attila is basically fixed (broken public order, broken AI, units dont route too easily etc..). The only thing they still need to fix is the constant skill pointing. But this game is basically what Rome II should have been.. and then some..! (had they not released Rome a year too early..!). The 'Warhammer twist' adds a whole 'nother dimension to the game.. and the spell casting etc. is a great feature.   HIGHLY RECCOMMEND.

An absolutely fantastic experience. The developers screamed 'Have fun with this great island we created!', and oh, I have had so much fun it is unbelievable. Vaas is probably the best villain in a game this year, on the same level as Comstock and Handsome Jack in my books; he seems like a genuinely crazy person, with full control of his insanity. You really learn to be afraid of him, and he can be truly intimidating, in a different way than most of the modern villains we see in movies and games, respectively. A must-buy for everyone. Just a little notion: I recommend you have at least a GTX 460 or the AMD equivalent, since you will want to experience this game in its (near-)fullest glory; the world does so many wonders to the story, so enjoy it all by having a decent PC! The game is really well optimized as well, so you can pull amazing graphics on older systems as well, so give it a go no matter what! Truly one of my recommendations I can be really happy about.

Planetside 2 is a pioneer in the realm in both the genres of MMO and Military FPS. Set in the far future on the planet Auraxis, it pits 3 factions against one another in an eternal struggle for territorial dominance. You incarne a soldier off one of these 3 factions and thanks to the increbidible advancements in nanotechnologies, you have virtually unlimited lives, but so does your enemies. This results in a virtually endless fully PvP driven war.  What does this means in term of gameplay? Picture this, a typical server may host thousands of player at any given time and currently the battlefield consist of 4 huge maps, called continents. Said maps are dotted with dozens of bases each, some relatively small, others huge and all with a unique layout. However your objective on each base remains the same, to gain and maintain control over the one or multiple capture nodes, similar to a domination match in Call of Duty or the Conquest mode of Battlefield. It's actually closer to the Conquest style of Battlefield because the game features combined arms style warfare, including 5 basic classes of infantry, a heavy 7 ft tall mech suit for each faction, 5 different land vehicules, one of which is unique for each faction and 4 air vehicules, againt with 1 unique to each faction.  However, the game being an MMO, you will NOT (well rarely) have even fights in the style of classic FPS without some work. Sometimes you will join a group 200 strong to go capture a base that merely 10 people show up to defend and not even need to fire your gun once, other times would will be among the 10 dudes getting stomped by an army. And that doesn't sound really enjoyable now does it? No. The trick here is that you must use the map tool provided to you to find the good fights, would it be small skirmirshes or abosulety insane 200vs200 showdowns, you must learn to find these relatively fair encounters and stick to those. If you simply wander off at random, PS2 will not be a great experience.  Being an MMO, it would do you good to also find an outfit (called guild or clan in other games) to join so that you always have people to play with. It is exceedingly rare that a solo lone wolf player will be able to affect a battle with any degree of significance. Planetside 2 cares little for your K/D ratio. As a sniper you could kill 20 people and never die and still lose the fight because you ain't killing the medics reviving those 20 people you killed earlier, negating your efforts. Likewise an engineer who killed no one during and entire battle but kept his tank lines alive so THEY could kick some ♥♥♥ probably contributed more to a victory than the guy who picked off a few isolated kills. Planetside 2 is a game about logistics. In order to win a fight, you must bring at least a matching number of offenders to defenders and then manage to break the reinforcement lines of your enemy, usually by destroying key assests like Sunderers (Heavy transport vehicules that can be deployed as spawn points) or sieging the spawn rooms of a base.  When a side wins a battle can captures a base or succesfully defends one, they will naturally transition to going after the next base over and try to conquer it, at which point the losing side of the previous battle must muster their numbers again and try to defend that new objective. In a way, once you find a good fight, it's quite simple to keep following it wherever it evolves and keep enjoying your time with PS2. Following your outfit when they rally in numbers to execute a specific plan is also a good bet. In the worse cases, you can always click that 'join squad' button and deploy where the game thinks you'll find some action and it will give you a decent fight, most of the time.  As far as customization goes, it's fairly solid. The game gives you most of the basic, all around set ups you need to be effective and you can purchase additionnal weapons with more specialized roles later on. You can customize A LOT of stuff, from all of your infantry classes, mech suit and vehicules, to the implants you are using and the look of your character. There's a lot of functionnal and cosmetic upgrades. The gear you can get with in game currency you acquire as you fight or with real money. Mostly the cosmetic stuff is with real money only (They have got to make a buck some where I guess) My only beefs with the upgrades and customization are these : 1. It takes A LONG TIME to upgrade your account with in game earn credentials. The stuff is expensive! Gettting all of it for free will require you hundreds if not thousand of hours of play, so you better buckled down for a long treadmill ride. 2. While most of the gear you acquire could be considered sidegrades, like a gun that trades off the accuracy of your basic gun for a better rate of fire for example, some of the stuff you can eventually unlock is simply a plain upgrade over the basic gear. A good example would be the engineer's repair tool or the medic healing gun, which both have a series of linear upgrades that give them more range and faster revive/repairs. A guy with fully upgraded flak armor will take 50% less damage from explosion compared to the greenhorn who probably only just got the basic 10% one and so on and so on.  The end result is that people who paid more than you or played longer than you will have an edge until you catch up. It shows when a few newbies try to tackle even one experienced player, but it becomes nightmarish when a few newbies meet a few experienced players who better knowledge of the game, more practice, better teamwork AND well upgraded gear. Pro tip, you find high level players from your team? STICK WITH EM. Join their outfit too if they let you.  Technically the game at the time of writting this review works fine. Used to be very buggy and unplayable, but they fixed most of the bugs. You will however need a fairly decent PC to run this game. Nothing too extravagant, but do not expect an 8 year old machine to run this game. Big fights become notoriously CPU demanding So I would invest in a modern CPU, at least a decent i5 or you will have to skip the title entirely.  However for those who can cope with the specs requirement, the F2P grind and the challenge of learning how to find the good fights, Planetside 2 will reward them with a very competent and enjoyable Massive Multiplayer First Person Shooter Futuristic War Simulator. That's a long list of barriers to entry I understand, but at least you can try it out for free. Give it at least 5-10 hours before you decide. You might get hooked for one hell of a ride.

Dota 2 is a great game, easy to get into and very, very, very hard to master. Actually that's a lie. It's IMPOSSIBLE to master. It by itself is a great game, with tons of chareacters as well as a variety of arcade gamemodes. It's main gamemode is a competitve team battle, for the competitive gamer. The only things that could be looked down in my short time of playing are these; the game is not very open to the noob who doesn't really try to get better, just kinda sticks to the basics. To me that is good, as only players who have the drive to get better will really enjoy the game. That said, some people will view this as a bad thing, mainly because either they are that player or they feel that everyone should be included. There are better arguments out there to support this being a bad thing, but none I can presently remember. The other problem is the extremely salty community. A lot of dota 2 players that I've seen jump at the chance to criticize people worse than them and blame a lost game on them. That isn't to say that all players are that way, I've met some pretty nice dota 2 players who are competitive and aren't that salty. There are also times when it is completely reasonable to blame someone, like if that someone is throwing a game or just fooling around. But, a lot of the time dota 2 players are unjust in their criticism, like blaming first time noobs and players who are not playing at their fullest. But in all, the behavior of some players pales in comparison to such a great game.

Now, I haven't played this game for long, and i've neglected it since I first found out of it's exsistance a couple years ago, but this game is really fun. Many, many heroes to choose from, each with their own distinct abilites. It's insane fun. The community is mostly good, some bad apples here and there, but I cannot reccommend this game for one sole reason; the punishment system.  Now I live out in the country side, and my internet is pretty good most days, but there will be a day or two where it will be so bad, I will lose internet for a good few minutes. Now when i'm playing DOTA and that happens, that really ticks me off. I lose connection, i'm kicked from the game and given a penalty, having to play specific amount of single-draft games before I can play regularly. This pisses me off, and I think for a good reason. I can see why it would deter people from playing, and I don't blame them.  So for all of you out there with questionable internet, I advise you to stay away from this game, unless you enjoy having the urge to find the nearest puppy and kick it. Valve, if you read this, please, PLEASE, remove this punishment crap from the game. TF2 doesn't have this problem, but I understand why you think punishing people from a game like this might be acceptable, but try to consider those whose internet is that of sticking my ethernet cord into a potato. But yeah, Valve, fix your crap.

Just play ♥♥♥♥ing cookie clicker, seriously. This game is ♥♥♥♥. There is NO reason to play this game instead of cookie clicker. The art style, uninspired, generic, boring. You stare at a square and watch generic enemies die and immediately get replaced. SO ENGAGING. With Cookie Clicker you have a theme, yes it varied to things that didnt produce cookies eventually, but heres the thing, that was a JOKE, and it got more and more extreme. This just does whatever it wants, its not funny, the descriptions and names arent clever, its just oh hey heres an upgrade.  Seriously, theres assassins, Betty Crocker, and a tree monster. Its not even consistantly more absurd it gets more and less unreasonable as it wants. In cookie Clicker, the upgrades were funny, in here, they're upgrades. Cookie clicker was something subtly clever that had a feeling of actual structure and progression, it knew what it wanted to be about and where it was going, from cookies to eltritch gods.   It doesnt even have all the features cookie clicker has, Theres no wrinklers, Golden Cookies, no text on the top telling clever jokes, nothing. The only new feature is a line of unlockable abilities like this is ♥♥♥♥ing WoW and its far less interesting. It ***MAY*** have a ripoff of Cookie Clickers presiege system with heavenly chips and such, but as far as I can tell that wont be of much value, and frankly its not worth your time to get there.  Everyone saying that you'll break your mouse is an idiot, everyone knows clicking stops being useful in cookie clicker relatively quickly. The art styles generic, theres no theme or humor (at best theres an enemy that looks almost lawsuit levels of similar to TMNT, and something about one of the upgradable characters holding back) by the way, it doesnt give you like buildings or troops to ramp up absurdity, it gives you some random character of some random proffesion, soon to become obsolete, but they do occasionally have an upgrade that buffs everyone, at least Cookie Clicker had something to keep your cursors useful, buffing theme for every building you have, this doesnt have something like that.  The most insulting thing really is that they put microtransactions into this low effort ripoff, not even the sound effects or music have the slightest bit of originality, just play ♥♥♥♥ing Cookie Clicker, Candy Box 1 or 2, or A Dark Room, and if you want music listen to your own damn music. Hot tip devs, what do Cookie Clicker, Candy Box, and Dark Room have that you DONT.  One, some ♥♥♥♥ing charm, they all have something unique and interesting about them other than just idling and occasionally ♥♥♥♥ing with them, from hidden game mechanics to jokes and wit, to hidden lore and progression to the absurd. Also, some MEANINGFUL progression Cookie Clicker shows you what youve accumulated, and grows, Candy Box expands far beyond what you'd ever expect, Dark Room adds some new tricks, expands, and gives you a twist that those who werent paying attention would never expect. This game is shallow, ininspired, cripplingly lacking in charm, and just ♥♥♥♥ing generic and soulless.  Did you know Cookie Clickers still being developed, yeah the guy didnt abandon it despite its 15 minutes of fame being over, its come a long way, and its far more inspired and charming than this. Also A Dark Room and Candy Box while being a bit different still have a charm and soul to them that this game simply cant have. Wanna know WHY? People say that when art ceases to be about art they mean it doesnt exist because the art itself is its reason to exist, it stops being about something that deserves to exist and be created because its just to good to let fade into the void. When you create something new, you get something new, when you make something to spread a message, you wont learn anything but the message you forced in and cease to learn or grow from it, when its about money, you cut corners and refuse risks and shamelessly rip off the work someone else has made because you dont care about creation enough to make something ♥♥♥♥ing interesting, in short, no, this games not interesting, this isnt a a good idle game, it has no charm, it has no soul, and despite being free it still feels either made for a quick buck, an amature product made for practice that was uploaded to steam because why not, or some blend of the 2, its not worth your time.

Planetside 2 was amazing. Was. The beta and alpha releases were spectacular. The different races were balanced, the different weapons were balanced and there was no 'Tactic to Rule Them All' because for each combat style there was an effective counter.  The game looked amazing, and handled like it too. Shiny graphics in decent frames even on my average computer. (GTX 560, 3.2Ghz core.)  Then about one or two weeks after came the first patch, and I'm not entirely sure what SOE was aiming at, but it literally broke the game engine. From being able to run the game at a ~70 FPS on high/highest graphics, after the 'patch' was installed my computer could barely start it up. It became a personal war on .dll files to even be able to play the game. This was the first graphical improvement patch that SOE released. This was apparently the kind of work that SOE considered an improvement.  They then went on to 'improve' the game balance by ruining the class weapons for one race while buffing the same class on another to the point it was the only one worth using. (Example: The Vanu MAX anti-air guns became more useful for shooting infantry with than that class' anti-infantry guns which got nerfed into the ground. The NC MAX anti-infantry shotguns became so powerful they could be used to destroy light vehicles at 200 yards.)  And you might ask: 'But the alpha and all that happened ages ago, and there have been many updates and improvements since.'  And I ask in turn: Do you think those improvements are deemed as such by you as a player, or by SOE? The team who within a month of release had managed to destroy their own game by trying to make it better? It's true that they released the Roadmap system to try and combat their own incompetence, but it was too little too late and it's not exactly something they have followed anyway.  In short, do not recommend. It's a weird situation where I say that the alpha and even the beta were better than the current release. If you want a sci-fi multiplayer combat game, try one of the Star Wars Battlefront games instead.

First of all I want to excuse me for my English and I'm going to explain all the issues I had with FC3.  Before I bought the game I used to play it 'pirate' with the version 1.04 that was working normal on single-player.  1. My game crashes after every match on MP and as I searched there's NO SOLUTION.  2. For a week I was not able to join any game and got stuck on the finding lobby. I have no idea how I solved it. All other games/programs and Uplay games where working ok.  3. I lost all my save games and I couldn’t use a download save game because they are encrypted with your Uplay username. As someone who played WHFB in the 4th and 5th edition days, I am very pleased to finally get to play it on pc. It's like my childhood come alive, but without the exorbitant prices of miniatures and the lead poisoning.   The races has been lovingly recreated and play very differently from each other. DLC is fairly frequent and more importantly, of a very good quality (I didn't get the Beastmen one, so can't speak for that). Some people have been concerned about the price, and while it can seem high it pales into insignificance compaired to the truckloads of cash I've forked over to GW for little metal dudes in pointy hats throughout my misspent youth. All three games in the trilogy + all the DLC will cost you less than the tabletop game and a single army. So there's that.  Now, bring on the High Elves. I  need  them.

The storyline in this game is solid. You start as some tourist and some terrible circumstances turn you into a bada**.   I only have 2 complaints (SPOILERS SORTA)    1. You 'die' too much in the story. I stopped counting at the 4th attempt on my life by Vaas. I am not done iwth the game yet but I think the writers went a bit overboard with the number of times people kill you in the story and yet somehow you miraculously survive. Not a game breaker though.  2. Your character 'Jason' falls deeper and deeper into complete bada**ness as the game progresses. This is awesome. However, I think they fell short on the voice acting here. His voice throughout still sounds pretty innocent and clueless. I would have preferred the actor put some more ...'growl' in it as he becomes more jaded with life. Again, not a game breaker.   I would recommend this game for sure. The combat is solid, the jungle is beautiful (but sadly not as flamable as the dry plains in FC2), and the finishing moves are awesome.

Note this review is very strict :P .  Planetside 2 review  I USED to like the game , now I dont. I stopped playing about 3 months since March 2014 and came back during the Hossin Continent update, in hopes of a more fun and balanced gameplay. But it dissapointed me on so many levels. I was rusty when I came back but none the less I still remember the core mechanics and how to point and shoot. I played a few hours and died a lot, but its was to be expected after 3 months of leaving the game. About 15 hours in and not only my PPH (points per hour) was still drop to a measely 500/hr but my kill death ratio per game was more or less 0.2 to 0.1, not that I'm complaining since I'm an objective based player, but there is a lot of scenarios that I would have gotten a kill and survived with heavy injuries, but still alive before this update rolled out.  The changes are noticeble, infantry shield and hp was lowered , especially noticeble on the MAX suits , weapon damage was also changed for some of them. Some of the utility or special abilities of the class was changed in term of drain/ cooldown/ effect/ power , making a significant improvement in 1 of the classes but a significant drawback for the other. Graphics wise, it still looks the same but something has been change and is eating up my pc's power. Vehicles have been change as well and their weapons as well, mostly buffed. The point system is overall the same , that or slightly better. The deathcam has been improve I guess , but only slightly. The Hossin map is still under testing phase so the constant infantry and vehicles stuck are neglible and the map itself is good , thought that area lacks people playing. The teamwork of the game have mostly been lost , and objective based gameplay is pretty non-existent , most players now just care about their kill death ratio. The factions itself is now very unbalnced as well , it was about 30% TR , 30% NC , 40% VS when I last played , now its around 60% TR 30% NC and 10% VS. Now right now I maybe sound like some VS supporter, but mind you I play as all 3 factions and my favourite is TR because of their increased firerate and magazine size. But now the factions dominance is so unbalanced it's almost impossible for other minority to recover some of their bases. TR can fight on 3 front of the continent and win 2 of them, while the rest fight on the remaining continent barely making progress. As usual SOE still kept their currency at a decent price not too high and not too low. But the charge for most of the in game item is still expensive and the progress of getting cert ( the games earnable currency ) is still very bad grinding no matter how good you are.   This is what gets me now, for all games I review based on 10 main things, the New user experience, the casual player experience, the experienced player experience, music , art style (or graphics) , price ( in this case in game microtransation items ) , progress (if the game has any) , its main theme ( multiplayer , single player , story telling , etc ) , its community , and last but not least , the MOST important thing for games, whether you are satisfied playing the game or completely hated it or mutual ( short version : fun or not).  New user (1 to 10 lvls) : Worst than before, the shield and hp system is very weak for the new user and hence they will die a lot faster and their starter weapons are not as good as they used to be.  Casual players (5 to 40 lvls) : Overall not much has changed based on what I seen , you can play normally without getting 1 shotted most of the time and an advantage will normally guarantee your 1v1 scenarios.  Experience players (41 and beyond) : Pretty much has all the infantry stuff mastered (not sure about vehicles ecause gameplay choices) , has very good gear that can overpower most low level enemy players and a very upgrade suit.  Music : Hasnt changed from what Iheard from the 3 factions, them songs is still the same I believe with TR a bit sadistic , VS and bit weird and alien like, and NC as um... western texas type of music. Weapons sounds have been change and is sounds much better now.  Graphics : No comment other than cant see cloaked inflitators while using low settings.  Price : Free but in game microtransactions are a tad bit high  Progress : Utterly slow at all levels unless you become a member, then you have a score system that actually means nothing when you think about it, cert gain is a pain as mentioned before ( exp 30 certs for a scope and 250 score pts to get 1 cert pts, so around 7500 score points to get just 1 scope) as for weapons, even longer as anyone would expect.  Main theme : It should be a competitive multiplayer on a very very very large scale. It does that well at the start but because of the unbalnced faction, its not like that anymore, you either win or lose with a landslide on the normal to large scale battles (not accounting for the 4v4 base atk and def, cuz that's not large scale :P)  Community : I chatted with the players in game, allies and enemies, visited the forums, overall quite good for a shooter, much much better than Call of Duty's community.  Fun or not: As of the Hossin update no, unless you are leveled with decent suit upgrades and weapons, new users will get destroyed no matter what, even then the unbalanced faction wars couple with slow progress makkes the game a pain to play, statistically the weapons arent overpowered when compared with the dafault ones, but when you play, you will notice that its very different in comparison. For the paid or the one with the heart to grind throught everything, its an enjoyable experience. At the based level we all deserve a free to play game that is fun right from the start, not after paying over 60USD or grinding 800 hours into the game.  Serious Score: 47. 67 % (Note: decimals dont mean anything) Normal Score: 63. 54 % dropped as of Hossin Update

Imagine you go to a restaurant and order a salad. The plate comes back with 3 medium-sized peices of lettuce, and nothing else, not even silverware. You ask the waiter, 'Where's my salad?'  The waiter responds, 'That is your salad. Lettuce.'  'Where's everything else? Tomatoes, carrots, and all the toppings.'  'Oh, that'll be extra.'  That's what this game is. They give you the extreme bare-bones for a game for 60 bucks, then release the rest of it in $10-20 peices. One of the 'DLC's' literally only adds a bit of extra blood to some of the animations... for 4 bucks. What a rip-off.  Other than that, it's an excellent game. I don't recommend it so people might choose to not buy this and the game company won't be rewarded for robbing us blind.  Edit: Lol, due to all the reviews ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on them for their horrible DLC poilcy, they gave us a 'free content upgrade.' All it is is a couple of heroes, and a reskin of another one... They continue to mock us, thinking they can cover up the terrible things they did with a bit of flash.

First I want to say how much I have enjoyed this game. It is a great game. The Total War gameplay has come a long way, and it is very impressive. However, I cannot say that I can recommend this game. In comparison to other Total War franchises, the content isn't bad. The problems I have with the game are more related to the lack of Warhammer content. I had chose to wait to write this review hoping that they would release the missing races/factions as free DLC. Man was I wrong. While I got the Chaos Warriors for free as a preorder bonus, anyone else is going to have to purchase these guys at $8. Then, if you want to actually see blood effects, decapitation, etc, you are out another $3. Come on Sega. That's crap. This is a war game, that stuff should be included. I said to myself, 'Lets wait it out and see'. Nope. I was still wrong. Now, starting 7/28/16, you can pay another $18 to buy the Beastmen(A race that should have been included to begin with). I know that sega is prob still in the hole to creative assembly and is using these DLC to pay for it, but I am serious when I say do not waste your money on this game. Do not even pay 50%. Because you will end up spending at least another $30 in an attempt to complete this game. Be forwarned, they will release another race for this at more rediculous pricing. Can't say I didn't warn you.

No low level Duel mode, near impossible to hone your skills when you're vastly outclassed by your opponent. Free For All, Last Team Standing, and Team Objective all have low level servers, but as fun as they are, they don't really help you improve in one on one situations.  The community is terrible. Everyone seems to have f'd my mother!! You aren't allowed to use game mechanics without constant whining.  Overall, I'd say the game isn't worth its price tag. Sticking Free For All on and running about screaming and smashing heads is good for a laugh, but the game's flaws really show in Duel mode. Probably worth around £5-10.

This game is fantastic!  A lot of people seem to be uncomfortable with the union of Total War and Warhammer game play and lore, but, I have found it to be a breath of fresh air in the Total War collection. The biggest complaint is that you cannot conquer every territory and to that I say... so what? Each nation has specific victory objectives that have nothing to do with those territories and it keeps the end game interesting because you cannot neatly shield in your empire without having these little gaps for the AI to sneak into, even if you have razed the province.  Which brings me to the biggest con, the AI is not great. Battle AI is fine but the campaign AI leaves much to be desired. Why is it that by turn 93 the Vampire counts have not taken a single territory?? Playing as the Counts you can easily unify Sylvania in a few turns... WTF? The only region that seems to actually expand are the Greenskins and I am starting to believe it is only due to the fact that they are blessed with the Waaaagh! and can throw their might around without any real strategy like a noob…  There does seem to be a great deal of balancing issues and many graphics problems and even spelling mistakes in game (and no I am not talking about armour and the like) how about “wielding an az” WTF is an az? Last I checked “az” is a Dwarf word for place. So the Dwarf soldiers wield a mighty place?  Most of the things that frustrate me about this game a product of present game manufacturing: Rush to launch with a great idea and bank on massive patches and updates to fix all of the things you weren’t willing to devote the resources to earlier on. Remember when a game would go up for sale and when you installed it that was it? You’re best hope back then was for an expansion pack… Now it’s all DLC and hotfixes… at least the updates don’t cost anything… yet…

Your life in Dota will begin with you being a complete noob. Let's skip that part. You will then, hopefully, become an all-pick player, having progressed out of limiteds. Everything will seem hunkey dorey. Then, if you made it to phase two, you will advance to RANKED matches. Once you get to ranked, you will notice things.  Your team always seems to suck. Your team always seems to blame you for their shortcomings. When you call mid, put your token on mid, and lock in a mid character, two other teammates will do the same after you. When you have a stable mid going, teammates will wander over and stand around taking your farm under the pretence of 'ganking'. When you have a nice safelane, you will suddenly be jarred from farming as the pudge with a 3 level advantage hooks you out, because your mid was too busy to call missing and your supports too busy rushing aghanims to buy wards. When you die, and had a controversial pick, your team will immediately report you and tll you they did so. For good measure they will probably throw in a few 'noob unistal doto' and 'noob stahp fed'. You will be lucky if you get an apology or a commend from those players 30 minutes later as you carry them to victory.  No matter how much you are wounded, no matter how much MMR you lose to ♥♥♥♥ teams, you will ALWAYS come back for more.

I have't played Planetside 2 (PS2) in months, but I'll write from what I remember. PS2 is very zergy. Fights are boring stalemates among a a couple a of bases that don't move for hours or possibly days. Also, random, unneeded nerfs are the norm with this game. Go to the official forums and you'll see a lot of threads whiny people calling for nerfs for little to no reason. The devs also seem very apathetic to the game and make very little to no new content besides random guns, camos, and other cosmentics. Also the maps are rather boring and lifeless. They lack functionality and despite their size, most of the time you'll being playing arena deathmatches in bases or just sitting your spawn room while the enemy bombards it. Vehicles are made of tissue paper and hit like tennis balls while infantry just demolishes them, thus making vehicle play far more on the useless side. This game is very grindy and the grind is pratically the only point to it. There's no real interesting goals or anything for long term play, just grinding and killwh*ring. There's far more bad things I could say, but I'll start to wrap this up. This game is basically a mind numbing and boring slog with little point. The large battles are rather poor and unimpressive. Honsetly, if you want to try out a good game witht this IP or sci-fi like MMOFPS, there's always the first Planetside at here:  https://launch.soe.com/installer/PS_setup.exe , but that's a hacker ridden and dead game. To me it's just far better than this POS. This review could be more me being ultra jaded on this game and me realizing that Planetside 1 is FAR better. but my opinion stands. Avoid this game completely. Your valuable time and money are better spent somewhere else. This game's major gimmick of large battles is not worth taking an intellectual dump and wasting anything of value of yours on it. This is a fundamentally f*cked up game with an identity crisis, and in my experience, games with an identity crisis suck.

NO.. You might have the Dota 2 Logo all bright and shiny everywhere in the UI but this is not Dota. After this mandatory pre-beta Reborn download it's just been downhill, hit rockbottom and kept digging. After every update, it just gets worse.   I'm fine with cinks and bugs, I freely participate in Beta releases like Hots, Reborn, Windows 10 etc. It's not the bugs, it's all these changes, that has made me hesitate to double-click the Dota icon for me. After 700+ hours Dota takes away levels and gives me an icon that changes when I level up. Great but now the one match I'm playing with people with 1000+ hours and it's how Dota always was. Next, a match with people who don't even have a steam profile yet. The experience mmr bracket is ruined by the new levelling system incorporated into this chaos.  The T5I is over and the compendium rewards are STILL buffering. We were supposed to get them easily 4-5 months ago. 'There have been compatibility issues regarding the desert terrain and the axe immortal is still being made', fine you're busy, but then why rush a pre-beta then and release several treasury items when we're still waiting for what we paid for since the beginning of 2015?  I'm not saying it's a horrible game, I'm saying it's not what it was and I don't like the direction it's going into. It changed too much too quickly, it's missing several key factors that is being pushed aside for the illusion of progress.   To those who are thinking of joining the Dota 2 community, Dota is not what it used to be. I do not recommend Dota 2 Reborn at this current time and probably will not in the future.

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: I was very excited to play Fallout in 3D, but for several reasons, didnt enjoy my time. The most annoying thing was the slow pace of the game: The character moves very slow, pathes are blocked everywhere, so that it takes ages to get to a certain undiscovered location, and the inventory is very limited, so that you will have to travel back to town all the time. Then, i didnt like the new combat mechanics, that are a mixture of first person shooter and turn based. And finally, i didnt like the atmosphere of the game. I understand that the game plays in a post-apocalyptic world, but the setting just doesnt apply to me...
The game is fun at first but it just gets boring over time, I regret buying this game I am sorry to say. Maybe other people will like it more I just don't like it

My nominee for 'Best us of a Farm Animal' award 2016 - and may god have mercy on me for it.  The developers say so right in the description on the store page, this is a waste of your money...well they're right. It manages to be fun in 20 minute increments before becoming boring. Some time later it may interest you again, but the interest wears off quickly. Still, I can say I've had way more fun playing this game than I should.  This game is a packaged asset flip using free assets, bought assets, donated assets, and dropped together in a physics sandbox consisting of a handful of maps where you, a goat who breaks everything you crash into, run around smashing things into other things until unexpected stuff happens which makes you laugh. Usually these things involve explosions, you flying through the sky, fire, cars, building collapses, and whatever else you may not immediately think of. If you are the kind of person who goes, 'I wonder what will happen if I toss x at y,' you will be well served by this game.  The gameplay gets no more complicated than that, there are weird things to find across the map which change up how you make stuff crash into other stuff, but nothing gets more involved than running around a map creatively breaking things.  Goat Simulator is what it is. It doesn't try to be more than it advertises, and that may be its best strength. The quality is far higher than any one-note-joke you can download for free, but a quality one-note-joke wears out as quickly as a cheap one. I don't regret my purchase and I've had more fun in this game than I probably should have, but I will say your money is better spent elsewhere.

FULL REVIEW: I love this game so much. The fact that you can bring down a full gas station is enormously funny, plus the fact that every time you blow up a car by headbutting it, the explosion sends you majesticly careening into the air, which is twice as good in slow motion to watch. I also love that the game has a workshop to download even more things to make the game better and ultimately extend the hours that you play the game. To me, every hour is worth it. I love how this game has really funny AI to where if the ragdoll, it's over for them, and you can them lick them and drag them around, which is hilarious to watch and listen to the person you have captive. Plus, I love the ring of goats where you can fight the goats, and the challenge is always pushing you to try again, unless you're easily frustrated. The game has many other funny things that I enjoy as well, like the AI in the Coffee Stain Studios building flying into a wall and still typing, or really any AI getting stuck in a wall to the point where they have a seizure. The goat though, I have not yet adressed. The goat constantly has a tongue hanging from its mouth like a dog, and the neck the goat has is so glitchy that sometimes when you headbutt something the neck extends to the point that a giraffe doesn't look very awkward, and the head flys upward along with the head. No, the neck doesn't go very smoothly either. It spazzes before it flies. Not to mention, if you headbutt something explosive, such as a gas tank or a propane tank, your character literally flies. One thing I didn't address was that it has a spazfest before it begins to majestically fly. The baa button is also very clever. You could press the button once and it would let out a normal baa. But sometimes if you press the button, the  goat lets out a banshee-like scream, adding to the hilarity of the game. What's nice about the developers is that they listened to their fans, and they made a MMO mode, which I have not yet had the chance to experience, but from what I've heard and seen, it also looks as great. Which goes to show Coffee Stain Studios does infact listen when their fans speak, unlike most other game developing companies, indie or not. Now you noticed that at the beginning of my review I didn't go into any detail about the workshop. So as my final thing to address on this game is the workshop. The workshop allows you to download what are essentially mods for the game, whether it be a horror map, which function quite well if enough time is put into them, or a skin for the goat, which can turn out hilariously wrong. What is nice about the ability to download different maps is that you can use your imagination and do literally whatever you can within the already widened parameters of the game itself.    FINAL VERDICT: Goat Simulator is a very enjoyable game to play, as I have played past the point of a day, and nearly to the point of 2 days, and every second has been thoroughly enjoyable enjoyable. I could not find one thing bad about this game whatsoever, and thus Coffee Stain's Indie game Goat Simulator earns a perfect score of 10/10!

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: The game is pretty bad. After finally losing a good time solving the crashes that happen every 10 seconds, you'll start to play a game where enemies are bullet sponges (and to top that you have the accuracy of a blind ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ toddler - with or without the useless VATS system), the dialogs and consequences are stupid, everything is expensive to buy and stupidly cheap to sell making the player character a dumb, gullible imbecile, and by the time you've spend enought experience points to alleviate one of these problems, the others will still be there but you'll probably stop playing before that even happens (like myself). Oh, by the way, big ♥♥♥ boring lands without at least a vehicle to traverse them the first time (you have to 'discover' locations before you enable fast travel).
great game to play with friend

UPDATE: March 04, 2016: I've deleted the review and uploaded a version without cursing, in an attempt to see if that's the reason the review wasn't showing up on the store page.  -------------------------------------  *is killed before i can even see the sword flying at my face*   me: 'well that's a dumb exploit'  guy: 'it's not an exploit because it's a part of the game'  (direct quote, i've also heard it from about 50 other 'pro' players)  devs: 'what he said'   I recommend it if you have a time machine that can take you back to 2013. Otherwise sod it  --------------------------  Let's be serious now.  I am not the type to chicken out at the sight of a little competition, but this is ridiculous, and no self-respecting human being should have to subject themselves to having to perform sly, underhanded trickery tantamount to hacking in order to win in a (BEEP)ing video game.  I HAVE had legitimate duels with skilled players who didn't 'drag' or feint, and it is some of the most fun I've ever had in a multiplayer game.  However, In the last 75-100 hours of play I've probably had less than 50 of those.  But let's not blame the community for everything, after all, the developers could have easily fixed these problems, and if they had this game would no doubt still be extremely popular.  If they had fixed these issues. if they gave a flying (BEEP) about their game, it would most likely still have the excellent, funny, chivalrous community I fell in love with 2 years ago.  But they didn't.  Oh, well. At least I can buy a microtransaction that makes my sword look slightly different.

Dota 2 is a great game, at least for the FIRST COUPLE HOURS (yes in caps). The most terrible thing in this game is the community. They swear at you for no reason or for just some small mistakes that will not have a big effect on the entire match (i.e not denying a creep when playing a support. And that was only one creep). Or sometimes you get cussed by a person because of the person's own mistake (i.e A lvl 2 Faceless void rush to the enemy tower to chase an enemy hero with 40 HP left, and then the void dies while the chased doesn't. The void curse at Rubick, his/her laning partner for not giving a heal) it's like messed up. Or sometimes you can also find people being racist. I personally stop playing public matches for like 4 month and I only play againts bots (because they don't curse at you). In a month period (perhaps), maybe i'll just stop playing Dota. Unless some miracle or something unexpected happen. And the chance for those event to happen is like 0.01%  I definitely don't recommend this game (I myself actually regret dowloading this)

Does that game seem good? And to add to that trainwreck of a game I just described, there are microtransactions! Who needs to wait for some monster to die when you can just use real money to speed things up? So when you play the game (should I even refer to it as a game?) you have two options: Wait incredibly long amounts of time for no reason, or pay real money to not wait incredibly long amounts of time. Or you can do the third option: Don't play it.

Far Cry 3 does everything a open world fps should do:  + The island you're in is GIGANTIC. There is always something to do, explore, and discover  + The missions are unique from fast-paced action to stealth to platforming  + Killing enemies is challenging but very rewarding, escpeically if you use stealth which the game encourages.   + You're able to equip 4 guns of any class and customize them however you want   + Crafting is simple and essential to increase your survivability  My only nitpick isn't in gameplay but the games NPC's, who I find annoying (especially the character you play as). The exception is the games villians Vaas and Hoyt who are the most developed and sadistic.   Overall, I highly recommend this game on sale.  EDIT: Nominated for 'Villain who just needs a hug' award.

Years of PC gamin' and this is by far the most skilled game ive found.   Accuracy, positioning, timing, reflexes and prediction.. everything is important in this game (specially when archer) or youre dead. Also mindgames are nextlevel and reading body movements and feints is always a challenge.  Initially u will just suck ♥♥♥♥♥ and know nothing, but when learn all basic mechanics (~lvl20) the game changes completly.  2,50€ on steam, this is a game for play years and years and never get bored  10/10

This game can be a lot of fun and but it is also pretty unforgiving and frustrating. Be prepared to watch hours of guides and play hundreds of matches before you even understand how to truly play. Right when you feel like you're over the learning curve some player comes along with 2,000 wins and in depth knowledge of the heroes stats and abilites doing mental math on the fly with wizard-like keyboard skills that absolutely shreds your @$shole and you know you're in for a S#itty 45 minutes and you'll be begging the other team to just end so you can get on with your life. Also be prepared for salty players to call you out for being bad despite feeding themselves. This game reveals the worst elements of human nature when whiny f*ckboys who are insecure blame you for their own mistakes, and also be preapred to constatnly mess up yourself because this game takes forever to get good at. And that's all if you're lucky and your team speaks english. If you want to play a game that is fun and rewarding, Dota can be that, but only after countless hours learning the game and grinding your MMR (Matchmaking Rating) up to a place where your team isn't hopelessly bad. Just a rant from a former player who had to say goodbye to a game because it was just to god d@mn stressful.

Some facts about this game:  It takes about 100hrs before you are a noob, before that you are essentially worthless. I'm not exaggerating. It will take at least 100hrs before you feel good enough to say you 'know the basics.' This game is not fun without friends - seriously - everyone agrees you need teammates you know to enjoy learning the ropes. This game is a masterpiece. I cannot recommend this game - losing is so infuriating and crushing that you'll sit down to relax, play a game, then an hour has gone by and you are angrier than you ever could've imagined. This game is a time vampire, and it isn't worth it for the 50% chance of gratification in my opinion.

I just don't know what went wrong. After trying so hard to appreciate and even like this game, I found myself having the opposite of fun and wanting some sort of hourly wage just for playing this. People finally managed to talk me into playing this 'game,' and FNAF not only doesn't compare well to other titles I've been pressured into buying but just doesn't seem to be a game at all. The player has very little actual control and a lot is left up to random chance. Just about the only feedback the game provides the player with is jumpscares. Winning a level doesn't feel rewarding at all.  The best way to win this game is by refusing to play. You can then construct the lore of an employee of Freddy Fazbear's Pizza suing the owner for wreckless endangerment after Night One, making millions of dollars in the resulting media fallout and cheesy horror movie series deal. The CIA then swoops in and has the infernal machines cold-rolled and then melted down into a solid cube to be launched into the sun by NASA. The creator of the animitronics is placed on a watch list and told to never create another machine again under threat of assassination. THE END.

I think i played > hour and i got 0 progress done. How am I suppose to compete against >30 players? I spent most of my time driving into battle, with 1 minute of combat as a reward. Make a 1-20 lvl starting zone, to give new players a fair chance to get into the game. Otherwise I will stand there with my lvl 1 engi turret against a plutoon of tanks.

In a few words: everything wrong about video games nowadays. It should be called Grinding: The Experience. The only saving point would be the achievement hunting, but that is not enough for me. If you like casual games, where you do nothing but kill time, it seams addictive, but it lacks difficulty and its not really fun. Not a good game (for people how look for goo free games). As a casual game, would give it a 5 out of 10; as a game it would be -10 out of 20.

At the end of the day, it's not 'doing a lot of damage' or 'being a high level' that makes games fun for me, it's being able to do more different and interesting things with those improved abilities. Many other games in the genre have advantages over this game, such as a stronger visual style, being on a mobile platform and, notably, continuing to reward the player giving input (outside of setting up a macro).

This is sadly not a great game. I think I fell for the hype. Yes, I only played for less an hour but I think I've seen enough of what this game is all about. You basically play as a security guard sitting in a room in some Chuckee-cheese like place looking at security cameras to see if the animatronic characters are moving or not. If you look at the cameras, you lose batter power slowly and you need to make sure you have enough to last out the night from midnight to 6am. And you have to do this for five whole nights. So yes, the animatronics are creepy and there are some jump scares, but this is really it.  Come on, this wasn't an amazing game.

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: Before I write my review the reason I have 0.1 hours is because this game didnt work for windows 8.1 so I had to mess with the files to make it work. While I did get it working it disabled steam for some reason. So now the review. This game is plain boring. There I said it. I am tired of people selflesly defending this game and dont look through its obvious flaws. This game dosnt come close to Fallout Games such as New Vegas. The story is absolute sheit. Mommy dies D: , Daddy leaves vault to make water clean, Go after him, Go through boring filler quests, Find daddy, Oh no daddy killed by men in power armour, Other men in power armour helps you because the men in power armour who killed your daddy dont like the men in power armour who help you, Big robo guy fights for you and you get to water purifier, Go in and die. (Or not) Kinda like schrodingers cat depending if you payed extra for a dlc. The story is bad, The map is boring. OH BUT THE MAP BIGGER THAN OTHER FALLOUT GAEM. Bigger dosnt mean better. OH BUT THE EMPTINESS GIVE ATMOSPHERREEE. Oh yeah sure mate, but the reason I play a game is TO HAVE FUN. Not to be bored out of my mind so I can be 'immersed' in a world full of bugs. Dont buy this unless your a hipster who just plays a game so he can tell his friends how he played the 'classics'. Go play fallout 1 or 2 much better investment than this.

I'll start with the positive: the battles look amazing. It's fun to watch the different units tear into each other, if you are willing to wait until you actually encounter another race (which takes a while as the empire or vampire counts.) The negative, for me, is the departure from total war. The economy in this game is completely awful. I agree with another reviewer who said they just added in background income to try to fix it. There is no point in building economic buildings, since they give so little income. This means you can't field multiple armies, just one or two. When the Chaos warriors arrive, you basically get to set there and defend, in battle after battle, with no hope of expansion. You are never able to autoresolve. The vampire counts v humans & greenskins v dwarves combined with quest battles take out a lot of the create-your own stratgey, snadbox feel and gives the game a linear progession.  If you never played total war, then hey, you might enjoy this. I have bought every total war title since the orginal rome, but I will not be buying the next total war warhammer. I wish I could return this one...

NO game should release any let alone 3 pieces of DLC 2 months after launch   As for the game itself, the map feels smaller than others in total war mostly due to fact you are limited to where you can conquer, mods fix this but its not like previous TW games where you fight a variety of nations. In warhamer TW you fight 5 : bretonnia who are unplayable empire, dwarfs, orcs, vampire counts,  chaos who you have to pay for unless you preordered   they have differnet names ie middehaim and nordland etc.. but have exact same roster and are indiguishable from one another  -mechanics arent anything innotive if anything its a step back -combat isnt anything special -campaign doesnt feel the same as other TW campaigns alot more linear ie, unify faction, defeat factions main enemy and defeat chaos    All in all a waste of £40 which only got me part of a game

Typically, I'm a massive fan of Total War games in general, and Warhammer as well as that.  The game itself, is quite fun. However, what you get the base game is the choice of 4 races essentially - with CA now charging ~£14 for the latest DLC installment of Beastmen. If you weren't lucky enough to preorder the game, you're already paying an additional ~£25 for Chaos and Beastmen. Two of the core races of the games setting. God knows how much it will cost for any additional races to be added later, let alone additional campaigns / maps.  Would definitely avoid, or wait a few years until you can get it for pennies from somewhere else.

I don't know if I 'Get' this game. I've run around, I've blown up people, I've destroyed cars, I've let people ride me. I'm a goat, hear me bleat!  While Goat Simulator is a nice relatively simple game, it's just that, an overall relatively simple game. It's not like a lot of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ 'simulators' that try to cash in on Goat Simulator's success. It's also not like the really well thought out simulators, like Bus Simulator or such.   It's hard to really describe Goat simulator. You're a goat, you run around and do anything you want. You have bad animation, but you rarely look at the goat itself. There's even a skate board ramp at one point, only thing is you don't 'Skate' you just ragdoll your body and throw it around, and yet it works.   I don't know if I'd heavily recommend this game, because it feels unpolished at almost any angle, the animation of the goat is weak, and the 'game' is... well I don't know if there's really a game.   But it's still wicked fun to go run around the level and act like an animal.  If you have a couple guys over and want to just have a blast, the local co-op actually works quite well. Definitely good for a half hour of so of just laughter seeing what you can do.

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: Mix of RPG and FPS, only the roleplaying and the shooting sucks hard. Character creation is a joke: stats have minimal impact on gameplay, skills too easily and too quickly max out, and most perks just boringly add skill points... every character inevitably turns out the same and hits max level before finishing the base game. Some skills were borderline pointless as was food, drinks, and drugs in general. The dialogue system is shallow and choices, if any, are limited and rarely have meaningful or satisfying consequences. There are not enough interesting towns to visit, Megaton was the only area that felt semi-complete, other settlements only consisted of a few buildings and useless people, none which felt the least bit believable. Moira in Megaton is one of the worst written characters in video game history and a shining example that Bethesda doesn't understand Fallout humor. Similarly, the vampires and treeminders should have stayed out of Fallout 3 and remained on Oblivion's cutting room floor. The weapons, especially energy weapons, were incredibly lacking and combat outside of VATS was deplorable. The storyline was terrible, the world was bland, there weren't enough sidequests to stay interesting, and voice acting was terrible. Navigating DC was just a pain and the maps were terribly unhelpful. With all that said, the game did do a good job of making killing feral ghouls in a dark cellar effectively spooky. This game is not deserving of the Fallout name, nor do I believe it is a good game in general, how people seemed impressed by its rampant mediocrity I'll never understand. Forget this game like Star Wars Episodes 1-3 and Indiana Jones 4...

The original DotA was unique blend of RPG and RTS that surprisingly worked like a charm. It single-handedly created its own genre of games, heavily influencing the likes of LoL, HoN and Monday Night Combat. Valve saw what and decided to take it under its godly wings and apply its magical touches and perfect this already perfect game.   It has the most incredibly addictive online gameplay I've ever seen (playing since 2005 and counting) that takes you through levelling level up all the way from the start each single game, yet never get bored with it. So many different heroes and items and so many possible scenarios that make each and every match a blast.  One thing to watch out for though; Dota 2 is just like a girlfriend; as much as it will get you satisfied, It will also drive you insane.

Moms Meatloaf:  Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F.  In a small bowl, stir together the oats and milk. Thinly slice 1/4 of the onion and set aside. Finely chop the remaining onion. In a large bowl combine the turkey, oat mixture, chopped onion, bell pepper, eggs, Worcestershire sauce, ketchup, salt and a few grinds of pepper. Mix just until well combined.  Transfer the mixture to a 9 by 13-inch baking dish and shape into a loaf about 5 inches wide and 2 1/2 inches high. Pour the tomato sauce over the meatloaf and sprinkle with the sliced onions. Bake for about 1 hour or until an instant-read thermometer registers 160 degrees.F.  Remove from the oven and let rest for 10 to15 minutes before slicing. :)

Slow, clunky control scheme. The fact that it can't decide whether it wants to be a real time strategy or competitive multiplayer deteres me. If I want to play a real time strategy game, I'd play something good like Age of Empires or Civ and if I want to play a MOBA then I'd play Smite. My time played counter may be miniscule, but my experience with the game is more than that.  Conclusion: slow, boring, clunky, would not recommend for either casual or competitive play.

Total War: Warhammer is the first Total War game that I have played since TW: Medieval 1 and being a Warhammer fan back before Age of Sigmar days, I was really excited about this game.  That being said, I have some Pro's and Con's for this game:   + Combat looks and feels immersive. Great physics on unit collision. + Great soundtrack + The 6 possible factions you can play all feel unique and very different. + Graphics are impressive.  - This game still needs to be optimized for Nvidia gpu's. I'm running a 980 and there is a slew of graphical issues like screen tearing with Vsync on...  8/10. Let's hope they stay focused and deliver the other faction DLC's with high quality work.
Early Access Review

Chivalry has an extremely intuitive melee combat system that is totally destroyed by hitboxes. A standard slash can somehow manage to hit people directly to your right and left, and 1st person mode does an awful job of portraying whether or not an attack hit.  Lag in this game is so bad. Even with my 'maximum ping' at 50, that doesn't guarantee the server you join that has 47 ping isn't gonna be full of people with 300+ ping that jitter around and win every fight.  There's 2 game-types, team deathmatch, and free-for-all. Truthfully, there are more than that, but they are literally unplayable. Objective based maps are plagued with utterly useless players who are either AFK or just sprint into every fight and team-kill you, swinging their sword around like they were trying to hit a bee. Not only that, but most objective based matches are filled with people who somehow don't know what to do, despite large objective markers and a constant objective box.   The community is literal cancer. Taunt spamming, borderline immature arguements, and people with twice as many deaths as kills telling you that you suck balls plague the chat 24/7.  If you wanna buy Chivalry, I hope you're content playing with bots.

There are only a few medievil-themed FPS games out there, but I would recommend any of the other ones above this one. This has to be one of the most laughably-bad games I have ever played. I have a good ping, my net connection might not always be the most STABLE mind you, but when it's up it is SOLID. Yet it doesn't really matter in this game, as often when I join a server, even those listed as East Coast Official servers, my ping is the only one below a 100, and most are well above that. I joined a US server once where everyone had a 200 or higher. I think by now everyone knows WHY this is bad for a competitive online multiplayer game, but in Chivalry it gets even worse...even with zero latency issues between you and your opponent, aim and where the weapon will strike have very little to do with one another. I've played War of the Roses pretty extensively, so I had an inkling of how the combat in this game would pan out, but NOTHING I aimed ever hit where it was supposed to. I often just swung randomly out of frustration, and ironically this is where I got most of my kills. There were also several players I met, all wearing custom skins, who just seemed absolutely unkillable. They would obliterate you with 1 hit blocking or not, yet any counter-attack on your part was shrugged aside, and didn't even break their swing, and as with WotR 2-handed swords are definitely the be-all, end-all of this game, unless you are a ping exploiter and prefer the fast-swinging hammers that often kill you in a fit of lag and leave you staring at a red screen going 'wha?'. More than once I was killed by someone I had swung at before they even reacted to me, only to instead be killed by them as they phased through me and attacked my shadow.  All in all, the hit-detection and serious, SERIOUS latency issues, both of the game and the player-base, make this a joke of a game at-best to me. The best thing I can say about it is that a game hasn't made me laugh this hard in a LONG time.  Which is unfortunate, as I'm pretty sure that is not the intent of Chivalry: Medieval Warfare.

With a huge open world to explore and many intelligent and ruthless enemies (including the local wildlife) to make that exploration difficult, Far Cry 3 has many many hours of entertainment and satisfying gunplay to get absorbed in. The day/night cycle, the beautiful islands and the effects from the array of weaponry are all a fantastic sight. The satisfaction to be had from 'liberating' an outpost by stealthily doing some recon and tagging all the soldiers before picking them off one by one is equally as much fun as doing it the less subtle way. Enemy AI is intelligent enough to not make it that easy for you to just run off in to the woods and hope they leave you alone, making for some very intense moments waiting for them to step on the tiger instead of you.  The slight disappointment with this game was the main story. At times dark and sombre, at others just downright strange, and with the odd moment of humour it was as though the game didn't quite know what it wanted to be. It was fun, and the hunt for the psychopathic Vaas has some fantastic character portrayal to keep you entertained but the whole thing culminates in a somewhat unsatisfying ending, leaving you to wonder what the hell just happened. You're left to scrambling around the islands to mop up the side missions and do the grind of finding relics and other inconsequential items. Overall though there is plenty to like about Far Cry 3, and I will probably give it a play through again at some stage, on a higher difficulty as the challenge of taken down outposts is worth it alone.

Goat Simulator is fun, but in astupid fun kind of way. Now, I personally don't have a good enough computer and so I lag horribly, but I still struggle through the intense lag in order to play it. Goat Simulator is basically like one of those games that a group of friends made for fun, but it is still amazing. This game has comedy, great physics, great and immense controls, and endless possibilities despite the map being so small. The map includes a great many things for you to ♥♥♥♥ around with, including a castle with goat followers in it, a dried up pool with trampolines in it, a group of protesters, a goat version of Fight Club, a satanic ritual, a Zero Gravity Simulation area, a construction site, and even includes the office (which is actually just in a house) of the developers. What's more is that you can play an even more ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t game than Flappy Bird called Flappy Goat. If you ask me, this game is totally worth the ten dollars. Buy it if you want hours upon hours of endless and stupid fun.

This game is nothing other than money grab. Valve is too busy creating cosmetics for easy money to fix bugs that have been in the game for years like creeps following you through fog of war or a more recent game breaking bug that causes the screen to freeze and turn completely white in the middle of the game forcing you to restart Dota with no guarantee that the game was paused. You can also expect to be put in low priority games about once a week because it currently takes around 3 reports in 20 games to send you to low prio. That is 3 people reporting you out of the possible 180. The game is centered around competitive play to the point that there is really no reason to play if you don’t intend on getting better. However the ranking system is currently the simplest and most inadequate of any “competitive” game out there if you win you get +25 MMR if you loss -25 no matter your performance. Go 15/2 as a phoenix that started the game as a support then was forced in to the carry role because you’re the only one that isn’t currently 0/10 clearly you’re not a good player or you could have won that game. The ranking system is so awful that a black market of accounts has popped up so now any scrub with 20 bucks can buy an account in your ranking were he doesn’t belong and give you 0% chance of winning the game. I wouldn’t consider getting in to the game at its current state 12,000,000 players and it’s still a buggy mess with incompetent players that are unavoidable at any skill level.

Chivalry is a game like no other. It has an amazing hardcore Medievil melee combat system that favours skill over luck and be aware of teammates swinging wildly as their is friendly fire. Its game modes are fun and have a decent variety, you have everything from your basic deathmatch modes such as team, free for all and one on one duels, but thier are also objective modes such as siege, all of them are fun and playable and action is always present. It has a small but dedicated community, and their has never been a time when I logged on and couldn't find a game. Their is a small selection of weapons for each class, some are better in certain aspects such as speed and power but all seem to have a good balance. Overall the game is a lot of fun and the melee combat is satisfying and One on One Duels are intense as hell at times. Highly recommended!
