At this point I have 180 hours to this “game”, & I use that word lightly. It is unlike anything else I have ever played before.  Goat Simulator originally was a hoax, a trailer from Swedish based Coffee Stain Studios poking fun at the seemingly endless barrage of mind numbingly boring simulators flooding the market, but as the collective response of the mentally challenged individuals on the web screamed YOU HAVE TO MAKE THIS GAME, there was only one obvious rout to go, and thus Goat Simulator was born.  With a very short development time Coffee Stain Studios have admitted there are bugs [and will only fix game breaking ones], but ask you embrace them as they make the game more entertaining. I mean how was a Goat supposed to climb a ladder anyways?  The objective, if you can call it that is to mooch about doing everyday goat activities, like destroying Goat hendg, interrupting protests about pennies shaped foods, destroying Coffee Stain Studios office, sacrificing unsuspecting individuals to become a satanic goat, welding almost any object with your tongue, bouncing on trampolines, riding bicycles, eating mushrooms, being abducted by aliens, buying hats, licking anything and everything, parkour, taking over deadmau5 rooftop party, strapping fireworks to your back, pushing boulders into garden barbeques, Ow, if you were expecting things to make sense then you’re an idiot.  Now with the addition of 4 DLC’s, MMO, Goatz, Payday & Waste of Space you can expand the bazaar & ultimately pointless shenanigans of the everyday life of a Goat and its friends it numerous ways. Adding story arcs, new maps, vehicles, quests and more, if you were one of the weird people that enjoyed the base game then this is more of the same on a stupider and grander scale.  WARNING: This game may leave your with a fetish for Goats, I know it has for me. 10/10

A good game that keeps getting better : I started playing that game at launch, being a fan of the Total War franchise since Rome : Total War. Back then, I was pleasantly surprised by the variation between factions, each race bringing its own twist to the campaign map, and by the fun factor of the battles ; but for me it lacked the replayability of the other games of the franchise due to boring settlement management and limited diplomatic options with few relevant AI-controlled factions on the map. Since then, the DLC and FLC have added new factions (even if you do not own the DLC you will see the new factions under the control of the AI) and the campaign is considerabely more dynamic and unpredictable.  + Diversity of factions AND rosters + Fun and brutal battles + Minotaurs - Price of DLC - Campaign management streamlined
Dense storyline, great gameplay and a vast island to explore. Well worth your money.

Free Chaos DLC period is almost over, so I'd like to give some insight on the game (debatable) faults for those of you, that still can't decide if this game is worth buying. I'll write in no particular order, mind you:  1. Cheating AI. To usual economic cheats (enemy can sustain big stack of mid/top tier armies even when he owns one province) a movement cheat was added. AI can move farther than you and move after attacking a city and razing/sacking it, while player lose all movement points after succesful siege. This creates situations when you chase an enemy for multiple turns with multiple armies, trying to corner him. AI also seem to know your army composition, because when two full stack armies face each other, enemy will run if autoresolve is not in his favor (even before you initiate a battle, you, as a player, learn later about autoresolve obviously). You can use agents to block enemy movement, yes, but forcing a player to use them feels inappropriate.  2. Tactical battles. There's no unit formation. No loose, no wedge, no nothing. Battles seem to be even more fast-paced than before. I don't think even one of mine last longer than 10 minutes. You no longer have a position battle before actual one. You don't have any strategic points to conquer to gain in-battle bonuses. Enemy just rush you, even if they are defenders. Heck, I've even seen enemy going downhill to meet me on flats, while they artillery was left at the top. Not a wise choice when there are flying units avalaible. Units seem to rout too easily. Sometimes even single artillery attack makes enemy run for their lives, even if damage to the unit wasn't that great. Sure, they calm down after a while, but usually they're too late to change the outcome. Reinforcement works weird in this installment. Even if you attack two enemy armies standing next to each other on the strategic map, on the tactical one, enemy reinforcement may show up behind you. Also, there's no custom grouping, you have to group your troops at the beggining of every battle. Again, and again, and again. Quite frustrating after few dozens of manual battles.   3. Unit animations. For those who liked to zoom in and look at your little ants' fights - units swing at empty space, making enemy die from air pressure. Anime like. No collision detection, no finishing animations. Well, at least they fly nicely when they stand atop the walls and are hit by artillery. Angry dwares, anyone?  4. Sieges. You knows that walls surround a city/castle, right? It seems that in Warhammer world it is customary to attack only from the front. That's right, lads, you can't make multidirectional attacks. One or two gates, a few towers, and walls between them, that's it. To make the wound hurt more - town's towers have range on the whole battlefield outside walls. That's right, you start a battle and you're already attacked. I have no idea what kind of a general would position their troops in towers' range without any breaches or siege equipment, beside artillery. Also, AI seems to know where you positioned your troops, and puts defenders accordingly.   5. Units. Balance in this game is non-existent. Some top-tier units do less damage than mid-tier ones. Not only that, but if you make specialized hero for low-tier units, and make techs for them, they are better than some top-tier ones! Example? Low-tier dwarf artillery saved my skin numerous times. But (supposingly) best dwarves units, some sort of helicopter, are complete let down. Both anti-infantry and anti-large make almost no difference to the final outcome of the battle. The first one makes mediocre damage, and the second one miss more than hit. On the other hand, artillery is crazy accurate. I've even seen a trajectory change of a crump, hitting my unit.  6. Multiplayer. Regretfully, no comeback of Shogun's 2 avatar system. You can either play custom battles (no matchmaking through) or co-op/versus campaign. While playing co-op you can't choose the same faction.   7. Strategic map. I may be spoiled by Crusaders Kings and Europa Universalis but... This map feels really small. Sure, Japan isn't very big either. But here you can occupy only half of it. Vampires-humans can't take dwarves-orcs settlements and vice-versa. Who would like to take dwarf mines full of gold and gemstones, right? Factions aren't too numerous too and most of them feel passive, made only that main ones can consume them. Sure, I know many of them are missing, wood, high, and dark elves, skavens, ghoul kings, etc. but I'm talking about base game, not some future dlcs. Also, since I'm not a Warhammer lore expert, I can't understand why we can only choose a race and not factions within races. Are they really so different that they need an additional work on and separate sell?  8. Heroes. Although it's really fun to develop your own lord(s) and hero(es), there's one thing I don't understand. Traits. I see no reasoning behind some of them. Why one guy guarding a fortress get's -5% movement points, but the other, doing the same thing, gets +5%? And there are many, many others like that. Or there are some with general description, e.g. cornerstone. You're cornerstone of the army and are really good with supporting others. But what does that mean exacly? Wider area range, better buffs, longer duartion, all of the above? Also, you get followers for lords and heroes, that work like equipment, you put them in designated slots. But sometimes they leave you. Not die from age but leave you. And we don't know why. And two turns later you get the same exact follower. What's the point?  9. Chaos. Arch-enemy of everything that's alive. Here... It's weak. Few full stacks of not so great units. If not for their three allies, they would be a laughingstock. I've even seen AI dealing with them on their own (although, they seem to leave Archaon, main evil guy, for the player). Chaos invasion feels more annoying than threatening, since both Chaos and Norsca run from the player (AI movement cheat). But the main problem with Chaos is that the Warhammer would be better (sic!) without it. Why? Before it you have quite interesting struggle for power, you want to conquer as much as you can, but you can't really do it too fast, since you are surrounded with enemies and temporary allies. So you strategize, you plan, you put that plan in motion, you build defenses, you create new armies, etc. Every new territory is a success, quite enjoyable one at that. And soon, much too soon, Chaos arrive. All enemies become allies. All temporary allies become loyal dogs. And every fifth turn you diplo-annex your one of your race faction to the point, where you're the only one. And when the Chaos is gone... Well, you're a huge blob on the map, there's nothing that can stop you. Boring.  Enough with the rant. As you can see I've spent some time with this game. and I don't really regret them. And I'll probably spent another 50+ hours. Why the negative review then? First, avatar system could easily double or triple that time, since Warhammer seems to be perfect for it. Second, there's going to be lot of paid dlcs, since many races, factions. and territories are still missing. Maybe even more than in previous titles. If your not hyped on this game I would recommend to wait on GOTY edition. On the other hand, if you're hyped you probably own it already. Cheers!  PS. 10. No, there are no woman or people of colour lords. PPS. 11. But there are are dwarfs, anemics, and people with some skin condition making them green, so cheer up!

Hi, all. Just a little review of Chivalry for you.  I enjoyed this game so much that it moved me to make a review. I love this game. It has a very deep and gritty melee combat system and very silly voice acting. 'CHAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAARGE!!' e.t.c. 'BALROG IS A DOOB!' :P The community is ok. I've come across a few ♥♥♥♥♥ (I play in Australian servers because I'm from New Zealand, so the community for that is alot smaller) but mainly noobs that just bought the game for the sake of having fun. Like me.  Pros: Fun gameplay  Hilarious voice acting  Various and unique game modes  Over the top violence (If you have ragdolls on)  Very balanced classes/ class progression  Good competition  Very challenging when you first start  Cons: Sados in servers  Laggy servers (occasionally and not very serious)  Irritating vote kick system (Hasn't harmed me yet, but people with high ping usually get vote kicked)  Noobs that constantly kill you and realise that they are doing so and yet pretend they dont so you get angry and   call a vote-kick on them. :P  Thats all the cons for me.  Final Verdict: 9 out of 10. Must buy this game! Didnt get a ten because of servers and vote kick e.t.c. But thats fine. BUY DIS GAME!!!! <O> ,.., <O>

This game is single handedly fulfilling my friend and I's large-scale warfare fantasy. The game is really good fun. You will have to get over dying if you're new because unlike other shooters it's not a very big deal to die as long as you are contributing to the team in some way.  On top of that, this game excels at promoting a team environment and rewards you substantially for working together. Plus there are a TON of ways to contribute in this team environment.  9/10 Progression is a bit slow or I would have given it a 10. However, I'm new so I probably don't know all the secrets to faster progression yet. Although, it's not a big deal at all. if the game even sounds remotely interesting to you check it out. :)

Pros:  -Warhammer Universe -Easy to pickup if you're a newcomer to the Total War Series -Small Variety of new units and mechanics to Total War -Expanded General and Hero systems -Modding community fixes most of the basic shortcommings. (Conquer Anywhere Mod)    Cons:  -Lacks a ton of depth. Lots of mechanics from classic Total War are now gone. -Only two true 'religions', Chaos and Vampirism. Both of which can just be mitigated and don't massivley affect your gameplay. -Unit management is very dumbed-down from other titles. -DLC is stupidly expensive. ($15 for a single-faction. Really? And it's just another Horde Faction too. The only real work went into modling them.)  I'd reccomend the Base Game, if you TRULY love the Warhammer Universe. Otherwise, you're not missing much skipping out on this Total War Title.

review_text: Pros: One of the best RPGs I've ever played Great voice acting Liam Neeson Ron Perlman VATS system is awesome Easy to get lost into the vast wasteland, making it perfect for exploring There's a lot of freedom on how to do an objective. Endless ways on how to build your character. I felt like I've reached level 20 (original maximum level) way too soon, but with the new level 30 cap, it's more convenient. The DLC is a must. Gives you more to add on the already giant world. Affordable. Even better seeing as I notice this game going on sale often.  Cons: Not optimized for Windows 7 and later. Expect crashes. Save often. Read some guides on how to reduce crashing frequency. Can get a little glitchy.

Switch 'Launcher.Exe' & 'Fallout3.exe' compatibilities to 'Windows XP Service Package 3' and |Run As Administor| for 'Launcher.exe'   Thank you for reading, if this does not work, then what ever I was doing, worked for me and I will need to trace back.   -------------------------   Fallout 3 Is wonderful, it is the perfect Open World type for those who want to explore after a horrific world wide event, it also includes memorable characters and crazy effects that land on your foes (and companions too!) Fans of this game, please do not explode with rage, this is just my opinion, and people will have opposite opinions with this game. I dunno, but this game really really dissapointed me in the 'Horror' genre. You see, this game right here focuses on just you sitting in the office, just waiting for the animatronics to jumpscare and absolutly pierce your ears. Here's my take on horror. It's about the atmosphere, which I give this game does have good atmosphere. The game needs buildup, which it has but oh god why does it just have to be loud, loud jumpscares. Silent Hill is a good example of a horror game franchise I absolutly adore, what that game does is buildup and play around with your mind, tricking you, makeing you feel helpless,and hell, when the monsters actually do appear, they don't let out ear piercing screams to let you know of their presence. I just expect something better from this game. But if you're interested, by all means, buy this game. I am not stopping you.

I have started playing Farcry 3 many times, because all of my friends tell me how good it is, and how I am an idiot for not playing it. Well fair enough I suppose, so I start it again, play until the first few missions and then quit, the story fails to captivate me and I fail to get immersed. But then a thought occurs, let's just screw the story and go on a quest for fun. So I gather money by hunting animals and pirates, and build up a decent arsenal, crafting my ammo pouches as I go, and suddenly I realise why this game is so brilliant. It's fun. Remember that sensation, fun, the one we used to have with games. There are very few quicktime events in this game, and thank your deity of choice for that, because this game shines through it's organic gameplay. I love how I can sit an spy an enemy camp with a silenced sniper rifle, plotting a surreal fight with the guy who has saucepans strapped all over his person, only to get a pack of wild dogs overrun the camp and kill every pirate in it, the first time this happens you will probably be abit taken aback. The next time, you might have instigated it yourself.   The game rewards you for your organic thinking, and there is almost never just one way of doing things. But there is always a fun way.

Say what you will about the rampant popularity and memes of this game, but it has genuinely given me a feeling of unease and fright that most other games haven't. The concept is pretty unique and the lore for FNAF is interesting as well. For the most part I recommend for a scary fun time. It's pretty tough around the 4th and 5th night as well.

I'm going to be honest. In my eight hours playing this game, I've had good times, and I've had bad.  But overall, I'm going to have to give this game a no.  Allow me to explain.  The combat is heavily skill based, relying on you learning how to ' Get Gud '. While this is usually perfectly fine, and I enjoy a challenge, it does not work well when most of the rest of the community has two bodies, and a spare leg and a head above you in experience.  You will rarely find other players that are at the start of the leveling tier. Why? Because most are turned away by the sheer cliff of difficulty when it comes to learning the moves of the game, and actually being able to combat people who have done it for far longer than you, of which is little to impossible.  It gets worse when most of these high level players stack on their own team, making it impossible to make a dent, and ending with the match being steamrolled.  I had fun at times, but overall, there's more rage than fun to be found here.  I cannot reccommend this game, at this time.  I'd more than happy give this another shot, if some sort of rank matchmaking system were implemented, placing you in games with people of your own level of skill. But unfortunately, even servers ment for someone of my skill level, are filled with players levels 20+, who mow down people like me in a moment.  This needs to be fixed. Hopefully, someday it will.  TL;DR: I want to badly love this game, but I simply can't.

Rewriting this review from further in the game. For a horror game, the clicking is pretty frantic. Does this mean it's a 'terror' genre, and not 'horror'? Still, more frantic manipulation than I'd like. Also, the power management system means that if you screw up early in the night--and by screw up I mean 'spend too much time with a camera on'--you will suffer for it later. I didn't really find it a fun mechanic.  Now I'm not saying this is a bad buy. This game will stick with me for a long time, and haunt my draems for weeks to come. I just don't think I'll spend much time playing it.

To describe this game in just a few words: immersive and impressive yet anti-climactic. For me, it provides no closure or sense of accomplishment -- there's no way to win in this game, and that makes it feel empty. Taking over territory has no direction besides gaining certification points, which are used to buy upgrades (so you can get more certification points?). By definition, you can't really call this a game -- it's more of a combat sandbox and social experiment. If that's what you want, go for it.  It's only really fun when you have several hours to play at a time during an alert with a platoon with leadership that communicates and strategizes. Otherwise, you're stuck wandering around trying to find a fight that is evenly matched. Nobody wants to just sit there and get spawn camped when you could be somewhere else getting more cert points.   The scale of this game is incredible, but the payoff just isn't there. If you feel like you're winning, it's rarely because of something you did, and it feels like you're just in the right place at the right time. Instead, victory goes to the team with the most people.

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: Starting life in an oversized bank vault, you are part of an isolated community enjoying all the delights 1950 style americana can give... whilst in one of the many fallout shelters Scattered across the nations capital. Sustained living in these shelters was not meant to last as long as it has. After around 200 years or so the systems and populations of these vault's are falling to pieces in one way or another. Some have opened their doors to the outside and ventured into a new world unaware of the horrors it has in store for the happy go lucky and the naive.  This post apoplectic RPG has you neck deep in scraps and filth trying to fix your broken down gun while mutated creatures and people try to eat you so they can survive another day in the radioactive wasteland you now call home.

Great if you like FPS games with great action, large landscapes and vehicle action.  Not so great if you ahven't played it before and not to mention that it will suck up your time trying to grind those certs just to get your character at the level everyone else is.  9/11 would use aircaft to crash into peopl.
So addictive.  10/10.

I can neither recommend this nor fully condemn it. It's a PVP hack and slash whereby you face off against opposing players (duh, PVP) You can decimate your opponents by means of blocking, feigning attacks to get your opponent to block and then striking him as he lowers his guard. It's actually quite fun but as for re playability, it gets boring really fast. As for the quality of the graphics, they do leave a lot to be desired. One may land up rage quitting during the tutorial as it is somewhat flawed. The instructional NPC suffers from lock jaw in that there is no mouth movement when he instructs the player on tactics to overcome his enemy.  Pros:   -You'll have a few good chuckles at the hilarity of your kills. Some of them are really satisfying (I seriously didn't find many things that I liked about it. Overall it was frustrating to maneuver and felt like I was constantly trying to wade out of mud)   Cons:  -A lot of broken AI. Most times I'd find the bots running against fences or in circles. (You'd use the bot matches to get accustomed to how things work on your end) -Very dated graphics -Your character truly does run as slow as dirt. Yes, yes it is understandable that they were obviously trying to add the realism to how SLOW someone would move in a heavy full set of armor, but come on, this is video gaming. If you really desire such realistic experiences, might I suggest joining a medieval reenactment group.  Overall....NO

After playing for a few months and quite a few battles, here's what I have to say about Planetside 2:   Pros:   -Vehicle/soldier selection and customization: graphics are nice, customisation seems pretty cool.  -Always players online; no waiting: because of its MMO nature, there are always teamates to play with and enemies to shoot at.  -HUGE battles: when I mean huge, I mean huge. The maps are enourmous and have varied terrain.   Cons:   -The difficulty curve: while there is a tutorial available when you first play of the game, it's mediocre at best, and does not go into depth with vehicular controls (especially problematic with aircraft; more on that later). Also, once you finish the tutorial, the game proceeds to throw you into the biggest battle it can find, basically guarenteeing you'll die in a matter of seconds.  -Poorly developed identification systems: besides the bullet and vehicle colors, it's difficult to determine who's on your side and who isn't, especially at night, in dark areas, or from a distance. Guess it would make too much sense to have character outlines or at the very least markers (the hud isn't all that great, either). Also, team markers carry over to different factions, which I found was a very serious problem in combat, and has led to quite a few friendly fire accidents (the Terran Republic still uses red markers regardless of the faction you pick, for example).  -Aircraft controls: They're horrible. Seriously. The very nature of the controls makes them ridiculously counter-intuitive. WHO WAS THE GUY WHO THOUGHT IT WAS SMART TO BIND ROLL TO THE MOUSE?! Ok, that may be a bit of an overreaction, but mouse controls should be customizable (come on now, it's been at least two years since release, and while they said they would add this feature last year, it has yet to be implemented). Also, I've been finding that the vehicle HUD needs a redesign (third person has no indicators whatsoever, and the first person view is a bit constricting, leaving tank drivers at a disadvantage).  -Customizations are too expensive and require excessive amounts of grinding to get: because it's unlikely you'll be getting a lot of kills when you start, it's near impossible to get enough certs (in-game currency) to upgrade anything, leaving you stuck with the starter items.  -EDIT: After trying this game once again, I can also say it is poorly optimized, even on high-end computers. Seriously, in battle, I rarely, if ever, get framerates above 5 FPS.   Overall: This game has potential, but it still has far too many problems for me to seriously recommend it to anyone. Don't bother with this one.

This is a bad game, it has a high learning curve with numerous arcane mechanics and controls (creep denial, activated items) making it extremely difficult to understand. The games are often decided in the first 10-20 minutes but easily go on for an hour despite that. No surrendering mechanic means that if you want to get rewards for a match you have to just wait it out while dying repeatedly, not fun. Comebacks are technically possible but I have yet to see one that didn't involve someone leaving the game, which just sucks because everyone was pretty much cheated out of or in to a win. When you get a number of kills you gain far too much momentum and can easily become literally unstoppable, which just is not fun on the receiving end. I understand snowballing is a part of the game but other games do it much better than this, where you are powerful but can still be killed if you are out of position or the enemy makes a good play. The community is pretty damn toxic, which is par for the course in MOBAs but still a downside for players. IMO, in this game fights are simply far too short, it is quite possible to die in a single second too early in the game. The visuals are okay I guess but as a WC3 player I feel they innovated far too little and it just looks like all the same models. (which was probably their goal but I disagree with the design choice)

Why, why, why? Why did I buy this game? It looks like never-finished-alpha-version. The tutorial is so buggy that I had to quit the game and start over because the message 'Press CTRL to crouch' just wouldn't disappear. And believe me I crouched like 100 times!!! Overlapping text on the screen where you are supposed to choose the faction? Seriously? Nobody noticed before? Shame... The weapon masters usually say 2 sentences at the same time, so you can practice multitasking. How do they do it? It's a mystery. The gameplay doesn't have anything in common with Chivalry. It is about: Kill that guy in armor from behind while he is busy fighting the other guy. Chivalric it is!!! If there is a skirmish of more than 2 players, you can be pretty sure that you will get killed by the bad guy or by a friend. Because it is just unpredictable. Kids slashing their own team members and nothing happens? Facepalm... Another thing: So, I am with the red team. Great. But that guy with the red shield just killed me. Ahaaa! So it was just a freaking red shield but he belongs to the blue ones. Tricky one! So basically the point is to eliminate other players like in Counter Strike but only with slow and 'shtako' weapons. No quests, no story. Just kill them and count the kills! The Deadliest Warrior DLC added at least some cool looking characters and obviously time travelling feature. I am pretty sure that Ninjas, Pirates with pistols and Spartans wouldn't like to cooperate, so lets kill each other. This is the first opportunity to do it because they would never meet in the real world. I'll play it when I'm drunk, maybe I'll change my opinion. And maybe I will forgive... Once...

Unplayable [Deadliest Warriors]  A complete waste of time and vulgar insult to it's father. It spends far too much time adding 'new' things that only makes the entire experience a slog. The new teams and weapons are a paper thin attempt to add content to an old formula, and the maps do not lend any sort of balance to the combat, which aside from some new ranged weapons, is completley unchanged. When the game actually decided to load you were dropped into a hellish landscape with no chance of survival.  I already have an issue with team-based games that no one fights with honor or chivalry (Whoa, wait a second) and that it play more like an RTS where the other team took your resources. Fights boil down to several people trying for the weakest in a group, if they are even lucky enough to be in one, and moving up the scale while everyone trys to fend off the horde.  I miss multiplayer games that didn't need to do anything more than let people have fun, have two or three different weapons to scissors-paper-stone the gameplay so all you need to do is be skillfull with your tools, rather than just play long enough to get the best weapon so you can scare off all the other players.  tl;dr People like numbers so 3/10

This is BY FAR my most favorite game I have ever played. The MOBA element demands that you have teamwork. The diversity of the 'hero' roster makes every game a different experience. I prefer this game to other MOBAs(LoL for an example) because in my opinion, it looks a lot more polished- or life like if you want to put in those terms. It has a steep learning curve so it may not be for you, but if you want to take on the challenge, give it a go! I have some friends that refuse to play DotA 2 because its 'ghetto' since its a free game, this is not true at all. At a glance, it may seem that way, but this game has made BILLIONS of dollars(the little $$$ things if thats what you prefer) off of 'micro transaction'- small things that make your 'hero' look cooler. I thought I would never fall prey to these little things like, getting a new beard for a tree dude, but- sadly, I couldn't resist.(totally worth it by the way :P) Try the game out, you have nothing to lose! 11/10

Far Cry 3 is probably the first single player FPS experience I've spent more than 100 hours in. Although the multiplayer is terrible, the single player is quite frankly a blast to play. As a prissy high-class snob, you're left on your own on Rook Island, a cruel and dangerous place, where you have to survive by killing pirates, wild life and explore the island for secrets and help the inhabitants with the strangest things.   The gameplay is solid, the gun mechanics are spot on, and the game looks beautiful. Not Crysis level, of course, but it's still one of the prettiest looking games to date.

Five Nights at Freddy's is a game based around the security guard, Mike Schmidt (The Player), surviving the night shift at a Pizza Place for kids called ' Freddy Fazbear Pizza ' starring Freddy Fazbear, Chica the Chicken, Bonnie the Bunnie and Foxy the Pirate. At Night (12 A.M.) the animatronics begin to wander around the establishment and if Mike is seen by one of these animatronics, they may mistake him for an endoskeleton without a suit on. Upon seeing him this way, they will try to forcefully stuff Mike into a empty Freddy Fazbear suit filled with componets incompatable with a human, hence Killing Mike. To survive from these animatronics you are given two steel blastdoors with exterior lights, One Tablet/Computer hooked up to the security cameras around the establishment and limited power. By using these, you run the risk of draining power to both the doors and the lights, where you will be vonerale to the animatronics. You must regulate your eletricity usage to survive til 6 A.M.   ' What could go wrong? '

Of the half-dozen people I started learning Dota 2 with, three still play regularly. Though there are hundreds of thousands of players of our approximate skill level populating the matchmaking queues, the four of us are more like each other than we are like anyone else playing Valve’s isometric wizard-’em-up.  Spending a year learning to shuffle a gaggle of fantasy heroes up Dota’s teetering stack of rules and game mechanics will do that to you: we’ve developed a secret language of our own, one that runs parallel to the talk of creeps and lanes and farm and rax common to everyone who plays the game. “Whack a ward on the donkletron I’m going to stick one up their jungle” is a sentence I can say out loud and be completely understood by at least those three people. For some reason, there’s also a lot of singing involved. It’s a lot like being a sailor.

This is a game that could have been so, so, so much better! 3D melee MMO mayhem, right? Cutting various limbs off people and charging headlong into bloody battles brandishing a variety of solid steel objects meant to slice, crush or otherwise turn enemies into bloody pulp. Sounds like stuff of dreams.   BUT... And it is a massive BUT... The game is buggy as f#@k. Other problems include clunky controls, unbalanced weapons, unfriendly and often abusive community, unbalanced maps with clear advantages and disatvantages (so you have groups of players swarming one or two chokepoints which defeats even the most rudimentary team tactics) and laggy servers. I tried to enjoy the blasted thing. I really wanted to. Heck, I've been waiting for a game like that since I saw 'The Two Towers' back in 2002 and thought 'Hey, wouldn't it be awesome to have a medieval FPS where you can attack and defend castles with your buddies?' That dream remains unfulfilled.    A massive disappointment is what I call this game. A bloody shame since it had so much promise. Definitely not worth the price tag. If you get it for 80% off and have a few friends to play with then maybe it'll be worth an hour or two of your time. I myself will return to Rune: the game may be 14 years old but the deathmatch is still more fun than this laggy, buggy mess.

I'm not normally a big fan of horror, by any category (Or jump scares for that matter) - But this one caught my attention. For me, this is not about the horror, or jump scares, I am rather immune to that stuff - But what I love is the strategy part, to learn where the animatronics are, how they move in general, how to complete the game perfectly. With that said, I must admit I also love the whole idea, both story, design and gameplay - With much of the story left unexplained, there is a lot of theories to exchange with other fans, which I enjoy being a part of. It is a very interesting game, and I have enjoyed it a lot (On my friends steam, in case you are wondering about my low play time number). I guess some might say it lack a story, and it tends to repeat itself (On another level, if you complete a night) - But I suppose it is mostly used for scaring, which (According to myself) makes the repetition fine - There is no need to make it more stressful no matter who the player is - You know exactly what to do, which makes the game more fun for a longer time. The phone calls are an excellent way of a 'instruction booklet / guide' - Not to mention it also added a bit more scare to the already creepy atmosphere - The only lack at this, was the fact that a new player probably wouldn't listen all that well, being too caught up in the cameras and doors / lights - Speaker tends to mumble a little, I would recommend listening to the calls online, instead of in game, it can get a little confusing. When you've learned all the jump scares and calmed down a little, the real game begins: Are you able to make it trough all nights simply by technic? - Give it a go, you wont regret it. A little summing up: It's a great game, the lacks it have is not problematic enough for the game to not get a good score - If you're a easy target to scare, watch others play it first, that might help. Good luck on your night shift!

Early Access Review
I made a new category in my library for this game.  'Games I wouldn't save in a fire'

To see the review with pictures and video, please visit  Vox Ludicus  [voxludicus.com] .   I look upon the battlefield. The Greenskin horde, a full WAAAAGH in fact, was preparing thier assault. I had already been driven back by Grimgor Ironhide, and now he had backup. But I was not going to give in. I would take as many grobi as I could with me as I went to the halls of my ancestors.  I arranged my Dawi on top of a nearby hill, Cannons in the center of a half circle, surrounded by Quarrlers, ready with axe should the enemy close. Around them my stoutest Longbeards, veterans of many engagements and very angry. And in the center stood my general, Ungrim Ironfist the Slayer King!  The Greenskin tide sweep up and after a long, protracted battle, they wiped out my forces and wounded Ungrim. But I gave an accounting of myself: I wounded Grimgor and the other generals, and wiped out over half the forces.   This is the account of a single battle in Total War: Warhammer. I have have done quite a few such battles in my time with the game. I have spent around 8 hours thus far, and have tried the Empire, Vampire Counts, and Dwarves for races. I have conquered keeps, been forced back by rebels, and driven the hordes of the undead before me.  And I have loved every minute of it. Truly. I love a good strategy game, and I love the world of Warhammer, and I have been waiting for a game that captured the feeling of the tabletop game, but allowing me to play without spending thousands of dollars.  This game is amazing looking. You have two primary things you will staring at: The campaign map, and the battlefields. Both have a distinct view.  The Campaign map is easy to read, and while the UI could use a little work, it’s servicable. It took me a while to figure out how to read the settlement screens, building trees, and even figure out where the movement points for my armies were, but once I figured it out, it became second nature.  During battle, however, you go into an actual representation of the area you are fighting in. These can get a tad repetitive, but there is some variation. The worst for me was when I was fighting in the Greenskins’ domain, which is mostly desert. It’s very dull, lifeless, and foreboding. It gets the job done, but is bland at times.  The character models are solid and detailed. I played using high settings and was pleased with how everything looked. When zoomed out you have to use the Unit Flags to determine where your units are, and who is doing what, and I must say that on occasion the blob of units can get a little silly.  Magic effects honestly could use some work, but again, they are serviceable. Most of the time it’s muted as I spent my time using buffs and debuffs and didn’t use much in the way of offensive magic. The few videos I have seen however show them as being decent. Overall, I love the visual presentation and really enjoying zooming in and watching a mob of dwarves smash into some goblins.  Also, the soundtrack seems great. I say seems, because I never hear it in game. No, really. The only time I have heard the music outside the menu has been this video on Youtube. It sounds great! And yet it never seems to play.  The sound effects in battle however are amazing. Humans scream when taken by fear effects. Your troops shout and groan and scream during battle. The sound clips that play during diplomacy are hilarious as your faction leader says things to the other leaders. Overall, the sound effects are solid but really nothing stands out, other than the actual soundtrack not playing.  Now, be aware that all Total War games are a mix of two gameplay types. First, you have the Grand Strategy section, played out on the Campaign Map. This is where you move armies, take over settlements and cities, perform diplomatic relations and build up your research and development.  The second section is the Battle system, which plays out in the form of a Real Time Strategy game. You setup your troops in formation and then move them into combat. You cast spells, use abilities, and generally try to murder your opponent.  You can however avoid the RTS systems by using a function called Auto Resolve, but with Total War Warhammer you cannot use this for Quest Battles, which are the story battles for each Legendary Lord.  There are 4 base races and 1 DLC Race. The base races are Empire, Greenskins, Dwarves, and Vampire Counts. The DLC Race, which if you pre-ordered the game you got for free, is the Warriors of Chaos. Each race plays vastly differently from each other, and allows you to try different playstyles.  The Empire is your standard human faction, a mixed arms style of play with a variety of magic users and tech. They are the closest to a traditional Total War army. The Dwarves are slow, tough, and have no magic ability. They have some of the best ranged units in the game, however. The Greenskins need to be in constant battle and raiding as they have a stat called Fighteness that if it gets too low they start smashing themselves in boredom. The Vampire Counts have no ranged units whatsoever, but their Vampire Lords are extremely tough and they have some very fast and hard hitting units. And the Chaos Warriors are a Horde Faction, having no settlements to call their own, being nomadic raiders.  You start the game by choosing your faction, and then your Legendary Lord to start the game. The Chaos Warriors have three lords to choose from, while the other factions have two.  After that the game puts you into a tutorial fight, and then right into the Campaign Map. From there, your goal is one of expansion and survival. You have to upgrade your settlements to unlock new unit types, manage income and recruit new Lords to lead armies, then take those armies out into the world to conquer and enslave (or liberate) other settlements.  Most factions have the simple goal of controlling a certain number of settlements while also keeping the Factions of Chaos in check.  A good example of some Gameplay would be this video I did, where I started a Vampire Counts playthrough.  Difficulty-wise, the game is hard – in a good way. Even on easy, which I admittedly play on, I struggle on occasion. The AI is pretty smart, keeping their ranged units away from you, ganging up on you with reinforcements, and such.  However, there are a few issues. Offensive Magic, for instance, scales poorly. Apparently, the Unit Size setting in the options causes Magic to be a bit wonky. Set unit size to Small, and you can sometimes two-shot entire units and lords with spells, but having it on Large causes the spells to be borderline useless.  Also, on higher difficulties the AI will spam Agents, which are individual units that cannot be attacked which will do things like sabotage your army, your walls, and even outright assassinate your own Heroes. You can do the same, but it never seems to work. I had one army besieging a Castle, and a goblin agent walked up and attempted to assassinate my Hero every single turn until it succeed.  Despite its faults, this has been a fantastic release. Little to no bugs save a launch day issue that was quickly resolved, great gameplay, fantastic replayability and striking visuals. This is a game that any Strategy gamer would be remiss in skipping.

First things first. If your gaming on a PC, you can't assume every game you buy will work without a hitch on your system. If you read the negative reviews, you'll notice almost all of them say 'game won't start' or 'it crashes'. Bad luck, your system isn't compatible. There might be a fix, there might not be. You can't review a game if you haven't played it, so don't.   Right then, the game itself.  I was incredibly excited for this newest Total War game and when I get excited for a game it usually falls a little short of my expectations. Total War: Warhammer is not one of those games.  The only cons I can find are very minor ones, such as deselecting when I try to organise formations. The pros are vast. It breathes a new life into the game series with it's unusual unit types and faction mechanics. The excitement that comes from the first battle against a new race far outweighs that of the previous games and the smaller tweaks to the real time battles, such as the deeply satisfying cavalry (or monster) charges only help to raise the bar on this incredible game. I never stop laughing as Chaos Spawn send Dwarfs flying.  Buy this game and I hope it works for you. If it doesn't, contact the tech team instead of leaving unfair reviews. Just a thought.

I will preface this review by saying I generally despise playing 'joke games' - ones that are made to be intentionally bad for Youtube and Twitch entertainment.  Goat Simulator is different. It's an April Fool's Joke (literally) taken to its logical conclusion - a ridiculous game that's all about fun, rather than frustration. You are a goat who runs around and does ridiculous goat things in a physics sandbox. That's all it is, and all it should be. It's also a great game for achievement hunters, sending you all over the levels to track down ridiculous secrets.  Of course the game style just won't click for a lot of people, and that's fine. But for those who it does work for, it's like nothing else.  Did I mention the game has goats in it? It also has fantastic emoticons.
MAA is the best!

The game itself looks and sounds fantastic. Graphics wise the level of detail is truly stunning and on a surround sound system being in the midst of combat really does sound like you are in the middle of a war zone. Bullets fly, explosions rock the floor. I would love to be able to recomend this game, but I can't  The main problems are that the stunning graphics and sound are NOT matched by an equally stunning gameplay or development team.  Extemely repetitive, and VERY slow to advance, this game is more a grind than a game. Tedious and frustrating in the extreme the game is unbalanced and quickly becomes a chore to play. When you have to play for several weeks in order to upgrade a single weapon you know something is seriously wrong. Because it takes so long to progress, it is ESSENTIAL to spend real money in order to get the gear you need, making this game VERY expensive to play, and effectively pay to win.  In addtion many of the players in this game behave like complete jerks. It is not uncomon to be shot or run down by vehicles driven by a member of your own team (some of which will deliberately alter where they are going to make sure they run over you).   There are also a VERY large number of people playing this game who are cheating. It is not unusual to find yourself getting killed in impossible ways, being shot when you are on the other side of a wall from your attacker, for example, and cheats such as aimbots are not unsual. The developers don't appear to do anything whatsoever to prevent this, which is probably why it is so prevalent.  The final area that ruins this game are the developers themsleves. While extra content has been added over time, the developers don't seem interested in dealing either with reliability issues or with other problems such as the number of cheaters, or ongoing issues with purchases of Daybreak Cash used for buying in game items. Finding the 'Submit a Request' on their website is nearly impossible, and their customer service is a complete joke. Should ANYTHING cause a problem with your account, there is a good chance the hundreds of hours you have put into the game and the money you have spent on in game items will be instanttly obliterated. In addition, it is not unusual for items purchesed in the game to be changed. This often renders an item that was purchased when it was absoutely fantastic, to become one that is largely useless. The developers do this frequently. The behaviour of the developers, especially regarding areas like purchased items is more in common with the kind that would be expected from a scam artist.   All up this is a game that with could be so much more, if the developers actually dealt with the problems instead of milking it for everything they can get.
Playing this game is like taking drugs. It's addictive, wastes your time (and money if you actually pay for gems), deteriorates your health, and makes you feel good about doing nothing.

- Made for even younger audience than other MOBA - Revolves around its marketplace (silly skins and crap like that) - Too much focus on casual aspects of the game - Normal games require no skill - Forget about competitive play (unless you're happy to grind xp, A LOT) - Designed to be easy for children to pick up and play - Colorful, cartoony visuals & characters - No blood - Fantasy violence - Boring early game (shoot minions / enemy, rinse repeat) - Very, very slow first half of each game - Announcer stolen from Unreal Tournament (1999) - Impossible to master (unrealistic to learn 110 heroes and all their abilities) - Only late game matters (provided you're not braindead or afk) - Horrible engine (Source 2 better but not a whole lot) - Inferior compared to say League of Legends (technically, UI, content, mechanics, etc.)

Sorry Coffee Stain, but I'm gonna have to say no to this game. Why? Well, granted, it's fun for maybe the first twenty minutes or so, but it gets inexplicably boring after a while. We've all seen ragdolling everywhere before, so watching a goat spazz out isn't exactly hilarious. I mean, if you want ragdolling, Garry's Mod is the place for that. Also, the map. For a map that's supposed to house a goat that could possibly get hit by a car and fly away, it's pretty tiny. Like, we're talking tiny tiny. Also, if you follow what the game tells you to do, after maybe an hour or so you'll end up with some serious lag. It's like, fresh at the start and dead at the end. There's no way you can reach that high point goal unless you're ♥♥♥♥in' a with combos.   However, this game isn't all that bad. I mean, the Easter Eggs made me snort a little. Also, there's a Workshop mode, so you can play other maps and play as things other than a goat, such as the Heavy Weapons Guy.  So, this game. 4/10. Take the disclaimer seriously.  Unless you can afford to throw around 10 bucks like it's ♥♥♥♥. Then by all means, buy this game.

I loved both Far Cry 1 and 2, but uplay is a horrible DRM system that you can't get around, even with the Steam version. The console way of going through options and interacting with stuff also affects FC3 and heavily so. I personally have raged so hard over this, because it started as a PC game and I looked so much forward to FC3. What a load of zhit. Honestly and I I'm sorry for the language, but this is completely ret@rded. Waypoints even on the hardest settings showing where to go to begin with. You have to mash space to knife a guy, and you have a feeling that the game is made for five year old kids. A hint system that is forced upon you, and while you go through it you can't do anything. All options are locked, you want to throw a stone and make some noise? Well too bad, wait for the game to allow you to do so. You need to jump over an obstacle, you just press space and your characters does it. Forget about the game engines of Quake or Unreal, where you actually could jump around and had a feeling about the world. Don't buy it and make the same mistake I did, get the pirated version and decide afterwards whether this is something for you. Money completely wasted on my behalf.

I dont usually buy games made by Ubistoft (Because I hate ubisoft) BUT this game was too damn good. The story was amazing, you had to save your friends and do some other stuff as well. The graphics was good and even when you finished the story you had to do a lot of things such as control towers and kill bad guys stealthy.You can also drive cars kill animals, craft items and customize your weapons.

Yeah, it's scary....at first.  You say 'Oh god stay away!' the first few times, then after a while you start saying 'Dammit Chica go away....! Stop HOGGIN MY POWER!'.  I personally loved the idea of this game, preserving power by keeping yourself open for attack. And jumpscares are one of my weaknesses in video games, but it started to effect me less and less as I played.   Your job is to guard the resturant at 12 at night till 6am in the morning, while fending off 4 animatronic animals that want to kill you by stuffing you into a suit. They come to your door, say hi, you say ♥♥♥♥ off, and close the door. You see them on the security cameras messing with you and taunting you. The four are Bonnie, Chica, Freddy, and Foxy. Bonnie and Chica roam the halls taunting you and making faces at you through the security cameras while Freddy silently makes his way toward you after a few nights. Foxy waits at 'Pirate Cove' and if you don't watch him from time to time he will run straight to your security room and kill you.   Your only defence is your doors and lights, which apperently run on AA batteries, so you can't keep the doors shut at all times, you have to keep the doors open and keep yourself exposed to survive the nights.   When I played, I would check Foxy and Freddy, then turn off the camera, checking my lights, then repeat. I only died once due to my power running out and Freddy singing his song for 2 seconds.   This is where frustration more than fear kicks in.  I never got suddenly killed by Foxy or the other two characters because I kept checking my lights every good 7 seconds, then checking my cameras to keep the other 2 at bay. That makes you run out of power fast, but what other strategy do you have? What if you don't check Freddy or Foxy at all? What if you don't check your lights? You die. Just by not checking anything, not even the cameras or lights, after 15 seconds, I'm down 10% power.   The game failed to scare me after watching youtube video's of people getting ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off that they lost because they actually played the game right and because of how random things are, they died.   After the 2nd day, I wasn't scared at all, I was more happy that I made it to the next night without getting killed from some accidental miss click of the lights or I checked the cameras for too long.  I only recommend this game to people who have a short time spand to waste, I beat the game in an hour and only died once.

SINGLE PLAYER - Nearly a perfect sandbox first person shooter  MULTIPLAYER -  The actual multiplayer is fun and fast paced. The issue? The multiplayer is so broken that it could take you literally an hour to find a game, and after one game, Farcry 3 will crash. After every multiplayer game. This is because Ubisoft chooses to not have dedicated servers and make people play through their service called uPlay. You can't play with steam friends. You have to add your friends on uPlay. You don't get steam achievements, you get uPlay achievements. uPlay is literally the dumbest thing ever and Ubisoft should be ashamed of themselves for releasing Farcry 3 and not EVER fixing the multiplayer crashes and bugs. I'm not the only one who experiences this, almost every player who plays on direct x11 will deal with it. A small number of people can play fine with Direct 9x but why limit yourself so much graphical degration for a game you payed for that should of been COMPLETE. I'm never buying another Ubisoft game again. They lost my buisness and i highly reccommend you not buy any Ubisoft games if your interested in playing any Multiplayer. They've also been known to intentionally degrade graphics on PC on some of their games to make it look more like the console versions. (Watch Dogs for example) Thumbs up my review, let people know before they buy. The decision is yours!

I have to be real here. I get the idea of combat being the major focus of Total War games, but I never played one before. This was the first total war game that crossed over into a Genre I enjoy.  I don't despise the game, but I feel some elements could have been done better.  Pros - I like that they put vampires in. I'm pretty sick of Orcs versus Humans in everything Warhammer, including 40K. People forget that other races exist in the setting.  - The war simulation is pretty cool with massive units running around beating each other up.  Cons - The war simulation gets old after awhile. I end up just auto resolving so many fights with the AI, which I'm thankful there's buttons for it. - War controls are not clear or when actions you do matter. I had to watch you tube videos of veterans of the Total War franchise to get any idea how fighting really works. Like being able to hold keys while dragging units to move them in formation. I don't mind a tutorial on HOW TO CONTROL ARMIES! - Autoresolve uses some odd math because any battle autoresolve says DOOOMED, you'll probably win if you fight it out. Now sure why they put it? - Kingdom management is as deep as a puddle. I have more fun with other games in the genre (Age of Wonders 3 for example) that allow a bit more depth. - One world map? No random maps? Modded maps? Nothing? - I must be doing something wrong with chaos faction DLC because these dudes take forever to build up. This might seem like a LEARN 2 PLAY NUB moment, but that's what tutorials are for.  Overall, Total War fans will probably like it, I think there's better High Level Strategy games out there. You might like it, I felt some things could be much better!

review_text: The first word in post-apocalyptic roleplaying, Fallout's 3rd (ish) installment brings the tactical, turn-based tale of survival through the Wasteland to the DC area and into the 3rd dimension (in real time!). It does so incredibly well; providing hours upon hours of rich lore, side quests, great voice over, and horrifying mutants. Once upon a past, I used to actually like Planetside 2, and liked it enough to spend a bunch of money on it. I realized, however, that I was clinging to the nostalgia of Planetside and the massive battles we used to have, with crazy fights over the LLU, courtyards filled with mines, doing REK Checks, granny-hacking a door because NO ONE ELSE BROUGHT A REK, holding the CC... things like this. I was holding on to it, telling myself that we'll have that back soon.  Planetside 2 is a shadow of its former self. The team is either too small or too under-funded to get this game up to fill the boots of its aged predecessor. Worse still, is how many things are broken.  The Main Battle Tanks for each faction went from requiring teamwork to a gigantic storm of metal rolling/hovering down the dirt roads, each occupied by one person who has locked the vehicle to prevent a second person from helping them in the aux gunner's seat. The tanks are woefully screwed up: Terran Republic Prowler has an Identity Crisis -- its special ability, Anchored Mode, implies that it would be great for long range shelling work. It can be. But you rarely are in a situation to LR shell anything for more than 30 seconds. New Conglomerate Vanguard has a Lovechild Crisis -- its special ability is an overshield that can last up to eight seconds, for maximum GTFO ability, and it recharges for use at a ridiculous rate. Vanu Sovereignty Magrider has a Red-headed Stepchild problem -- Magburner. Seriously? A one second boost in any direction that you then have to wait HOW LONG for a recharge on?   The MAX suits aren't much better. Should've let Nanite Systems make those, instead of each faction developing their own tech, just for the sake of balancing them, including their weapons. The specials, I can't really remark on: They're mostly okay, though Vanu ZOE seems to promote the concept of Strength In Unity. Also, the NC get shields. Again. Giant phalanx shields. So... TR are at a standstill with lockdown. NC can advance infantry from behind a wall of shielding MAX units. VS can just do their blurry ZOE thing and kill everything. Sounds legit.  The infantry game is really dry at this point. Enter base. Get people on points long enough to flip for the timer, then go hide. Kill anything that approaches the point from hiding spaces. Lather, rinse, repeat. Control Point Capture is just dull and uninspired. You'll end up just following the footzerg around and twiddling your thumbs far too often, even in an an outfit.  I've played the game for a while. It doesn't get better. The content needs improvement.  My suggestions, if Higby, et al are reading, are as follows: Bring back the LLU runs. This encourages open space battles, instead of the cramped up hallways with no doors. Stop coddling people in their spawn rooms -- I remember being killed when I spawned in Acan, in my own spawn room, by a bunch of worthless rebel scum in AI MAXes. They blew the other tubes, kept one, and used it as a meatgrinder for idiots who thought they could spawn there. I hated it, but it was a tactic, and secretly, fun. Require maintenance of bases. ANT runs, as an example. It'd also give lowbies something to do besides jumping face-first into the fray. Hossin. Searhus. Cerysh-- no, wait, ♥♥♥♥ Ceryshen.  I've given up on asking for the old ACE back. I've given up on the FDU for now.  I just want the fun to come back. :(

If you buy this game, you're rolling the dice: it might simply not work.

Five Nights at Freddy's is a game where you work as a security guard at a local kids pizzaria. But... the night shift (of course). You work from 12:00 am to 6:00 am. There are four animatronics there. Bonnie Bunny, Chica Duck, Freedy Fazbear, and Foxy Fox. There is also a easter egg in the game. Golden Freddy. The animatronics there are energized by night, for they had been standing still all day. So they tend to wander a little. Then after hours, they no longer see you as a person. They will see you as a metal endo skeleton (the skeleton of the animatronics). Then they try to stuff you in a Freddy Fazbear suit, (which is too small for a man) instantly shoving your eyes out the front, killing you. The animatronics are friendly singers by the day, and vicous hunters, with a dark shadowy secret by night.

Explore the island as you like or quest until you can not quest anymore! There are so many things to do in Far Cry 3. Many things to find and collect, kill, and (my favorite) raid enemy camps. I love this game because you can easily spens 1-5 hours in a sitting without even noticing. I recommend this game 100%!

Clicker Heroes is an idle game, which means it is supposed to pretty much play itself, i.e. keep progressing even while it's not running. And while in theory it might be an idle game, in practice it turns out it isn't,  really . Why? Allow me to elaborate.  What you have to do in the game is click on the current mob you're fighting to do damage to it, or let your heroes kill it since they do damage automatically. When you kill the mob, you get gold. You use the gold to level your heroes and buy more powerful ones. When you kill 10 mobs on a level, you advance to the next level, where the mobs have more HP. However, their HP rises exponentially, as does the price of leveling your heroes. And, although the gold mobs drop also gets increased with their level, that's not enough to cover the hero levels you need to keep you going at the same speed. So when the progress gets too slow, what do you do? You restart. Restarting gets you Hero souls which increase your heroes' DPS, so in the next run you can go a little faster and/or get a little further.   However , the reason you can't just leave the game be and expect to progress is that every 5 levels you get a boss mob which has to be defeated within 30 seconds, otherwise you automatically go back to the previous level. So if you leave the game running for a while, you're going to find your heroes on a pre-boss level having farmed some gold. Then you'll use the gold to level the heroes and get past the boss, only to find yourself, after a few levels, at the same slow pace you were at previously. Your heroes can farm gold for hours, days even, but it's not going to amount to much since the cost of leveling them rises exponentially.  What it all amounts to is that if you want to have something like a constant rate of progress in the game, you will have to keep clicking every X minutes. Otherwise, your progress will grind to a halt. Compare that to a game like Adventure Capitalist where you only need to put in a few clicks a few times a day to maintain good progress and you can see how, while it may suck you in at first, Clicker Heroes will likely frustrate you with the time it demands.  TL;DR Not really an idle game, you have to keep clicking.  Protip Use a gaming mouse with macro support and use an autoclicking macro to give you a huge boost in the beginning before you get a decent idle DPS going.

I consider this game having three acts, the first starting out on the island and hunting down Vaas, the second having you reach the second island, and the third having you complete the game.  It has 38 story missions total, so about 12-13 missions for each act. The game is also split between two islands, the first two acts take place on the first island with the final act taking place on the second. The game starts off great, I was really enjoying the first act, and the side missions were fun enough to keep me doing them. However, after a while the side missions just get boring, as unfortunately they fall into the Ubisoft formula of 'Go here, kill this, come back.' that plagues their games. I completed about 2/3 of the side missions before I just started ignoring them, and strangely all of the side missions you can do to get special animal skins to craft the best upgrades are all on the first island, so you'll have every upgrade before you finish the first act. Also for the first act you talk a lot with your new buddy, Dennis, and he helps you through learning the ropes of the island. I really liked Dennis, and by the end of the game I really felt bad for him.  The second act is where I found the game really fell flat. I quite enjoyed Vaas and his role in the game, but unfortunately he doesn't stick around until even the end of the second act. After him you have to deal with his boss, Hoyt, who has hardly even been mentioned until this point in the game and isn't nearly as interesting. Along with losing interest in the side missions, I was also losing interest with the story. There wasn't really much keeping me going at this point, even Jason was starting to irk me, as I just couldn't understand a lot of his decisions and most of what was even coming out of his mouth anymore.  However, I feel the third act is where the game really shines. The last 10 missions are fantastic, and your new new buddy, Sam, is a really fun character and adds a lot of spice back to the game. I definitely like Sam more than Dennis, and the story missions with him are by far the best. Fortunately Jason was getting a little better in my eyes and I was liking him again, and a lot of the stupid things he was saying in the second act have passed. The final few missions were amazing and I finished the game with a significantly higher opinion of it than I had by the end of the second act.  Meanwhile, there are lots of collectibles, as is to be expected from a Ubisoft game. This game seems to try and one-up Assassin's Creed by having at least a thousand chests scattered around the two islands (this is probably an exaggeration, but good lord there has got to be at least 500), not to mention 120 relics, 20 Japanese WWII letters, and 20 drug dealer memory cards to collect. As with all Assassin's Creed games, you can purchase maps to show you where everything is, then you just have to collect them.  Overall, the game is very fun despite the weak middle part. Though keep in mind that it will be a test of endurance if you plan on achieving 100% completion as the collectibles and side missions are an exercise in tedium.

This is the only FPS MMO that I will play because of it's non-resemblance to an MMO. Sure, there are unlockables, levels, and an in-game store, but you really don't need to do anything but shoot the opposing faction. This game is basically a Sci-Fi free version of Battlefield.  Of course, there are some glitches in the game that any MMO has, but most of them are not game-breaking or do not really give a person an advantage.  The real fun in the game is joining a Platoon on the conquest across one of the three continents. Battles for capture points can end up being 200 on 200 and end up being really fun and long-lasting battles. The downside to that is since great action packed battles are based on the amount of players each side has, early mornings or weekdays can get pretty boring with battles consisting of everyone ghost capping points or one side being able to rush an entire continent without opposition.  Other than the fact that the game is really reliant on the amount of people playing at once, it is a great game to pick up as your primary game or even to be played once in a while, like I do.

Chivalry: Medieval Warfare...   This game tests your reaction speed and quick thinking. With a large amount of weapons to choose from this game gives a nice variety to different situations. A leveling system that also rewards you with new available weapons and armor/color. A solid amount of maps to play and servers to play those maps in. Full controller support(be sure to max your sensitivity, trust me).   I have clocked in over 500 hours into the game because I cannot get enough of the killing, the winning and the vast amount of fun this medieval combat presents me.  Those moments when you are outnumbered and surrounded and you unleash your instinctive ability to fight for your life, kick that person, duck the first swing, turn around with a swing, chop head off, lunge towards unsuspecting fighter with s stab to the chest, turn to final opponent, block, overhead swing, overhead again... Such sweet moments. I personally enjoy using the Knight with Maul to smash my enemies' heavy armor in.   There are 4 different classes to choose from: Man at Arms, Knight, Vanguard and the Archer.   I love this game as much as I love people, so much that I just want to chop them all up.  Truly, a game worth playing over and over again. 10/10, 5/5 * * * * *

I've been playing total war since Shogun 1. This is the worst total war so far. The battles don't require tactics just charge and have beefier units. The campaign map can be beaten in 5 hours (I fully united the empire on Very Hard in 1 hour so I am being an optimist with the long story of crushing Chaos)  There are so few units that the game is very bland. I was hoping for some unit customization like one can do with Warhammer, or at least chosing your own color. The Map is about the size of my bedroom and they only included one continent of the 7 or so in Warhammer lore.  I should have seen this comming with how Rome 2 was constructed, it took Divide et Impera to make the game what it should be. Also their DLC policy must be, 'let's rake them over the coals.' Because one race per purchase means that the total cost of this game to get the full experience is going to be well over $200 vs. all factions and units at the beginning of Medieval 2 for $60 upon initial release.  At least there are very little if no glitches I encountered. Go save a lot of money and go play Mount and Blade for more unit diversity and just as good game play.

Played for 50 minutes. Wasn't a massive fan. Returned.  Now for the uber simplistic Pro/Con list that everyone loves!  Pros: - RPG Elements = Fantastic. - Chaos/Vampric Corruption mechanics. Love it, rewards the patient player.  Cons: - Slow. You thought Early GTA 5 had loading issues.... Oh boy have I got news for you. It takes about GTA's load time to get into a single battle. - Graphics. Eh. Much like Attila, nothing has changed and frankly I'm PERSONALLY not a fan of the art style. - AI. Terrible. Not an ounce of tactical awareness. 'Oh look, he has a bigger army than me... Let's just back up into the corner and hope he passes by...'. Better than early Rome 2 granted, but not by much. - Horribly simplistic. No loose formation, no tax fiddling, no advanced group formations, no fine adjustment of army movements like in ETW NTW & S2TW. - Clunky? Hard the explain, but everything feels so slow and overburdened... - Yet fast? Again, no idea how nor why. Despite the units needing a fitness trainer and some weightwatching... Battles are all too fast. Units barely even connect before one side is drastically losing and routing.  Conclusion?  Oh I don't know. What did we expect? So many people are selling this game on the new mechanics like magic and flying ♥♥♥♥... well? That's all cool stuff. But the fundamental basics of the game are still missing or not in a good state. I think its good that CA have been able to step out of the usual boundaries and create something with a genuinely refreshing personality in terms of gameplay mechanics.  But I have a horrid feeling that CA has become lazy. Like so many other dev's who just want to pump out games and rake in the cash. Leaving the mess in their games to be cleaned up and fixed by their fantastically loyal communities.  Mods are for enhancing a game. Not fixing it... And yet this game will be defined by the mods avaliable for it like with R2TW & ATW... Not for its simply enjoyable core.

This game is like LoL (League of Legends). I never played LoL, but I can tell you this: LoL is more of a non-serious game, where you compete for fun. It is more easy as well, but DOTA 2 (Defense of the Ancients 2) is more serious in terms of being bad = being reported. If you get reported, most likely you will be sent to low priority which results in longer wait time for finding a game. It is also more punishing than LoL, which results it making more harder than LoL. If you are looking for another MOBA game, give this a try. If you are tired of noobies in LoL, play this and quit LoL. More likely you will find better players in here than LoL. There is also good sportsmanship in this game. Rise up the ranks to be in better games. 9/10

This is a great single player game with the potential to eat hundreds of hours. The modding community also produces a good amount of content to further extend the game for players looking for changes here and there.  That being said, I simply cannot recommend this game...   First and foremost, lets talk about MP... Sub Optimal Balance and online cheese is of course to be expected, especially with a new title. What's not to be expected and imo shameful considering the tens of thousands of times people have clamored about this issue is that pulling your internet plug during a MP does not result in a loss, nor does it result in a win for the player on the other side. It results in a ♥♥♥♥ing 'Draw' meaning every other game some 12 year old who can't handle loosing just avoids the hit to his/her stats and at the same time waste the hell out of your time. Starcraft in 1998 (18 years ago) had a FAR better system than this.  Next point, which seems to be represented in volume already is the DLC policy... Blood/Gore as a dlc? What?! Pulling a race out of the base game and selling it as a DLC from the get go... What?! Already releasing a 20$ DLC with large numbers of key units missing within 2 months of the games release.... What?! I fear that the combination of Sega and Games Workshop has resulted in a critical mass of greedy DLC...  All in all... Save the purchase of this game and dlc till it's on sale and if you're looking for reasonable MP just avoid this and other total war games all together.

I really disliked playing this. It's got a very generic sci-fi shooter feel to it, the captain of my squad took this game way too seriously and tried to be a real marine, and my absolute least favorite part: it's pay-to-win. The other thing is that the game is always changing. Now, I play Ingress, so I don't dislike that fact because I'm used to the portal right next to my house always changing hands. Hey, whatever, it gives me experience. But it means that if you ever want to have fun with this game, you pretty much have to play it 24/7, and I frankly don't care.   TL;DR: You need to pay-to-win and you need a lot of time to dedicate to clicking if you want to pretend to be a real soldier.

I've been a Total War fan since Rome I and have bought all the main games and main expansions. I don't normally write reviews but I had to put in my two cents. I was honestly never going to preorder this game after the Rome II debacle, but I decided to buy after all of the great community content on Youtube and the decision to include the Chaos Warriors DLC as free for the week after the game was released and the free content to be released. I decided to preorder a week before release date regardless of previous experiences.    This is by far the best Total War game that I've played. I've never had the experience of having so much fun that I played the campaign with all the main races- It's been 3 days since release and I've already played through Dwarf, Vampire, Chaos and just started the Orks- It's a really fun game. I'm actually excited for future content because I've had a blast. It's fun- i love the addition of the heroes and seeing them in the battlefield - they feel impactful on the outcome of battles. I would love to read up on their lore and interact with them more- this is a huge improvement on generals in the family tree. Not going to joke I become attached to them and if I lose them in a battle I reload.     The game isn't perfect- there's a couple of bugs I noticed but nothing game breaking, I think the cities sieges can be improved. I feel limited with some of the customization of my characters- I pick up a lot of gear but I'd love to do quests to build or equip and level my characters in more interactive way- would love to see them wear the cool gear on the battlefield. I'd like to customize my wizards more- sometimes they don't feel powerful at all. This would be great for a multiplayer similar to Shogun 2- I think that that concept would be an excellent add here.     I previously had no interest in the Warhammer universe, since then I have sunk my teeth into the material and I think the execution of the Warhammer universe is excellent. It's fun- it's interesting, it's unique, its refreshing, there is tons of replayabiltiy- This is up there with one of the great classic games- like Heroes of Might and Magic and Civilization.    CA- Great game, cannot wait for more.
