I'll just tell you from my small experience the three odd things I found while playing:  1. Treadmill 2. Ferris Wheel 3. Cow Farm  Now here, we find a few things about each of these. The treadmill likes to send you flying fast at 73 goats per hour. Really fast. The ferris wheel has 18 passanger carts that can hold a total of 73 goats. The cow farm, on the other hand, has many hoomanized cows, but only 18 of them rank up to kick the living sh*t out of you.  Each of these things share one thing in common. The hoomans know we love the treadmill when we place them on it. They know we cannot resist the temptations of the spinning wheel of death. They know that we must challenge the cows in staring contests in accordance to our 8th law. The hoomans are trying to control us. We cannot fall into their trap, for we cannot spare them of their desire. We will overcome them all! We will make them worship us!! Come on, my brothers and sisters! WE MUST STAND STRONG AGAINST THE HOOMANS FOR THE CHEESE!!

After putting 50 hours of single player campaign play of almost purely auto-resolving battles due to the lack of battle tactics and micro play, here is my review.   Let's all agree that the peak of this series was Shogun 2, (Rome 2: Emporer Edition close 2nd, my opinion) this game is pathetically tragic. Only reason i continue to play is my overwhelming desire to play another Lord of the Rings Battle for Middle Earth, obviously meaning this game reminds me of it. I was depressed unit formations were competely removed, (Hoplite Wall, Testudo, Wedge for cavalry) the unbelievably dry battles that rely completely on your ability to effectively manage your unit morale disgusts me. The fact that 1 whole unit of Orc Arrer Boyz breaks due to taking 4 volleys of quarreler fire is pathetic. I understand this title is not the norm for this company and love that they expanded their genre, but why, with all of Creative Assembly's infinite wisdom, would you remove mechanics that made the game effectively pleasing; unit formations are gone, city battles are gone (unless there is defense which now takes a building slot which is ridiculous) sea battles gone, agents are mostly gone, city building has been efficiently reduced to a disgustingly laughable minimal set of incredibly linear 2-3 tier buildings that directly effect income, tech, and public order of course, (oh and defense, can't forget the only way to defend a city without an army garrisoned).   If I had watched gameplay first I would not have purchased it.   5/10
If you love being spawn killed, then this is the game for you.

I've been playing this game for 2-3 years now and I'm still learning a lot of new things playing new heroes. I got better since the beginning of course but there are still a lot of things hindering me from becoming better due to the people I often get teamed with. Unreasonable, uncultured, foul, uncooperative, egotistical and indenial people ruining my games 80% of the time. People like to say not to complain about others and work on yourself to get good and that's true. I can live with my mistakes and I know I do sometimes. But complaining about a team that snowballed pretty well until the mid game where every crumbled because of the refusal to get BKBs isn't my mistake when I've been telling them for 15 minutes to get a BKB and end the game. It was too late when my carries had their BKBs because they've been losing the past few team fights due to not being able to survive. Nobody cares how much damage per second you can do when you can hardly survive a fight. It's like having the fastest car in the world with no engine. Logic? I'm not a high skilled player and not very mechanical but I observe a lot of the things people do in pub games and often times my team makes the most mistakes. Primarily because they like to play for themselves and refuse to strategize and listen to the shot caller. I've been in normal skill bracket all my life since I started so I know how they play very well. If only my team is on the same page with me, I'd win most of my games and not have to waste time on a bunch of immature, fun loving (as in spoiling games and throwing), and unreasonable ♥♥♥♥faces.   TL;DR : I hate how most Pinoys, Indonesians, and Thais play. Mainly Filipinos and Indonesians because they think they know the game but they can never show it in their plays and for Thais, they barely speak a word of English so it was very difficult to communicate strategies with them.

Kinda feel like I bought a nice new car, only to find out that the tires weren't included.  Edit: Since people aren't finding this review helpful, I will expand.   TWW is actually a good game at its core, but the problem is the DLC policy. It's not OK to shave off portions of a complete game in order to sell them back to customers who already paid (very) full price. The Chaos faction's assets were already in the game at launch, but locked behind a pay wall. Likewise, Creative Assembly is charging for a higher gore setting -- something that a more scrupulous developer would add as a free update.   At some point, this game may be worth buying as a deeply discounted, 'game of the year' edition. I really wish I had done a little more research before paying full price for 80% of a game. That's my fault for expecting to be treated like a customer and not a sheep in need of sheering. As it stands, I can't even sit down to play the portion of the game I *do* have without getting angry, both at CA and at myself for being a sucker.

What is Goat Simulator?  Recently there has been a lot of hype revovling around this game for its randomness and such, but is it really worth it to buy and play? Better question, will this game last you a long time, or at least long enough to get maybe a decent amount of hours in before your sick of it? For I regretably found the creul truth of this game, it's just not enough fun. There isn't nearly enough fun, wacky things to do as a goat in this game to keep you occupied. Of course, just as I did, you'll have an hour or so when you'll say something like'BEST GAME EVER!', later you'll find out it's more of a in the moment feeling. I did have a good hour or so when it felt like it was so much fun, not knowing what to screw up as a goat next, but then very soon it was evident, the game got boring. (THE GAME LIVES OFF THE FACT OF YOU BEING A GOAT TOO MUCH!!!)  What do you do in the game?  The game consists of you, a goat, being well, a goat. You basically terrorize a small(and I mean SMALL) town and do what ever you really feel like whether it's ruin a family's dinner or grab a big boulder with your tounge and hurt stuff(kind of fun). Your main things you can do are move around with the W,A,S,D keys(duh), run with the shift key, use the E key to grab to stuff with your tounge and take it somewhere(maybe out for dinner?) and of course jump with the SPACE BAR. Also as you do more things in the game more small abilities unlock like the GOATBORN, which is basically you being able to Fus Ro Da as a goat, which I admit, can be fun.  Should I Buy This Game?  Really I don't know if I can tell you the answer completly, but I may be able to push a little towards my idea of the situation. This game is is fun for only how long you let it be fun. By that I mean it's fun only if you sort of have an imagination or like just messing around with no real incentives, or goals. Personally, when I play a game I feel I need some sort of goal to push towards and acheive because well that's sort of what makes a lot of games fun. Now there are a few small 'goals' you can do, but nothing really worth going into depth like doing a backflip, but earning nothing in return, horay. So if you want to spend 10$ on this game go ahead, just remember, the game in a nutshell dosen't have much substance to it so it won't last long if you don't like just messing around.  NOTE: Also just like to note that there isn't any multiplayer, but there is a workshop kind of thing where you can doownload other people's maps, which could grant a few more hours of play.   VERDICT: 7/10 It's Ok  Pro Your a goat Gives you a good laugh Only 10$(Could also be a con couldn't though?) Good if your bored one afternoon and have nothing to do   Con Causing destruction and such gets old after a while Graphics glitch out(I realize that it's suppose to be in the game, but can be annoying) No goals or at least anything really worth striving to do  Costs 10$

This was a real turn off for me as I was hoping to play games with only my friends. Even simple indie games like SpeedRunner have better party organization than this. As for the rest of the game, the fighting is fun even though the combat seems very clunky. Everything swings slowly, creating a very awkward gameplay style when a 1v1 lasts forever with no one getting hits in. Save your money and put it into a worthwhile game for both PvE and PvP play, such as Dark Souls 2.

CLICKER HEROES:  I CAN'T BELIEVE THEY STILL MAKE THESE Clicker Heroes is Cookie Clicker clone no. 2646953, in the sense that it's gameplay revolves entirely around clicking on an idle object until another idle object is satisfied that the first idle object has been clicked enough. After a little while of this the game presents you with an idle object that takes arguably longer to click away because the idle object that checks your clicking has sodded of the the Winchester for a couple of pints with the lads. This game is boring. Painfully boring. And I mean literally, my left finger hurts. This game is more likely to progress your arthritis than it is to progress itself. After my 5 minutes of seldomity and boredom, I quit out (via Alt+F4 because it has no pause menu, quit button, etc) and did a little research. It turns out that Clicker Heroes is a flash game released onto various flash game sites until it somehow got ♥♥♥♥ onto greenlight, which then re-♥♥♥♥ it onto my Discover list. It's literally a single .exe created most likely using a .swf to .exe converter, if I had to guess. It's lazy. It's surprisingly glitchy. And it's given me stiff fingers.  Clicker Heroes gets a Medical Bill out of 10.

You want to play a game. Not just any game though; you want to play a game that will take you to a massive world with lots of people playing. A game that promises to give you an exciting adventure and make you feel happy with it.  But you heard of Planetside 2.  Its alright, however. Its a free game and by some miracle you have a computer that can atleast run this at at the lowest resolution at the lowest graphics setting at around 30fps. Technically its all good in the interstellar hood. You get the game downloaded and feel excited about the journey ahead. Maybe you will be a sneaky sniper that takes out important targets. Maybe an engineer or medic to help people and gain allies in jolly cooperation. Maybe you will be a grissled baddass of norse legend, running into combat with nothing but a LMG and pride for your made-up nation.  You decide to go the faction that is basically Space-America, because the other two are about as morally north as the moral compass of the Westboro Baptist Church. You go through training, and boy is it arduous. A whole tutorial on what a gun is and how to walk around. You also learn how to use teleporters, which are all around for an unknown reason that supports no claim to sound logistical usage.  Its time. Its finally time to get out there and not only be somebody, but kill somebody in the name of Space-'Murica. You drop into the battle, heart on your sleeve and smile on your face. Its game time. The pod crashes in the most intense fighting on the whole continent and you are at the center of it. You take a whole 5 seconds to survey the scene: a squad of your infantry is decimated by an explosion as a tank drives past you, seven shades of dropship are bringing in friendly and enemy troops, tracers are going everywhere...  Death...4....3....2...................2? SPAWN  Thats alright. You're still positive. Its just that you are new. Its fine. Your claim to fame will come. You decide to take it easy and become an Infiltrator. Hanging back, spotting high value targets, maybe taking a few out here and there. Sounds pretty sneaky. And awesome....mostly awesome.   However this doesn't last long because there are dozens of other snipers out there, all are better then you. You try every class in the game and slowly treck through every territory on the map hoping for a fight you can win. What you didn't realize is that Space-America is the worst faction in the game. They have less people and apparently don't know what vehicles are because you haven't seen a friendly one in ages. Wait...is that dropship ours? Oh thank god! Thank sweet merciful christ! Take me with you, I want to have fun!  He swoops down as if to pick you up. And then runs you over at terminal velocity. Death....4.....3.....2.......4....SPAWN  You are in dismay now. You wanted a fun experience and to get into large fights that seemed to be so equal and coordinated. Massive tank assaults, valiant infantry raids. None of that seems to be there for you. You just run from base to base as each one is taken by another faction. The enemy vehicles and infantry seem inexhaustible and the armor of both is impenetrable. There is no hope of your success; of your feeling good. You are just a cog in a dying war machine.   You go to the top of one of your last friendly bases and watch your allies march on to the front. You never did learn how to get into a squad with people. If only the tutorial had explained how to do that. Oh well, you leap off of the base and hurtle to the ground below, striking it with what you imagine would be a soft squish.  Death.....prepare to respawn.
This game is good, but it's a huge cash grab with all the overpriced DLC and you will not get enough content for your buck. Will not buy another Total War game again...

It may have started out as a great game, but now it's just a massive fustercluck as you struggle to figure out what the flying ♥♥♥♥ity ♥♥♥♥ is going on around you.  I found the game simple enough while it was just a matter of defending my faction's structures and a simple matter navigating lightly defended enemy structures with maybe a teammate or two to back me up. It was fun, and even though I died quite a bit I felt like I had a handle on what I was doing.  But when I got to the massive 80 vs. 80 sections where my team was laying siege to a heavily defended structure, I had no idea what was going on. I'd often die and not even know what killed me due to the killer being too far away. There was no direction, no one in the squads was any help, and overall it just wasn't a pleasant experience, not helped by the games useless tutorial.  I'll give the game props for being ambitious with its server and game sizes, but there's not direction. An AI commander giving you suggestion of where to go might've helped, but I can't say such a change would make me want to go back seeing as this would only benefit the new guys like me and not the seasoned veterans.

ATTENTION! MY RESONS FOR NOT RECCOMENDING THIS GAME HAVE TO DO WITH THE ABSURD DLC POLICIES. READ THE REVIEW IF THAT DOESNT CONCERN YOU   The GOOOOD 1.) The main factions are all unique and play very differently. and i have noticed very few balance issues.  2.) the map is gorgeous, if a little small  3.)The new siege battles are intense, quick, and can be challenging.  4.) the legendary lords work out beautifully  5.) EASILY THE BEST LAUNCH CA HAS HAD IN YEARS. No game breaking glitches, no crazy OP units, good job team  The BAAAAAAAD Most of the issues i have revolve around them trying to fix past mistakes  1.) In the past, balance issues have always been a problem. so, in this game the 5 (soon to be six) factions are all done really really well: at the cost of all the minor factions just being copy-pasted verisons of the main ones. doesnt really make sense  2.) Small city battles had a tendancy to get dull and repetative, due to the small number of MAPS for the small city battles. So the best fix for that would be to make a larger variety of maps, yes? NOT ACCORDING TO CA. They decided to get rid of small city battles altogether, meaning that you'll be fight out in the OPEN. This basically invalidates the garrisons for small cities. Not much point fighting when you cant tactically deploy. As such, you might as well auto-resolve, save you some time  3.) again, in response to naval battles not ever beingreal good, they simply go back to the medival 2 style, of forced autoresolves  The rest of the issues are only concerning if they dont make an effort to fix them. Leaving to reason i cannot reccomend this game:  4.) Cereative assembly is charging absurd prices already for Downloadable content. The Call of the Beastmen expansion adds a new faction to the game. Thats it: It adds everything that a new complete faction would need. And they decided to charge you 19 dollars for this. THAT MAKES THIS FACTION MORE THEN DOUBLE THE COST OF ANY OTHER FACTION. Case in point? Chaos Warriors are 8 bucks. They expect you to pay a THIRD of the price the FULL GAME was, for ONE faction. As such, i cannot in good conscience reccomend Total War Warhammer.

Basically the worst rts game I've ever played in my entiry life. Not because of story or the units but the controls. A good rts game should be playable with the mouse only or at least it should be possible to move over the map with the mouse. But for that you need w & a & s & d on your keyboard. And to change the angle you need c & v. WTF?! They must have been on a permanent lsd trip. You can change the controls but only to other control keys on your keyboard and not for example your mouse. Would it be so hard to stay confrom to the rts genre?! Press scroll button on the mouse to change the angle and press and hold the left mouse button to move over the map? It would be that simple. I know it sounds kind of strange and for some people it might not be a huge problem but for me it's making the game unplayable.  LOL and the game doesn't support multiple monitors by the default settings. You have to set a checkbox which capures the mouse within the frame. Why is this not selected by default?! Another 45 bucks burned for nothing.

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: I've finally got to play Fallout 3 and you know what? It is an amazing skydiving simulator!   From an experienced skydiver and as someone who has played Fallout New Vegas I can say I don't miss the views of New Vegas as Fallout 3 has so many more places to view and skydive in, the level of detail that has went into this game is brilliant! Compared to the other games you can actually fail, not in the sense of not landing on target, but in the sense if you don't check your gear properly before hand it can fail! Really is a game I would recommend to people who are considering skydiving! I've startred using it for training at my work. For those of you who don't have the guts to jump from a plane, this will give you the experience without the danger! (Maybe put a fan on for wind and an oculus rift)  Anyways, amazing game, I will give my review if I ever get to play Fallout 2, but I am worried this game has now spoiled me!

At first i felt like this game was trying to hard to make this game Open World. Dont get me wrong i loved this game, but i bought it for open world and side quests. Far Cry 3 had 'side quests' but these quests would mess up the story line and often mess up the main story line. The open world aspect to it wasnt open world at all really just a large world filled with nothing in particular. In my opinion i would recommend it to people who like a game that sticks to the storyline and just that. I would not recommend this to people who like games like 'skyrim' or 'fallout'. I do know its bad to compare these games to this, but if thats what your looking for, dont get this game.

Let me just say that all of Total War games I've played, Total War Warhammer has been so far the best one. In a grandiose launch, the game was already delivered bug-free and gorgeous, with stunning graphics and (at least so far) no major bugs. The FPS and optimization was extremelly well done, so one does not really need a high end PC in order to play it (of course, that doesn't mean that everyone will able to play with Ultra settings on, but still).  Lore, flavour, and depth-wise, the game does not let the its fans down aswell. Although few, all factions have diverse and unique rosters, aswell as technologies, quests and lore, making each playthrough an unique experience. Furthermore, the quest system which was added grants the game a more fantasy-like feeling, bonding the player to the experience delivered and creating a more immersive atmosphere than in any Total War game before.   These have definitely been the best spent US$59,99 of my life.

A review written from a different angle:   PROS: 1, AGENTS: In most of Total War games the variety of agents is pretty limited. Here however the fantasy setting allows to coherently include a higher variety of agents, especially imperial wizards. There are three of them. Well, some may complain that there are not more. But lets be honest, currently one has to cheer to every game that has more arcane magic users than the generic fireball/lightning-thrower. It is pretty nice that one can chose between getting support from a priest or a wizard in a single fraction. 2, Pretty nice QUESTs which do make actually sense (lore wise) and naturally include you into the story line. 3, How they included that chaos and necromancy CORRUPTS the realm of man is pretty nice.  4, I absolutely love the fact that it is not possible to CONTROL EVERY PROVINCE on the map. If the fractions are not compatible, then you cannot properly interact with their buildings. That makes so much sense and keeps the fraction's distribution stable. Also because therefore the AI does not do unreasonable stuff, like Kislev takes over the dwarfkindoms or the empier ends up in the ork lands wile Bretonia controls the actual empier. 5, I also like the fact that the game includes DIPLOMATIC into mini quests. Many complain about the simple diplomatic system. But in fact the game reacts to your actions on the map and offers you quests to chance your diplomatic status with other fractions.  6, I like the BALANCING. Let me first start off by saying I am a huge Warhammer Fantasy & 40K fan, and a pretty big fan of the Total War series in general.  Secondly I play this game using mods, many of you may not enjoy mods, especially the ones I use, the main one being Radious Total War & Radious Units Pack. I will say without mods I would probably play this game less, but the addition of mods makes this game a beautiful thing, that can grow into fruition, along with any new DLC that comes along the way.   So with that being said, I thoroughly enjoy this game, it is fun, its something I had been hoping for ever since I had played the old 'Warhammer: Mark of Chaos' game, that was like a botched experiment that got my hopes up and let them down hard. This game has so much potential to grow, they're already adding more factions/units, and additional content. My hope for this game is that all the tabletop factions & units from fantasy make it in, so we can truly have a 'Grand Campaign'. If you like Total War games, and Warhammer, then this game is definitely for you.      -I may edit this review later depending on the course of the game & content-

While I do have another game of a similar nature (AdVenture Capitalist), I can't recommend Clicker Heroes.  My main reason for not recommending this game is the attachment to clicking, and the idea that to maximize playtime is to use autoclickers to play the game for you. I think idle games are fine in general (although they aren't much of a game to begin with), but I think clicking-focused games cross a line between game and Computer Hardware Testing Simulator.  This game might be a right fit for some people. Some people might enjoy this style of play. It's not a poorly-designed game graphically, and functionally it works how it should. But if someone asked me for a game recommendation, free or otherwise, this game would have to take a connecting flight for the privilege of standing in line to be considered for a spot at the bottom of my recommendation list.

Another enjoyable Total War game and a must play if you enjoy the world of Warhammer!   The game is streamlined and simplified from previous TW titles which is good in my opinion as it speeds up gameplay This makes it easier to jump into a new game whether you are new to the series or are starting your 10th campaign. I do miss some of the variety of formations during army set up from Atilla: TW and earlier but its a minor thing.   The game looks beautiful and the soundtrack is excellent as with earlier TW titles.   The expansions have each added some new features to the campaign which were welcome and added new depth to the game. The Beastmen DLC was a little too on the nose in that they (the Beastmen) were obviously just mash-up of Chaos and Orcs mechanics. The King and the Warlord, however, was very enjoyable and allowed for playing the Orcs in a totally new way.  Overall I recommend this game. 9/10

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: For starters, let's say I didn't hate playing FO3. I've beaten it few times, did the majority of quests and even played all the DLC's. I even had fun doing that. Do I recommend playing it? Maybe. Is it a terrible game? No. There, I said it. Moving on.   Here's my main gripe: FO3 is what happens when you take a fantastically written post-apocalyptic game series and hand the rights over to a company whose writers appear to be 12-year-olds.  Imagine a world where every city, every store and every household is an entity separate from the surrounding world. Nothing has an effect on anything else. There's a town a miles down the road with a problem with Raiders? Yeah, that doesn't really affect this storekeeper couple. Heaps of radscorpions make life a living hell for a bunch of settlers living in a run-down village? Yeah, that has no bearing on this other community a stone's throw away, their only problem pertains to fixing their fertility robot. Oh, and getting their hands on a vacuum tube located 20 miles away because reasons.  When you have dozens of locations with seemingly no connection to one another or the main plot, you end up with a huge sandbox that barely resembles the intricate interconnected plots of the first two games. That's Fallout 3's setting in a nutshell. Real world doesn't work like that. If your counter-argument is 'this is a game, not the real world lol' you're completely missing the point. Fallout 1 and 2 came out years before FO3 and yet they still managed to accomplish a sense of reality - albeit a very far-fetched and sometimes tongue-in-cheek one.  Take Fallout 2, where you have a complicated, interconnected political web between New Reno, Redding, Vault City and NCR. Take Fallout: New Vegas where everything rotates around the ongoing conflict between NCR and Caesar's Legion. Everyone has a say in this, everybody is affected. Your choices affect the outcome and the ongoing power structure. That's how you write a game. And that's where FO3 falls flat on its face.  The main plot is bland. I felt like I had no reason to follow the PC's dad. Instead I ran around, doing quests here and there, fetching this and killing that, getting little satisfaction from the caps and experience I accumulated. It wasn't really rewarding. None of it. Just a mindless, momentary distraction on the road to the grave.  Oh, and the metro tunnels suck.

If you are looking for a digital representation of the table-top game this is not it!  Foolishly I did not do any homework on the game and naively hoped it might actually mirror the way the real game works as it is turn-based - that's about as close as it gets.   Ever since GW games first started appearing electronically a large section of the table-top gaming community have yearned for a faithful representation on the PC whether it be Warhammer or Warhammer 40K...I don't think it will ever happen :(  So, the game itself is ok if you are into all that resource gathering malarky - for me Warhammer/Warhammer 40K and resource collection don't belong together - give me a full army list, different battlefields and a way to set a points cost for a battle and let me play the AI or a human opponent - simple - I don't want over complicated and frankly boring world politics. In fact, take away the army skins for Warhammer and this could be just any old turn-based resource gathering, build your army schtick.   The mouse control for looking around is awfully clunky although manouvering the units is failry straight forward. There is just too much information in the game for my liking - all I want to do it fight decent battles against the AI without the whole boring campaign getting in the way and as I have already said, no access to all units unless you research stuff and build buildings and so on, and so on...YAWN!!!

Chivalry is a well executed medieval warfare platform. Chivalry doesn't have the best visuals nor the most advanced combat however the combat is suffiecent and well executed. Like most games out there, there are skill gaps and Chivalry has one, however I'm not sold on there being much skill involved in cluster grouped fights which is most of what FFA is on small maps and smaller Team based maps. This is very frusturating as what usally ends up in the clusters in one of two things: Team killing and poeple blindy swinging their wepons hoping for a kill. All four of the classes besides Knight which is kinda boring have their moments of greatness and lows. I was also surprised at the amount of depth when it comes to maps objectives, and both handheld and siege weapons. All in all Chivalry is a vey fun game and one that I'll be hopping on and off for a long time. 9.13/10 -Bascially Skyrim with swords.

I am completely aware of my bias for warhammer/total war fandoms in writting this. If you do not like Warhammer or total war you will hate this game. If you happen to like one of those things you will probably like it. If you like both, say goodbye to your friends and social life.  This is total war and alot of what you expect from total war(rock, paper, scissors and big battles). The AI still needs a tweak but it is hands down the best AI so far. Thankfully the took Rome II's horrible AI and threw it in the garbage. Art is great, way more immersive than any total war to date. Graphics make Rome II's graphics look as bad as they actually are. One of the things that really makes this game different is the RPG elements and story. The vanilla game I found challenging but not impossible. This game has a ridiculous amount of mods, expect alot of mod based replay.  What sucks? The price tag for the game plus all DLC is alot. One day developers will FINISH a game then give us ADDITIONAL content. This game will make you buy most of the factions in the game now. Beastmen DLC sucks, there I said it. It gives one faction and costs almost $20 and only one legendary lord. Vice-versa, Wood Elf DLC gives the same faction in 2 flavors, Trees or Elves and costs the same. Wait for sales.  If you are waiting for unreleased factions (High Elves and Skaven), keep waiting. Creative Assembly is going to make WHOLE OTHER GAMES and make us buy that over-priced peice of software just to get new maps and factions.  In the end I like the game. The cost is ridiculous and anti-consumer. The very idea that I will have to buy another $60 game to get $20 of DLC is absurd. That is why I cannot recommend this game. This game was shipped with Day 1 DLC (Chaos Warriors), a faction that is heavily apart of the base vanilla game aand should have been free. Day 1 DLC is a cancer on our hobby and the only way to really show your displeasure is with your wallet. I don't know about you guys but I am really tired of having to buy every big game twice or more.

ATTENTION! MY RESONS FOR NOT RECCOMENDING THIS GAME HAVE TO DO WITH THE ABSURD DLC POLICIES. READ THE REVIEW IF THAT DOESNT CONCERN YOU   The GOOOOD 1.) The main factions are all unique and play very differently. and i have noticed very few balance issues.  2.) the map is gorgeous, if a little small  3.)The new siege battles are intense, quick, and can be challenging.  4.) the legendary lords work out beautifully  5.) EASILY THE BEST LAUNCH CA HAS HAD IN YEARS. No game breaking glitches, no crazy OP units, good job team  The BAAAAAAAD Most of the issues i have revolve around them trying to fix past mistakes  1.) In the past, balance issues have always been a problem. so, in this game the 5 (soon to be six) factions are all done really really well: at the cost of all the minor factions just being copy-pasted verisons of the main ones. doesnt really make sense  2.) Small city battles had a tendancy to get dull and repetative, due to the small number of MAPS for the small city battles. So the best fix for that would be to make a larger variety of maps, yes? NOT ACCORDING TO CA. They decided to get rid of small city battles altogether, meaning that you'll be fight out in the OPEN. This basically invalidates the garrisons for small cities. Not much point fighting when you cant tactically deploy. As such, you might as well auto-resolve, save you some time  3.) again, in response to naval battles not ever beingreal good, they simply go back to the medival 2 style, of forced autoresolves  The rest of the issues are only concerning if they dont make an effort to fix them. Leaving to reason i cannot reccomend this game:  4.) Cereative assembly is charging absurd prices already for Downloadable content. The Call of the Beastmen expansion adds a new faction to the game. Thats it: It adds everything that a new complete faction would need. And they decided to charge you 19 dollars for this. THAT MAKES THIS FACTION MORE THEN DOUBLE THE COST OF ANY OTHER FACTION. Case in point? Chaos Warriors are 8 bucks. They expect you to pay a THIRD of the price the FULL GAME was, for ONE faction. As such, i cannot in good conscience reccomend Total War Warhammer.

There are so many things to say about this game, both good and bad. Chivalry is an entirely different game for experienced players than it is for new players and I have to say that after learning how to play the game and getting used to it, I have a lot more bad things to say about it than I did when I first started. With that being said, the game itself is actually really good, it just happens to be plagued with many significant issues.   The game is not only imbalanced but also very broken with more game breaking bugs than a tropical rainforest. Because of these issues the game is unbelievably frustrating at times, especially for someone who wishes to play the game competitively at a high skill level. But for what it's worth, the game still manages to be very addicting when you look past its flaws.   The way the game is designed combined with its cancerous community provides a very hostile environment for new players but the atmosphere of the game and the overall feel of being a part of it more than makes up for getting completely demolished both verbally and physically. I was having so much fun just playing the game when I was new that I didn't even care how poorly I was doing nor what other players were saying about me.  The game is deceivingly complex and has quite a steep learning curve and an even larger skill ceiling but is enjoyable enough for casual players and begginers alike. The games flaws only become apparent when you actually realize how big of an issue they are. The great thing about the issues is that they are not design flaws, and need only be fixed by the developers. With the game still being fairly new and the developers working steadily, I believe Chivalry will only become better over time and is well worth every penny. For an indie game, it is far better than most of the garbage we get nowadays and never ceases to amaze in every way. If you're into this kind of game, you won't regret buying it.

First thing I want to say is that I have a lot more playtime on this game then what steam is showing. For whatever reason steam doesn't record my hours played on occasion. That said let's talk aboot the game. I loved it. I always had a place in my heart for FPS games and open world games and this brings both together in a splendid manner. The gameplay is great and involving and the best thing is you choose how to play it. You get to choose how to do things and what to do first. You could, like me, spend the first 10 or so hours just roaming the world, hunting and crafting and killing things galore. Or you could focus on the story and do side activities when resources are needed as the game becomes more difficult. The weapons aren't anything crazily innovative or creative but all of them feel different and with the addition of customization of these weapons, both functions and painjobs make using them a real joy. The silent and deadly bow, the large, heavy and noisy shotgun, the revolver you keep as a last resort, and the sniper to snipe the stragglers.  If you haven't noticed I really like this game. Another reason being the story. While most people on the internet, mainly reviewers had some weirdly harsh things to say about the story it's pretty good and the story missions themselves are rather enjoyable to play. The characters are usually well developed and they have realistic dialogue for the most part. While there are a few downsides, most of which minor, I still recommend this game to anyone that likes guns, open world gaming, or strategic thinking(especially on the harder difficulties) this game might be for you, so why not have a play? Thanks for reading my rambles and incoherent writing guys.

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: Where to start.. This game made me laugh, cry, rage, and just... feel in general. :( Proud to say this was my first Fallout game and it taught me to appreciate what I have before it's gone. Good games like this are honestly hard to come by. U:   Pros:  • Story line will move you to tears, or at least it did for me. It kept me intrigued and wondering what was going to happen next.  • Good voice acting - THREE DOG! :D  • It has DLC that's actually WORTH BUYING! (wow! C:)   • The world is HUGE! There's so much to do and to explore.  • The nostalgic green tint and dark ambient music really make the atmosphere feel.. well /dead./ In my opinion xD It actually feels like you're in a post-apocalyptic wasteland. :3 Seriously man like sometimes I'd discover some old building and like.. it would creep me out and I would barely be able to go in. D: I'd nope the heck out of there xD  • Graphics aren't bad for an older game ^o^  Cons:  • None :D  Just buy it, you'll thank me later. xP Well, probably not but hey at least you got an *AWESOME* GAAAME! 8D

Excellent game for when you need a break from studying, work, etc., and you are too tired to want to solve puzzles or play a fast paced twitchy game. If you want to chill, this is how to do it. Crack open a beer and laugh as you lick gas cans and use them to ruin family dinner, or charge head-on into a car, just because you can. It's a stupid game for when you want to have good clean stupid fun, and not have to nitpick over builds, strategy, or stealthy approaches. If you want a puzzle game or something deep that makes you think, this isn't it. If you want to laugh and make goat noises at your screen while you headbutt some foolish human into a gas station pump for your own twisted amusement, welcome home. For $10, this is the perfect chill game. Get you goat face on and pick this up.

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: Bethesda should've patched this version better on Win7 or Win8. It IS a classic and has made so many revenue so you!!!  Down vote until a better patch is out.   ------------------  For now, you have to do the following thing from the link:  http://www.nexusmods.com/fallout3/mods/20371/?tab=2&navtag=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nexusmods.com%2Ffallout3%2Fajax%2Fmodfiles%2F%3Fid%3D20371&pUp=1    ------------------  Making Fallout 3 work on Windows 7 & 8  Getting Fallout 3 to run on win 7 and 8  Step 1: Copy the D3D9.dll from the “Source Files” Folder into the main Fallout 3 Directory (Not the Data directory)  Step 2: Right click on the “FalloutLauncher.exe” and “Fallout3.exe” and go to properties.  Step 3: For both “FalloutLauncher.exe” and “Fallout3.exe” right click and go to properties and set the compatibility mode to Windows XP (Service Pack 3)  MAKE SURE THAT FALLOUT 3 IS NOT OPEN FOR THE NEXT STEPS Fallout 3 Config File Editing  Before you try below copy the “Fallout_Default.ini“ file included in the “Source FIles” Folder and place it into your Fallout Directory (NOT THE DATA ONE)  Manually Editing the config file if the above doesn't work. Step 1: Open up the Configuration file in Notepad in the fallout 3 directory, (Which should be named 'Fallout_default') press Ctrl+F and find the following line of text. NOTE: THIS IS CASE SENSITIVE  bUseThreadedAI=0  You must change this to:  bUseThreadedAI=1  Step 3: Directly underneath the changed line of text, create a new line and type:  iNumHWThreads=2  Step 4: Save the config file and then close. Then try to launch Fallout 3.  These steps are basically telling the game to launch using just 2 cores. This way it will make sure that the game will not freeze due to errors trying to find 'outdated' cores.  This fix will usually solve your problems, however if this has not worked and the game is still crashing then try these additional steps:  -Uninstall Fallout 3, disable .NET 3.1 under 'Turn windows features On or Off', then reinstall.  -Renaming or deleting the music folder inside the Fallout 3 folder apparently helps as well somehow?  Now it should work    GOT FOSE get it to run on win 7 & 8 here Step 1: Right click and go to properties. Then go to compatibility mode and set it to windows XP (Service Pack 3) and check “Run as Administrator”

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: Fallout 3 is a post apocalyptic RPG which takes place in Washington D.C- This is my all time favorite game and that means a instant 10/10 and here is why:  The setting and atmosphere is brilliant and almost to good since it can be rather depressing. The world is so exciting you actually want to see everything which is good since the game has around 100+ hours ingame content and 250+ hours content if you get all the dlc. And one of the things which is about 1/4 of the score is the soundtrack.  I have spend around 800 hours in this game and it just never gets old. Even now I found hidden things and equipment I had no bloody idea even existed, and that makes me continue playing the game. While the gameplay can seem rough since its a fairly old game, the quality still manges to shine through each second you play.   I absolutely love this game so much, I am having trouble describing its brilliant content. Many people focus on having big open worlds but that usually leads to a empty feel of the map. Fallout went for density which makes the Capital Wasteland packed with hundreds (If not thousands) of things to explore.  10/10 By far the best ♥♥♥♥ing game I have ever had the privilege of playing.

review_text: An awesome, must-play game. So much content. Brings back all the nostalgia. Well, thats my review, now give me that Leader of the Community Badge!

Both a triumph and a revolution for the simulation genre. Though there are minor aspects of realism sacrificed for the sake of playability, namely the third-person (third-goat?) view, the game as a whole pays stunning attention to the finer details of daily goat life. The controls are slick and intuitive, making licking, bleating, and headbutting a straightforward matter. Of course skill will allow you to perform more complex goat actions such as mid-air flips and other such acrobatics for which the graceful goat is so well known. However, it is my opinion that the game's brilliance is most evident in the masterfully wrought storyline. You begin the game as a young goat living in a peaceful neighborhood, but destiny calls you from beyond the low-lying fence of your grassy yard. From the game's outset, you have control of the story. In true RPG fashion, you are allowed to explore the massive open-world sandbox and forge your own legacy. Will you follow in the footsteps of the great Michael Bay? Will you become a notorious outlaw? Perhaps explore the upper reaches of the stratosphere for the good of goat-kind? Will your ambitions lead you to the arena to defeat your enemies in single combat? Maybe you will become one with the darkness and serve the Blood Goat. Or perhaps you shall rise to prominence and power as the lord of all goats: The Goat King. The possibilities are endless. If you are one of the many people around the world who has yearned for a realistic and satisfying goat experience, then this game may just be the very thing that brings peace to your soul. 10/10

I enjoy Dota - what initially began as a way of connecting with my brother has evolved into a casual play when not conquering AoE/TW franchises or completing Skyrim for the fifth time - essentially, I continue to play Dota even after my brother defected to a second hand PS3. It's one of the very few multiplayer games I play after rage quitting RoTMG.   Here's the problem, I'm no good at Dota and after hours of gameplay, maybe I never will be. As previously mentioned, I dabble in a variety of games and like most, have a life outside fabricated worlds. I die often, fail to purchase 'necessary' gear, haven't learnt how to opperate a courier - nor do I feel then need to. The urge to win isn't strong enough to study Dota - win or lose, its been a good game if I've tried my hardest to support/carry victory. Understand I've won about half the amount of games played, half full.   I think most reading at this point are thinking - just GTFO. Its been the general response I've recieved during gameplay, and generally from team members. I can handle being called idiot and noob, even the rusty english some europeans hurl through their microphones - its harmless and almost pathetic, a laughable offense imo. I've even experienced games where team members will hang back when I've landed into danger/conflict with the enemy - and then be complained to about feeding stats, even if together we could have outweighed the opposition.  I've even been reported - its actually what spurred me to type this review, when I last logged onto Dota I was greeted with yet another drop down in priority. Admittedly, I quit the last game I was in prematurely just because I could be bothered with three angry european/american mix slinging abuse my way - instead I went to go make a sandwich. The agression this game brings out in some people makes Dota feel as if you're grinding through the majority of an hour, necessary back up replaced with heaps of swears.   Pro's  - Beautifal, intense, fast-paced gameplay. - Fantastic balance in characters & roles.  - Responsive & simple to control.  Con's  - A considerate amount of abuse if you're new to the game. - A considerate amount of reports if you're new to the game.  - The least helpful, most angry gamers in a server I've ever seen.  Do I recommend this game?   Yes - If you're a seasoned player  No - If you're just a beginner

Planetside 2 was fun. Don't get me wrong. However, nothing screamed 'epic' or 'must have' or 'next gen' or even close to being 'groundbreaking'. It's Tribes 2 done bigger. Absolutely nothing in this game is phenomenal whatsoever. In fact, Warframe is a lot more fun to play. So is Natural Selection 2. Geesh, CS is even more fun. If you want a large scale war to zip around in, have ships, have terrain vehicles, have weapons loadouts and the whole 9, you would do better to look in some other place. Think Tribes 2, Blacklight Retribution, Firefall, Hawken and Mechwarrior Online. If you want a paid game, think BF4, Survarium, Ghost Recon Online, CS GO, BF3, etc, etc. Anyway, it's free and it IS fun, just don't expect the world to crumble around you because it's just THAT good. It won't happen.

Clicker Heroes is a good incremental game if you like incremental games. I have wasted hours running it in the background while doing other work. Quite honestly, I kind of hate it. Yet I still check it everytime I start steam up, before I play the game I actually want to play. Gotta get that gold.  [ I should clarify my 'negative' review here to repeat that this is a decent enough idle/incremental game. The mercenaries, which give you timed sidequests that help in the later levels when it takes a long time to save up for the next hero, are kinda nice. The clans are an addition for playing with friends for a while (until everyone inevatibly forgets about it because they have better games to play). Even with these nice things, I can't think of any reason I would really 'recommend' this game. If someone asked me for an incremental game recommendation, I'd probably suggest Candy Box (and Candy Box 2) or Kittens Game, instead. ]

If you follow games at all, you already know that Far Cry 3 is one of the best, most immersive single-player first-person shooters to come along in years. It combines a chilling story, thought-provoking themes, solid gunplay, beautiful graphics, an excellent soundtrack, and jam-packs all of them into an expansive and immersive open-world that is just as fun to explore as it is to kill baddies in.  The intriguing main storyline will pull you in from the start. The main character undergoes a bone-chilling and believable transformation from a priveleged, pampered rich boy to an angry, ston-cold killer. The rest of the story is also full of complex and entertaining characters (not to mention one of the best villains in recent memory), and yet you will be just as pulled in by the opportunities to hunt, craft, kill pirates, liberate forts, and explore the beautiful Rook Island for side-quests, relics and assorted goodies that allow you to build up your skills and expand your arsenal.  The combat, while far form the only draw, is exceptional. In this open-world, the choice is yours: would you prefer to go in stealthy, set-up shop on a tall hillside with your silenced sniper rifle, or go in guns blazing with a wide variety of SMGs, shotguns, assault rifles, and explosives? The shooting mechanics are very well done - the guns have a real punch to them - and there are plenty (30+) to choose from. The AI is also solid; your enemies will take cover, try to flank you, and will kill you easily if you play foolishly.   The graphics are excellent, and the design of the island is beautiful. Water ripples in the moonlight, sun-rays glimmer on your screen, bullets ricochet to and fro, and explosions look and feel powerful - as do the after-burning effects that can quickly consume a small forest. The electronic soundtrack is also great: it ebbs and flows with combat, and becomes somber in more heartfelt moments. It's integrated excellently throughout the game - you won't often be able to tell it's there, but it will get your heart pumping.  While exceptional, the game is not perfect. Exploration might have even been even better if the map was revealed more naturally instead of through radio towers, and I often found I had way too much money and not near enough to spend it on. The interface, crafting and customization options could also be improved. Still, as a whole, Far Cry 3 is a fantastic game that you will easily get 25-30+ hours out of and enjoy every minute of. There's much more that could be said, but this game is incredible value for anything less than $10, and you should really enjoy and explore the beatufiul but dangerous Rook Island for yourself!  9.2/10

At first, Goat Simulator struck me as being too goofy to be enjoyed. It seemed like a pretty terrible game. However, it has grown on me and now it's hard not to love it. The map is a bit small, however there are two different ones you are able to freely travel between. It takes a little time to get used to, or at least that's how it was for me. Once you discover how many different little things are in the game, it becomes hard to not want to play mroe to see what else you can find/do. For example, you can ride a bicycle, which is actually kind of difficult to balance on. You can also ride longboards and a bunch of different rides, like a roller coaster, ferris wheel, and things like that. Your goat can even eat shrooms (if you can find them.)  All in all, this game is pretty great. It might strike a lot of people as too silly and maybe like it is designed for a more immature crowed, but give it a chance. You might end up really liking it.   I should add that I have played it on more than one OS on the same system. The game runs horribly choppy when I run it using windows 7, however on that same computer it runs much smoother on Ubuntu 14.04. However, there are a few bugs when running on Linux because I don't think they're completely done with it. For example, it will freeze when traveling between maps.

This game seems pretty nice in the pictures and videos, but once you try its gameplay by yourself it becomes horrible. Be prepared; the game won't even teach you how you're supposed to play it.  - Expensive upgrade and weapons system. You will feel that everyone has a better gun than you, and that's because they might have put some real money in the game (which causes a real difference) or spent 1000h of their lives playing this crap.  - Needlessly huge experience system. Leveling is tedious and way too slow. And guess what? You don't even unlock >60% of the things by the year you hit maximum level.  - Tutorials are useless.  - Total lack of objectives. As a new player you won't know what on the earth is going on or where you are needed.  A couple hours were enough to let me see how much overpowered people there are and how new players are treated. Definetely not recommended. Pay to win - massive spawn camp simulator. Horrible experience.

Is it fun? At times, in short bursts, sure. Its fun.   Great melee system. A variety of weapons make for varying playstyles and strategies.  None of which you get to actually enjoy. Because every single time you start to do so, an Archer will simply snipe you in the back and pad their kill numbers. Or that enemy you've been battling with, slowly whittling them down? They're all covered in blood and nearly dead, and...POW! Right in the back, and another archer has stolen yet another of your kills.   And if you get close, surely the squishy archer is a dead man, right? Wrong. Then they just whip out a lightning fast, unblockable dagger and stab you to death.   This is Chivalry: Archer Avoidance, in a nutshell. Run to a fight. Get sniped by archers. Whittle down a potential kill, to have it stolen by archers. A great melee system ruined by the addition of completely unnecessary ranged class.

Five Nights at Freddy's is a clever concept with a unique theme, but whether it's a 'horror' genre game is debatable. A thriller maybe, but there is a distinct lack of gore or much sense of the macabre, and it has a distinct tongue-in-cheek quality to it. Unfortunately, that tongue is haunted! *WooooHooooo!!!!!*  You play a newly hired night watch person at the Chuck E. Cheese-esque establishment. Your job is to man the cameras and make sure the animatronic characters, who roam around at night, do not make it into your control room. You can pull up a laptop to view stationary cameras set in various rooms, operate door switches leading into the office, and operate lights outside the office. You are limited in how much power you have to utilize all these electric devices, and thus it becomes clear what the game really is: a resource management simulation in an apocalyptic world where there is no power grid.  There are some genuine jump-scares, initially. The longer you play the less sensitized you become to it though, because there isn't enough variety in the 'attacks' that happen. There is some dread, or defeat, you feel when in the last hour or two you realize you do not have enough power left to make it to the morning. Each night gets progressively more difficult to make it to the morning, because the animatronics become more active and you are forced to use more power. I guess, ultimately, this has to do with your boss being a penny pinching miser (just look at your paycheck at the end of the game!). There should be an expansion to this where you become part of a class action lawsuit with all the other Five Nighters to collect for withheld pay, physical pain, and emotional suffering.   As you become more proficient at the resource management they throw a twist at you in the form of 'Foxy' - an animatronic character who can run and will sprint down a hall into the office. You can close the door, if you're quick enough, but you still lose. You lose because every time Foxy gets to the closed door he bangs on it - and when he does it depletes 6% of your precious power. If he does this 3 times in one night - that's 18% of your power! *screwed*  I give props for the originality of the game itself, but the execution leaves something to be desired. Hitting ESC, for instance, doesn't pull up a menu screen or pause the game as it does in 99% of PC games. Instead, it quits the game. No problem, because the game saves what night you were on last. Great! What the game doesn't do is provide for more than one game file, so if you accidently click 'New Game' instead of 'Continue' it wipes your game file. *son of meat packer!*  I like the concept, but I'm tired of being r@p3d by robotic automatons.
Not a game, but an abomination of abused math. Seriously, there are thousands of games out there; don't waste your time.

Chivarly:Medieval Warfare is one of the best Multiplayer games I've ever played.This game brings you back to the old age of war where no guns existed.The game is based on two factions:The Mason Order (aka the bad guys) and the Agatha Knights (aka the good faction).These two factions are constantly battling against each other.The game has a unique leveling system and certain objectives so you can unlock new weapons.The game will never get old and you will always like it.After you've unlocked all the weapons of all 4 classes and customized your character over and over again , then you should get on the battlefield once again and wreck havoc! Some classes are harder than the others but they're all balanced.Totally recommending this game! You will put over 100 hours into it.Trust me, you'll not be good at it at the start but hey, everyone has been in that noob position ;)

CORN FOR THE CORN GOD BRAN FOR THE BRAN GOD  This is my first review of a total war game but I have been a huge fan of the series since Shogun 2. I've played hundreds of hours of Rome 2 and Shogun and found them to be some of the best strategy games I've played. I am quite aware of the sleazy practices of SEGA and their DLCs and botched launches but CA has seemed to do their best to make their products as good as they can given their publisher constraints. Given this, here is my review of Total War: Warhammer   Performance   Warhammer is the most solid Total War release since Shogun 2. The game runs well on most systems, it doesn't have a plethora of crippling bugs, and it is low on broken game mechanics. I don't have the most powerful system but I've played 60 hours so far and haven't experienced any major performance issues. This is extremely refreshing after the almost unplayable releases of Rome and Atilla.   Campaign Gameplay  I am by no means a fan of the Warhammer universe. In fact, in the past I've actively hated on Warhammer and its fans. So I was not terribly excited when Warhammer was annonced. However, after playing as 3 of 5 races in the campaign I have found that the fantasy setting breaths a lot new life into the Total War model. The greatly exapanded RPG elements of customizing skill trees and renaming units and characters creates stronger attachments to characters and increased the immersion in the game. The dangerous monster units, lords, and heroes add some exciting and interesting new tactics to the game. The presence of these units also makes the AI much more dangerous and fun to engage with. This is perhaps my favorite new feature. The AI in this game is as devious as ever and will actually present a significant challenge during the campaign. Conflicts with factions often last much longer than previous titles and the armies that you encounter are much more high tier. This is opposed to most other Total War games where the AI would mostly wander around with stacks of terrible units and beating them usually only took a battle or two. The improved AI armies and tactics mean fights are much closer and allow wars to actually feel like a intense campaign instead of a border skirmish. This is so refreshing for a title I was worried was getting repetitive and the biggest plus for me.   Multiplayer Gameplay  This is the part of the game that I feel is the most negative. The multiplayer model is essentailly the same as Rome 2 and Atilla. The quick battle and custom battle are the only options for competitive play and there is no progression system. For a game that introduced a fun new skill system with heroes and lords it is disappointing that this wasnt transferred to the multiplayer. Custom Lords and Heroes would have made multiplayer a much more engadging experience. However there are some positives. The different races interact with each other in ways that are much more interesting that previous titles. The diversity of units and army compositions that one can experiece in any given fight adds a lot more depth to the strategy and makes developing good builds more challenging. The addition of more races will only improve this. Also, the multitude of maps are well designed and there is a lot of variety in the terrian, making for diverse engagements. Its a solid system but there was a lot of potential to make multiplayer a stronger aspect of the game.   Design  While I am not a fan of Warhammer, the art design of this game is absolutely gorgeous. The map is full of fun landmarks that are visible on the battle field, the units are beautifully animated and designed, and the UI is clean and well organized. The impacts of the larger units are epic and the engagements are cinematic. The production value of the title is truly a step forward for the series.  Overall Takeaway   A beautiful, engrossing, and well performing title that breaths new life into the Total War title. There is easily 100+ hours of good content in the campaigns alone. Multiplayer is fun but the lack of innovation is disappointing. All things considered it is a great new title and I would reccomend it to anyone who enjoys the strategy genre.   Score  8.5/10
Save yourself while you can.

It's a good idea, and the best in its genre - but still executed poorly and  will have you saying 'that was bulls-' every 2 minutes . It's not fun anymore.   The meta-game has just devolved into who can cheese and exploit the mechanics the most ... for example; landing overhead attacks instantly by turning around, ducking, and looking up - so that you catch them on the backswing.    Combat with multiple people just doesn't work , which is surprising for a  multiplayer  game. Teammates will hinder you more than help you, and you will end up hitting your own team (or they will end up hitting you) by accident. Movement is too sudden, so people will instantly appear infront of you. It makes using heavier weapons more punishing because you're more lethal to your team.   It feels like a waiting and running simulator  with the 10 second respawns and the 30 seconds of running to get to the fight - just to potentially die instantly when you get there - having to do it all over again. Even worse if your teammate ran into your weapon, making the respawn longer   The latency compensation is horrible , so good luck using any short weapons like the double axe. It's impossible to hit someone who is running away from you with this weapon.   The community is rancid , as you will get attacked by your own teammates if you choose an archer. If you choose to defend yourself, you will get kicked for doing too much team damage.  Chivalry does have its cool moments, but they're very few and far between... you spend most of your time just waiting for a cool moment to happen, like popping 3 heads in the space of 5 seconds. But then your teammate will jump in and catch you on his back-swing so you stagger, then whilst you're staggered, you die.

I've been a fan of Total War since Shogun 2 came out, I've also gone back to old games to buy them such as Medieval 2. And when they announced Total War: WARHAMMER, I was hyped. Big fan of the Warhammer Fantasy Scene, and when two of my favorite games mold to make one. Makes me a pretty happy camper. Now I saw the day-1 DLC and was disappointed, but what do you know CA goes and says 'Nah fam, you buy our game within one week *actually more like two* you get the Chaos Warriors free'. So that was a great move on CA's part. Blood and Gore DLC for 3 dollars, that's been happening for a while now and makes perfect sense to me. Have the game with no blood for a lower rating for more copies to be sold to younger people, than a month later come out with the bloody stuff so that the older fans can enjoy a higher rated game.   This beastmen DLC going on however has me a bit ticked. Now I understand not every faction can have all their cool and unique units, but the Beastmen roster is already so small, that removes two or four units is basically almost cutting it in half. Now I'm disappointed in the size and the price, but that doesn't mean it doesn't have a good size. CA is adding the Beastmen to the grand campaign as foes REGARDLESS of us owning the DLC. That adds more ♥♥♥♥ to the game regardless, not to mention the new stuff we're getting from Update 2.   Now what has me really scared is the Skaven, my number 1 favorite faction, getting their roster slashed a bit. If the new major factions in the coming expansions and DLC have a smaller roster than the 5 Major factions we have now. I will be very disappointed and angry with CA. But that's another story in general because you are wondering one thing.   'Red, why are you telling me all this ♥♥♥♥ but you recommend this game?'  BECAUSE IT IS A GREAT GAME. Sure it doesn't have nearly as many factions as other Total War games, but be honest how many of those factions were even remotely different? Each faction in this game has unique mechanics, heroes, leaders, and units. So yeah I recommend this game, do I recommend the DLC for this game? That depends on what you consider a good deal. For some the DLC is a no go, for others its a great deal.   EDIT- The purpose of this review was less about the game in general, but more about how people are ticked off and giving the game a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of bad reviews when they aren't upset about the game they are upset about the DLC.

I've played this game for a bit now, I've also been in the competitive scene, and I must say that this game is pretty bad. Sure, this game seems pretty cool at first, the cool dismembers, and the awesome combat makes this game seem very fun. But, after you see all the unrealistic forms of fighting, you soon come to learn them and use them against people and it seems as if the game becomes not what it should be. You do full 360 spins, 180 spins, you exploit the game of it's many glitches that the developers don't fix. That's another thing I must say about this game; the developers are just so money-hungry. They do not care about the community, all they care about is money. They only release REAL gameplay changing updates about ONCE A YEAR. That is not acceptable on any terms, ESPECIALLY since the developers are making ANOTHER game, so that shows that they didn't give up, they just want money. Sure, you can say that they were working on their new game the entire time, but you can't tell me that you can't take the time out of your day and just listen to the community of this game, and fix what needs to be fixed. Oh, but don't worry, the developers DO release other updates throughout the year. They release one update about once a month, but it's not anything involving gameplay changing. It involves FAN ART and WEAPON AND MODEL SKINS THAT ARE REALLY OVERPRICED. There isn't any steam market for the game so that other people can sell their skins for what they think is worth. But no, the developers only care about money, so they force you to pay them directly for the overly priced skins that just make your character(s) look fancier. There isn't much to this game other than hack and slash. Also, the game has a very low population count, so all the servers are filled with the same 100-200 people that you see on a regular basis, and I'm being generous with the 200 people, I feel it's 100-150, but I've only been on the NA servers. I do NOT recommend this game for anyone, and I do NOT look forward to their next game. If you are looking for a medieval combat game, there is a game called Mordhau. It is not released yet, but there is one trailer out, and with that one trailer, the game looks twice as good as Chivalry: Medieval Warfare. I repeat, do NOT get this game! It's a waste of time and money.

Still in closed beta, They give out keys to people who fill out a survey almost every 2 weeks. It is a game where you pick from mostly 'mythological' themed heros and battle in a little war, 5v5 against other player controlled heros. Its won by destroying the enemy's main base which is protected by towers.  You fight the other players as waves of minions from your allied forces and your enemy's forces clash in 3 lanes. Killing enemy players and minions, either in the lane or in the forest gives you gold to buy items. Items like Manta Blade let you create multiple illusions that deal damage, Shadow Blade lets you become invisible, and Ghost scepter makes you etheral.   Hero examples are Dragon Knight who is a knight that transforms into a dragon and breathes fire, A giant Treant that roots enemies in place and steals their health, a Stealth Assassin that has permanent invisiblity and uses smoke bombs, and an undead Lich that casts frost magic.

I bought this game back somewhere between late 2012 and the middle of 2013. The combat was excellent; probably one of the best melee systems I've seen in a game - and that was only bolstered by the fact that the gore was brutally fantastic. It was ineffably satisfying to hack someone's arm off with a huge, heavy two-handed axe and then come back around with another swing while they're still clutching at their socket and take their head off. Combat was heavy and precise, the maps were cool, and the music was pretty good. So why am I not recommending it?  You'll remember I bought this game late 2012-mid 2013. Basically nothing has changed about this game since then; there's been a few miscellaneous tweaks and fixes, but there's nothing  new . No new maps, no new weapons, no new music; they never fixed the fact that you can't change the time limit on your own dedicated server, so you have to deal with the map trying to switch itself every ten minutes. Also, something changed about the combat along the way; I can't exactly pinpoint it, but it doesn't feel as fluid and responsive as it used to.  At some point they decided to stop making big, important changes and additions to the game and start implementing new helmets, and new armors, and new weapons skins. Cool! So what's the catch? The catch is that you absolutely cannot acquire   any   of these by legitimately paying the game. See that fancy helmet? That'll be $5. See that cool skin for your zweihander? That'll be another $5. There's so many microtransactions in this game that I wouldn't be surprised if it was possible to drop over $100 on all this superfluous, superficial stuff that doesn't really make a difference to the overall experience. I understand TB has to make money, but there should be much more to every update than just more skins you can purchase and a few tweaks - it's pretty ridiculous at this point.   It's sad to see the game go this way, as I made some great memories with this game and enjoyed the experience, and I'd say I got my money's worth; but I'd probably unbuy it if I could. They even put out a Deadliest Warrior DLC, and I abstained from buying it since I knew it was just going to be abandoned as well.  If you're new and you're reading this review and you're considering purchasing this game, I'm not here to dissuade you. Chivalry is an excellent experience and still has some of the best melee combat I've ever seen in a game, and I've definitely had my fair share of good times with it. But if you're buying it and you expect the current core experience to grow and evolve, absolutely do not buy this. It hasn't changed in the past two years, and I suspect it never will.

On the flip side, I got bored of the main story in the end and just wanted to be off that god forsaken island forever.  On the most basic of level, it's a terribly optomized FPS skin for Assassins Creed in an awesome landscape with lots of fun, open world exploring. Awesome game, very solid gunplay and feel. It reminds me of Far Cry 2 in that you could take over a base guns blazing, or with stealth. Though you get more XP and its just way funner to take the stealthy approach. I've yet to try Multiplayer/Co-op, so this is just a singleplayer review.  I do wish weapon wear was still in the game. By that I mean the weapon starts to jam/rust over time after using it a lot. This was good to keep you from just picking up enemy's weapons and not buying them, as their weapons start out in pretty bad condition. Of course the problem with this in Far Cry 2 is that the fast travel sucked, and getting to a base/gun shop to replace yout weapon was tedious, but now that fast travel has improved, I see no reason why that feature wasnt re-introduced. The way you can get free guns in the game also made it a bit easy to be very OP very quick.   Also the storyline was nothing to write home about, it was very cliche and really poorly written, although Vaas was a cool character, we kinda got 'spoiled' with the trailers of the game, they just showed all the good parts of him in the trailers.   Other than that, awesome game, I love the Far Cry series. The stealth is fun, and the open world element of the game is flawless. Spend your money on this game. 9.5/10
