'Far Cry 3' came out a few years ago. It's an open world FPS, with some roleplaying elements, like weapon upgrades and skills, and a rather strong emphasis on story and characters, although at the cost of some interesting side mission. The game is all right : the main problem I had with it was that it uses 'Uplay', that it's a console port and thus badly optimized. I apologize in advance for ranting way too long about those part, and not talking more about the game. To me, these two parts are tied together, and I cannot just ignore the flaws of 'Uplay', especially if it has repercussions in the game itself.  'Uplay' is similar to Steam, except worse in every regard. That it is necessary to launch it, and Steam, at the same time, for copy protection reasons, shows just how much Ubisoft actually cares for a user friendly product. That it is slow and unhandy would be the core of my gripes with it. That it actually taints the game is unforgivable. Since the inventory menu in 'Far Cry 3' is in the main menu of the game, and said menu needs to check online with the servers for whatever reasons, it can take ages to do want you actually want to do in-game. That is not a correct way to proceed. Why can't I check my inventory if Uplay can't connect to the servers, although it could when I launched the game? Is it because I played during the release of 'Watch Dog'? Is it really possible that, because of the launch of another game overloading the servers of Ubisoft, I couldn't check on my inventory in Far Cry?! That's insane! Yeah, how can you even try to get some immersion going...  Oh, as a side note : I already had an Ubisoft account, before using Uplay, but I couldn't login with it using Uplay. I had to login through their website first, and then login through Uplay. Obviously Uplay never bothered to tell me that, only that my internet connexion was down and that the fault thus laid with me. Thanks. Very helpful, and user friendly once more.  It connects when Uplay launches, it connects when the game launches and it connects to the servers when you open the main menu of the game. Because of the poor optimisation, and my wish to tweak the game as best as possible, these logins delays were a serious pain. There are troubles with SLI, and even crossfire apparently, even though it's an AMD game. The stuttering with SLI was finally resolve for me by using a third party program. Still, sometimes the game just bugged out and only one card out of the two actually worked (first time that ever happen to me), requiring yet another time wasting restart of the game. The graphic options menu leaves a lot to be desired. It's impossible to remove motion blur or ambient occlusion (which makes the game look worse in my opinion, and even cost more resources). You need to tweak that in the game files, and even then bugs appear, like sound bugs (how does a graphic option affect sound?!) But the worst offence? The game doesn't even look that good for the resources demanded. 'Crysis', -the first one!-, which came five years before, looked way better in every aspect. It's even better if you take into account the fact that in 'Crysis', the game world was more interactive, and destructible: you could mow down trees and blow up sheds. Not so in far cry.  The game itself can be shortly describe as an amalgamation of 'Skyrim' mixed with 'Just Cause 2', except it leaves the best part of those games at home. 'Skyrim' had lots of different looking environment, and different cities with their respective style. 'Just Cause 2' had a very insane gameplay, which was quite fun, but repetitive. In 'Far Cry 3', the game world is quite small, which is probably for the best since repetition already sets in as it is. Secondary quests aren't that good, though the main plot is quite interesting. It reminded my of Hotline Miami : a descent into madness and mayhem. The gameplay is that of an average FPS : aim and shoot, although it can be pretty “organic” in Far Cry, with multiple approaches on how to overtake a stronghold. It sadly doesn't work that way during quests, either secondary or principal. You will often fail an objective because of unclear restrictions or arbitrary limitations, which is stark contrast with the free-roaming experience. The characters are interesting enough even though I don't know if there are one step short of being campy or so insane that they transcend such definition. The tone of the stand alone, 'Blood Dragon', shouldn't be a surprise as the path visible here already alludes to such extravagance. The endings could use a lot more polish thought: they are just too easy and don't amount to anything. It's just a quick wrap up. There are worse endings out there, but you could have taken more than ten seconds to come up with one, surely.  As it stands, I'm glad to have played, but had I known before hand how horrible Uplay is and how poorly the game runs, I wouldn't have bothered. If you lack the patience and tolerance for such nonsense, I wont blame you and you wouldn't be missing out much regardless.

At this moment of writing, there are 23k players playing this game with an all time peak 33k+. That is kind of outrageous.... in a good way.  Game mechanic is very simple, you merely click furiously on your screen to kill monsters, hover over the gold to pick them up, and buy mercenaries/heroes + upgrade them to increase your damage.   Level progression is very linear with an ever increasing monsters' HP.  Maybe this simplicity what makes the game fun for many people. It sounds silly, but it does the job right.   And with the free to play tag, with micro-transactions being very harmless, there's no way I won't recommend this game.  8/10, fun to play.

review_text: Never have I regretted so much purchasing a game I was so fond of. Why? Even with the exhaustive modding and configuration guides the community has developed over the years, it still regularly just decides to stop working, forcing me to do a clean install and go through all the steps again. Lazy work from Bethesda, even though Windows XP was already on the way out when this was first released.

The pattern of 'streamlining' for casuals continues. Sieges are very arcadey deployed right into tower range for example, unit formations are gone, group formations are limited to a couple of options. I don't know if modders will be able to crack these issues, if they can then that's my only hope. In the meantime I'll probably go back to the excellent EB II mod for MTW2. Earlier TW games had much more detail and more options overall with the exception of ship combat for Shogun I, MTW I, Rome I, MTW 2. The series has continued to be simplified more and more which is pretty devastating to people who played the thinking part of the series. The TW series in general has had issues with AI whether CAI, BAI, or DAI, but little has been done to improve it over the years. The focus seems to be more on a cinematic immediate gratification fest rather than a thinking, methodical strategy game.  I was really hoping (I should have known better) that CA would return to their roots in terms of the combat at least, but I was sorely disappointed. No open city fighting either as far as I can tell (or naval combat for that matter). I feel like this is just the way things are gonna be as the series is concentrated on simple accessibility with a lot of flash but less and less substance. I won't say the game isn't fun at all, but knowing how much better it could have been if it was actually designed as thinking man's strategy game.   Since Rome 2 the series has felt like the strategy version of CoD in a way. When I see what modders have been able to do with the EB II mod for MTW2 compared to the simplified systems implemented by CA since Rome 2 it's obvious at this point that what sells is simplicity. If I sound enraged it's because this was one of my favorite franchises (as well as my youngest brother's btw) but since Rome 2 the direction of CA is now overwhelmingly clear; cater to the casual because it makes $$. Can't blame them from a business standpoint, but considering the strategy games I grew up with I have to wonder if it's a generational indicator of where we are now (which makes me want to watch Idiocracy).  To reiterate, I'm not saying the game isn't fun, I'm just saying it's very, very arcadey and even more so with gutting of tactical options (sure they added magic, but meh that's not really a big deal vs unit tactics/formations.  I still play MTW I, Rome Total War I, and MTW2 on a regular basis. The amount of detail that went into those games AT THE TIME they released was indicative of significant TLC and catered to a different kind of crowd that liked options, detail, traits, etc. There is no such corresponding effort from CA since Rome 2 and this latest entry is no different in that respect; accessibility over substance, simplicity over detail, limitations over options.  For a Warhammer (as opposed to old guard TW) fan it is worth it, especially if you never played the other TW games WHEN they came out (if you're like my brother and I anyway and want it all: tactical options, improved AI capable of executing sieges with MY OWN planning, etc). Shogun 2 I would say was the last total effort by CA. You can have fun with this game, but I could not in good conscience recommend it to the old guard.

I'm not sure what I expected. It's the same tired formula of far cry 2 and other ubisoft games. A large beautiful environment, but filled with pointless fetch quests, terrible dialog, and nonsense story. I feel sorry for the artists and voice actors. I'm sure they did their best, but there's nothing rescuing the lackluster quests, story and dialog. The writers failed this game.  The gunplay and combat are alright, but none of the characters or storyline inspire any sort of desire to help them or advance the story. A lot of wasted potential. This is seriously some of the worst writing and dialog I've ever seen.  Go play Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon. It's a way better game but was way too short. This garbage was way too long.

Far Cry 3 is an open world first-person shooter published by Ubisoft Entertainment. It is the next installment of Far Cry series after Far Cry 2.  Far Cry 3 gameplay, it has open world, it has small RPG element, and it has one of the best villain character ever. In my opinion Far Cry 3 open world feature is almost similar to Assassin's Creed where you have to climb a radio tower, interact some sort of panel to explore some area on the world around the tower. In Far Cry 3 you don't just get to shoot somebody and run. You can buy and upgrade weapons in store, level up getting new tattoos which conveniently giving you new abilities such as walk faster or something, also, there are some upgrades that require you to hunt for animals hide or plants. The best part is, when you shoot a tiger, it will fight back! Let your guard down and a leopard will eat you. Got bored? Maybe you should go to a village and play some poker games and rob those poker players. Do you want to become Hawkeye? Legolas? or maybe Rambo? Use explosive archer and blow some goats. Got angry? Use a flamethrower and burn the forest! Far Cry 3 has many great feature for a first-person shooter. You will like it.  Far Cry 3 has cool graphics, it is one of the best graphics I've ever seen, not because its so advanced, but because the weapons first-person animation is unique, so alive and... Okay maybe it's not one of the best, but I like it. Far Cry 3 has very good performance.  Too bad Far Cry 3 multiplayer feels like it has been left out, because it's not as awesome as the singleplayer mode. I was thinking the multiplayer will be more like huge maps on the same island, hundreds of players fighting together, something like that. Same thing about the cooperative play. But at least you get to blow something up with bow in singleplayer.  Far Cry 3 is not bad, its good, I recommend this.  Rating 8/10

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: Pros:  -Excellent plotline -Wide variety of playstyles -Fun character customization and levelup processes -Huge open world to play in -Liam Neeson voices your father -Massive amount of content for the price -Massive replayability   Cons:  -Buggy -Compatibility issues with newer systems is common -VATS is basically required in order to use guns effectively -Some stats are decidedly more useful than others   Overall:  Fallout 3 was Bethesda's first foray into the Fallout universe, and it was also Fallout's first three dimensional game. The graphics are about on par with Elder Scrolls: Oblivion, and the open world has the same feel to it. The game is amazing and fun and a huge time sink if you take the time to explore everything. NPCs range from deeply well developed, to entertaining, to annoying, and everything in between. Leveling up oftentimes can open up entire new ways of playing the game, and exploration is always rewarded. Bethesda is known for their open world games, and they did a great job here as well. It's worth the buy if you like... well, anything Bethesda has done in the past decade. It's likely you won't encountered everything in one playthrough, and any serious encounter will have multiple solutions, making the replay value of this game through the roof.  The DLC is all included in the GOTY edition, but the vanilla brand Fallout 3 is available on Steam as well if you want to save a few bucks. You'll have to pay to buy the DLC for that version however, which makes this version more cost efficient.  The game crashes frequently, and has compatibility issues with newer systems, particularly Windows 8 and up. But if you can't get it to play consistently, you can always refund it within the first 2 hours of gameplay, so there's no harm in buying just to see if you can play it on your computer. Additionally, because this is Bethesda's first attempt, they hadn't quite figured out gunfights. Hip-shooting is comically inaccurate, and VATS is required in order to have any real shot at hitting things beyond melee range. This is resolved in New Vegas and Fallout 4, but in Fallout 3, Perception and Agility are both must-haves if you plan on using ranged weapons of any variety.  Still, these are very minor issues. The game is easy to become immersed in, and I often found myself in game for several hours longer than I intended just finishing that 'one last thing' before quitting. I played the whole game once before getting it on steam in a sale, and replaying it years later, it's as good as I remember it being. Pick it up if you're itching for more Fallout and haven't experienced this one yet.   Bottom Line:  Definitely worth the money

app_name: Fallout 3 - Game of the Year Edition
review_text: After reading other players' glowing reviews I thought Fallout 3 GOTY would be worth a try so I bought it during Steam's Summer Sale. I had held off purchase for years and thought perhaps by now (2014) Bethesda finally addressed some of its many, infamous bugs. But apparently NOT! How Bethesda garnered so many accolades and awards for such a buggy product I will NEVER fathom.  I tried the many fixes and suggestions to get the game stable enough to play i.e. actually got as far as Megaton initial quests e.g. Those! but the game STILL randomly and often freezes up, especially when entering indoor spaces. Only using the CTL-ALT-DELETE to Task Manager i.e. 'Fallout 3 - Not Responding' error msg and Ending it gets me back to desktop.  I don't think it's my rig as I can play BioShock Infiniite, Borderlands 2, Skyrim Legendary edition and with mods, etc without so much as a hiccup.  And I think I've tried nearly ALL the fixes available e.g. multi-core - ini file fix; K-lilte codec, disabling GFWL, etc. I followed Ben W.'s guide including installing the Ultimate Fix mod plus others, but nothing helps. At this point I'm stumped. So sadly, for me this is just another Steam version game that is essentially unplayable.  However, there are many other players that have gotten Fallout 3 GOTY to work (even on WIN 7 OS) that highly recommend it , so purchasing it IS a gamble - you have to decide whether or not it's worth the risk - esp. as it's not optimized for WIN 7.  For that reason I strongly suggest for those willing to risk it, to wait until Fallout 3 GOTY is on FIRE SALE to minimize loss of funds, just in case - like me - you can't get the game to actually play.  P.S. Will update this review if I ever do get the game to run.

The only disappointment, at the beginning, was the limited number of playable races, but I hope they will be implemented in future DLCs. The last complain could be about the price of the upcoming DCL including the wood elves, which in my opnion in quite high.  Overall I think it's a good game and I would reccomand it.

TL:DR this game is the perfect combination of Total War and Warhammer. I'd highly recommend this game to fans of both. I cant wait till the whole series is out.  This game is the perfect crossover that I had always dreamed of seeing and whats even better is that CA have done a great job of turning this into a really enjoyable game. Its the first non-historical Total War game and it feels like a breath of fresh air for the series. There arent as many playable factions but the factions that are here are more diverse and play quite a bit differently to each other, compared to factions in the historical titles which were largely similar but with a few different unts.  You have the human Empire faction,which is probably the most similar to the traditional TW factions in other games with a good mix of infantry,cavalry and ranged. The Dwarfs lack cavalry but have excellent ranged and strong infantry with the book of grudges being their unique feature where you have to settle grudges with other factions or suffer a penalty. The Vampire Counts lack ranged nits but can raise undead units for quick reinforcements as well as spreading Vampiric corruption on the campaign map to decrease public order in enemy provinces. And finally the Orcs who also have a decent mix of unit types bt can suffer attrition from infighting if you dont keep fighting and raiding.   The game also has hero characters and lords which can be levelled up with new abilities and equipped with weapons and armour with unique lord characters having their own quest battle story chains. Magic also makes its TW debut and is handled quite well with spell cooldowns and miscasts if you over use a spell.  Good points: - The factions feel unique enough from each other to be interesting and to offer different challenges and playstyles. There are some really fun units like flying monsters and giants for example that add more tactical options than previous TW games. - The campaign is pretty good with the Chaos incursions in the latter part of the campaign offering a challenge that can make the late campaign a lot more interesting. The quest battles are also good and give the players some useful rewards for completing them. -This game is optimized a lot better than Attila was and I love the unit and map design that really brings the Warhammer universe to life. - The heroes and lords are handled well with heroes being useful both as agents on the campaign map as well as being embedded in your armies for use in battles. The leveling system is also great and makes you really feel invested in your generals.  Bad points: - sieges still feel a bit underwhelming though they still play better than in previous TW games. - the AI has a tendency to spam agents against you and this gets pretty annoying

Let me get this straight, you want me to tell you a review about this game? Whoever you are, you might as well go to the curators, because if you've come for a review on this game, you've come to the wrong place. However, if you have come for an outstanding chocolate chip cookie recipe, you've come to the right place. --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Ingredients 1/2 cup (1 stick) unsalted butter 3/4 cup packed dark brown sugar 3/4 cup sugar 2 large eggs 1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract 1 (12-ounce) bag semisweet chocolate chips, or chunks 2 1/4 cups all-purpose flour 3/4 teaspoon baking soda 1 teaspoon fine salt  Directions 1. Evenly position 2 racks in the middle of the oven and preheat to 375 degrees F. (on convection setting if you have it.) Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone sheets. (If you only have 1 baking sheet, let it cool completely between batches.)  2. Put the butter in a microwave safe bowl, cover and microwave on medium power until melted. (Alternatively melt in a small saucepan.) Cool slightly. Whisk the sugars, eggs, butter and vanilla in a large bowl until smooth.  3. Whisk the flour, baking soda and salt in another bowl. Stir the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients with a wooden spoon; take care not to over mix. Stir in the chocolate chips or chunks.  4. Scoop heaping tablespoons of the dough onto the prepared pans. Wet hands slightly and roll the dough into balls. Space the cookies about 2-inches apart on the pans. Bake, until golden, but still soft in the center, 12 to 16 minutes, depending on how chewy or crunchy you like your cookies. Transfer hot cookies with a spatula to a rack to cool. Serve.  5. Store cookies in a tightly sealed container for up to 5 days.  For a Rocky Road Bar: 1. Lightly butter a 9 by 13-inch baking pan. Make the batter as per cookie recipe and fold in 1 cup chopped walnuts along with the chocolate chips. Spread batter in prepared pan. Bake until the edges are light brown and the batter sets, about 45 minutes. Cool slightly and cover surface with 4 cups marshmallows and 1 cup chocolate chips. Broil at least 8 inches from the heat until marshmallows turn golden brown, about 2 minutes. (Keep an eye on the marshmallows, and turn the pan frequently--they go from golden to char in a wink.) Cool, cut and serve.

I love mobas. As far as PC games go, it's my favorite genre. I've played the original Dota for years. League of Legends and I've dabbled in Smite and HoN. Dota 2 beats all of them as far game play, balance, hero design. It has holiday events, free skin drops. They allow you the option to sell your skins and other drops in the community market. My steam wallet is sitting at over $40 as we speak strictly from Dota 2 community market sales.  There is one critical flaw in this game. I can honestly say, that in my personal experience over 95% of the players can not, or will not speak english. Not in text, not on the mic. This makes team strat damn near impossible for an english speaker. The game allows you to check which servers and language you want to be included in - any that you leave unchecked will not add you to the matchmaking system in those locations/languages. I live in the US, and I can only speak english. So I only have US servers and english checked. Yet still every game I feel like a foreigner in my countries own servers.  I ask them why they click US/English if they can't speak the language, but it's a redundant question since they have no clue what I'm saying.  There really is no excuse for it and sadly enough it ruins the whole experience for me. I might as well be playing with bots.  In conclusion I will say that this is a great game. But unless you speak every other language except english, you're going to want to go play something else.

Like a lot of other people i thought it looked fun from youtube videos.  Don't, just don't.   If you're here because you saw a youtube video where it looks like they're having fun. Don't get it.  You explore a bit, scare some people, bounce on a bouncy castle and then you realised that's the extent of the fun.  Within about an hour your frame rates will drop stupidly, even on a good computer and you'll reset the game out of frustration.  The glitches are quaint for about fifteen minutes, the music will drive you nuts and you'll go and play a different game, having lost a few quid.  Seriously at most this is worth about £1 of fun.  Got get Little and Big instead, it'll probably be cheaper, it's fun for longer and it has story.

I see a bunch of negative reviews from long-time, hardcore players who have fallen out of love with this game. But you're not an experienced player if you're reading this trying to decide whether or not to give it a try, are you?  So: as a player new to this game, let me share my experience.  I love it. There is some learning curve to the combat (the controls could be a bit more intuitive), but once you get the hang of them it's SO rewarding. It feels visceral and fun. You feel like a total badass in combat. Looks and feels fantastic. Solid. Definitely the best medieval combat I've ever played.  Yes, there is team damage, it happens. War is Hell and messy. If you can deal with that, you'll have fun.   How to maximize your fun: 1) Don't take it too seriously.  2) Do the tutorial. It's a bit buggy but genuinely useful. 3) Play on the low-ranked player servers to begin with.  4) Start a private server and practice your skills against bots between matches.  5) Learn the different weapons and get a feel for their timing and ranges.  6) Almost-empty servers are a good place to have fun without so many enemies and learn from more experienced players. 7) Learn how to use stab and hack and the alternate attacks. Bind them to their own keys.  Maybe it won't be a game you play for years or get seriously competitive about. But so what? For the money, you absolutely get more than a fair share of entertainment value! Absolutely recommended!

Runs crappy, looks fairly crappy, and the differences between the factions could be a lot better. The weapon choices for some classes, like the MAX, are very sparse. Some features, like shields for the engineer are completely missing. The meta game is very rudimentary and unimplmented.  All that said, this is probably STILL the best free MMOFPS out there. It is really fun and I recommend it through the downsides. The cash shop doesn't really give an unfair advantage to nonpayers and offers exclusive cosmetic items amongst unlocks a free player can reasonably achieve as well as the usual XP boosts. I remain confident that SOE will continue to improve the game as this is their flagship FTP game.
